HEADLINE: The Pavilionaire 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW SOLOMON; Andrew Solomon is the author of "The Noonday Demon," to be published in June by Scribner.

 BODY:
If you've somehow grown tired of palaces, spacious ballrooms or other manifestations of your own grandeur, Jeffrey Cayle will build you a simple little hut. He is a designer of relaxed places, where you go to dissociate and unwind and think peaceful thoughts, and where you never need invite an unwanted guest. Though Cayle has turned into an architect of nature, his first jobs were in set design, and the stagecraft of his structures is unmistakable: they whimsically marry the pastoral and the theatrical. With twigs woven into them, thick rafters and funny-size windows in unlikely places, they appear as if they had sprung from the earth. They are like treehouses without the trees, or the Unabomber's shed without the Unabomber: a permanent and luxurious Outward Bound in your own backyard. 
 Lest you mistake one for a summer-camp cabin, Cayle accessorizes them with a modicum of glamour: in one, a crystal chandelier may hang anomalously from the beams; another may be completely fitted in handmade willow furniture. Cayle always includes a bed. "These are places for sound sleeping or a tryst," the 43-year-old Colorado native says. "I hate those mini-castles in the Hamptons. People don't know what they want, so they surround themselves with everything they can buy." 
 These sorts of architectural follies are hardly radical, but are rarely visible, since their roots are more European than American. The upper classes of 18th- and 19th-century England, Ireland, France, Germany and Czechoslovakia often built simple pavilions for their amusement on their estates, but the idea was too enmeshed with class to catch on in the United States. Thomas Jefferson went to the D 1/8sert de Retz, one of the greatest follies in France, in 1786. While it had bearing on his subsequent adventures in architecture, America was too fresh-faced to embrace such studied simplicity.
The most famous proponent of such follies was Marie Antoinette. She didn't much care for court life at Versailles, so she commanded her landscape designers and architects to build an imitation peasant village, Le Petit Hameau, on the royal grounds. For herself, she took over a little palace called the Petit Trianon, where she covered the walls with straw, placed straw mats on the floors and had the vases filled with wild field flowers. She wore only white when there. 
Such affected carrying on eventually led the little queen to the guillotine, but that has not prevented others from following in her footsteps, though they do not carry things quite so far. To the best of my knowledge, Vogue's creative director, Grace Coddington, has not been found flirtatiously churning butter; Daryl Hannah has not taken to wearing a shepherdess outfit to stroll the lawns; the photographer Bruce Weber is not practicing a "simple gliding step of incomparable grace" (as a visitor to Petit Trianon described Marie Antoinette); and neither Bill Blass nor Alexander Vreeland has proposed that the people eat cake. These people have all, however, commissioned rustic huts from Cayle. 
Cayle began his own experiments in back-to-nature housing about 15 years ago, and now he does it nearly full time. He describes his creations as "garden-structure getaways," though a few of them are rigged with telephones that can make your time with nature oddly similar to your time in civilization. "They're simple," he says, "and I try to make them organic. They let you get away from the overload and to feel what's around you." His design process is similarly organic: "I come into a place and I try to find something that really inspires me, like a color or a certain type of wood. I don't plan it out, because I want it to develop as I build. I never do architectural drawings -- some doodles maybe, but nothing too fancy. I get a bunch of artists and craftsmen and carpenters and we just build this stuff."
Blass wanted a thatched roof. Weber has sod, with all the grass growing on it like velvet. "The building has to grow from the materials," Cayle says. "I'll often use some retrieved materials from old buildings, too." But simplicity is in the eye of the beholder. Weber also wanted an outdoor gunite "swimming hole," which he likes to keep warm on those cool Montana nights, so Cayle built an underground mechanical room to house the soaking system for the sod, as well as the heater for the pool. Nor is construction always a relaxed affair. For a treehouse in the Adirondacks, the crew worked 22 days straight through the black-fly season, covered in netting, to finish the structure in time for the Fourth of July weekend.
In her book "Follies and Grottoes," the scholar Barbara Jones writes: "It is built for pleasure, and pleasure is personal, difficult to define.* Folly seems a bad name, for folly is deliberate, and to be foolish one must know what is sensible; the men who built follies put them up quite seriously.* Follies come from money and security and peace." She continues: "The most isolated English cottage is set in civilisation, with a bit of garden and a path, but follies are jungly and embowered in brambles.* They are cut off from worldly contacts, and lose all humanity, becoming more mineral than artifact, resolving into stones again." 
Cayle's projects, novel though they may seem, are the perfect heirs to this grand tradition. His pavilions flirt with excess while giving the appearance of frugality. They are contradictions, and in the late decadence of the fading Clinton economy, this kind of ostentation via simplicity somehow recaptures the imagination of jaded urbanites. In crossing Thoreau with the fantasies of European aristocracy, and a touch of the Japanese teahouse, Cayle has come up with an exotic escape that is often no farther than your own backyard. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: This page and opposite: the sod-roof pool house in Montana that Cayle made for the photographer Bruce Weber is built of logs from dead trees clawed by bears. The open living area can be tented off by canvas shades hung behind the inner columns. The heated concrete pool wastinted gray to resemble an abandoned foundation. Water spills off its end into a trough, where it is recirculated.; This page and opposite: in Grace Coddington and Didier Malige's East Hampton sleeping pavilion, the wainscoting and hand-hewn beams are from an old Elks lodge. The iron bed is from an antiques store.; This outbuilding in southwest Colorado contains the heating and electrical systems for the main house nearby. HEADLINE: Worth More Than It Costs 

BYLINE:  By Margo Jefferson; Margo Jefferson is an arts critic for The Times.

 BODY:
 On Her Own Ground
The Life and Times
of Madam C. J. Walker.
By A'Lelia Bundles.
Illustrated. 415 pp. New York:
A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $30.
 HAIR: We are not content to let it lie quietly on our heads, but must color, cut, crimp, straighten, braid, supplement and adorn with plastic, shell, bone, metal, silk, velvet and every kind of hat. For women, it is mythology, obsession, religion and sport. What culture does not have some version of the old adage about hair as a woman's glory? Hair connotes standards of beauty, taste, power, money, class and caste. For black women, whose nonstraight, wavy or curly hair was considered yet another sure marker of racial inferiority, Madam C. J. Walker brought hope in jars that helped them grow and "cultivate" their hair. Her formula, combined with the hot metal comb invented by a Frenchman in 1870, gave hair a resilience and an appearance of straightness that allowed black women to wear the popular styles of the day, from Gibson girl to bob-haired flapper. 
Walker's biographer and great-great granddaughter, A'Lelia Bundles, does not overestimate her importance when she calls Walker one of the pioneers in her use of direct sales (the Fuller Brush Company was founded in 1906, the same year as Walker's), marketing strategies and commissions. Bundles writes: "As an early advocate of women's economic independence she provided lucrative incomes for thousands of African-American women who otherwise would have been consigned to jobs as farm laborers, washerwomen and maids." Walker's philanthropy ranged from the virtuous Y.W.C.A. to the radical N.A.A.C.P.; she began her career soliciting Booker T. Washington's approval and ended it working with W. E. B. Du Bois, Monroe Trotter and Ida B. Wells-Barnett. Shortly before she died in 1919, she planned to organize her sales agents into local clubs that could use their economic clout to protest lynching and other civil rights abuses while improving conditions in their communities. 
Bundles's well-paced and well-written book, "On Her Own Ground: The Life and Times of Madam C. J. Walker," is as much social history as biography, filled with the detail and texture of culture and politics. And rightly so, for Walker's life encompassed Reconstruction, the Gilded Age and World War I. She moved from the kind of poverty that usually ensures anonymity to a 34-room mansion in upstate New York, near the big show houses of John D. Rockefeller and Jay Gould; from visits to Tiffany's for diamond jewelry to plans for attending the International Paris Peace Conference in 1919 with a group of blacks determined to lobby for African independence -- which won her a place in the Military Intelligence Division's file of "Negro subversives."
She was born Sarah Breedlove in Delta, La., in 1867. Her parents were laborers on the same plantation where they had been slaves, and Sarah labored beside them, chopping and picking cotton. She got about three months of schooling. The rights that Reconstruction had so briefly granted blacks were being snatched away. The Freedmen's Bureau disbanded its education division. And two offshoots of the original Ku Klux Klan were founded nearby, the lyrically named Knights of the White Camellia and the curtly named White League.
Orphaned at the age of 7, Sarah lived with a cruel brother-in-law and a passive sister. "I married at the age of 14 in order to get a home of my own," she later said. She was a mother by 17 and a widow by 20. In 1888 she took her 3-year-old daughter, A'Lelia, and headed north, like thousands of blacks who were fleeing violence and looking for opportunity. For more than half of the employed black women in St. Louis, opportunity meant work as a washerwoman. Sarah did that for 10 years, moving from boardinghouse to boardinghouse.
What Bundles calls Walker's "scrupulously crafted life story" began in 1903, when, as she told it so many times afterward, Sarah found herself going bald. (Most rural and poor urban women knew nothing about hair hygiene. They would wash their clothes and scrub their tenement floors, but they might wash their hair once a month.) She prayed to the Lord for guidance, she said, and one night in a dream, "a big black man appeared to me and told me what to mix for my hair. Some of the remedy was from Africa, but I sent for it, mixed it, put it on my scalp and in a few weeks my hair was coming in faster than it had ever fallen out." After trying it out on her daughter and a neighbor she decided to sell her formula; it was "inspiration from God," a gift to be placed "in the reach of those who appreciate beautiful hair and healthy scalps which is the glory of woman."
The actual story wasn't quite so visionary or simple. Walker began as an agent for the black businesswoman she eventually outstripped, Annie Pope-Turbo, whose Poro School of Beauty Culture was already well established in St. Louis. (And whose products, Bundles writes, probably helped Sarah's hair grow back.) In 1906 she headed for Denver, armed with Poro products and a third husband, C. J. Walker. She had her own company by 1906 and a divorce by 1912. Helped by her daughter (who much preferred to party but did her best to please mother), Walker took her Wonderful Hair Grower across the country, selling it, setting up shops and training women in her hair-care methods. By 1907, the washerwoman who had earned $300 a year was earning $300 a month. When she died, of kidney disease, her net worth of $600,000 made her a millionaire in myth, not fact. But that sum, the equivalent of $6 million today, did make her one of the richest businesswomen in America.
Walker was a brilliant publicist. When she spoke of her fears or needs, her tone was unyieldingly crisp: "I was at my washtubs one morning . . . and looked at my arms buried in soapsuds. I said to myself: 'What are you going to do when you grow old and your back gets stiff? Who is going to take care of your little girl?' That set me to thinking, but with all my thinking I couldn't see how I, a poor washerwoman, was going to better my condition." But she grew pithy when she talked business; she enjoyed her own toughness. "Everybody told me I was making a mistake by going into this business, but I know how to grow hair as well as I know how to grow cotton," she declared. And: "My advice to every one expecting to go into business is to hit often and hit hard; in other words, strike with all your might."
She was a genuine philanthropist who put her money where her beliefs were -- and that money included the advertisements that helped A. Philip Randolph start his socialist magazine, The Messenger. (Randolph's wife, Lucille, helped run the magazine but was also a trained Walker agent.) But she was not above turning accusations of "undue extravagance" into race testimonials, telling critics that her mansion, Villa Lewaro -- a pleasure dome with a stucco facade of marble dust and white sand, whose treasures included a Louis XVI chamber suite, an Estey organ and Rodin sculptures -- was "a Negro institution," built to show the race "what a lone woman accomplished and to inspire them to do big things." There is truth here, and there is disingenuousness. Both are fascinating and I wish that instead of presenting them, Bundles had analyzed the relation between them. She suggests that Walker evolved her own version of Andrew Carnegie's "gospel of wealth," which deemed surplus wealth "a sacred trust to be administered for the good of the community in which it is accumulated." An interesting parallel, and Bundles might have further analyzed a woman who had the ruthlessness of a capitalist and the conscience of a progressive. And Bundles need not have been so euphemistic about that fact that in the process of cultivating black hair, Walker's products did, in fact, straighten it. There was a time, especially in the 1960's and 70's, when Walker was accused of fostering black self-hatred. Now, artificially straightened hair is just another option. I am sure that today Madam C. J. Walker would be marketing those treatments for artificially kinked and frizzed hair that have become so popular.

GRAPHIC: Photos: At top, Madam C. J. Walker once before and twice after discovering her hair care products. Below, an early packaging of the hair grower itself. (A'lelia Bundles/Walker family collection/from "On Her Own Ground")

HEADLINE: Even Baboons Get the Blues 

BYLINE:  By Rob Nixon; Rob Nixon is the author of "Dreambirds: The Strange History of the Ostrich in Fashion, Food, and Fortune."

 BODY:
 A Primate's Memoir
By Robert M. Sapolsky.
304 pp. New York:
Scribner. $25.
 ROBERT M. SAPOLSKY had the good sense, from a writer's point of view, to do a lot of crazy things while he was young. Most of them involved baboons. The week he graduated from Harvard, he set out for the plains of southwestern Kenya, where he was to follow a baboon troop on and off for more than 20 years. He did so both in his professional capacity as an animal behaviorist and in his less professional capacity as one of the troop's low-ranking males.
As a boy, entranced by the primate-filled dioramas at the Museum of Natural History in New York, he dreamed of morphing into a mountain gorilla. But his letter to Dian Fossey met with silence, and his scientific curiosity steered him toward questions of social organization that no forest primate could answer. Sapolsky resigned himself to abandoning all gorilla aspirations: "You make compromises in life; not every kid can grow up to become president or a baseball star or a mountain gorilla. So I made plans to join the baboon troop."
Sapolsky's earlier works, "Why Zebras Don't Get Ulcers" and "The Trouble With Testosterone," established him as one of the finest natural history writers around. "A Primate's Memoir" consolidates that reputation while offering something more. This time we are also treated to the nonfiction counterpart of a Bildungsroman, a portrait of the field biologist as a young man. The book's life flows largely from the youthful Sapolsky's penchant for throwing himself at the world and weighing the consequences later. Case in point: what specific aspect of his fancy education can help him escape a cave that he finds himself sharing with a large, drugged baboon and an impala (half-eaten, but alive enough to keep kicking him in the head)? His strategy also has to accommodate the baboon troop that's massing at the cave's entrance and hollering for impala blood.
Sapolsky has a bent for comedy that triumphs in quick, sly asides. Consider, for example, his introduction of a baboon baby he calls Obadiah: "This was one weird-looking kid. He had a narrow head and long stringy hair that formed an elongated wing in the rear; he looked like a dissipated fin de siecle Viennese neurotic." At times, however, Sapolsky spins off into long (sometimes page-long) riffs, and the effect is like being cornered by a host who's overeager to assure you that you're in for a good time -- when you just wish he'd let you size up the territory for yourself. Fortunately, as the book gathers pace, this strained joviality abates and Sapolsky does what he does best, trust his readers and his stories. And with good reason, since his stories are remarkable.
What impresses is their sheer variety: a camp hand spends an ill-judged night in the meat-storage tent and gets into a tangle with a hyena; a Masai employee, disdainful of Sapolsky's sugared ices, decides to invent the cow's-blood ice instead. Feeling adventurous, Sapolsky journeys to the Ugandan source of the Nile only months after the fall of Idi Amin. He later races up the Ruwenzori mountains with a malevolent guide who he suspects may have been party to Dian Fossey's murder. Sapolsky also sketches lively portraits of a wide range of figures, from Fossey to a Kenyan autodidact who wields his education against his brutal ranger-turned-poacher father. And he introduces us to the scams, cross-cultural blunders and chance delights of East African camp life. En route, he muses on everything from anthropomorphism and cultural relativism to how the Kenyan park system has declined beneath the weight of poverty, corruption and a rapacious tourist economy.
But the adventures that Sapolsky recreates in "A Primate's Memoir" are undergirded by a serious scientific intent: a study of male stress. Years of baboon observation prompt him to challenge the prevailing view that "testosterone plus aggression equals social dominance." Instead, he deduces that in a stable hierarchy, low-ranking males -- the ones who fight most frequently over status -- exhibit higher testosterone levels (and are more prone to stress-related disease) than the dominant baboons. Moreover, regardless of rank, the lowest stress hormone levels among males appear among those that engage regularly in social grooming and other nonaggressive contact with troop members.
Ultimately, Sapolsky finds he has to factor in something as quirky as personality. Take the case of Nick, stressed-out, mid-ranking, type-A Nick. One day, trying to make a move up the hierarchy, Nick picks a fight with Reuben, who quickly signals defeat by sticking his bottom in the air. Nick pretends to play by the rules, which dictate that he saunter over for a victorious but noninjurious sniff. Instead, he gives Reuben a nasty bite across his peacefully raised buttocks. Sapolsky the scientist and Sapolsky the layman concur: Nick is one mean sucker.
THE memoir's emotional drama builds in large part around Sapolsky's efforts to reconcile these two versions of himself. Sometimes he needs to regard the troop with clinical dispassion -- in the guise of a Stanford professor who publishes papers on the dynamics of bovine tuberculosis transmission in the olive baboon, Papio anubis, in The Journal of Medical Primatology. But he is also a man who has come to know these animals intimately and to feel great affection for them, someone who, when he learns in the book's wrenching finale that Daniel, Absolom, Benjamin and other favorites have been felled by that same tuberculosis, struggles to devise a ritual way to grieve. He fails. And he stays haunted to the end: "These baboons only remain as ashes in my head."
One closes his book a lot more knowledgeable about plenty of baboon-related matters. But mostly one has already begun to miss the company of this sometimes cranky but always impassioned, learned and winningly irreverent man. What more can we ask of a writer than that he draw us into the charmed circle of his obsessions? That much (and more) Sapolsky has done in a book that achieves an almost Homeric emotional range. Sapolsky steeps us in baboon-land variants of heroism, lamentation, vengeance and loneliness in a plot thickened with kidnappings, trysts, betrayals, out-of-the-blue tenderness, palace coups and sundry wars of attrition. "A Primate's Memoir" is the closest the baboon is likely to come -- and it's plenty close enough -- to having its own "Iliad."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
New Flights Are a Sign Of Confidence in Asia

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
UNITED AIRLINES is declaring its confidence in the Asian travel market today, with an expansion it hopes does not end up looking like an April Fool's joke. United is reinstating its around-the-world service -- which it suspended in spring 1999 because of Asia's financial crisis -- by adding flights from London to New Delhi and New Delhi to Hong Kong. 
 The carrier will also inaugurate a 15-hour flight over the North Pole, from Kennedy Airport in New York to Hong Kong, and begin flying from Chicago to Beijing. The airline -- the world's largest and the American carrier that takes the most passengers to Asia -- will also add two more trips each week between San Francisco and Shanghai, giving it daily service on that route. 
 Some of the flights will come about because of new trade agreements between the United States and other countries, but at the heart of United's expansion is a confidence among its executives that Asia has emerged from its worst economic problems.
As an example, they say, tourism has been booming across Asia for much of the last two years. 
More people visited Cambodia and Thailand last year than in 1999, according to reports from the Pacific Asia Travel Association. Cathay Pacific, the Hong Kong-based, airline, plans to increase its fleet by more than 20 percent this year, and Garuda Indonesia and Philippine Airlines are expanding, too. 
Northwest Airlines, the second largest American carrier in Asia, says that it filled 82 percent of its seats over the Pacific last year, up from 76 percent in 1998. On March 1, Continental began the first nonstop service between the New York area and Hong Kong, a 16-hour flight between Newark and Chek Lap Kok International Airport.
Adding all these new flights carries some risk, however. Asia's economies, while healthier than a few years ago, have generally weakened in the early months of 2001. Last month, Japan Airlines said that it planned to cut 4,200 jobs over the next two years, partly in reaction to the slowing world economy.
The worst scenario for travel companies would be a repeat of the late 90's, when they expanded just before tourism declined dramatically. In those years, as Asian currencies lost value, businesses in South Korea halted many trips overnight and Americans and Europeans grew wary of going to the region, in spite of the low prices, because of the turmoil. 
"When people hear there is a crisis in Asia, they avoid Asia," said Lily Shum, the Americas regional director of the Hong Kong Tourist Association. 
The crisis came after years of manic hotel building, designed to capitalize on what was supposed to be the world's fastest economic growth for years to come. At the same time, a new aviation pact in 1998 between Japan and the United States allowed for dozens of new flights a week across the Pacific.
"You had this huge bump in the number of seats at the same time traffic declined," said Stuart Oran, senior vice president of the international division of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United, which had operating profits in Asia of $405 million in 1997 and just $49 million the next year. "We still haven't absorbed all of the new seats."
The oversupply helped put Sempati Air of Indonesia and Saega Airlines of Malaysia out of business in the late 90's.
But now, many countries are receiving more visitors than they did before the crisis. When figures from last year are all counted, the number of visitors to Singapore may surpass 7.5 million, which would be the most ever, according to early estimates from the Pacific Asia Travel Association. The number had dropped 13 percent between 1997 and 1998, to 6.2 million.
Cambodia, China, South Korea and Thailand also may set records when tallies are completed for 2000. Countries with less stable political situations, like Indonesia and the Philippines, have been slower to recover, tourism officials say. United stopped flying to Manila during the economic crisis and has not returned.
Absent a serious economic downturn, however, the Asian travel market is likely to remain much healthier than it was a few years ago, and bargains have become harder to find as a result. 
In Hong Kong, hotel rates increased about 9 percent last year, to an average of $107, after having fallen more than 40 percent in the previous two years, according to the Hong Kong Tourist Association. And mirroring a rise in air fares across the region, Cathay now charges $1,200 for its three-week pass for unlimited Asian travel, up from $1,000 in 1999. (People who buy the pass over the Internet and agree to receive e-mail advertisements from Cathay still pay $1,000, the airline says.
Liberalized trade agreements and new airports are driving the boom. Last year, the United States agreed on the framework for its first multilateral aviation pact, deciding with Brunei, Chile, New Zealand and Singapore to halt restrictions on flights among those nations. 
Russia is allowing more flights over the North Pole, a route that can save two hours between Asia and North America. And a huge airport in Inchon, South Korea, about 35 miles from Seoul, was to be officially opened Thursday, joining new airports in Beijing, Hong Kong, Shanghai and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
It will all make for more convenient travel across the Pacific. But unless the airlines are overly optimistic about the region's economic health, the big bargains of the late 90's may be harder to find.

HEADLINE: The Sound Of New Music Is Often Chinese; 
The Offspring Of a Grim Revolution

BYLINE:  By SHEILA MELVIN and JINDONG CAI; Sheila Melvin is a freelance writer who was based in Shanghai and now lives in Baton Rouge, La. Jindong Cai conducts at Louisiana State University and is a regular guest conductor of the Shanghai Symphony.

DATELINE: BEIJING 

 BODY:
WHEN the Central Conservatory here reopened its doors in 1977, after the 10 barren years of the Cultural Revolution, it received applications from 18,000 musicians across China.
 "We had only 100 spaces," said Wu Zuqiang, a composer and former dean of the Central Conservatory. "We accepted 100, but then we accepted 100 more. We had nowhere to put them, but it was such a shame not to take them." 
 Selecting 200 of 18,000 musicians desperate to pursue the professional study that had for a decade been denied them was no easy task, but the conservatory chose well. Indeed, the roster of composition graduates from that 1977 class includes the names of several composers internationally prominent today: the recent Academy Award winner Tan Dun, Chen Yi, Zhou Long, Guo Wenjing, Qu Xiaosong, Ye Xiaogang. Yet paradoxically, they are far better known in the United States and Europe than in their native country. Until recently, their music was rarely heard in China. 
During the 1980's and much of the 90's, anyone wishing to hear contemporary Chinese music might have been better off going to Europe, where the Nieuw Ensemble in Amsterdam and the Festival d'Automne in Paris were leading the way in presenting works of Chinese composers. Similarly, anyone wishing to meet these composers in person would have been more likely to find them in New York than in Beijing. To this day, those wishing to purchase recordings or scores of their music need to look somewhere other than China, where even the biggest music companies do not publish, record or sell works of Chinese composers.
"There are now many Chinese composers, but very little of their music gets played in China, either of the composers who left or the ones who stayed," said Wang Xilin, a Beijing composer. "Chinese orchestras don't perform Chinese pieces. They perform only foreign pieces. To publish a score or a compact disc takes 20 years. Nobody cares about composers. Conductors get cars. We get bikes."
But in the last few years, the situation has started to improve. The prestige of Chinese composers outside China has begun to be recognized here, perhaps kick-started by the nationwide telecast of Tan Dun's "Heaven, Earth, Mankind," which was commissioned for ceremonies commemorating the return of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
Mr. Tan returned to China twice last year to conduct performances of his works, and his name, if not his music, is now widely recognized. The China National Symphony this year began a series called Dream of China, dedicated to works of contemporary Chinese composers, and has held concerts of music by Chen Yi and Bright Sheng. The Hong Kong Philharmonic is featuring more music by Chinese composers. New-music ensembles now exist in Beijing and Shanghai. And most encouraging of all, young composers are choosing to stay in China, and more experienced composers who did emigrate are returning to compose and teach.
As a result, contemporary music in China is entering new territory. Composers no longer look solely outside China for guidance, as they looked to the West for the last 20 years and to the Soviet Union before that. Instead, they are delving deeper into their own musical roots and seeking inspiration in Chinese traditions. In the process, many are fundamentally re-evaluating long-held perceptions about both Western classical and traditional Chinese music. The going is not always easy. Composers in China still face economic, cultural and political constraints that would be hard to imagine in the West. But for the first time in the history of Communist China, a significant number of composers are working on a level field with composers outside China.
"Many composers complain that Chinese orchestras don't play Chinese composers' work, but this is changing," said Guo Wen jing, the chairman of the composition department at the Central Conservatory, whom many consider the best composer in China. "Also, commissions have started to improve in television, movies, orchestras. There are many more opportunities in China than there used to be."
Mr. Guo is perhaps the only Chinese composer who has established an international career without having lived outside China for an extended period. His first international commission came from the Nieuw Ensemble in 1991, and he has done other works for it since, including the opera "Wolf Cub Village" in 1994. Another opera, "The Night Banquet," will be performed at the Festival d'Automne this fall and at the Lincoln Center Festival next year.
In his music, Mr. Guo evokes the folk music and opera of his native Sichuan, but in a voice that is decidedly his own. The cries of Yangtze River boatmen, the distinctive timbre of traditional percussion, the extreme range and color of Sichuan opera singing: all are not so much reflected in his compositions as absorbed into them and recreated. But his intimate understanding of southwestern Chinese folk music is not innate.
"Our problem is, we graduate from the conservatory, we know the oboe, we know the flute, but we know nothing about the Chinese flute," he said. "The students in the traditional-music department study Western music, but the students in Western music don't study Chinese traditional music. I think the biggest gain I've made is learning about Chinese traditional music."
Although Chinese symphonic music has long paid homage to traditional Chinese music, its deeper debt has been to Western classical music, especially to the technique taught by Soviet-educated professors in a conservatory system modeled after that of the Soviet Union. Only now, with composers like Mr. Guo coming into positions of authority in the conservatories, are inroads being made in the terrain that separates Western classical and Chinese traditional music. In his teaching, Mr. Guo is helping establish those inroads, but in his composing, he strives to free himself from any theory or tradition whatsoever.
"Ultimately, I want to break away from Western influence and break away from Chinese influence," he said. "I can't do this completely, of course, but I have a goal."
An even more radical approach is being advocated at the Shanghai Conservatory, where Qu Xiaosong returned to teach in 1999 after many years in New York. Together with colleagues like the composer He Xuntian, Mr. Qu is aiming to alter drastically the parameters of conservatory education that he feels have too long been biased toward Western music.
"European music is only one part," Mr. Qu said. "Students should understand Chinese music, too. Chinese and Western music are so different, and of course there are Indian music, African music, so many different traditions."
Mr. Qu has organized Shanghai's first contemporary Chinese music ensemble. After the group's first concert, last November, he told The China Daily that the first step toward a Chinese music renaissance was to wash off the pollution of Western music and return to the purity of classical Chinese music. His own music, like his recent "Mirage," for a vocalist and three percussionists, increasingly embodies that less-is-more philosophy. In the conservatory, he encourages students to compose for Chinese instruments and think independently.
"Conservatories give you the recipes, but how you finally make the dish, that's up to you," he said.
Like Mr. Qu, Ye Xiaogang returned to China after many years in the United States, where he graduated from the Eastman School of Music in Rochester. He teaches at the Central Conservatory, and in 1995 he founded a contemporary-music group, Ensemble Eclipse. Mr. Ye is kept busy with commissions from film studios, orchestras and government bodies like the Shenzhen Propaganda Bureau and the Beijing Culture Bureau.
"My music is played everywhere, and my commissions are very high," he said. "There are so many opportunities here. I'd never have these opportunities in America."
Generous government commissions, often associated with major political celebrations like the 80th anniversary of the Communist Party on July 1, are a new phenomenon in China. Because of the political nature of these commissions, some composers are reluctant to accept them. But music is music, Mr. Ye says, no matter who commissions it.
"I can do whatever I want," he added. "Music cannot be controlled. People's circumstances are all different. If I can earn $1,000 writing a chamber piece for Europe or $35,000 for a piece here, what am I going to do?"
Of course, not all composers working in China have such options. "Younger composers, who came of age after the Cultural Revolution, have different views," said Mr. Wu, of the Central Conservatory. "I often tell them that they caught up with the good times. It was easy to connect with the outside world. It was not the same for us."
True, composers of Mr. Wu's generation, including Luo Zhongrong of Beijing and Zhu Jianer of Shanghai, suffered badly during the Cultural Revolution, but they also had the good times of the 1950's, when many were sent to the Soviet Union to study.
Mr. Zhu, the resident composer of the Shanghai Symphony since 1975, has long supported young composers and contemporary music. Although his own compositions are heavily influenced by folk music of Yunnan, Tibet and Guizhou, he tirelessly explores new ideas and techniques. Politics prevented him from writing his first symphony until 1986, when he was 64; he has since added nine more.
It is the generation after Mr. Zhu's -- including Jin Xiang, whose opera "Savage Land" was performed by the Washington Opera in 1992, and Wang Xilin -- that suffered the most, leaving the conservatory just in time for the Cultural Revolution. Mr. Wang was exiled to rural Shanxi Province for 14 years after his graduation, because he publicly criticized the Maoist dictum that art must serve politics. For much of this time, he worked as a laborer; but for three years, he was imprisoned, made to sleep on the floor and beaten regularly. In 1968, his jailers dragged him to a field in the middle of the night and buried him in a pit up to his neck.
"I thought they were going to bury me alive," he said. "But it was just to scare me. This treatment because I spoke the truth. I didn't steal anything. I didn't hurt anyone. This is when I started thinking about expressing all that in music."
Mr. Wang's music relentlessly recounts the suffering of intellectuals. "I want to tell people about the tragedy and darkness of Chinese history," he said. "This is my music."
Because tragedy and darkness do not suit commissions for celebratory political occasions, and because Mr. Wang speaks his mind in words as well as in music, he finds it harder to get his works played than do composers who avoid politics. And he is often engaged in bitter battles with the authorities.
Few composers still face such political problems. But all must deal with issues like the conservative stance of the Chinese Musicians' Association, the near impossibility of getting scores or recordings published in China, inadequate copyright protection for music, the preference of most orchestras for Western classics, and the small audience for contemporary music.
Still, most composers acknowledge that the environment is much improved and that they are indeed fortunate to have caught up with the good times.
"In 1979, nobody would have believed that so many Chinese composers would be standing on the world stage," said Mr. Guo, the Beijing composer. "Nobody would have believed how many young Chinese musicians would win international prizes. I never dreamed my pieces would be performed in Europe. These last 20 years are so hard to believe, I can't guess what it will be like in 20 more years."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
War Memorial or Soccer Field?

BYLINE:  By JOHN SWANSBURG 

 BODY:
AT Mamaroneck High School, sophomores take a history course known as Global 10. The class begins its journey in 1750 and moves at the frenetic pace necessary to arrive in the present by June. It's usually mid-March by the time students turn their attention to World War II. This March, they are not alone: people throughout the community here are thinking about the war -- and, more broadly, about the relationship between the past and the future. 
 The Board of Education is now preparing a five-year, $49 million plan to improve schools' facilities. Much of the renovation will take place at the high school. In addition to architectural improvements, the plans originally called for rotating the school's football field 90 degrees to make room for a new entrance, safer parking and a soccer field. 
 In order to rotate the field, however, the school would need to relocate the Richard M. Kemper Memorial, a park and monument dedicated to Mamaroneck High students who died in World War II. The memorial has stood near the school's Boston Post Road entrance since 1946. 
The plan to move the memorial has met with staunch opposition from relatives of Richard Kemper, in particular Paul Cantor, Mr. Kemper's nephew, and Mr. Cantor's brother Richard, who was named for his uncle. "We are really outraged," Paul Cantor said. "We are going to fight." 
Because of the family's objections, the board decided recently to postpone the decision on the memorial so as not to delay a vote on the other elements of the plan. It has not, however, scrapped its initial proposal. The board is looking into alternatives to moving the memorial, but the board's president, Ronda Lustman, said its options are limited by the site. The board is therefore also exploring its legal rights, should it choose to proceed over the objections of the Cantor family.
Lt. Richard Kemper, class of 1937, was killed in battle on Aug. 6, 1944, near Mortain, France. Two years later, his father, Adolph Kemper, bought land near the high school where he and his wife, Helen, dedicated a monument bearing the names of the 98 men and one woman from the school who died in the war. 
After the dedication, the Kempers donated the monument and the park to the school district. In the deed, they asked that the land "be held and maintained in perpetuity for public and school uses as a memorial to the late Lt. Richard Kemper, and the other students and former students . . . who gave their lives in the service of the United States of America in World War II." 
The school board and Mr. Kemper's relatives interpret this directive differently.
The school believes it can fulfill its duty by maintaining the monument, but in a new location. Dr. Sherry King, superintendent of schools, said that honoring Adolph Kemper's wishes has always been the school's intention. "But we want to do that with a plan that will speak to the community as it exists now," she said. "I don't think those two goals are mutually exclusive."
Dr. King believes moving the monument would, in fact, increase its presence on the school's grounds. "We are looking at the possibility of moving the memorial to a more central location and to one that would be beautifully landscaped," she said. "Not everyone knows about the memorial, and by moving it we could enhance the whole location for everyone."
For Mr. Kemper's family, however, moving the memorial is simply not an option. "We consider that park sacred," Paul Cantor said.
Mr. Cantor is not alone in his belief. On March 13, Richard Cantor spoke to the Larchmont Historical Society about the memorial's future. Jan Northrup, the society's president, said Mr. Cantor delivered "an incredibly moving speech." The result was a unanimous vote by the society to draft a resolution stating its "unequivocal opposition" to relocating the memorial.
Ms. Northrup said she believed that Adolph Kemper intended the memorial to be composed not just of the monument, but of the entire surrounding park as well. She believes his vision is evident in the language of the deed. "No matter how inconvenient the park is right now, his message couldn't have been any clearer," she said.
The dialogue between the school administration and the Cantor family has been strained from the beginning. The family is upset because it feels the board tried to move ahead with its plans without the family's consent. 
Dr. King said she did not know of the Cantor family at the time the initial plans were drafted, and regrets that the board acted without consulting them. "We have apologized profusely," she said. "The moment we became aware of the Cantor family we reached out to them." 
The Cantors do not live in Mamaroneck, and Paul Cantor, who teaches economics at the University of Massachusetts, admitted that the memorial -- and his family's connection to it -- had been largely forgotten. That is why Mr. Cantor approached the school in August with the hope of reviving the memorial's role in the school community. 
Mr. Cantor met with the principal, Mark Orfinger, and Lorna Minor, the chairwoman of the social studies department, to discuss ideas for making the memorial part of the school's curriculum. Ms. Minor said she was not aware of the memorial's significance. "I've been teaching here for 30 years and I never knew about it," she said. "I knew it was there, but I didn't know what it was."
As soon as the memorial was brought to her attention, Ms. Minor said, she realized it was an untapped resource. "We thought it could help make history come alive," she said. 
Mary Cronin, a history teacher at the school, recently tested Ms. Minor's theory. The day after quizzing her Global 10 class on the battles of World War II, she took them to visit the memorial. Asking her students to quietly reflect, she read the names on the monument out loud. "A couple of times I could feel my voice catch," she said. "You can't help but be moved by it."
Several students shared Ms. Cronin's emotional response. Lucy Malcolm wrote afterward of the experience: "It was very moving. It was very weird to go back to our class and think that those people possibly sat in this room. It was interesting to hear the names because many of the names are familiar to me. I definitely felt some kind of presence being there."
Both Ms. Lustman and Mr. Cantor want students to learn from the memorial, but Ms. Lustman said her duty to the taxpayers also requires her to provide for the many students here who learn on the playing field. Mr. Cantor said that if the board decides to move the monument, the only lesson it will be teaching is that it's acceptable to break a promise.
Ms. Minor hopes that no matter what the outcome, the dispute, like the memorial itself, will provide an opportunity for learning. "It will be very interesting to see how the public debate adds to these historical lessons," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Richard M. Kemper Memorial, a park and monument at Mamaroneck High School, above. A photo of Lieutenant Kemper and his father, Adolph, circa 1943. A rendering of how the monument might look if it were moved to another site at the school. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/44th Street Between Fifth and Sixth Avenues; 
In Center for Clubhouses, Remnants of Small Stables

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE Harvard Club's plan for an eight-story addition to replace its little buildings at 33 and 35 West 44th west of the main clubhouse is just one part of the general revival of what was established at the turn of the century as the club center of New York. The clubs themselves settled here in the 1890's because others disdained the noises and smells of the Civil War-era stables that then dominated the street. Now it appears that the last of the stables are disappearing.
 In the 1850's and 1860's, row house construction flourished west of Fifth on 42nd and 45th Streets, but for some reason 43rd and 44th were dominated by small stables. Perhaps the block-long stable for horse-drawn trolley cars at the Sixth Avenue end, built in the early 1850's, spoiled the flanking blocks for higher uses. 
 In 1865 Benjamin Jones and Andrew Luke, grain dealers, built four two-story stables at 43-49 West 44th; only 47 survives, as an annex to the Hotel Iroquois. They sold 47 to 1865 to Wedworth Clarke, an oil dealer who lived in a brownstone at 55 West 45th. It must have been Clarke's coachman, William Dunn, who shows up at the stable address in the 1869 city directory online at the Web site Ancestry.com. 
The same directory shows the block as one of working class occupations: at 35 West 44th Street, a stable built in 1859, lived a coachman, a watchman, a trunk maker, a carpenter and an oysterman, William Reckhow.
In 1871, Elisha Brooks built a new stable on the site. Brooks, who moved up from Union Square to Fifth Avenue near 46th Street, was a member of the firm of Brooks Brothers.
His new stable was designed by the architect William Laimbeer and is the most intact of the stables remaining on the block, with its cornice and upper floors remaining from its stable days. 
Brooks died in 1878 and his family sold 35 West 44th Street to George D. Phelps, who had graduated from Yale, was a member of the Union League Club and was independently wealthy; in 1881 The New York Times reported that he had been charged with insulting two women on a Broadway stage with "vile and indecent language" while drunk; he paid a $10 fine. When he died two years later from a fall while intoxicated, The Times reported that he had recently been swindled in a purchase of some Kentucky horses, "which were not what they were represented to be."
Around the same time, the Clarke family sold 47 West 44th Street to Edward Brandon, a prominent Wall Street stockbroker who often traded for the financier Jay Gould. Brandon went bankrupt in 1890 and the next year had to sell 47 West 44th to Henry G. Trevor, a sportsman who founded the Shinnecock Golf Club on the East End of Long Island and lived at 6 East 45th Street.
BY this time many of the original stable owners had moved farther north, and changes were occurring that would significantly alter West 43rd and 44th Streets. Because the stables depressed land values, these blocks attracted users looking for economical sites.
In 1887 John S. White, the Harvard-educated headmaster of the private Berkeley School, built a gym for the school at 19-21 West 44th Street (it has since been demolished) and established a men's athletic club there to defray expenses. This was the first club on the block. 
Two years later the New York Academy of Medicine (also demolished) and the Century Association built on West 43rd Street, attracted by the modest land costs and proximity to Grand Central Terminal. In 1890 the Brearley School, a private girls' school, built a building at 15 West 44th Street (which no longer exists). 
Most private clubs were still in second-hand buildings, and in 1891 the Real Estate Record and Guide said that clubhouse architecture was "utterly unknown in New York until recently" and also made a prediction that perhaps seemed reasonable: "there is no club centre in New York, nor is there likely to be." In 1893 the Harvard Club started its Georgian-style clubhouse at 27 West 44th, and the St. Nicholas Club began a Dutch-style building at 7 West 44th (later demolished). In 1894 the Bar Association built its own clublike headquarters at 42 West 44th, and in 1899 the Yale and New York Yacht Clubs started clubhouses at 30 and 37 West 44th Street.
In the same year the multimillionaire James Ben Ali Haggin bought the old Brooks-Phelps stable at 35 West 44th Street and raised it one story, apparently reusing the original cornice, and replicating the brickwork of the lower floors. Haggin, who was not a member of any of the clubs on the block, lived at on Fifth Avenue near 47th Street. 
He had made his fortune in the California gold rush and owned several thousand horses; his father was born in Kentucky, but his mother was Turkish. 
In 1900 Henry G. Trevor moved from 45th Street and sold the 47 West 44th Street stable to the new Hotel Iroquois at 49 West 44th, one of several hotels that developers built as the fortunes of 44th Street rose markedly. 
Such changes were also reflected in the census returns; the 1900 census shows an influx of occupations like bellman and waiter into the old stable structures. That year The New York Tribune noted the sudden transformation of the block, calling it "Bachelors' Alley" because of all the rooms for single men; some of the clubs had also taken blocks of rooms in the 1897 Hotel Royalton, at 44 West 44th Street. 
The City Club, a civic organization, was the last club to build on the block, putting up its eight-story house at 55 West 44th Street in 1904.
The next year The New York Times said that sightseeing buses routinely went down 44th Street, where "you could not throw a stick very far without hitting either a magnificent clubhouse or a dingy stable." 
The 1920 census records a completely changed tenancy in the old stables; 33 West 44th Street, built in 1860, was the home of two ""motion picture" actors and a lawyer, and 35 West 44th, the Brooks-Phelps-Haggin stable, was the home of Julia Azez, 65, who was born in Syria but arrived in the United States in 1888, along with her Arabic-speaking daughter Alice Azez, a landscape artist.
The club buildings of 44th Street have generally survived and even prospered. The Harvard Club now has 10,000 members. Several years ago, the Penn Club reclaimed the old Yale Club, which had built its present clubhouse on Vanderbilt Avenue in 1915. The Penn Club acquired the building from Touro College, which had been located there since the early 1970's.
Within the last month 44th Street was blocked off as new steel was lifted to the roof of the old City Club, which is becoming a hotel; Philip Murray, whose firm Gilsanz Murray & Steficek is the structural engineer for the project, says the steel is for 10 additional stories to be added at some future date.
Stephen Brighenti is the head of Metropolitan Hotels, a partner in the development of what is being called the City Club Hotel, which he expects to open in June. Mr. Brighenti calls 44th "the most accommodating block in New York," including all the clubs that offer rooms for members.
The City Club project involves the restoration of its exterior, but the Harvard Club's plan, designed by Davis Brody Bond, calls for the demolition of 33 and 35 West 44th. That would leave 47 West 44th as the last recognizable stable structure on the block; it now appears empty and abandoned. But Paul Celnick, general manager of the Iroquois, says that by the end of the year the hotel is going to make it into a banquet and convention space for the Iroquois. The funny little arches and keystones will disappear too; the facade will be rebuilt to match that of the hotel.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Eminent Domain Challenged in New London Project

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: NEW LONDON 

 BODY:
ON occasional Sundays Vic Frausini, a 71-year-old mason from Waterford, comes back to the old Italian neighborhood of New London where he was born and raised to salvage usable bricks out of the rubble left behind by the demolition of homes near Fort Trumbull State Park.
 Once a stable enclave overlooking the Thames River, bounded by East Street, Trumbull, Nameaug and Walbach Streets, the area fell into deep decline along with rest of the city. Now it is being leveled to make way for a $200 million complex of offices, upscale housing and a hotel on a total of 90 acres. And it is the subject of a legal battle over the use of eminent domain to acquire property for a project in which private companies stand to gain, a technique that is in dispute in a number of places in Connecticut. 
 Mr. Frausini said he feels bad that so many homes and businesses of his former neighbors have been torn down. "For some people it's very painful," he said. "They've lived here for generations. But everything is deteriorated -- dilapidated. What the city is planning will be good for New London." 
With 60 percent of its real estate tax-exempt, the 11th highest tax rate and fourth weakest economy among Connecticut's 169 municipalities and with no land left for development, this city of six square miles is struggling. Local government welcomed the Fort Trumbull project with unequivocal approval from the City Council, the Planning and Zoning Commission and the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments. And the project got $73 million from the State Department of Economic and Community Development for planning, site preparation, soil remediation, infrastructure improvement and roads. 
The balance is to be raised by Corcoran-Jennison of Boston, the city's designated developer and owner of the project.
Over the next five years it will build a 110- to 250-room hotel with an indoor pool and health club, a 200,000-square-foot office building and 80 units of high-end town houses and apartments. An existing 9,000-square-foot building is to be converted to offices from a former naval underwater warfare center. Plans for the first phase will be submitted to New London's Planning and Zoning Commission in May.
The city delegated its power of eminent domain and all oversight to the private New London Development Authority, headed by Claire Gaudiani, president of Connecticut College. She is currently on sabbatical until her resignation from the college becomes effective in June.
Her husband, David G. Burnett, is an executive at the Pfizer Corporation, whose new $270 million three-building global research and development headquarters opens in June about three blocks from Fort Trumbull Park. Through its acquisition of Warner-Lambert last year, Pfizer has the largest biomedical research and development operation in the world, and it has backed a $2 million loan to the Fort Trumbull project for working capital and improvements to Howard Street, a road leading into its headquarters.
"We are committed to about 30 percent of the new hotel rooms," said Kate Robins, a spokeswoman for Pfizer, "and we will have preferred access to its conference space for 15 years." Marty Jones, president of Corcoran-Jennison, said, "We are pleased to have Pfizer as a financial partner."
Everyone is pleased -- the city, the state and the general citizenry of New London -- except for the enraged Fort Trumbull homeowners and business owners who are being evicted for what they believe is the benefit of Pfizer, not New London.
"The eminent domain issue is hard for people to understand," Ms. Gaudiani said, "how it will lower taxes, improve schools, create jobs and bring people back to the city. Most of the press has taken the part of the people who are displaced, ignoring the big picture of how a city picks itself up."
Fort Trumbull Park is one of many examples across the country where eminent domain is being re-examined. In Connecticut, eminent domain for private gain has been used in projects in Ridgefield, Bridgeport, Torrington and Bristol.
To date the New London Development Corporation has used its power of eminent domain to condemn, acquire and dispose of 80 homes and small businesses at Fort Trumbull Park, according to Christopher Riley, a spokesman for the corporation. Some are now boarded up before demolition; others have already been bulldozed and their owners relocated. 
OF the 10 remaining properties, seven owners refuse to budge. Standing in the living room of her salmon pink 1895 house, Suzette Kelo, one of the most vocal holdouts, snapped, "They own the house!" referring to the development corporation. "The money is in City Hall. They tell me I can have it anytime I want it, but I don't want it. I'm staying." From her windows she has a 180-degree view of the Thames River and Pfizer, the city's largest taxpayer. "I was told that my property would be marketed, but not for what," she said. "It's for Pfizer." 
Working through the Institute for Justice in Washington, a nonprofit organization that specializes in fighting what it believes is the abuse of eminent domain, Ms. Kelo and her six neighbors obtained a restraining order in February preventing further demolitions and evictions until a lawsuit filed on their behalf in December by the institute is concluded. A trial, scheduled on May 21 in State Superior Court in New London, will focus on whether taking property by eminent domain for private profit is constitutional.
Scott G. Bullock, an institute lawyer who is representing the group, has accused the city and the development corporation of violating the federal and state Constitutions and the City Charter by subverting the process of eminent domain from its purpose of providing for the public good with roads, bridges, schools and so forth, to creating windfalls for private developers engaged in profit-making enterprises.
New London's mayor, Ernest Hewitt, sees it differently. "I think we've done everything within the parameters of the law," he said. "People left this city out of frustration that nothing has happened here for the past 50 years. They wanted something to happen, and by God we're doing it!"
But Terry Tondro, a professor of law at the University of Connecticut, thinks the homeowners have a reasonable case. "I greatly sympathize with these people," he said. "We should find a way to pay attention to the communities and the needs of people. It doesn't help to have a big tax-producing entity in town" with disproportionate influence over how a project is developed for its own benefit. "But," he added, "redevelopment has never been noted for sensitivity."
The circumstances vary in the cases in which eminent domain is under dispute in other places around Connecticut. Open space preservation is the context in which the town of Ridgefield wants to buy Bennett's Pond, a 680-acre tract of undeveloped land, the largest in Fairfield County, from Roseland Properties of Short Hills, N.J. The developer bought it from I.B.M. in 1998 for $8.5 million, planning to build 284 homes, 350,000 square feet of offices, a 200-room hotel and conference center and an 18-hole golf course.
The original plan was rejected by the Planning and Zoning Commission, and an offer of $12 million by the town was refused. But the developer is willing to limit a reduced proposal to 20 percent of the land, assigning the rest to open space in perpetuity. The Ridgefield Open Space Association wants nothing built and the property taken in eminent domain. "Taking land must be well defined as a public purpose," said Carl Goldberg, head of Roseland Properties. "I don't think that's the case, and even if they win, the amount of the award could be catastrophic for the town."
Last December the Superior Court of Connecticut ruled that the use of eminent domain by the city of Bridgeport to take the Pequonnock Yacht Club was illegal. The court said the city's action was not necessary to attain its goal of developing a $731 million plan for a hotel, conference center, retail operations and water-related recreational uses on a blighted 50-acre area called Steel Point. The city was ordered to return the club to its owner. Now the developer's contract has been terminated because it lacked financing, and the city has five new proposals to consider. To keep the site intact by regaining the Yacht Club property, the city is appealing the ruling.
In downtown Torrington, where a number of stores are vacant, Water Street along the Naugatuck River, Main Street and East Main Street are the targets of a plan to variously renovate, demolish and build new stores "to help solidify the town's hub," said Jed Hayes, head of Sullivan-Hayes, developers based in Farmington. Some 400,000 square feet of space would be affected by the introduction of two new department stores and a number of additional stores. But the relocation or demise of local merchants and the city's willingness to seize property by eminent domain from unwilling owners is worrisome to townspeople and prompted a cautionary editorial in The Litchfield County Times, a weekly newspaper based in New Milford.
The Bristol case involves a 30-acre homestead owned by the Bugryn brothers, John and Frank. The city took the property by eminent domain after negotiations to acquire it failed and Yarde Metals, which wanted it for expansion purposes, threatened to leave town unless it got its way.
Yarde Metals left town anyway, the Bugryns still live on the property, the city still owns it and the case is still winding through the courts after five years.

HEADLINE: Latest Census Reveals an Old-Fashioned Trend 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
IN the four years since Joe Grate moved his barbecue restaurant from downtown New Haven to the neighboring town of Hamden, a funny pattern has developed. Every so often, Mr. Grate sees a customer that he first met during his 20 years in the bigger city.
 "A lot of people that I have known in New Haven have come in," he said. "And I'll say, 'How are things going in New Haven?' And they say, 'Well, we live in Hamden now.' That's happened with hundreds of people." 
 Mr. Grate knows dozens of black families who have moved to Hamden in recent years. And he knows why, because he made the same move in 1968 for the same reason. "They want something a little better for their children, better schools," he said. "And a little more peace of mind. This is the same just like everybody else, lower-class and lower-middle-class people, they work, they have jobs and they want a better life." 
Early results of the 2000 census show declining populations in all of Connecticut's bigger cities except Stamford. Predictably, a large portion of the declines can be attributed to white residents leaving cities that are becoming increasingly black and Hispanic. But in New Haven and in Hartford, the large cities with the steepest population drops, there has also been a significant departure of black people and corresponding growth in the size and diversity of rim suburbs like Hamden or West Hartford.
Between 1990 and 2000, the number of Hamden residents identifying themselves as black increased to 8,632, more than 15 percent of the town population, from 4,666, which was less than 9 percent. During the same time, the number of New Haven residents identifying themselves as black decreased to 44,598 from 47,526, a decline of more than 6 percent. Hartford had an even steeper decline in its black population, to 43,775 from 52,357, a drop of more than 16 percent.
And while the number of Hispanics, Asians and other minorities in Connecticut's cities continues to grow, the number of minority residents in the suburbs is also increasing. In Hamden, the number of residents identifying themselves as Hispanic increased to 2,425 from 1,101, a jump of more than 120 percent. The number of Hamden residents identifying themselves as Asian increased to 2,000 from 915, a similar jump of nearly 120 percent. 
The population numbers are based on figures for 2000 and on 1990 data that were adjusted to make up for undercounting and overcounting in the 1990 census.
The shifts in Connecticut, which remains an overwhelmingly white state, suggest that the move from cities to suburbs that began in the late 19th century and continued through the 20th century among middle- and upper-class whites is being repeated going into the 21st century by upwardly mobile African-Americans and Hispanic, Caribbean and Asian immigrants.
City neighborhoods that were once occupied entirely by European immigrants are now filled with Latin Americans. Although Connecticut's cities remain centers of employment, they seem to have less and less to offer middle-class families with children.
"There certainly are some job magnets there," said David Rusk, a former mayor of Albuquerque and urban policy consultant who has studied Hartford. "State agencies, Aetna headquarters, major hospitals, Trinity College; all of these employ people of professional standing, many of whom may want to live closer to where they work but they are not going to do so surrounded by a sea of poverty. That just doesn't make sense, especially if they have children to raise." 
For Mayor Carl J. Amento of Hamden, the movement to suburbs like his is encouraging. "What you want to look for to make a town grow is an influx of new immigrants, even if they are native born immigrants," he said, adding that a move just across the border could mean a big change in people's lives. "People may be making a move that is a small move geographically, but a large move in terms of upward mobility," he said. "I'm excited to see we are growing more diverse and cosmopolitan."
And while Hamden's gain would seem to be New Haven's loss, Mayor John DeStefano Jr. of New Haven does not see it that way.
"We continue to be a place where new Americans and new citizens come to," he said. "If you go back 100 years in New Haven, you would have been in an immigrant city."
He said he viewed the movement from city to suburb as historically inevitable, a healthy cycle that makes room for each new wave of immigrants and does not reflect any weakening of the city center. 
"In our case, two-thirds of the housing stock is rental and 50 years ago, two-thirds of the housing stock was rental," Mr. DeStefano said. He said the new Hispanic immigrants were living in neighborhoods occupied a century ago by Irish and Italian immigrants. "You literally had these neighborhoods that were overly foreign neighborhoods," he said. "I am sure there were people that were horrified 100 years ago. But I think America did pretty well over the last century." 
In the movement of blacks from New Haven to Hamden, Mr. Grate, the restaurant owner, was a pioneer. Until the late 1960's he lived in New Haven, but then moved so that his four children could attend Hamden schools.
"I bought a house in 1968 in Hamden and that was to give my kids better schooling," he said. "That was the key to the whole thing." At the time Mr. Grate and his family moved to Mueller Drive in South Hamden, he said, "There was one black family besides us." 
Today, the neighborhood is thoroughly mixed. According to the new census data, of 4,511 people in the neighborhood's census tract, 2,678 identified themselves as white; 1,439 as black; 216 as Hispanic, and 103 as Asian. Both the Hispanic and Asian populations had doubled since 1990 while the black population grew by 150 percent. Neighboring census tracts show similar growth. 
A walk through South Hamden on a Saturday morning explains the town's desirability. Tidy houses, old Capes and Victorians, line quiet streets dotted with trees. There are children riding bicycles, joggers, a few people tending their lawns, washing their cars or walking their dogs. A postman makes his rounds. On Dixwell Avenue, which is the main throughway leading from the New Haven line to Hamden's town center, the parking lots of local shopping centers are filled. 
On Collins Street in the Hamden Plains neighborhood, Teyaka Sherman, 13, and her brother, Michael, 10, were playing with friends on the porch of the house where their mother, Diane, rents a duplex apartment. Ms. Sherman, a nurse, moved to Hamden with her children four years ago from Spring Street in New Haven.
"I wanted to move out of New Haven," she said. "It was getting bad. My daughter fought in the neighborhood every day. He was doing terrible in school."
Things could not be different in Hamden, she said. "It's a great neighborhood," she said, laughing about how her children had left the door to the house unlocked one night. "This is the only place I know where you can sleep with your door open," she said.
Ms. Sherman said her children were getting more attention in school. "They are more concerned than in the New Haven schools," she said. "They'll call you up and set up meetings. They'll stay after school with the kids."
Although the predominantly white Hamden police force has had some friction with the mostly black neighborhoods just across the New Haven border, Ms. Sherman said she believed the Hamden police were strict with everyone and were not unfairly targeting minorities.
Around the corner, on Lexington Street, Kim Dickey, 24, was cleaning out her car, outside the house that her mother and stepfather, a mechanical engineer, bought last year. "Decent black people, a good bit of them are doing better for themselves," she said. "They want to do better for their children, they want to do better for their families." 
And down the street, Ernesto Reyes, 27, said he preferred Hamden, where he has lived for three years, to his old apartment in New Haven. "It's quiet," he said. "It's nice. It's clean. You can sleep at night. You don't have to worry about shootings. The cops are strict out here. They don't play around."
Bob Vitale, 38, was delivering mail on Lexington Avenue. Mr. Vitale, who is white, has worked the same postal route in Hamden for 14 years, and said he has watched first-hand as the faces in the neighborhood changed. "On Wilbert Street," he said. "the first four houses were all bought by black families." He added, "They are moving out here where it's safer for their families, which is what we all want for our families." 
But while Mr. Vitale seemed to genuinely appreciate the growing diversity of Hamden, he himself is an example of another trend: the declining number of white residents. After living nearly his entire life in Hamden, Mr. Vitale and his family moved two years ago to North Branford.
In place of some of the white families that have moved out is a growing community of Caribbean immigrants. Among them is Lyndon Pitter, a native of Jamaica, who is the executive director of the Highville Mustard Seed Charter School.
"I know for Caribbean people, the way for them to measure their success is you begin to look at where you live and so people choose to move to the suburbs as their income level goes up," he said. 
After emigrating from Jamaica, Mr. Pitter, 35, lived briefly in Hartford and in New Haven before moving to Hamden. In the 10 years he has lived in the town, he said, "I have seen lots of white families move out and lots of black families move in." But he said that many of the town's new residents still rely on New Haven as a center of employment and as the base of a larger Caribbean immigrant community.
"The funniest thing is if you look at the immigrant population, many of them go to churches in New Haven, but they live in Hamden," he said.
Matthew Nemerson, a former president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, said the best neighborhoods in New Haven, like East Rock, had experienced tremendous increases in real estate prices over the last decade, making them mostly unaffordable to newly middle-class families. Those neighborhoods also remain predominantly white and may seem unwelcoming to minorities or immigrants. 
"The newly affluent or newly middle class can't afford the very well functioning neighborhoods and may not feel that comfortable there," he said. "So you see a great outflux of middle-class minorities to the suburbs." 
But in searching for a new home outside the city, all suburbs are not equal. Many black residents of Hamden said they had chosen the town because it already had a substantial minority community that made it seem more welcoming.
Mayor Amento said that Hamden's growing diversity is reflected on many town boards and commissions and would be highlighted on a new Human Rights and Relations Commission that was recently approved by the town council and will be appointed in the coming months. "I hope we are doing everything we can to make people feel welcome and to feel that we are very inclusive in our government and social affairs in Hamden," he said. 
Mr. Grate said that shortly after he opened his barbecue restaurant, he was visited by Mayor Amento and by Dale Kroop, the town's director of community and economic development. "When we got to Hamden, right away the mayor stopped by and Dale stopped by and said there are programs that could help us," he said. Through the town's micro-loan program for small businesses, Mr. Grate was able to borrow $25,000 to buy new equipment. 
And just as Mr. Grate was a pioneer in moving to the suburbs, he may be a pioneer in a future demographic trend back to cities. Mr. Grate and his wife, Peggy, moved back to New Haven from Hamden after the youngest of their four children graduated high school. In doing so, they became exactly the type of older adults with grown children that some urban planners said they believe are key to restoring urban centers. 
In Hartford, for example, the Capital City Development Authority is coordinating $700 million in public and private investment in revitalizing the city that will include new downtown housing units and a waterfront entertainment and retail project called Adriaen's Landing. 
"Our first efforts in this respect really will target young professionals who may live downtown and not have kids and empty-nesters who may like the idea of living just a few steps away from one of the most famous art museums in New England and a few steps from a walk along the Connecticut River," said Matt Fleury, a spokesman for the authority. "There is a very good opportunity to restore a great deal of energy to downtown by attracting empty nesters and young professionals."
