HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
As Tenants Trim Space, Sublease Offers Grow

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A GROWING amount of the available office space in the state is not in the hands of landlords. It is on the sublease market, offering an exit for companies restructuring their space needs, good deals for tenants and a mixed blessing for the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office marketplace, national real estate services companies say. 
 There are 4.1 million square feet of space being offered for sublease, or 26 percent of the overall available space, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Figures from GVA Williams show there are 3.3 million feet of such space, or 20.7 percent of all available space. And Insignia/ESG says there are 2.31 million feet of sublease space, or 13 percent of all available space. 
 Because of the different ways brokerages calculate space availability, their statistics often seem to be at odds. In the case of subleasing, Cushman & Wakefield shows a doubling of such space from nine months ago and GVA Williams registers a similar increase but from last year. But ESG, which unlike the other two limits its surveys to buildings of 75,000 square feet or larger, shows an increase of 10,000 square feet from the end of 1999 to the end of 2000. 
Despite the differences, there is an unaccustomed amount of sublease space available these days for the first time in recent years as the uncertain national economy affects the office market. Rental rate increases have started to diminish, cautious tenants have trimmed their space needs and the pace of leasing has slowed in some submarkets. 
Most industry professionals agree there is a pause in the market. But with the overall office vacancy rate around 10 percent, no one is predicting it will collapse. 
"There will be more turbulence in the next four to six months before the market rebounds," said Mark Yeager, president of Gale & Wentworth, a real estate company with headquarters in Florham Park.
Eric Witmondt, chief executive of the New Jersey office of GVA Williams, based in Parsippany, has a more tempered outlook. "It will be status quo at least through the summer," he said, "as everyone takes a wait-and-see approach to what happens to the New Jersey and national economies." 
The crop of subleases is the result of corporate mergers, acquisitions and even expansions. Rearrangements to the corporate house, including those of Lucent Technologies, Prudential, Merrill Lynch and AT&T, are expected to continue, at least for the near term, industry professionals said. 
Lucent has 155,000 square feet on the sublease market in a 310,000-square-foot building on Woodhollow Road in Parsippany. The sublease is part of the company's restructuring, which will result in 10,000 people being laid off, 1,500 of them in New Jersey.
THAT "will create vacant space," said John J. Skalko, a Lucent spokesman. He declined to speculate on future sublease plans but said the company had 8.5 million square feet of space in 36 buildings in the state.
As part of AT&T's efforts to reshuffle its space needs to cut costs, the company has put some 1.8 million square feet of space on the market, said Gary Morgenstern, a spokesman. As those efforts continue, the company's 12 million square feet in 35 buildings "could further tighten," by 2 million feet in the next year, he said.
The sublet space is filtering onto a market where rents have stabilized after rising an average of 35 percent in the last two years. Subleases generally are priced at 25 to 50 percent below market.
Subleases are a concern because they bring "another pricing dynamic" to the market, said Daniel J. Loughlin, a managing principal at the Staubach Company, a commercial real estate service firm with offices in Murray Hill. But he said, and most other commercial brokers agreed, that barring a full-blown recession the market should be able to absorb the sublease space.
Among the reasons are that such space represents just 2 percent of New Jersey's 152-million-square-foot market, said Patrick Murphy, executive director of Insignia/ ESG of New Jersey, which is based in Saddle Brook. In addition, he said there has been limited new construction, keeping demand ahead of supply. That is expected to continue because financing from lenders to construct buildings on speculation remains tight, he added.
Mr. Witmondt added that the state had also not been as negatively affected as other regions by sharp cutbacks at dot-com companies, which could have meant more sublease space. Additionally, the state has a diverse tenant base, he said, adding that while some industries like telecommunications are shedding space, others, including pharmaceuticals, are expanding.
Mr. Murphy added that his firm knew of at least seven companies looking in the state for large blocks of office space, ranging from 150,000 to 600,000 square feet.
In today's market, brokers said the conventional thinking about sublets as small unmarketable space with short leases and bargain rents did not always hold true. Indeed, a sizable amount of the available sublet space is in blocks of 50,000 square feet or more, reports Cushman & Wakefield, which lists 13 such blocks totaling 2.5 million square feet. Mr. Witmondt said that with large blocks of quality space still in demand, such subleases actually "could help loosen up submarkets where there has been no new construction."
An example is the 150,000 square feet of space that Prudential, the insurer, has made available as a sublease at a 325,000-square-foot building it leases on Wood Avenue in Metro Park. That space, resulting from the insurer's consolidation of its operations, has 10 years left on its lease and is an option for tenants, "because there is nothing else available in that submarket," said Michael A. Cohen, managing director at GVA Williams, which is marketing the space for Prudential. Asking rents of $33 a square foot a year are competitive, he said.
The same is true for sublet space that has become or will become available on the Hudson River waterfront, where the vacancy rate is low. There, EDS, a computer services concern, recently shed 45,000 square feet in a building in Weehawken. 
In submarkets where new construction is brisk and sublease space is abundant, it could drag down the market. In Morris and Somerset Counties, which have the largest amounts of subleases, such space accounted for 44 percent and 47 percent respectively of the overall available space in those markets, Cushman & Wakefield said. 
IN Somerset County the biggest block of space is the 400,000-square-foot building on Davidson Road in Franklin Township that Merrill Lynch will be making available for lease or sale. The building is part of the company's consolidation to its new 1.25-million-square-foot campus on 450 acres off Interstate 95 in Hopewell, Selena Morris, a spokesperson, said. That is slightly more than the 1.1 million square feet the company will ultimately be leaving, she said, noting that it will have 3 million square feet of space in the state. 
Mr. Murphy of Insignia ESG, which is marketing the building, said, "It will draw tenants in this kind of market because there is a flight to quality." 
That is also what Mr. Loughlin of Staubach is hoping for in marketing the largest sublease in Morris County -- the 340,000-square-foot building in Parsippany that Aventis Pharmaceuticals is vacating. The company no longer needs the building, which was a temporary location, because it is moving to its larger permanent headquarters in Bridgewater. "The lease has eight and half years to go, making it more marketable" than short-term subleases and "competitive with new construction," Mr. Loughlin said. "We will be aggressive, but rents will not be below market."
Meanwhile, developers continue to build in the county. Gale & Wentworth is building a 175,000-square-foot speculative building as part of the Center of Morris County in Parsippany, which ultimately will have 850,000 square feet in four buildings.
"The market still has enough depth," Mr. Yeagar, the company's president, said, noting that in Morris County as elsewhere his company "plans to continue to develop because the basics are solid." But reflecting a more cautious market, it is adjusting its strategy on speculative building. Mr. Yeager said his company would now want to have an existing speculative building at least half leased before starting another one.

HEADLINE: Measuring Suburban Markets' Strength 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
THE real estate market in the New York metropolitan region has stepped down from its relentless quest for historic peaks to a sort of high-altitude base camp, several observers of housing trends say, with price increases leveling off -- somewhat -- and demand moderating.
 In an economy buffeted by stock-market plunges, confidence-eroding earnings reports and scattered layoff announcements, the data that the housing watchers cite and the mix of their contentions offer insights into national and regional housing markets that are coming off four straight years of record-setting price increases and home-ownership rates. "The froth is off the top, but the market is still strong," said Rae Rosen, senior regional economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 
 "We've seen a mood shift from irrational exuberance to contagious pessimism," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "In reality, the pessimism has gone beyond the underlying economic fundamentals." 
Steve Berman, a survey statistician at the Census Bureau -- pointing out particularly that sales of new homes in the nation slipped slightly to 903,000 last year from the all-time record of 907,000 set in 1999 -- said, "People are concentrating on the drop, and forgetting about the level."
But George W. McCarthy, a housing economist at the Ford Foundation, is less sanguine. Low mortgage interest rates "are the only thing that's contained the fall in demand in the last few months," Dr. McCarthy said. "And anyone who thought you could maintain double-digit price increases annually over a long period doesn't know history. That defines a bubble."
If it's a bubble, it hasn't burst.
According to the National Association of Realtors, the median price for a single-family home in the suburban arc around New York City rose from $203,200 in 1999 to $230,900 in 2000, a 13.6 percent increase.
More locally, the median price in Nassau and Suffolk Counties rose 12.4 percent last year, to $214,000 from $190,400 in 1999. In Essex County, N.J., the median climbed to $236,500, a 19.7 percent jump from $197,500 the year before. And in the New Haven-Meriden area of Connecticut, there was a 4.5 percent gain, from $145,700 to $151,600.
There was, however, slippage in the number of sales recorded in 2000. While New York state held virtually steady at 179,300 transactions -- 200 less than in 1999, the association's figures show -- New Jersey's sales dropped 2 percent, from 141,900 to 139,000. And Connecticut sales were down 3.9 percent, to 49,000 from 51,000.
"We've had a decline in consumer confidence in recent months," Dr. Hughes at Rutgers said, although a rebound was reported this week. "Yet, we haven't really seen a major market softening."
"The price frenzy prevalent through the first half of 2000, and over the last five years, has dampened," Dr. Hughes continued. "But have prices still held firm? What's no longer happening is people bidding up prices."
Ever-upward profits seemed the market mood only a year ago: 1999 had been the fourth straight year during which the median price in the region broke the previous record, and the $208,000 median that year represented an 11 percent rise over the 1998 median of $187,400 -- nearly triple the 3.9 percent national rate of increase.
By another measure of the market, the ZIP-code-by-ZIP-code repeat-sale survey conducted by the Case Shiller Weiss home-price research company, 1999 was the second straight year during which all of the 576 ZIP code areas (those for which there was sufficient data) in the 14-county ring around New York City had prices appreciate -- 396 of them by 8 percent or more.
In 2000, according to the new Case Shiller Weiss report, while once again every one of the 574 ZIP code areas with adequate data had price rises, the number that appreciated 8 percent or more actually jumped, to 453 -- and this despite slippage during the fourth quarter. (No Case Shiller data is yet available for the first quarter of this year.)
Some industry officials see value in a softening. "If prices moderate, more people can afford to buy," said Joseph Mottola, chief executive of the Long Island Board of Realtors. "And maybe the seller finally believes the market's topped out -- you know, how high is high? -- and is more willing to negotiate, to sell."
"There is a calming effect," Mr. Mottola said. "What realtors essentially want, what's best for the industry and the consumer, is a balanced market."
Dr. Hughes sees firm footing in the regional market, at least for now. "To this point, the metropolitan economy has not slowed as much as the nation's," he said, largely because it is less dependent on manufacturing than the rest of the country.
"Therefore, we have significantly less exposure," Dr. Hughes said. "Except for the shakeout in the dot-com and financial sectors, the region is well positioned to weather the national slowdown. We have continued income growth, job growth."
John L. Weiting, regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, said job growth in the tristate region slowed somewhat last year "from the robust expansion of 1999."
Approximately 232,000 private-sector jobs were added in the region last year, raising the total from 11.9 million in December of 1999 to 12.1 million at the end of 2000 -- a 1.6 percent increase. The 232,000 new jobs were 90,000 less than the 322,000 created in 1999. 
"Now I'm going to shift gears, give it to you a bit more positively," Mr. Weiting said, "because the job figures are still on the plus side and, so far this year, we haven't seen any downturn. This is not a bad story."
For Dr. Hughes, beyond new jobs, the primary load-bearing pillar of the housing economy is the baby boom generation. "We have more people today 44 years of age than any other age group," he said. "And that is a period of peak income and peak housing consumption, because they want to settle in to finish rearing their children. That is a force that will only be postponed under the most dire economic circumstances."
At the same time, "the oldest boomer hit the double nickel, 55 years of age," Dr. Hughes said, "and that double-nickel brigade is becoming empty nesters."
"They're rattling around their McMansions; they've spent a lifetime cutting lawns," he said. "Now they're looking for housing that's accessible to entertainment, culture, dining. Clearly, the empty nesters, as we move through the decade, will become a more powerful force."
Ms. Rosen at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said she had "one quibble" with Dr. Hughes's assessment: while the baby-boom trends provide "long-term underlying support for the housing market," in the short run sales are more sensitive to pricing, consumer confidence and interest rates.
"Pricing has held up well," Ms. Rosen said. "Confidence surveys suggest that consumers feel comfortable now, but are worried about the future. And affordability has improved with the decline in interest rates."
KEITH GUMBINGER, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage statistics company in Butler, N.J., said the current average of 7.17 percent interest on a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage is "within shouting distance of long-time lows."
"The low in the last 10 years -- in fact, the last 33 years -- was 6.68 percent in October 1998," Mr. Gumbinger said. The rate's recent "high-water mark" was 8.82 percent last May.
"But in early January and again late in January," he said, "the Federal Reserve slashed short-term rates twice -- a total cut of one full percentage point -- to get the economy back on its feet." And 12 days ago, it cut the rate by another half percent.
Mr. Berman at the Census Bureau pointed out that the nation reached a record home-ownership rate of 67 percent in 1999, and broke that record last year with a 67.7 percent rate.
But Dr. McCarthy at the Ford Foundation -- who casts a particular eye at how the market affects those who can least afford to buy or keep a house -- is worried.
"There's a different dynamic for people at the lower end of the market, where there's an absolute shortage of affordable housing," Dr. McCarthy said. "And those are the people who are most vulnerable to recession in terms of losing their jobs, losing their homes."
The problem, Dr. McCarthy said, is that house prices are a trailing indicator, not a leading indicator. "Therefore, when they fall, it means that labor markets have already been hit badly," he said. "And the corollary is that houses might seem a little more affordable, but there are fewer people out there with the wherewithal to buy."
At the same time, Dr. McCarthy said, statistics provided by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America indicate that delinquencies and foreclosures rose 0.8 percent since the third quarter of last year, "the first rise in nine quarters."
Part of the underlying problem is that, increasingly over the last decade, the American mortgage market has been backed by foreign investors who purchase mortgage loans that have been bundled into securities by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-chartered housing lenders.
"If we see increasing default rates, the value of the mortgage-backed securities will fall, and that will curtail the flow of investment money available to finance new mortgages," including from foreign sources, Dr. McCarthy said.
At the same time, he said, "Foreign investment in mortgages could be further weakened by the Federal Reserve's inclination to reduce interest rates, thereby weakening the dollar and making the mortgage-backed securities less attractive."
Without the liquidity that the mortgage market has enjoyed because of those foreign investors, "we'll have a credit crunch," Dr. McCarthy said, "which would likely spark a significant softening of the housing market."
"I hate to be such a downer," he said. "I hope I'm wrong; it would be O.K. with me to be wrong."
Real estate brokers, with their seemingly eternal, and certainly external, optimism are willing for him to be wrong.
"No one's hurting," Mr. Mottola of the Long Island realtors' board said. "It's not as frenzied, but sales and prices remain firm."
They certainly were firm last year.
In Nassau County, the median price for a single-family house rose 9.8 percent in 2000, from $230,000 to $252,500. "Now the median for Nassau in January and February this year was $259,350," Mr. Mottola said. "Up $7,000 since December. So no slackening."
Waxing site-specific, Mr. Mottola said that in Baldwin the median jumped 24 percent last year, from $188,600 to $233,250. And in Levittown, it rose 17.8 percent, from $180,000 to $212,000. Nassau's sales volume, however, dropped 5.2 percent, from 7,389 transactions in 1999 to 7,002 last year.
Tracking real estate trends by the numbers defies absolute precision. Although single-family house sales are reported by local realty boards, not all real estate agents are members of the boards and not all sales are made through agents, so not all sales in a given area are recorded. At the same time, while one board may use a median price -- meaning half the sales are above that figure and half below -- others calculate an average. Still, the numbers serve as barometers of market patterns.
And the upward pattern in Nassau last year was confirmed by the Case Shiller Weiss ZIP-code study. The survey employs a table showing the average price for all single-family homes sold in most ZIP code areas, year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 2000, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each ZIP code area during the year just ended, compared it with the price the house brought the last time it sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the previous purchase price to what it probably would have been had it sold in 1999. The 2000 sales prices for homes within each ZIP code area were then compared with the estimated 1999 prices to compute the average change.
In Nassau, the survey showed that 25 ZIP codes appreciated by 4 to 8 percent, 34 by 8 to 12 percent and 5 by 12 percent or more.
In Suffolk County, Mr. Mottola said, the median in 2000 was $190,000, 18.8 percent higher than $160,000 in 1999. More locally, the median in Cold Spring Harbor high-jumped 33 percent, from $675,000 to $897,000. And in Brentwood, there was a 15 percent increase, from $130,000 to $149,000.
Of the 79 Suffolk ZIP code areas for which there was sufficient data, the Case Shiller survey indicated that 2 had prices appreciate by 4 to 8 percent, 13 by 8 to 12 percent and 64 by 12 percent or more. 
Suffolk's sales volume, however, dipped by 10.3 percent, from 11,265 to 10,096.
MEASURING the market in Connecticut is complicated by the fact that the state does not indicate property type on deed transfers. Yet, by far, most transfers are residential, said Vincent Valvo, publisher of The Connecticut Law Tribune, which tracks economic trends.
Citing data from Warren Information Services, a business statistics company, Mr. Valvo said the median price in Fairfield County through November 2000 (the latest data available) was $245,000, up 4.8 percent from $233,750 a year earlier.
According to the Case Shiller survey, of Fairfield's 45 ZIP codes, 22 appreciated by 4 to 8 percent and 23 by 8 to 12 percent.
"Here's the downside," Mr. Valvo said: volume in Fairfield dropped 11.2 percent, from 18,419 to 16,348. "It's not grim," he said, "I'd call it cautious."
Reviewing local records, Randi Hutton, a broker at Tilghman & Frost Coldwell Banker in Westport, said the average price in Darien rose 24 percent last year, from $718,052 to $890,504. 
In Redding, Ms. Hutton said, the average price climbed 23.4 percent, from $470,815 to $581,113. "Two years ago, you could find something under $300,000," she said. "Now, there's just a handful left."
And in Stamford last year, the $500,635 average was 11.7 percent higher than the $447,922 in 1999. In January and February 2001, the average was $506,083. However, Stamford's 972 sales in 1999 slipped to 897 last year.
The higher-price, lower-volume pattern was evident in Westchester. According to the county's multiple listing service, the 2000 median for single-family homes was $407,000, an 18 percent rise from $345,000.
Of Westchester's 65 ZIP code areas, 1 appreciated by less than 4 percent; 3 by 4 to 8 percent, 14 by 8 to 12 percent and, by far, most of the county -- 47 areas -- by 12 percent or more. But sales volume slipped 8 percent, from 10,253 to 9,433.
Robin Friedman, manager of the Houlihan/Lawrence brokerage firm in Irvington, said the average price in Mount Vernon increased 16.1 percent last year, from $249,323 to $289,563. In Hastings-on-Hudson, she said, the 1999 average of $422,324 rose 9.8 percent to $464,017 in 2000. And Bedford experienced a 28.4 percent jump, from $881,972 to $1,133,143.
There was insufficient data in Rockland County for the Case Shiller survey to make accurate calculations. But in 2000, Rockland's median price was $265,000, and in 1999 it was $238,000. "That's a substantial jump," said Ann Garti, executive officer of the Greater Hudson Valley Multiple Listing Service -- 11.3 percent. Rockland recorded 1,783 sales in 2000, down 9 percent from 1,960 the year before. 
Stony Point, "a community of smaller, older homes," Ms. Garti said, had an average price of $255,637, "a slight slippage" from $256,618 in 1999. And in Sloatsburg, which Ms. Garti described as a blue-collar community, the average was $181,715, up 4.5 percent from $173,884 in 1999.
Virtually by genetics, Peter Van Winkle takes a long view of real estate trends in northern New Jersey.
Mr. Van Winkle is president of A. W. Van Winkle Real Estate in Rutherford, a company founded by his great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-grandfather, Waling Jacob Van Winkle, in 1692. 
He does not get the jitters.
The prolonged presidential election played a role in undermining confidence, Mr. Van Winkle believes. "Uncertainty brings a decline; people want to stay put," he said. "And if you had called me in November, December, I would have said people are running scared."
"But whatever people thought about the election, they were glad a decision was made," Mr. Van Winkle continued. "And since the first of the year, all inventory in South Bergen is gone."
According to the National Association of Realtors, the median price for a house with two or fewer bedrooms in the 10-county northeast region of New Jersey was $145,000 at the end of 2000. For a three-bedroom house, it was $213,000. For four bedrooms or more, it was $343,000. And all 10 counties experienced price increases last year. But sales volume in all but one county, Somerset, slipped.
By way of example, the median in Passaic County was $170,000 in 1999, and $198,600 in 2000, a 16.8 percent increase. But there was a 13.1 percent drop in volume.
The median in Hudson County climbed 13.7 percent, from $134,600 to $153,000, while sales slipped by 19 percent. And in Hunterdon, the $283,300 median at the end of 1999 had climbed to $304,000, or 7.3 percent, in 2000, with sales dropping 3.4 percent.
Of the 321 ZIP codes in the 10-county area of New Jersey surveyed by Case Shiller, 2 had prices increase by up to 4 percent, 66 by 4 to 8 percent, 215 by 8 to 12 percent and 38 by 12 percent or more. 
Asked to check recent records, Mr. Van Winkle said the average price in his town, Rutherford, was $241,148 in 2000. "So far this year, it's $245,670," he said. "So we're up $4,000 since the end of the year."
Then, without adjusting for inflation, he took a long look back.
"There's a three-bedroom colonial on Lincoln Avenue in Rutherford, built about 1910," he said. "Listen to this progression: In 1924, it sold for $8,500; in 1928, $9,800; 1948, $13,500. And just recently, December 18, 2000, it sold again -- for $255,000."

HEADLINE: THE CITIES; 
Another Holding Pattern For Newark Airport Plan

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
Like so many episodes of "The Perils of Pauline," the plan to build a hotel and conference center in an old rail yard here and has been up and down, near death one moment and miraculously rescued the next.
 From the beginning, the project -- connecting the hotel and center with a train station that would be the juncture of the new Newark Airport monorail extension, the Amtrak line and New Jersey Transit -- seemed a marvel. 
 Planners envisioned businesses within a mile of one of the nation's fastest-growing and busiest airports astride a station where air travelers could connect with other travelers on commuter lines as well as those up and down the Northeast Corridor.
But as the developer, Hartz Mountain Industries, prepares to submit its plan to the Newark Planning Board on April 16, new problems are threatening the project. Moreover, if the problems are not resolved, say officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport, the authority may be forced to veto the project all together. 
While many people involved in the project, including Mayor Sharpe James, would cast the Port Authority as the leering, mustache-twisting villain of this piece because of the hurdles it has placed in the way of the hotel and conference center, development in older urban areas that are densely populated and near airports has always been a dicey affair -- fraught with delays, clashing interests and the vagaries of the business cycle.
That said, Mayor James has had nothing but praise for Hartz Mountain for the perseverance it have shown and hopes that there is more where that came from.
A decade ago, the project was first bedeviled by a costly and time-consuming environmental cleanup to remove hydrocarbons and heavy metals from the Waverly Yards, which had been a staging area for locomotives that hauled freight and passengers. About $6 million in federal and private funds were put together in one of the state's first brownfields cleanup projects.
But then the Port Authority objected to the complex on the grounds that the height and location of the 600-room hotel ran afoul of the Federal Aviation Administration's rules governing the proximity of buildings to the center line of airport glide paths.
In response, said Emmanuel Stern, the president and chief executive of Hartz Mountain, he scaled down the height and moved the building to comply with aviation agency's requirement that it be 350 feet from the center line of the glide path.
Next, questions arose about arcane but well-settled federal restrictions on the use of airport-related facilities like the monorail, which is financed with airport-generated revenue: Could Mr. Stern construct an enclosed walkway connecting the hotel and the train station?
Projects financed by the federally authorized Passenger Facility Charge like the monorail and the station must be for the exclusive use of airport patrons, said aviation agency officials, and providing access to the hotel might turn the station into a regular stop on the Amtrak or commuter line for those going somewhere other than the airport.
Together, the cost of the one-mile extension of the monorail and the station complex -- where it will join with the Amtrak and New Jersey Transit line, is $415 million, said a spokesman for the Port Authority, and $250 million of that cost is being paid for out of the Passenger Facility Charge. The extension and the station are due to open in September.
Mr. Stern's solution to this problem, which was ultimately approved by the aviation agency, was to promise to set up a concierge desk and service in the connecting walkway between the station and the hotel. Attendants in suits and ties would assist travelers -- and restrict access between the hotel and station to all but arriving or departing air travelers.
The arrangement meant losing the easy comingling of train and airline travelers that he had envisioned, said Mr. Stern, but he remained confident of the project as a business venture.
"The airport isn't going away, and it is the fastest-growing airport in the region," said Mr. Stern. "So there is not a chance that we would pull the plug on this project."
That prediction is likely to be tested.
Chris Ward, director of planning and external affairs for the Port Authority, said that the developer's earlier accommodation -- moving the proposed hotel site to fit the aviation agency's requirements that it be 350 feet from the center line of the glide path -- may prove inadequate. 
"It fell short of a stricter, 500-feet requirement that airlines had voluntarily adopted," Mr. Ward said.
The voluntary 500-foot guideline is the work of the International Civil Aviation Organization, a 187-nation group founded in 1944 to promote uniform safety standards for airports serving international carriers.
He added that this "self-imposed safety" guideline was likely to lead airlines to limit the weight and number of passengers on flights destined to land or take off on that particular runway, thereby limiting its value to the airport.
But Denis Chagnon, a spokesman in the Montreal office of the International Civil Aviation Organization, said that its guidelines were aimed at airport operators rather than airlines, adding that there were no sanctions imposed on those who do not adhere. 
Mr. Chagnon , aware of the differences in the aviation agency and the international organization, said that while there had been discussions about adopting the stricter standards, he knew of no changes or alterations in airline practices at locations that observed the F.A.A. standards.
In the meantime, Mr. Ward conceded that for Hartz to move the building any farther to meet the stricter standard would mean not only more delays but also the loss of the ability to develop an adjacent and additional site on the rail yard property. Mr. Stern had envisioned additional offices and parking on this site, and Mr. Ward said that the Port Authority was willing to give reasonable compensation for the loss of the ability to build anything else there.
"The Port Authority has been supportive of the Hartz project, but it must also ensure the economic viability of the airport and most importantly public safety," said Mr. Ward. "We are currently in active negotiation with Hartz to reach an acceptable financial solution and construct the hotel outside of the restrictive glide path and at the same time provide access to the station."
For his part Mr. Stern said that the negotiations on this latest problem had "stalled" in recent months, but that he had not completely closed the door. He said he was determined to put his project before the planning board in hopes of moving the hotel proposal forward another step even while it was seemingly left circling or sitting on the tarmac like some delayed flight.
Long before the latest obstacle, Mayor James had lost patience with what he saw as the Port Authority's dilatory tactics. Throughout the project's troubled history, the Port Authority had not so secretly coveted the land for itself, the mayor said, and sought to protect the airport-based Marriott Hotel from any competition.
Mr. Ward denied the accusations, but the mayor was adamant.
"The Port Authority threw every obstacle at them to make them think it wasn't a doable project all because they wanted to get the land for themselves," he said in an interview. "They tried to tell us that we didn't want this project. But we stuck to our plan, and now we stand to get not only an airport hotel but one that serves the city also."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Lekha Menon, Jason Patrick

 BODY:
Lekha Menon and Jason Richard Patrick were married in a civil ceremony on Wednesday by Blanca Ramos, a deputy city clerk at the New York City Municipal Building. On March 11, the couple had a Hindu ceremony at the Guruvayur Temple in Guruvayur, India, which was led by Sri Vaidyanathan Namboothiripad, a priest. 
 The bride, 33, is keeping her name. She is the director of research and donor relations in the fund-raising department at New York University. She graduated from Barnard College. She is a daughter of Jayshree and Unni Menon of Durham, N.C. Her father retired as an engineer in the Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia, office of Saudi Aramco, the oil company. 
 The bridegroom, 29, is a scientist at Environmental Defense, formerly called the Environmental Defense Fund, a nonprofit organization specializing in scientific, economic and legal analysis of environmental issues in New York. He graduated from the University of California at Berkeley and received a master's degree in environmental management from Yale. His parents work at Middlesex Community College in Middleton, Conn., where the bridegroom's mother is a professor of art and the chairwoman of the art department and his father is a political science professor and chairman of the political science department.

SUBJECT: WEDDINGS & ENGAGEMENTS (92%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (90%); ENGINEERING (78%); HINDUS & HINDUISM (77%); POLITICAL SCIENCE (76%); COMMUNITY COLLEGES (75%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (75%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (75%); FUNDRAISING (75%); NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS (75%); ENVIRONMENT & NATURAL RESOURCES (73%) WEDDINGS AND ENGAGEMENTS 

COMPANY: SAUDI ARAMCO (57%)

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
Money Can Motivate. So Can Love of the Job.

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
VINCENT VAN GOGH made virtually nothing from his paintings. James Joyce, the author, lived in poverty. And America's school bus drivers earn, on average, just $10.76 an hour.
 Despite their relative penury, these people can teach a lesson to American companies about executive compensation. After all, one of the main arguments offered in defense of sky-high pay for chief executives is that they need incentives to do a good job. 
 But is money such a great motivator? In some ways, yes. Systems that radically divorce productivity from reward are destined to fail, as they have in the past. Yet it should come as no surprise that, once their basic needs are met, people are motivated by a lot more than money. And the better the job, the less important money seems to be.
Consider Joe DiMaggio. He cared deeply about money and bitterly resented the feudal system that deprived him of bargaining power with the New York Yankees. Despite feeling underpaid, he still managed to be a great baseball player. Similarly, van Gogh and Joyce excelled without multimillion-dollar stock options. And school bus drivers apparently need no great financial incentive to keep our children safe. 
The president of the United States, meanwhile, has an annual salary of $400,000, a pittance for a high-powered executive. (It was just $200,000 until January, when it was increased for the first time since 1969.) Yet there is never a shortage of candidates for that job. Among the 50 states, not a single governorship has gone begging for want of bonuses and stock options.
Is running a public company so much more onerous? Is that why John F. Welch Jr. of General Electric made $144.5 million last year? And did it get so much harder for the admittedly able Mr. Welch that he deserved an increase of more than 100 percent from the previous year?
None of this is to say that gigantic paydays are bad; I myself would love to enjoy a few, and Bernie Williams, DiMaggio's latest successor as the Yankees' center fielder, is entitled to whatever astronomical sum he can get, since the free agent system amounts to an open auction for his services.
The problem is that the pay of America's chief executives is not much subject to the discipline of the marketplace; the whole process is far too chummy, with many executives in effect paying themselves and claiming that they will do a good job only for a compensation package that would make Croesus blush. 
Despite chief executives' insatiable needs for incentives, there is a body of evidence suggesting that pay for performance is not a very effective workplace motivator, at least when compared with others like giving employees a sense of mission, worth and proprietorship. Pay for performance probably is most effective in settings where the work isn't much fun and the output can be counted easily. Piecework pay for making widgets will generally result in more widgets per hour worked. But it begs credulity to suggest that an extra $10 million for the chief executive will finally make him put his nose to the grindstone.
The late W. Edwards Deming, a guru of quality control, was a particularly vigorous opponent of trying to pay for performance, as Andrea Gabor points out in "The Capitalist Philosophers" (Times Books). Deming believed that if you hired the right people for the right jobs and put them into the right environment, everyone would perform pretty well.
Pay for performance is particularly dubious in bad times: During a recession, Ms. Gabor writes, pay for performance becomes a zero-sum game that produces more losers than winners. A bigger slice for the chief executive can mean smaller slices for everyone else.
WITH the economy slowing and stocks in a slump, shareholders may finally become less tolerant of excessive executive compensation and severance packages. In effect, the chiefs will have to do more work for less money.
I predict, and you heard it here first, that there will be no wholesale resignations, despite the great hardships of running businesses on a few million dollars less. America's chief executives will just have to learn what any school bus driver can already tell you: money isn't everything.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Profits Are Down. So, Boss, Can I Have That Raise?

BYLINE:  By JOBERT E. ABUEVA

 BODY:
NOT long ago, many good employees who wanted more money needed only to stroll into the boss's office and ask. Even the hint that a valued worker might jump ship in a tight labor market was often enough to prompt a raise, or perhaps other perks, like stock options or a better job title.
 But that is not nearly as common these days. With the economy slowing, some employers are looking for ways to cut expenses and improve profits by freezing wages, reducing their work forces or streamlining operations. And it is not just struggling dot-coms that are feeling the pinch; corporations like Procter & Gamble, Lucent Technologies and Boeing are also cutting jobs. 
 Companies that continue to offer regular raises are doing so modestly. The average merit increase for salaried workers, excluding top executives, is expected to remain unchanged from last year, at about 4 percent, according to the 2001 Report on Salary Surveys, published by the Institute of Management and Administration in New York. 
"The projections remain modest because salaries have already been raised in response to the tight job market, and inflation has been low," said Laime Vaitkus, editor of a monthly newsletter published by the management institute. "In many cases, any merit increases a manager submits over the allotted percentage have to be justified and approved by executive management."
Does that mean a sizable raise is out of the question? Not necessarily, say experts in career counseling and compensation. "If you are able to build a compelling case, now is as good a time as any to ask for a raise," said Lewis Kravitz, an executive coach and organizational consultant in Atlanta. 
Even when an employer is facing a financial crunch, Mr. Kravitz said, negotiating a raise is still possible, particularly for high-performing employees. As work forces shrink, the experienced, qualified worker may be seen as a valuable asset in getting a company through tough times. "But one needs to take initiative and do lots of homework" before approaching a supervisor for more money, Mr. Kravitz added.
FOR starters, it helps to know how much you are worth in the open market. Comparative salary data is available at Web sites like jobstar.org and salary.com, as well as through the Department of Labor (www.bls.gov) and industry-specific sites like law.com. 
But, Mr. Kravitz warned, "one can no longer assume that just because an employee with a like job at a major competitor is making more than you, that you should try and obtain the same."
Employee compensation involves far more than base salary. Besides benefits like pensions, retirement plans and health insurance, it may include bonuses, commissions and other long-term incentives. In fact, 78 percent of 856 employers surveyed last year by Hewitt Associates, a benefits consulting firm in Lincolnshire, Ill., had at least one type of variable pay. That compares with just 47 percent in 1990.
"You have to look at the entire pay pie, which includes both current and deferred compensation," said MaryLee Amendolia, a principal at Rhodes Associates, an executive search firm in Manhattan. 
Career counselors say employees should focus on merit -- seeking raises contingent on meeting specific goals.
"Easier said than done," said Bobbe White, a business development officer and 20-year employee at State Street Bank in Quincy, Ill. Ms. White, 45, says she has brought in several new accounts, exceeding department goals, and deserves a merit raise, but she has yet to receive one despite her well-placed hints. (She acknowledges she had never considered asking for a raise; she just thought you either got one or you didn't come Feb. 1 each year.)
Many experts recommend that employees first prepare a presentation and then rehearse it with a friend or co-worker.
"Before approaching your boss, list all your accomplishments that in turn also become your boss's," Mr. Kravitz said, adding that his clients used such lists to initiate discussion. He said employees should also imagine themselves in the supervisor's shoes, in order to anticipate objections.
A marketing manager for a Fortune 500 health care company followed many of those suggestions when he recently asked for a raise. But instead of approaching his supervisor directly, he said, he made an appointment with a human resources manager to discuss his intention. 
"I was performing my job well yet felt I wasn't moving ahead when compared to my peers," said the executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "I sought an objective sounding board to explain why I felt I deserved more money. The H.R. manager heard my arguments, and thought I had a valid case and therefore encouraged me to voice my views upstairs."
Twenty-four hours after a conversation with his supervisor, the health care executive received a promotion and a double-digit percentage increase in salary. 
For their part, most supervisors are willing to listen, since it costs money to replace a dissatisfied employee who leaves. 
The Society for Human Resource Management, a trade group based in Alexandria, Va., estimated that an employer needs 50 days, on average, to fill a vacant position. 
The average cost of the hiring process is $4,588, according to the Saratoga Institute, a human resources research and consulting firm in Santa Clara, Calif., although that does not include fees, charged by many search firms, of up to one-third of the executive's financial package for the first year.
Many employees who ask to meet with their supervisors to discuss salary are dissatisfied with some aspect of their jobs and may be giving a warning that they may start looking elsewhere, said Robin Mingle, vice president for human resources at the North American power tool division of Black & Decker. Depending on the employee, management may want to heed the warning and give an employee a raise or other incentive, Ms. Mingle added.
"If we, as H.R. professionals do our job well," she added, "we can help steer discussions from becoming confrontational between employees and their manager."
During the talks, Ms. Amendolia advised, it helps to speak in general terms and not to put a price on your head. She suggested discussing increases in percentages. 
"A boss will be more inclined to grant a 2 percent increase on additional revenue you generate rather than $25,000," she said, even if that $25,000 is a small fraction of a department's operating budget.
If you do not get what you want, Ms. Amendolia added, be open about it and ask when the company might reconsider and what goals you should strive for. Giving an employer an ultimatum is never a good idea, she said.
Of course, if money is truly tight, there may be other perks available, like more vacation, a better office, a job title or a more flexible schedule.
THAT was the tack that Ellen Fuller of Doylestown, Pa., took when she recently negotiated with her employer, the American Dairy Association/Dairy Council Middle Atlantic in Philadelphia. Instead of a raise, Ms. Fuller asked for changes that included working three days a week from home and two days in the office, at the same pay, so she could spend more time with her 6-year-old son and 11-year-old daughter. 
Ms. Fuller, the director for nutrition education and marketing at the association, said her negotiations went smoothly because she was able to offer a compromise. 
"I enjoy the flexibility of telecommuting," she said, "not to mention the savings in time and transportation costs."

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Another Harlem On Their Minds

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
THE Starbucks at Lenox Avenue and 125th Street was filled the other day with symbols of a changing Harlem: white tourists, speaking French and German; black professionals talking about their businesses; and young white newcomers, sipping latte and talking about the brownstones they owned a few blocks away.
 That no-fuss scene would have been unthinkable 10 years ago, when Harlem had become a place synonymous with urban blight. But the home of the Harlem Renaissance is undergoing another rebirth. 
 The 2000 Census found that the neighborhood grew by 3,000 people since 1990, and is home to more than 106,000 New Yorkers. Though the total of non-Hispanic whites in Harlem remains a blip, at just over 2 percent, that figure is up from 1.5 percent in 1990. Many say the real numbers are higher, because the current boom is still so new. 
One of those in the Starbucks was Reggie James, head of NuJapple, a black marketing firm in Harlem. In 1987, his company produced what he said was the first tourist map of Harlem. His hope was to revamp the neighborhood's image. Recently, the company reissued the map, trying to capture both the changes and the people and places that made the neighborhood famous. 
"One of my missions is to see that small businesses in Harlem thrive," Mr. James said. A map, he said, is a handy way to ensure that no one is overlooked. "I'm talking about black businesses that get pushed out when the rents start going up when an area becomes fashionable."
The map includes faith institutions, art galleries and historical landmarks. It has the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture on Malcolm X Boulevard as well as the Diamond Gym at 145th Street, a recent arrival. Mostly a colorful pictorial representation, the map also has text about the "resurgent Harlem" in Italian, French, Spanish, German and Japanese as well as English.
Mr. James, who plans to update the map in July and again next summer, grew up in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, but has a special fondness for Harlem, which he calls the "black mecca" of the world.
But people from the neighborhood, like Carol Baugh, who grew up there and is the funeral director at Henry W. Payne Funeral Directors, say that "mecca" is far less black these days, despite the census numbers. She and other blacks in business in the neighborhood are asking questions such as, Who owns Harlem and how should it be defined? Is it a black mecca where blacks have a special claim? Or is it a destined to become a trendy, diverse uptown community that was once mostly black?
Ms. Baugh, chatting with Mr. James in Starbucks, said she applauded the new diversity, but she feared that some black businesses may be forced out and some black people may not be able to afford the new prices.
In the 1930's her grandfather started the funeral business she now runs. Situated on Lenox Avenue, between West 123rd and 124th Streets, it is on Mr. Jackson's map. 
"Harlem is going through a necessary resurgence," Ms. Baugh said, "but there is a move to push out those who have a claim, those who have been here for years."
Walter J. Edwards, a developer who also heads the 20-year-old Harlem Business Alliance, which has 50 members, sees the changes as a struggle between two groups. "One group says Harlem is being gentrified and taken over," he said, "and the other group says everyone is welcome. I agree with both groups, but no one is coming up with solutions. We must have some equity in this new renaissance. We must buy property or own franchises or become joint venture partners with some of the newcomers.
"Harlem is recognized worldwide as a black capital," he added. "If you push out the black people who held it together, it just becomes another piece of real estate."
Mr. James calls the new edition of his map, "Harlem USA and Upper Manhattan." The old version was simply called "Harlem USA." He explained that in 1987, no one cared that the map declared Harlem to be any street above 96th Street on the East and West Sides. Now, some people in communities like Morningside Heights do not want their area classified as part of Harlem, he said. People in other areas, like El Barrio on the East Side and Washington Heights on the West Side, want to be recognized as distinct communities, too.
The fight over who can lay claim to a place is an old one. Follow the economy and the vagaries of the housing market to predict the winners. There is a long tradition of neighborhoods being "discovered" and renamed, and real estate boundaries reconfigured. That phenomenon predates Harlem and even New York City itself.
Remember Christopher Columbus?

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Richard A. Mayo; 
The Pelican Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
FINALLY, it seems, value matters.
 After years when indiscriminate investors were willing to ignore matters like competitive strategy and profit -- driving stock prices to unsustainable levels -- a focus on business fundamentals is coming back into style. And that is a good thing as far as Richard A. Mayo is concerned. 
 "We always had trouble seeing how you value companies that earn no money and might not earn any for three years," said Mr. Mayo, who runs the $120 million Pelican Fund. "What we can see in the marketplace now is that valuation matters and will continue to matter for a long time." 
His unwavering attention to value has served him well in a declining market. The fund returned 5.6 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Thursday, versus 2.1 percent for its large-value peers and 2.9 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500 index, according to Morningstar Inc. For the last 12 months, it returned 15 percent, versus a 0.2 percent loss for its peer group and a loss of 23 percent for the S.& P.
His investment style is opportunistic, Mr. Mayo said, like its namesake's fishing style. "Pelicans fly around until they see fish, and then swoop down and gobble them up," Mr. Mayo explained from his office, which overlooks Boston Harbor. Pelican is the only retail fund offered by Grantham, Mayo, Van Otterloo & Company, which also manages about $20 billion in institutional accounts.
Mr. Mayo, 58, works with six analysts to select the 100 or so stocks in the fund from roughly 3,000 United States companies with market capitalizations of more than $350 million; the fund's weighted average market cap is $35.6 billion.
Valuation is his mantra. "We try to find stocks that we believe sell for a significant discount to what we believe is their intrinsic worth," he said. "To do that, we're willing to be early and to look places where other people won't." He defines intrinsic value as the net present value of the cash that can be generated from a company's operations or sale of its assets.
When he finds nothing of value, Mr. Mayo stays on the sidelines. Earlier this year, he built the fund's cash position to 18 percent, compared with its usual 5 to 10 percent.
"As technology spending dried up, the economy fell faster and created a bigger squeeze on profit margins than most people had thought," he said. More recently, as valuations have continued to fall, he has been preparing to move back into the market, aiming to acquire stocks at what he thinks are 30 to 50 percent discounts to their intrinsic values.
While Mr. Mayo screens for stocks with low price-to-earnings multiples and similar value criteria, the bulk of the fund's purchases come from ideas generated during meetings with management, industry conferences and reports from Wall Street analysts. 
Currently, he sees value among energy stocks, which comprise the fund's biggest sector at 15 percent of assets and which he began buying in mid-1999. Mr. Mayo said he began attending energy conferences several years back, at a time when the sector had already underperformed the market for about seven years. "Most energy executives then were starting to worry that production was not meeting expectations," he said. "Also, most companies had bad balance sheets, so they weren't able to spend the money they needed to upgrade operations."
The prices of the energy stocks, he added, did not reflect his belief that oil and natural-gas prices would increase significantly because of limited supplies.
Another of Mr. Mayo's investment themes involves companies that other investors have penalized out of fear that the Internet would undermine their businesses.
And in general, he looks for companies with stable earnings that demonstrate improved earnings growth or profitability.
MR. MAYO generally trims positions in stocks as they approach what he considers as full valuation. He also sells shares when companies prove unable to improve their return on investment.
The fund's position in bonds, which peaked at 20 percent in 1990, has shriveled to 2 percent as yields have fallen to an average of 5 percent. Over all, the fund yields 2.7 percent, about double the yield of the S.& P. 500. 
Mr. Mayo recently bought more shares of Occidental Petroleum, the oil and gas company. He called Occidental a "classic contrary-opinion play," adding that he disagreed with the conventional wisdom that Occidental overpaid for a series of recent oil property acquisitions in Texas and California. To pay for the properties, Mr. Mayo said, Occidental sold unprofitable Canadian operations and its midcontinental pipeline. Management has significantly increased cash flow, improving its balance sheet, he said; he expects five-year earnings growth to average 12 percent a year. 
He started the position in June 1997 at $24.125 a share; it now trades at $24.75. He says the stock has an intrinsic value of $32.34.
Another favorite is the Kroger Company, which operates supermarkets and jewelry, convenience and other stores. 
Kroger generates significant free cash flow, which management uses for stock buybacks, he said. He predicts earnings to grow 12 percent a year, on average, over five years.
Mr. Mayo bought shares in March 2000 at an average of $14.90 and buys more when the stock price dips. The stock now trades at $25.79; he says its intrinsic value is $30.
He has been buying shares of First Union, the banking giant, since the start of this year, paying an average of $28. Starting last year, he said, new management sold off unprofitable operations and aligned employee compensation with improved profitability. He expects the company's diversified business model, ranging from commercial and retail banking and trust services to home equity lending, insurance and securities brokerage, to create five-year earnings growth averaging 10 percent a year.
On Friday, the shares closed at $33; he put their intrinsic value at $41.

HEADLINE: BACKSPIN; 
The Uncrimped Lifestyles of the Rich and Feckless

BYLINE:  By RICK MARIN 

 BODY:
A YOUNGISH couple comes into R 20th Century, a furniture and design store in TriBeCa that sells midcentury modern stuff. They see a $5,500 hanging lamp by Verner Panton, admire it and, a few days later, come back with their 6-year-old daughter to see if she likes it. 
 The lamp is for her room. 
 Zesty Meyers, a co-owner of the store, couldn't believe it. The couple bought that lamp and another one for their 2-year-old. "Last month was our best month ever, by far," he said. "Not by like 10 percent. Like 30 to 40 percent better." 
At the Park, the new club-restaurant-lounge in West Chelsea, the young and feckless throw back $11 cocktails. And Jeffrey New York, the boutique in the meatpacking district, can't keep a $720 Balenciaga handbag in stock. "I had several and they were gone by the weekend," Jeffrey Kalinsky, the owner, said. "We're not in a recession." 
Not judging by the behavior of the spending class -- New Yorkers who are or like to act rich and who refuse to let a few leading economic indicators cramp their style. 
"Fortunately or unfortunately," Mr. Kalinsky said, "there are people who are unscathed. Or people who find shopping to be one of the things that they don't have to give up."
One of the revelers at the Park on Wednesday night was Emy Shayo, an economist at Bear, Stearns. Ms. Shayo, 27, was out with a group of friends for drinks and dinner.
"I just bought season tickets for the Met, a new computer and two gym memberships," Ms. Shayo said. Her firm had laid off 400 people, she said, but the survivors feel secure. "We're not going to lose our jobs," she said. "I have faith in the economy. I have faith in Alan Greenspan."
One of her friends, Rafael Corres, 31, a corporate lawyer from Mexico, said that he was getting fewer new clients but that it hadn't affected his spending habits. "It's not reflected in people's pockets," he said. "We still earn the same money we earned a year ago." 
He had just made plans to fly to Argentina to visit his brother. "It will be an expensive trip," he said. 
The waitress came over, and the group ordered a bottle of Champagne. 
In another part of the bar, a man with a Middle Eastern accent could be overheard outlining his entrepreneurial vision to his date, a woman whose low-cut blouse brought to mind the old -- was it James Bond? -- line, "That's a nice little nothing you're almost wearing."
The man told the woman, "I want to start a jewelry business and sell giant diamond crosses to rappers." She stared wide-eyed in his direction. You couldn't really identify the music coming over the sound system, but it may have been a techno remix of that club classic "Fiddling While Rome Burns."
Helicopter Services and Instruction, based at Essex County Airport in New Jersey, announced last week that it will offer flights from Manhattan to the Hamptons for "only $303.57" each way. A package for the season goes for $8,500. Of the 50 available packages, "about 15 or 20" have already been sold, Jay Bloom, the company's chief executive, said. 
Is this the ideal economic climate in which to be starting a helicopter service to the Hamptons? 
"I was kind of surprised at the reception we got," Mr. Bloom said. Surprised that people were still so willing to indulge themselves? "It's not necessarily an indulgence. People just don't want to deal with the traffic," he said. And compared to the $1,800 fare of some helicopter services, Mr. Bloom's price is a bargain. "It's comparable to a limo," he said. 
Such is the calculus of this almost-maybe recession, even though Diane Saatchi, president of Dayton-Halstead, a real estate agency in the Hamptons, is seeing a much cooler market than last summer. "There is more inventory at the top end now than at this time last year," she said. "And at all points of the market." Last year, would-be renters would come out on a Friday, look at three or four places and sign a contract by Monday, Ms. Saatchi said. Now, "they can't make up their minds," she said. "They keep coming back to look more. They say, 'Maybe just a month.' "
Mr. Meyers, of R 20th Century, speculated that New Yorkers may have shifted the focus of their conspicuous consumption. 
"Maybe there are dinners or lunches or a sports car that get cut out," he said. "But for a piece of furniture that they're going to live with the rest of their lives, they're willing to spend." At his store, a $10,000 shelving unit by George Nelson had a "sold" tag on it. A rare Osvaldo Borsani coat rack had just been snapped up for $3,200. And Mr. Meyers had removed a $4,200 coffee table by Tapio Wirkkala from the floor because "they were selling too fast."
"There's not as much volume," Mr. Meyers said. "But the people who are coming in aren't just window-shopping."
Or window-eating. A call this week to Craft, Tom Colicchio's brand-new restaurant on East 19th Street, for a short-notice dinner reservation was greeted with: "We can take you at 5:30. Do you want to be put on the waiting list?"
For the long view on high-end dining in depressed times, consider March, on the Upper East Side. It opened in 1990, "one month after the federal government officially declared a recession," said Wayne Nish, March's chef and owner. "We hung out a flag that said 'Truffles and Foie Gras.' "
For his let-them-eat-caviar attitude, Mr. Nish was rewarded with three-star reviews. 
These days his beggar's purses -- lobster with black truffles, osetra and creme fraiche, foie gras and smoked salmon -- are going "at a very strong rate," Mr. Nish said. At $20 apiece.
Back at the Park, a lawyer and a consultant were sipping and flirting at the bar. Were either of them cutting back in any way?
Tom Summers, the lawyer, said, "Since I pay for everything, I don't think she's cutting back."
Christine Derisi, the consultant, added, "Whether I go out or not depends more on the weather than on the economy."
"The downturn hasn't tangibly affected me yet," Mr. Summers, 40, said. But it is giving him pause. "I'm the type that just puts the credit card down and pays for everyone," he said. "And I'm definitely thinking about that a little more."
Ms. Derisi, 30, said her most recent splurge was a vacation in Belize and Guatemala.
"We're in denial," he said.
"But you only live once," she added. They went on laughing and smiling.
But by 10:30 half the tables in the hottest new place in town were vacant. By midnight, just when a scene like the Park should be heating up, it was clearing out. The V.I.P. room upstairs was closed. Not just to nobodies. Empty.
Surely the beautiful people haven't been laid off?

HEADLINE: Split the Check: New York's Free Lunch Is Gone 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:
HERE'S news from a leading economic indicator -- Jim's Shoe Repair on East 59th Street, where the other day the seats were filled with waiting customers and conversation was humming. 
 An Hermes salesman in a pink button-down shirt lamented that traffic in his Madison Avenue store, home of the $385 beach towel, has slowed since its gaudy opening party last fall. A silver-haired mortgage consultant, Robert Haney, said that he's given up eating at the Metropolitan Cafe near Sutton Place and is patronizing a local diner for his hamburger and fries. And Jim Rocco, the shop's owner, said these days people are only repairing what is absolutely necessary, though few are giving up a shine. "It's a small luxury when you have to cut out the big ones," Mr. Haney said. "Instead of buying new shoes, I'll have my old ones resoled." 
Shoes may be shinier, but from Madison Avenue to SoHo, the Upper West Side to the Flatiron district, there is a duller consumer mood, and a lot of talk of personal retrenchment. The $4 double-shot latte is being replaced with coffee brewed at home. The $100 business lunch at the Mercer Kitchen has become the $40 lunch at a low-key no-name restaurant near work. 
With the stock market still probing desperately for a bottom, as investors say, and daily reports of layoffs coming in big round units of 5,000 and 10,000, the sense of uneasiness is spreading, even if a majority of economists say the country will avoid a recession. 
The number of those actually pink-slipped, like well-publicized dot-com workers, may be small; but a perception of coming hardships is widespread, and it is causing people to retrench. They are dressing more soberly, taking their entertaining into the privacy of their homes and cutting back on luxuries that had come to seem like necessities -- California cult wines, summer rentals, retro-hip George Nelson sofas. New York's wild party is winding down. 
"A year ago I wouldn't bat an eye over buying a $4,000 couch," said Chris Leba, 37, a clothing designer. "I don't make any less money now, but my mind-set has changed because I've lost a lot in the stock market. Now if I see a great couch I'm not going to buy it, because it would be tacky to spend that kind of money when so many people I know are getting laid off every other day."
The worlds of style track the economy -- not just in the obvious sense that consumers spend less when money is tight and they are pessimistic about the future; the message conveyed by what they buy also changes. During the big economic hit of the early 1990's, restaurants sought to soothe the shellshocked with value-oriented comfort food, discos gave way to quiet lounges and fashion faded to minimalist black. There was a moralizing overtone to those adjustments, a repentance of the opulence of the 80's. 
The economic slide of 2001 is nowhere near as severe, and may never become so. But already the style world is registering a mood shift. At last month's European runway shows for fall 2001, black returned as a dominant color, and there were echoes of the somber, withholding fashions of early-90's Prada and Helmut Lang. 
"There is very little frivolity, and that was a big thing a season ago," said Katherine Betts, editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar. "Everything from fur to bright pinks and reds. There was this whole pop generation of bright prints and bright graphics. It was over the top. I think people will feel self-conscious wearing that now. 
"In general the whole social mood is like that. "We were planning a whole party issue, but no one seemed interested in parties. Puffy and paparazzi and the downtown parties have sort of disappeared. It's not just the economy, it's the whole extravagance of being public. I think people are sort of turned off by that now. People are getting more private again."
Vicki Ross, a fashion consultant for L'Oreal and other companies, said: "I don't see myself buying something really expensive right now. I'd rather buy something from a vintage store. Something that is beautifully made and has gorgeous buttons, rather than some seasonal trend item in the department store."
Nationwide, sales at department and specialty store chains, including Saks, Bloomingdale's and Macy's, were down in February, the latest figures show. Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, said: "There has been no change among the very wealthy, but people who over the last couple of years have graduated from traditional department stores to specialty stores have become more cautious, because they don't have accumulated wealth and they spend much of what they earn. They were buying expensive designer clothes, jewelry and cars. Now they are buying more for their home. In times of instability, the home is a bulwark against the uncertainties of life."
Stephen Weiss, 24, understands that. A year ago he was working 70-hour weeks for RedFilter, an Internet direct-marketing company, and though he never lived lavishly, he could go out every evening, taking advantage of the endless round of Silicon Alley parties, where the drinks and hors d'oeuvres flowed freely. 
Since RedFilter went out of business a month ago, he has been spending quiet evenings at home. "I've been cleaning out my apartment because for the past two years I've been throwing everything into bags because I was too busy to organize it," he said.
"I was never living that large," he added. "I was making in the mid-20's, but it was more about the expectations. Most of us thought there was a chance that we could be millionaires. The worst thing I did last year was to tell my mother that this time next year she could retire."
Casey Kait, his girlfriend, 23, who was also recently laid off from her job as an associate editor at Salon.com, the online magazine, said that even before losing a paycheck, she had begun scaling back. "I was working on Fifth Avenue in the Flatiron district, and during the boom I would often go to Intermix at lunch and buy a $100 shirt," Ms. Kait said. "Not only did I start to bring my lunch to work, but I would eat it at my desk so I wouldn't go out and shop."
Mr. Weiss and Ms. Kait are now living, modestly, off the book advance for an oral history they are compiling, "Digital Hustlers: Living Large and Falling Hard in Silicon Alley," to be published by ReganBooks. 
Among Internet executives with jobs still to go to, Ken Kurson, editor at large of Money magazine and the founding editor of Green magazine, a personal finance publication for young people that folded in February, has noticed that they no longer dress in aggressively casual styles. "Now they're trying to look like they could fit in at I.B.M. in 1969, to show their investors that they can act more fiscally responsible," he said.
The dot-com workday has shrunk from 14 hours to one more typical of other industries, Mr. Kurson observed, now that dreams of stock-option fortunes have died. "Nobody is working crazy hours," he said. "I think President Bush has something to do with it. He works until 6 and goes home." 
Even the furnishings of Internet companies are coming down to earth. "It used to be if a company had fancy furniture and a nice office, that meant they were doing really well," said Brad Farkas, the managing principal of i-Hatch Ventures, a Manhattan venture-capital firm with a portfolio of technology companies. "Now if we go visit a company and it's all furnished with Ikea and other failed dot-coms' furniture, that speaks well of them."
The expectations of coming misery casting a shadow over discretionary spending are the flip side of irrational exuberance. 
"You had a lot of people who were very prosperous in the stock market or from the Internet and wanted a taste of the good life," said Jason Ader, a leisure analyst with Bear, Stearns, "so they stretched their resources to stay in the best hotels and eat at the best restaurants. That demand has all but dried up. I've started to get reports that restaurants' Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday business is slowing, and lunch is much slower."
Restaurants are always a bellwether of New York's mood, sensitive to everything from expense-account entertaining to the courtship rituals of singles. And here, the report is mixed. There are no mass closings, as there were a decade ago. Ambitious chefs continue to announce new projects, like Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who is coming to the meatpacking district, his business partner said last week. 
Tim Zagat, the restaurant guide publisher, said places that are feeling a crunch are overpriced scene restaurants, while midpriced bistros are doing better because they attract diners in a cautious mood. "I'm not sure if it's the weather or the economy, but things were slower this winter," he said. "I wouldn't go so far as to call it austerity, but I think people are being more selective and thinking about the value more than when money was sloshing around and they didn't think twice about slapping down an extra $5 tip."
John Harding, marketing director for Restaurant Associates, which owns Cafe Centro, Cucina & Company and the Brasserie on East 53rd street, confirmed that. "Business is still pretty strong in our mid-level restaurants," he said. "The Brasserie is as strong as it was this time last year." 
"There is a belt tightening that I think has a lot to do with perception rather than reality," he added. "I think this perception has many people cutting back on expense accounts."
Mark Wood, the owner of Canteen in SoHo and Commune in the Flatiron district, two restaurants known more for their scenes than their kitchens, has noticed a wind shift on Tuesday nights, typically a big night out for Wall Streeters. 
"They used to come out and bring parties of six and eight for dinner and buy many bottles of wine," Mr. Wood said. His bars are busier than ever, he reported, and filling up earlier, but few stay for dinner. "They seem to be going to the bar right after work to have a few drinks and then going home to order in." 
At the "21" Club, the financial industry stalwart where deals have traditionally been celebrated with expense-account meals in the mid-four figures, Chris Shipley, the wine director, has seen a slackening in demand for California cult wines, your Screaming Eagles and Harlan Estates. "A lot of young people who made a lot of money on the stock market were buying these wines," he said, driving prices up to $5,000 a case. "They are almost like Internet stocks. Their values were inflated way beyond their intrinsic worth. I will continue to buy them, but I expect the days of restricting the sales in order to keep them on the list are over. In the past a party would come in and drink the entire year's allotment in one night, but it seems the feeding frenzy is calming down."
