HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Micron's Bulls, Defying The Bubble

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
THE sound of technology stock bubbles bursting has become all too familiar in recent months. Snap went the Internet stocks early last year. Crack went the shares of personal computer makers in the autumn. Pop went the big networking stocks this winter.
 All that makes it triply amazing that Micron Technology, one of the market's most ethereal stocks, remains at celestial heights. 
 Back on earth, Micron Technology is a commodity producer of semiconductors and memory products that run personal computers and other gadgets. Last Thursday, Micron announced woeful results for its second quarter, which ended March 1.
But all seems right in the heavens, for despite its crummy numbers, an overall depression in the PC business and deep uncertainty among other technology executives about future demand for their products, Micron's shares are 17 percent higher than they were at the beginning of the year.
How bad were Micron's numbers? Sales in its second quarter were $1.06 billion, down 42 percent from just three months earlier. The company's gross margins cascaded from 49 percent in its first quarter to 18 percent in its second. Continuing operations at Micron generated a $4 million loss in the latest quarter, versus $359 million earned in the previous one.
Investors weren't thrilled with these results, even though a handful of Wall Street analysts remain inexplicably high on Micron shares. The stock fell 11.6 percent on Friday, closing at $41.53. 
At that price, the company's market capitalization exceeds $24 billion. Its shares trade at a stunning 5.6 times sales, if you extrapolate out from its second-quarter results. 
Investors have made Micron the third-most-valuable semiconductor stock in the United States, behind Texas Instruments and Intel. Yet Intel is down 12.5 percent this year and Texas Instruments has lost 35 percent of its value.
Fred Hickey, editor of the High Tech Strategist in Nashua, N.H., says Micron is more cult than stock, because traders like its volatility. "It's the best barometer we have of the love affair still going on among investors in technology stocks," he said. Many dot-coms are dead, he added, "but Micron is there, standing tall at $24 billion on the hope that some day the DRAM market will pick up."
Mr. Hickey, who has followed technology stocks for more than 20 years, pointed out that in previous periods when Micron's operations were losing money, or barely making any, its stock traded at much lower valuations.
In 1998, Micron lost money and its shares traded at roughly 1.3 times its sales. And in 1992, when the company broke even, the stock traded at a price equal to its sales. 
Mr. Hickey thinks that Micron and other semiconductor stocks have remained high -- even as shares of their customers have plummeted -- because the performance of chip makers' operations lags behind that of PC makers, Internet service providers and networking concerns. "Semiconductors are the last great bubble area of technology," Mr. Hickey said. "Because earnings have held up better there, investors stay in the stocks, even though that is where the collapse will be the greatest."
Investors may also be bullish on semiconductor stocks because they expect memory prices to rise. That seems unlikely, given inventory levels. At Micron, inventories stood at $1.1 billion in the most recent quarter, up from $690 million last August. Using the company's average selling price, investors can guess how many chips that $1.1 billion represents. A rough estimate is that Micron could supply about 25 percent of the world's annual PC needs with the chips it has on hand. It produces an additional 70 million parts a month.
Micron may not have much of a business these days. But its stubbornly loyal investors are making sure that it remains one hell of a stock.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
The Levitating Dollar

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Everything about the American economy is down lately: manufacturing production, overall growth and, needless to say, stocks. 
 So why is the dollar still rising? At the beginning of last year, when everything seemed to be going right for the U.S. economy, the dollar was worth less than one euro, and only slightly more than 100 yen. Now everything has gone wrong -- but the euro is below 90 cents and a dollar buys 125 yen. 
 Actually, I'm not surprised by the dollar's rise against the yen. We're nervous, but Japan is desperate; and since any recovery strategy in Japan will involve printing lots of yen, it will almost surely drive the currency down even further. But the continuing strength of the dollar against the euro is puzzling. In fact, it's downright weird. 
Foreign exchange rates are, after all, determined by supply and demand. Americans supply dollars to the market when they seek to buy things foreign: goods like French wine, assets like shares in Nokia. Europeans demand dollars when they seek to buy things American: goods like Kansas wheat, assets like shares in Microsoft.
These days Americans spend a lot more on foreign goods than foreigners spend on American goods -- that is, we have a large trade deficit, the largest trade deficit in the history of the world. Still, the dollar's strength a year ago was no mystery: the trade deficit was outweighed by the determination of foreigners in general, and Europeans in particular, to acquire U.S. assets and get in on the great boom. European individuals were buying the Nasdaq, European corporations were buying U.S. companies. 
But who's buying dollars now? The tech bubble has burst; Daimler is choking on Chrysler; it's hard to imagine that either individual Europeans or their corporations still see America as the great land of opportunity. Yet somebody must be moving from euros to dollars.
At a recent academic conference I spoke to a German economist, Hans-Werner Sinn, who suggested the two best stories I've heard so far about the weak euro/strong dollar conundrum. Both stories depend on the peculiar status of the euro, which right now is only a virtual currency: there aren't yet any euro bills or coins in circulation. But in January the euros will arrive, and Europeans will start trading in their marks and lira for crisp new bills bearing pictures of bridges and monuments.
Mr. Sinn suggested that one group that may be moving from European currencies to dollars is criminals, Russian gangsters in particular. If you happen to have suitcases full of marks, and you don't care to explain where they came from, you probably don't want to walk up to a bank and exchange them for the new currency. Better to avoid accumulating marks and hoard dollars instead.
Innocent Eastern Europeans -- say, Polish farmers -- may also be shifting out of European currencies. Generations of bitter experience have taught them not to trust either governments or banks, and they may not be quite sure what this euro business is all about. Better to play it safe and stuff your mattress with a currency that isn't going through any changes.
I have no idea whether these offbeat stories can really explain what's happening. But they do suggest that the strength of the dollar and the weakness of the euro are temporary. In fact, you have to wonder why big speculators aren't shorting the dollar right now. Where are the George Soroses of yesteryear? Still, one of these days dollar holders may do a Wile E. Coyote: they will look down, realize that the currency has nothing to support it, and down it will plunge.
That wouldn't be a terrible thing: the weak euro has damaged European pride, but it has probably helped the European economy at a time when the European Central Bank has been stubbornly reluctant to cut interest rates. But then maybe the E.C.B. is inhibited by its belief that lower interest rates would weaken the euro.
And that may be the moral of our tale. It's a good bet that the era of the strong dollar will soon come to an end. That will be no tragedy; but it will be a problem if a falling dollar distracts the Federal Reserve from its duty, which is to ensure not a strong dollar but a strong economy.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Big Pay at Not-So-Big Hospitals

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AT a time when hospital executives in cities around the country are crying poverty, it can gently be said that compensation figures are not declining.
 That is particularly true in New York City, home to dozens of large hospitals, where the compensation packages for executives tend to run higher than the national average. 
 In 1999, two of the nation's highest-paid hospital executives were in the city: Dr. John W. Rowe, president of Mount Sinai N.Y.U., who earned $1.3 million, and Dr. Paul A. Marks, who as president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center earned $1.2 million. (Dr. Rowe is now head of Aetna, while Dr. Marks is retired.) Dr. Rowe's second in command, Barry R. Freedman, now the acting chief executive of Mount Sinai N.Y.U., earned more than $1 million that year. 
While hospitals have been forced to make a variety of cost cuts in recent years, executive pay has seemed immune. Among not-for-profit hospitals, the trend toward larger salaries hit its stride in 1998, when compensation packages for chiefs of nonprofit groups in general rose at nearly double the 5.7 percent rate of 1997, according to the Chronicle of Philanthropy. Among the highest paid were chiefs of hospitals. 
That is largely because these centers are increasingly competing with for-profit health care organizations, other industries and one another. Not-for-profit organizations do not have stock options to dangle, so direct compensation is used. "There is enormous competition between profit and not-for-profit hospitals," said James P. McElligott Jr., a lawyer in Richmond who specializes in health care law. "And managing a medical staff and dealing with all the challenges of H.M.O.'s, finding and keeping good physicians and nurses is a major challenge." 
Others pointed to cost-of-living issues. Len Hale, the president of Hale & Associates, a health care executive search firm in New Orleans, said the lowest-paid hospital chief executive whom he had placed received $120,000 a year. The highest-paid got $230,000, Mr. Hale said. 
The lowest-paid hospital president in New York City in 1999 was Allan Gibofsky of Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, who received $177,308, according to Internal Revenue Service records. 
"In many cases you have to pay for the location," Mr. Hale said. "I have many people tell me, 'I will go anywhere but New York City or L.A.' That is the reason they are paying such high salaries there." And, many experts say, the more beds in a hospital, the better a chief executive can usually expect to be paid. 
Cost-of-living variations may explain why the head of Memorial Sloan-Kettering (437 beds) made more than Dr. John Mendelsohn, president of the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston (452 beds, $327,100). But that does not tell all the story. In 1998, the latest year for which figures were available, Miguel A. Fuentes Jr., the president of Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, earned $836,154. The hospital, with 589 beds, has no academic affiliation or area of lucrative specialty, yet Mr. Fuentes earned more than many of his counterparts in New York.
To live in the same style in Houston as one would in the Bronx, Mr. Fuentes would have to earn $615,134 a year, according to the Web site homefair .com, which does these calculations. By the same math, Dr. Samuel O. Thier, chief executive of Partners HealthCare System in Boston, should be making $1,367,892 a year, not the $648,000 he received for overseeing seven hospitals, four affiliated with Harvard Medical School, 3,172 beds in all. Are the men in Houston and Boston underpaid? Or does Mr. Fuentes make more than one might expect?
Officials of Bronx-Lebanon would not comment. But Mr. Hale pointed out that the hospital in the Bronx has 100 more beds than M.D. Anderson. "Does that justify twice the salary?" he said. "No. Do some executives have compensation that appears out of sight? Yes, but somebody wanted them more."
James A. Brickley, a business professor at the University of Rochester, said he found that among nonprofit hospitals, executives who produced the best financial returns received raises that were 8 percent higher than those on the bottom tiers. 
But how to measure that at a time when many hospitals are barely breaking even? "I would love to have 5 percent of what hospitals waste," said Mr. Hale, who worked for many years in health care.
Yet, as Mr. McElligott said, "clearly these are pricey packages, but to get good leaders you have to pay it."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Yes, the Chief Can Own Too Much Stock in the Company

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT

 BODY:
MAE WEST used to say that too much of a good thing is wonderful.
 But she probably wasn't talking about executive compensation. A recent study by John E. Core and David F. Larcker, accounting professors at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, concludes that too much pay can be counterproductive. (The study, has not yet been published, though it is circulating as a working paper and can be found at http:// knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/PDFs/ 857.pdf.) 
 On the one hand, the study substantiates the prevailing view that companies improve their performance if they include equity in executive compensation packages -- giving their chief executives incentives to make their companies do even better. But, on the other hand, the researchers also found that the point of diminishing returns is quickly reached -- and that companies whose chief executives own too much equity tend to be laggards.
Anyone who is familiar with how academics qualify their findings may be surprised that it is possible to reach such unambiguous conclusions -- especially in an area that presents as many difficulties as the relationship between corporate performance and executive compensation. 
But the two professors devised a solution that sidestepped many of those problems. They studied companies that increased, from low levels, the amount of equity they required their executives to own. By comparing the performance of those companies with comparable ones that did not increase their stock-ownership requirements, the professors could isolate the unique impact of executive compensation. The study focused on 195 companies between 1991 and 1996.
They found that companies that increased stock-ownership requirements performed significantly better. That was evident not only in the operating performance of the companies themselves, but also in stock prices.
But if some equity-based incentives improve corporate performance, why is it counterproductive to provide even more? 
The professors theorized that the answer had to do with the proportion of an executive's net worth that is represented by equity in the company. As that proportion grows too high, the executive becomes more conservative in the way he or she runs the company. In other words, elevated levels of stock ownership create incentives for executives to reduce their risk taking -- which may be just the opposite of what is good for the company as a whole.
The professors could not come up with absolute definitions of ownership levels that are too low, too high or just right. The answer is different for each company and each executive, because it depends on factors like the average compensation at comparable companies and the executive's total wealth. But Professor Larcker suggested to me that, as a general rule, equity ownership that is below the average among comparable companies is a negative signal for performance.
Helpful as that rule may be in judging executive compensation plans, other pay policies may be more important. A study by Professor Larcker and two other Wharton professors, Christopher Ittner and Richard A. Lambert, found that, at least among new-economy companies, equity ownership among middle-level managers could have an even greater impact on corporate performance than that by the chief executive. (This study, circulating as a working paper, is at http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/ PDFs/1001.pdf.) The study focused on 217 new-economy companies in 1999 and 2000.
Consider those new-economy companies that pay middle-level managers at least 20 percent more in options, relative to their salaries, than comparable businesses do. The professors found that the stock prices of such companies rose 5 percent faster per year. The same outperformance was seen at new-economy companies that paid their technical personnel at least 20 percent more in options.
Although these increased returns may sound modest, they are statistically important because they represent the average experience of a large sample of companies. Executive compensation is worth looking at when considering a stock purchase.

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
For the Boss, Happy Days Are Still Here

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
FOR the last decade, the chief executives of America's large corporations have offered their investors an implicit bargain. The executives made their companies ever more profitable, helping to create one of history's greatest bull markets. As a reward, they paid themselves more handsomely than ever before.
 Some made $100 million in a given year. By the end of the 1990's, the average head of a big company took home more than $10 million before taxes. 
 Critics complained about income inequality, and some activist investors said that even mediocre managers were reaping windfalls. But the executives' rejoinder was always a strong one: we work for our shareholders, and they are getting rich right alongside us. 
Then, in 2000, sales slowed. Companies warned that profit forecasts were too optimistic. Stocks fell.
And the chief executives of many of the nation's biggest companies changed the terms of the deal. To make up for the hit their portfolios took when the market dropped, they convinced their boards to give them thousands of additional stock options. A few even received permission to change the exercise price on their stock options or to use an accounting maneuver to cancel an earlier exercise of options that, in hindsight, looked financially foolish. 
Other chieftains asked for more actual shares of stock, which -- unlike options -- have immediate value even in a bear market. Many executives also developed a newfound interest in dowdy old cash, winning moderate raises to their base salaries and huge increases in their bonuses and perks.
In short, the notion that corporate America pays its top managers based on their performance went the same way in 2000 as the idea that Internet stocks should be valued based on "page views." As a result, the fortunes of the people who run the nation's biggest companies and the people who own those companies -- the shareholders -- diverged sharply.
While typical investors lost 12 percent of their portfolios last year, based on the Wilshire 5000 total-market index, and profits for the Standard & Poor's 500 companies rose at less than half their pace in the 1990's, chief executives received an average 22 percent raise in salary and bonus.
The executives also received $1.7 million in stock, on average, up 14 percent from the previous year. And they were handed an average of $14.9 million worth of stock options, largely because they received almost 50 percent more options than in 1999, according to Executive Compensation Advisory Services, which conducted a survey of pay at 200 companies for Money & Business. 
The typical hourly worker received a 3 percent raise last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Salaried employees got about 4 percent more.
In total, the chief executives in the survey made an average of more than $20 million last year, including options, based on a widely used method for valuing them. The median pay package was $6.2 million.
"The risk is being taken out of executive compensation," said Judith Fischer, managing director of Executive Compensation Advisory Services. "You don't even have to make the performance goals. The board will pay you anyway."
Apple Computer gave its boss, Steven P. Jobs, a $90 million Gulfstream jet and 20 million stock options even as its shares fell 13 percent. Sprint's stock dropped 70 percent during the year, but it paid William T. Esrey $53 million in cash and stock, including 300,000 options he had not been scheduled to receive until this year. Coca-Cola gave M. Douglas Ivester, who resigned abruptly after a disappointing two-year tenure, an $18 million severance package. Then its board ignored a shareholder-approved bonus plan and gave the new chairman, Douglas N. Daft, a $3 million bonus although Coke missed its financial goals. In the process, the company lost its tax deduction on the bonus, since it was unrelated to performance.
"The guy's done a great job," said Herbert Allen, an investment banker in New York who is chairman of the compensation committee on Coke's board, echoing the most common rationale for last year's pay levels. Mr. Allen said Mr. Daft had inherited a difficult situation, quickly developed a plan to cut thousands of jobs, settled a racial discrimination lawsuit and improved Coke's relationship with bottlers and government officials. His pay, Mr. Allen added, "is probably directly in line with executives at other companies." 
Beyond the overall pay numbers, the details buried inside company proxies indicate just how successful chief executives were in negotiating with boards last year. The AmSouth Bancorporation paid C. Dowd Ritter $6.2 million for meeting its long-term goals -- and an additional $2.5 million to help cover the taxes.
On top of $140 million in cash and options, General Electric paid $1.3 million in life insurance premiums for John F. Welch Jr. The MBNA Corporation spent $213,000 for Alfred Lerner to use its corporate jet for personal trips. Dozens of companies paid their executives above-market interest rates on deferred compensation; John R. Stafford, for example, received an extra $745,000 from American Home Products.
THERE were also some odd perks. H & R Block reimbursed its boss, Frank L. Salizzoni, for the $3,021 he spent on having his taxes prepared -- and then it paid the taxes on the gift. In a severance deal for Dennis Jones, a former chief information officer, FedEx said it would give him "executive access" to Disney World and Disneyland. 
Certainly, many executives did see the value of their portfolios decline, and some technology entrepreneurs who were billionaires on paper a year ago are now mere millionaires. Across corporate America, millions of stock options are under water, with an exercise price above the shares' value -- leaving fewer executives able to cash out options they had received in previous years. During 2000, employees exercised only 10 percent of outstanding options, down from 23 percent in 1997, according to a study of 40 big companies by SCA Consulting in New York.
Some companies, like Oracle, gave their bosses big raises based on stock gains that have disappeared since the end of their fiscal year. These companies could end up lowering pay in 2001. For overall pay to drop, however, the pattern of 2000 -- when executives used the downturn as leverage to get cash payments and huge options grants -- would have to reverse, pay experts said.
"THE reality is, managers love it when a bull market is pulling everybody up," said Joseph J. Melone, the former chief executive of the Equitable Companies who serves on the boards of three public companies. "But in a down market, there's a concern that people aren't adequately compensated."
"There is a bit of a bias in the system that favors management," he added.
Black & Decker, whose stock price fell 25 percent in its fiscal year 2000, gave Nolan D. Archibald one million options, up from 200,000 in 1999. Lucent Technologies gave Richard A. McGinn, who has since been ousted, 3.4 million options, more than twice the number he received the previous year, although its shares dropped 81 percent. At Pitney Bowes, with the stock price in the midst of a 46 percent fall during 2000, the board accelerated its pay plan and gave top executives the options that they were due to receive in 2001 and 2002.
Even some compensation consultants who have defended the high pay of the 1990's as logical and fair say they are surprised by the packages last year. "I'm actually a little disappointed," said Ira T. Kay of Watson Wyatt Worldwide, the consulting firm, referring to the contrast between results and executive pay.
Shareholders generally allowed boards to make pay decisions in 2000, though murmurings of discontent were on the rise. Last year, at one out of every 20 companies, at least 40 percent of shareholders voted against their company's stock plan -- a level that indicates that the company had to work hard to have the plan approved, according to Strategic Compensation Research Associates in New York. 
Four years ago, one of out 35 companies faced such opposition. 
And why did boards continue to award such high pay? Compensation experts give two main reasons for the influence that executives continue to wield over directors charged with setting salaries in the best interests of shareholders.
Running a large company is simply more difficult than it once was. With new technology and fewer regulations, companies can quickly steal market share from one another. "One bad decision by a C.E.O. is a lot more costly than it used to be," said Robert Frank, an economist at Cornell University.
Boards have responded by paying executives lavishly -- and firing them more often than in the past. Even with the hiring competition from dot-com companies all but gone, after having dominated executive recruiting in 1998 and 1999, management experts say top jobs outnumber good candidates.
"I'm not aware of a board that is trying to make up the difference" between what executives were worth in 1999 and last year, said Warren Batts, a director at Sprint, Allstate and Sears, Roebuck. "What they're trying to do is retain the best and brightest of their management group."
The other reason should be obvious, though it is often overlooked: Most of the people who serve on corporate boards are themselves top executives, and most companies set pay scales by researching the competition and then aiming to pay executives at the 50th or 75th percentile of what similar companies pay.
As a result, directors have an incentive to award ever-rising paychecks. Often, they also owe their presence on the board to the chief executive. 
The chiefs, meanwhile, typically hire lawyers to negotiate on their behalf. "Oftentimes, boards get outnegotiated," said Alan Johnson, a pay consultant in New York who represents boards.
The coziness between the two sides continues even when the relationship sours and the board asks the executive to resign, management experts say. In the last year, Jill E. Barad received a $57 million severance package from Mattel, and Xerox gave G. Richard Thoman, who had been chief executive for 13 months, $800,000 a year for the rest of his life.
Steven E. Hall, a managing director at Pearl Meyer & Partners in New York who advises boards, says directors take the attitude that "it's not worth taking it out of the hide of another person like us." 
"It's all done in a very genteel manner," he added. "People at these levels are treated very differently."
NEVER was that more true than in 2000. In past years, executives have argued that they should continue to receive the same number of options even as their companies' share price increased, guaranteeing them bigger pay packages each year. But last year, as stocks fell, the executives changed their argument, saying they needed more options to make up for the market's downturn.
With all the new options being handed out -- 715,000 per chief executive last year, up from 476,000 in 1999 -- companies have now set aside the equivalent of 13.3 percent of their shares for employees, up from 13.1 percent a year ago, according to the Investor Responsibility Research Center. Companies do not have to account for the cost of stock options on their earnings statements, but options dilute the long-term value of a stock by leaving existing shareholders with a smaller portion of the company than they once owned.
In 2000, executives also began pushing boards to make so-called long-term incentive payments more often, said Ms. Fischer of Executive Compensation Advisory Services. In the past, companies set long-term targets once every three years and paid cash or stock afterward, based on achievement of those goals. Now, more companies are setting a new three-year target each year.
"It used to be that long term meant long term," Ms. Fischer said. 
The average estimated value of plans set up last year grew 49 percent, versus plans established in 1999. In other words, 2003 is already looking like a good year for executive pay.
Other companies decided that it was not enough to design new executives contracts to pay handsomely even in a tepid market. With some share prices down 50 percent or even much more, executives sought to rewrite the rules on their old contracts. Some simply repriced the options they granted in years past. 
Others were more creative. A small number of companies -- including Cysive, a software company -- erased history by canceling options exercises that some employees had made. The stock had dropped sharply after the transactions, but executives still faced taxes, based on the difference between the exercise price and the stock price at the time. So companies took back their stock and returned the options to executives, as if the deal had never happened, said David M. Leach, a pay expert at Buck Consultants.
Still other companies ripped up loan agreements. Compaq Computer said it would forgive a $5 million loan it had made to its chief executive, Michael Capellas, in 1999 so that he could buy Compaq stock then. When Mr. Capellas bought the shares, after becoming chief executive, they were trading at $23. At the end of 2000, they closed at $15.05.
The company also gave Mr. Capellas a "special one-time bonus" of $300,000 in June and another "special one-time bonus" of $850,000 in October, as well as a $2.5 million loan to pay the taxes for the forgiven loan.
A spokesman for Compaq said the bonuses were a reward for the company's revenue gains and cost reductions, as well as Mr. Capellas's promotion to chairman. The forgiving of the loan will take effect over three years, encouraging Mr. Capellas to stay at Compaq, the spokesman said.
But amid the unquestioning generosity that swept through boardrooms in 2000, there were exceptions. General Cable, a 150-year-old manufacturer based in Highland Heights, Ky., also loaned its top executives millions of dollars a couple of years ago. Since then, its stock has fallen about one-third, to less than $11, and executives have grown "obviously concerned" about their debt, said Stephen Rabinowitz, the chief executive.
So will General Cable forgive the loans? Absolutely not, Mr. Rabinowitz said. "I'm firmly of the view that a deal's a deal," he said. "We all knew there was some risk."
Other boards decided not to pay chief executives the maximum possible bonuses when their companies missed certain goals. A few, like Airborne, Navistar International and Paccar, paid no bonus at all. 
And Schering-Plough reduced the pay of Richard Jay Kogan by $300,000, because two of the company's manufacturing plants failed inspections by the Food and Drug Administration. Of course, 2000 was still not a bad year for Mr. Kogan. Altogether, Schering-Plough gave him a $2.5 million raise, paying him $22 million in cash, stock and options and leaving him slightly better off than the average chief executive of a large company in 2000.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 8

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
New Turn on an Old Favorite

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
ASK the people who design executive pay packages what the plans' biggest weakness is, and the response approaches unanimity. Stock options, consultants and directors say, enrich mediocre managers when stocks are rising but fail to reward even successful executives in a bear market.
 Yet largely because of an accounting rule, most executive pay -- almost 75 percent last year -- comes in stock options, which recipients came to love during the long bull market. "We pay out billions and billions of dollars on a very rickety foundation," said Alan M. Johnson, the president of Johnson Associates, a pay consulting firm in New York. 
 One company set out to strengthen that foundation in 2000. The RCN Corporation, a three-year-old telecommunications company based in Princeton, N.J., began paying its top executives in something it called "outperform stock options." If the company's shares rise but still do worse than the Standard & Poor 500-stock index, RCN's executives cannot exercise their options. But if the stock appreciates faster than the index, the executives can make more money than they otherwise would have -- because a multiplier kicks in to increase the options' value.
"It ensures that management does not benefit from a rising tide that lifts all boats," said Tim Stoklosa, RCN's chief financial officer. To give the plan added bite, the company said that regardless of what the S.& P. 500 does, RCN's stock must rise to $38.125 -- from the grant-date price of $23.38 -- before executives can exercise any options. On Friday, RCN's stock closed at $6.03.
The company modeled its plan after one at Level 3 Communications, RCN's largest shareholder. But few analysts expect the practice to be widely embraced by American corporations because of the accounting pain involved.
When a company awards regular stock options, it does not have to report any cost on its earnings statements. An accounting rule issued in 1972 says that the cost of an option is the difference between the exercise price and the stock price on the day of the grant -- which is always zero for normal options. However, because the exercise price of RCN's options is not set until a later date, the Financial Accounting Standards Board requires the company to take a charge to reported earnings. This year, RCN's charge will be close to $50 million, Mr. Stoklosa said.
Pay consultants say there is no rationale for the different accounting methods.
"All options have a cost," said Russell Miller, a partner at SCA Consultants in New York -- they dilute ownership. But, he added, "only some show up on the income statement."
IN the 1990's, many executives who became wealthy because of stock options lobbied to prevent the accounting board from changing the rules. They do not want regular stock options to cause an accounting charge.
But, without such a change, the stock market's tide -- be it rising or falling -- will continue to have as much of an effect on most option values as a company's performance does. DAVID LEONHARDT

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Raising the Bar"With ordinary stock options granted to top executives, it is usually a matter of time before they are in the money. Here is an example of how RCN could make it harder for executives to cash in. THE GRANTAt the beginning of the year, an executive receives stock options, with a $40 strike price. THE STICK . . .The executive could exercise a normal option when the stock rises above $40. With an indexed option, the stock must post a better return than a group of other stocks. RCN uses the S.& P. 500 index as its benchmark. So if the share rises to $44 -- a 10 percent gain -- but the S.& P. 500 posts a better gain, the option is worthless. . . . THE CARROTIf the overall market is down, the executive can sometimes exercise the options as long as the company's stock does better than the benchmark stocks. RCN also sets a minimum price for the shares, at which the options become exercisable. THE REWARDFor each penny by which the stock beats the index, the executive can earn additional money because of a multiplier on the option. RCN would not disclose its multiplier.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
One Political Constant

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KAZIN; Michael Kazin, a professor of history at Georgetown University, is the author of "The Populist Persuasion."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE specter of the Gilded Age haunts the current debate over campaign finance reform. Advocates of banning "soft money" want to curb the power of special interests over politics, which they trace back to the benighted era from the 1870's to the end of the 19th century, when big business spent huge sums to gain sway over elections and policy-making. "There are two things that are important in politics," explained Mark Hanna, the wealthy Republican strategist of the Gilded Age whom cartoonists depicted in a tight suit checkered with dollar signs and a diamond stickpin in his cravat. "The first is money, and I can't remember what the second one is." 
 The first serious attempt to rein in plutocratic politics came in 1907, when Congress banned direct corporate donations to candidates. But that restriction was easy for fund-raisers and attorneys to circumvent and de-fang. If contemporary reformers hope to be more successful, they might reflect on the ways big money shaped political life a century ago and why their predecessors failed. 
 Not until the last years of the 19th century did big corporations and their rich directors acquire the habit of putting their money where their interests lay. Previously, party stalwarts paid the bulk of campaign costs, particularly for local offices. When Tammany Hall controlled New York City in the 1880's, the machine levied a tax of about 6 percent on municipal job-holders; candidates for mayor had to kick in at least $25,000 to finance their own races, or about $400,000 in today's money. But as the size and power of the federal government grew, industrialists stepped in, hoping to head off any restrictions on their power and profits.
Both Democrats and Republicans went begging for large donations from people with names like Rockefeller, Carnegie, Frick and Harriman. During the 1888 presidential campaign, the Republican Party boss of Pennsylvania, Matthew Quay, raised more than $3 million from steelmakers and oil producers fearful that a Democratic president and Congress would cut the steep tariffs that protected their firms from foreign competition. Quay's candidate, Benjamin Harrison, won, and soon approved a new law that increased duties on most goods.
As a result, by 1892, many corporate titans had grown blase about the prospect of a Democratic president. That year, Grover Cleveland sailed into the White House with the help of $100,000 from sugar manufacturers and sizeable amounts of cash from the Northern Pacific Railroad and Macy's department store. These were tremendous sums at a time when a well-paid worker was paid roughly $3 a day and the annual revenue of the federal government was a mere $355 million. After the votes were counted, the magnate Henry Clay Frick wrote to his partner, Andrew Carnegie, "I am very sorry for President Harrison, but I cannot see that our interests are going to be affected one way or the other by the change in administration."
But the prospect of a president named William Jennings Bryan was different. In 1896, Bryan's vow to help debtors by inflating the money supply and his jabs at "those who have been living on what other people have earned" enabled Mark Hanna to dun corporate friends for almost any sum the Republican campaign for William McKinley needed.
NO one was then required to divulge the source or amount of campaign funds. But key Republican officials reported spending at least $4 million, about 10 times what Bryan and the Democrats could muster. One day that fall, Hanna handed an aide an envelope containing 50 $1,000 bills from a railroad company's coffers. Another day, the president of a Philadelphia bank gave $25,000, saying, "We have never before contributed a cent to politics, but the present crisis we believe to be as important as the Civil war." With these funds, the Republicans distributed more than 250 million flyers and pamphlets, hired thousands of speakers, and staged parades in nearly every big city. After the race, Theodore Roosevelt quipped that Hanna had sold McKinley "as if he were a patent medicine."
How much influence all this corporate largesse bought is not clear. Then as now, politicians sought to bring prosperity to their districts and regions, and most were careful not to alienate large employers and investors. Organized labor, for its part, had neither the cash nor the political unity to compete. The American Federation of Labor first endorsed a presidential candidate in 1908, when Bryan made his third run. But A.F.L. President Samuel Gompers managed to raise less than $10,000 for the effort. 
Yet, the beneficiaries of the big money still had to assuage their humbler constituents, many of whom resented the flaunting of wealth and the concentration of economic might. In the 1880's, Senator John Sherman of Ohio accepted donations from John D. Rockefeller and then wrote an antitrust act in 1890 that provided the legal basis for the eventual break up of Standard Oil. Wall Street executives financed Theodore Roosevelt's race for governor of New York in 1898 and were shocked when, safely in office, T.R. called for a tax on corporations. "I have no command of the English language that enables me to express my feelings regarding Mr. Roosevelt," said the oilman Henry M. Flagler.
By the time Roosevelt was elected president, in 1904, the widespread hostility against big business (broadly, if imprecisely, labeled "the trusts") had fueled various attempts to regulate the financing of campaigns. In addition to the ban on corporate giving, nearly all Democrats and many Republicans backed a bill to publicize the names of contributors and the extent of their generosity. Yet few Progressives worked to assure such measures were enforced. When Bryan promoted the public financing of elections in the 1920's, few followed his lead.
This reluctance was due more to the worldview of reformers than a weakness of political will. Most Progressives did not think you could purify politics while leaving the structure of the economy alone. Senator John McCain of Arizona gets outraged at the parties for taking soft money from big firms but is silent about the market power of companies and their treatment of workers. In contrast, earlier reformers questioned every aspect of the looming incorporation of American industry. Some modernizers, like T.R., favored regulations to force big businesses to operate more efficiently and to serve the interests of wage earners and consumers. Others of a more populist bent, such as Bryan, sought to destroy "monopolies" and preserve the more human-scale economy they feared was passing into history.
BUT all manner of Progressives agreed that government should aid movements of aroused citizens challenging the sway of "trusts" over American society. That was the motivation behind new laws providing for factory inspections, an eight-hour day, the expansion of national parks and a variety of other measures that increased federal authority as a countervailing force to private power.
Reformers a century ago believed that the corporate funding of campaigns was simply one aspect of a bigger problem. Their present-day counterparts may come to agree with that if cutting off the flood of soft money just opens new loopholes for people with cash to spare and influence to gain.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Weird Economics; 
To Save Or Spend?

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
AMERICANS need to save more money. The nation's meager savings rate drives up interest rates, discouraging businesses from investing and hurting the United States economy.
 That sounds reasonable. 
 Americans save enough already. Consumer spending drives the economy. Money that is saved is not being spent. At a time when economic growth is slowing, an increase in the savings rate could be disastrous. 
O.K., so which is it?
Economics is a science. Like physics or chemistry, it is bound by ironclad rules: printing money causes inflation; higher prices cause demand to fall.
That's very reassuring, but you didn't answer my first question.
Economics pretends to be a science. Its practitioners fill blackboards with equations and clog computers with data. But it is really a faith, or more accurately a set of overlapping and squabbling faiths, each with its own doctrines.
Thanks. Now I really don't know what to think.
For two decades, a soaring stock market has fanned Americans' appetite for economic news and analysis. But, amid the profusion of contradictory advice, sometimes it seems as if economic theory has no underlying logic at all.
Actually, it's not that bad. Let's start with the basics, and please, try not to doze off: 
Economics has two major branches.
Microeconomics is the study of how specific choices made by businesses, consumers and governments affect the markets for different goods and services. For example, a microeconomist might examine how price changes affect sales of apples relative to oranges.
Macroeconomics is the analysis of the economy as a whole, an examination of overall supply and demand. At the broadest level, macroeconomists want to understand why some countries grow faster than others and which government policies can help growth.
The difference between microeconomics and macroeconomics is a bit like the difference between biology and medicine. Knowing that certain genes increase the risk of cancer is relatively easy. Figuring out exactly which people will get sick, or how to cure them, is a lot more complicated.
A lot of microeconomics is reasonably well understood. Take prices. A price represents the intersection of supply and demand for a given good. If demand for the good rises or its supply shrinks, its price will rise. How much it rises depends on how much consumers need the good and whether they can easily substitute other goods for it. If 90 percent of the world's apple crop disappeared tomorrow, apples would rise in price, but less than you might imagine, because other fruits make reasonable substitutes. But if 30 percent of the world's oil disappeared, oil's price would probably soar, since oil is vital to many industries and there are few good substitutes for it.
But many of the economic questions that policy makers most care about are macro, not micro: Is there a level of government spending that is optimal for economic growth? What tax system works best? And many of these macro questions have no clear answers.
In part, that's because economies are so huge and complex that isolating the effects of just one change is impossible. Sure, cutting taxes helps to boost economic growth by putting more money in consumers' pockets and encouraging people to work harder, since they will take home more pay. But what if the government cuts taxes and not spending? Then deficits will rise, leading to higher interest rates, as the government competes with private businesses for capital. High rates hurt business investment, and any cutback in business spending might easily outweigh the positive effects of lower taxes.
Figuring which of these forces is more important means guessing the relative weights of dozens of variables. And because there is only one petri dish -- the United States economy -- macroeconomists can't run real-world experiments with different approaches. They can only speculate.
Under these circumstances, predicting the impact of President Bush's tax cuts is a matter of ideology as much as economics. It is not that economists don't understand the effects that cuts will have. It's just that they can't be certain whether the positive effects will outweigh the negatives, or vice-versa.
The same trap reappears in other macroeconomic debates, even those that are less ideologically polarizing.
Take the question of whether Americans save enough money. For many years, economists believed that Japan's high consumer savings rate gave it a crucial edge over the United States by providing Japanese banks with a vast pool of capital that they could lend to businesses at low interest rates.
But in the last decade, Japan has stagnated, while America has soared. The Internet and information technology have made the United States such an attractive place to invest that domestic businesses have had no problem attracting capital from investors all over the world. Meanwhile, Japanese banks, which face a huge overhang of bad loans, have been slow to make new ones, and even when the banks make money available, Japanese businesses have had a tough time finding profitable places to invest.
Still, most economists think the United States would be better off if Americans gradually increased their savings so businesses here don't depend so much on foreign investment.
"Savings are really good in the long run," said Jeremy Siegel, finance professor at the University of Pennsylvania. But Mr. Siegel said that in the short run, consumers, who account for about two-thirds of all economic activity, need to keep spending to prop up the economy at a time when businesses are sharply cutting back on their investment.
"Any increase in savings by consumers right now could be enough to tip our economy into recession," he said. Thus the apparently contradictory advice -- spend more now, but less later -- turns out to make a certain amount of sense. Just don't ask Mr. Siegel exactly how much to save, or when to start.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Trolling for Brains in International Waters

BYLINE:  By JAMES GLANZ 

 BODY:
THE world is a global marketplace. Money flows like water across national borders, creating a perpetual motion machine of investment, development and wealth creation. Theoretically, it is a system in which everybody wins. 
 The global market for knowledge and expertise, by contrast, has developed far less rapidly, and thus far has produced only one big winner: the United States. Information technology (I.T.) generates about a third of the economic growth in this country with just five million workers, said Dr. B. Lindsay Lowell, director of research at Georgetown University's Institute for the Study of International Migration. And over one million of those people are foreign born. 
 But America is beginning to lose its monopoly on the world's best brains. From Ireland to India, South Korea to South Africa, and Australia to Albania, said Dr. Allan Findlay, a geographer and the director of the Centre for Applied Population Research at the University of Dundee in Scotland, resources are being poured into retaining native talent. 
Australia, for example, recently announced a $2 billion package of research grants, tax breaks and new education funding to attract and retain technical talent. Japan has budgeted billions of dollars to increase I.T. development and retain workers across Asia. And Taiwan, by expanding the scope of its graduate science programs and emphasizing the country's growing high-technology industry, has lured back some 50,000 scientists who had left the country over the last two decades, according to Dr. Tzu-Feng Marlene Lin at the National Science Council in Taipei.
Scientific knowledge and technical skill have become so essential to the economic future of nations that the migration of skilled workers has come under intense scrutiny. Transilience, which means to leap across, is now used to describe what Dr. Lowell calls "brain currents," the movement of educated individuals, like a new form of currency, around the globe.
In the competition for the best and brightest, the cost to the losers can be devastating. For example, a study by the Colombian government estimated that the nation lost tens of thousands of people with three years or more of higher education in 1999 alone, said Jean-Baptiste Meyer, a senior researcher at the Institut de Recherche pour le Developpement in Paris.
Dr. Meyer added that losses of the most highly skilled people from Colombia and South Africa, which he has also studied, are accelerating as international head-hunting companies have become active there.
"These countries are thus under tremendous pressures on their skilled populations," Mr. Meyer wrote in an e-mail message from Colombia. The same is also true of India and Asia, where local job markets often can absorb only a fraction of the scientists and engineers produced every year.
Rather than fight transilience, a number of countries are trying to benefit from it by keeping their borders open to technically advanced workers. In the short term, this may encourage scientists to leave their native lands for the United States or Europe, but they may return later, with extensive professional networks and far greater experience than they would have had otherwise.
Take India, which may have the world's largest diaspora of scientists. IndUS Entrepreneurs, a group whose members include the leading Indian software engineers in Silicon Valley, estimates that 30 percent of the software engineers there are of Indian origin. And AnnaLee Saxenian, an economist at Berkeley, has used a Dun & Bradstreet database to count 750 Silicon Valley companies run by Indians. 
ON the other side of the ledger, though, India itself appears to have benefited enormously from its far-flung citizens. The worth of India's information-technology exports has catapulted, to $4 billion in 2000, from just $150 million in 1990. And the Indian government projects that by 2008 that number will be $85 billion.
"The fact that all these Indians are here is enabling massive changes which are beneficial to India, and also beneficial to the U.S.," said Dr. Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University, who is a special advisor to the United Nations on globalization.
Sheer wealth and unmatched research infrastructure continue to make the United States the Mecca of scientists and engineers. Data from the National Science Foundation show that, except for a brief dip mid-decade, students from the top exporters of talent in Asia enrolled in American graduate programs in increasing numbers during the 1990's. Last year, some 75,000 were here from China and India alone. The most recent figures also show there are about 20,000 students here at any given time from the three largest European exporters, Germany, Britain and France. 
"Yes, yes, you are seen by us as a kind of vacuum cleaner or something," said Dr. Dominique Martin-Rovet, the Washington representative of France's Centre National de Recherche Scientifique.
But the growing global effort to retain highly educated workers may begin to level the playing field. The number of graduate students here from Taiwan, which has changed its research institutions to retain native-born talent, has fallen by 40 percent since 1995. And a recent National Science Foundation study concluded that China, South Korea, Japan, Mexico, Chile, Argentina and other developing countries are also undertaking structural changes to attract students and young scientists.
Research spending in Ireland has reportedly soared from a few million dollars to more than half-a-billion dollars in the past three years, and the University of Limerick recently announced plans to attract two dozen world-class researchers to new positions. Germany is overhauling its entire university system, in part to make it more attractive to young researchers and engineers.
AS the market for brains tightens, the United States could come to regret its reliance on foreign talent at the expense of educating its native born, said Dr. Lowell of Georgetown.
"In the short to medium term, the U.S. makes out like a bandit," he said. "In the medium to long term, the outlook is questionable, even for the U.S."
The first challenge the country will face, he said, is the impossibility of granting permanent citizenship to the vastly expanded pool of high-tech workers being granted temporary visas, following new rules enacted by Congress this year. "We can easily project a greater demand than current visas are available," Dr. Lowell said.
Assuming that those human and bureaucratic stresses can be handled, he said, the country will still have to deal with the slowing of wage growth in I.T. that an increase of temporary workers will almost certainly bring. If historical parallels hold up, lower wages will discourage women and minorities from seeking training in these fields, increasing the country's reliance on foreign talent even further, he said.
"Cheap labor puts off the day of reckoning for employers," Dr. Lowell said.
As the global competition for the world's most precious commodity heats up, the United States could come to regret its neglect of native-born minorities and the educational system that develops their talent and provides them with skills. America may learn the definition of transilience the hard way.

HEADLINE: March 25-31; 
A Killer Economy

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL

 BODY:
While mad cow disease is feared largely because infected meat might give humans a fatal brain-destroying illness, no such threat has ever been associated with foot-and-mouth disease. It is, instead, a completely economic plague. 
 The disease has only rarely been detected in humans. But in animals like cows, pigs and sheep, it causes blisters in the mouth and feet, making it painful for them to eat or walk. In the worst cases, the hooves can fall off. In young animals, the disease can be fatal. While most adult animals recover from the blisters in weeks, it can take livestock months to regain lost weight, and cows rarely produce the same amount of milk. And animals infected with the virus cannot be legally exported. 
 The virus can spread on the wind, in water and infected fodder, on exhaled animal breath and on humans' shoes or clothing. In less than six weeks, the disease spread from a single British piggery to over 750 farms and upward of 764,000 animals. Britain has performed mass slaughters and burned or buried carcasses to break the chain of infection, but the virus has moved into Ireland, France and the Netherlands. The United States has halted the importation of meat and meat products from the European Union and placed airports and other points of entry on heightened alert. 
But regions that do not export meat tend to take the disease in stride. In Hong Kong -- where, as in mainland China and Taiwan, foot-and-mouth is deeply rooted -- no animals have been slaughtered, no restrictions have been placed on the sale of meat and there is no ban on importing meat or dairy products from other countries with the disease, though at least 574 pigs have died of foot-and- mouth since April 2000. ALAN COWELL

GRAPHIC: Photo: Foot and mouth disease endangers the profitability of livestock. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Two Crises: Cows and Current

BYLINE:  By JOHN MICKLETHWAIT; John Micklethwait, the United States editor of The Economist, is the co-author of "A Future Perfect: The Challenge and Hidden Promise of Globalization."

DATELINE: LAGUNA NIGUEL, Calif. 

 BODY:
CUMBRIA and Orange County belong to very different worlds. But the fells of northern Britain and the sprawl of Southern California are now both digesting yet more bad news. In Britain, despite the pyres of burning sheep and cattle, foot-and-mouth disease is now set to jump tenfold. This week Californians discovered the harshest consequence yet of their energy crisis: an immediate rise in electricity prices by as much as 50 percent.
 Foot-and-mouth is a far more gruesome tragedy. On the other hand, California's electricity crisis may be both more expensive and more prolonged. Yet the reactions to the disasters in Britain and California have been strikingly similar. 
 There has been anger, to be sure, but, so far, it has been strangely dissipated. Given the failure of either government to deal with the crisis, heads might have been expected to fall. Instead, the people in charge -- Prime Minister Tony Blair and Governor Gray Davis -- have suffered relatively little politically so far. 
This is partly to do with the complexity of the issues. Foot-and-mouth is no easier to explain than electricity deregulation. Without obvious culprits, the media, particularly television news, often jumped to more straightforward stories -- the chances of a general election in Britain, the decline of Nasdaq, and (inevitably) the worldwide debate about Bjork's dress sense.
But complexity alone does not explain the muted anger. There has also been a marked degree of separation, a sense of distance from the pain. In Britain, farming accounts for only about one in a hundred jobs -- something disgruntled Londoners are quick to point out. For all his empathizing with the farmers, Mr. Blair will probably call a general election in May -- something The Sun, Britain's biggest tabloid, supports.
In California, consumers have had even longer to get used to the crisis (the problems with power emerged last year). The Public Utility Commission is also inflicting the price rises mainly on businesses rather than homes; many consumers will only suffer indirectly. 
The prevailing emotion among both Britons and Californians seems to be resignation: "We had it coming," one Hollywood executive explained, using the same words heard often in London. In many cases, this is linked to a suspicion that people are paying the price for unfettered capitalism. What on earth, Britons ask, was a farm in Northumberland doing feeding Asian meat to their pigs? In California, deregulation is often blamed for the energy crisis.
Whether this detached fatalism is realistic is another matter. It is already clear in Britain that foot-and-mouth is about far more than just farming. The much bigger tourism industry stands to lose $1.5 billion to $5 billion this year -- twice as much as the farmers. The deathly quiet that has fallen on many of the more beautiful parts of Britain has been caused not only by the much-cited "silence of the lambs," but also by the silence of American tour buses and holidaying German cyclists.
In California, electricity may be an old industry, but it is the lifeblood of the new economy. Price rises and, particularly, power cuts threaten not just Silicon Valley, but also California's core competence -- persuading ambitious people from all over the world to come to the state. Indian programmers will not flock to work in a hot place where the air-conditioning keeps breaking down. They can get that in Bangalore.
Another reason to be relatively pessimistic about California is that its crisis will last longer. The acrid smoke drifting across Wordsworth country may be grimly apocalyptic; but by the end of this summer, Britain should have killed or vaccinated enough animals to get rid of the disease. By contrast, the imbalance between the demand and supply of energy in California may not be fixed until 2003. And there is already talk that last week's price rise will not be enough to cover the state's bills.
Meanwhile, the deeper arguments about unfettered capitalism seem far from finished. People throughout Europe, already angry about mad cow disease (which unlike foot-and-mouth is dangerous to humans), call for more barriers against food imports, and more rules for agribusiness. Consolidation in the slaughterhouse industry helped spread foot-and-mouth, forcing infected animals to be driven around the country. 
Economic liberals reply that farming is the most protected and regulated industry in Britain (as it is everywhere in the Western world). The disease may have been partly spread by farmers' "bed-and-breakfasting" sheep, selling animals on a short-term basis just to claim subsidies.
Neither side seems ready to admit that bad luck played a role. Foot-and-mouth is, literally, a disease that can blow in from anywhere: it is carried by the wind. The route by which infected Asian meat found its way to a restaurant in northern England and was then fed as leftovers to pigs was a haphazard affair few could have predicted.
While foot-and-mouth might be excused as an act of God, California's electricity mess is man-made. But by whom? President Bush has jumped at the chance to imply that environmental regulators have held back the energy industry. Governor Davis, who clearly still hopes to enter the Democratic primaries in 2004, attacks greedy out-of-state power providers.
EVEN when you reach the heart of the problem, the state's regulatory system, another smog descends. Many on the left blame liberalization. Free-marketers reply that "deregulation" in the mid-1990's does not deserve that label. The state protected its incumbent suppliers, making it difficult for competitors to get into the market. It imposed rules that seem downright Soviet -- rate freezes that oblige suppliers to sell power at a small fraction of the price they pay for it.
The bigger, more complicated arguments about the cause of the crises may recede into the background as long as most Californians and Britons continue to grin and bear it. If, on the other hand, frustrations, perhaps heightened by gloomier economic news, begin to boil to the surface, the politics could change dramatically. That will be the test of the coming long hot summers in both Britain and California.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Milosevic Is Accused, but All of Serbia Is on Trial

BYLINE:  By BLAINE HARDEN 

 BODY:
THE moves by Serb officials to arrest Slobodan Milosevic late last week appear to be an effort to meet Yugoslavia's most pressing need.
 The erstwhile Serb strongman was cornered by the authorities in time to meet a deadline imposed by the United States. This keeps war-ruined Yugoslavia on track to rejoin the world as a respectable democracy. It also seems likely to unlock access to $50 million in American aid, as well as hundreds of millions of dollars in loans from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. 
 But what will the government of Vojislav Kostunica do with Mr. Milosevic, a demagogue who arguably is responsible for more death, war and mayhem in Europe than anyone since Hitler?
How that question is answered could go a long way in determining whether Serbs come to grips with the barbaric crimes, including mass murder, that were committed in their name in Kosovo, Croatia and, especially, in Bosnia.
The international community knows what it wants. In May 1999, the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague indicted Mr. Milosevic in connection with atrocities in Kosovo. On Friday, after hearing news of efforts to arrest him, the tribunal repeated its position that Yugoslavia has an obligation under international law to turn over Mr. Milosevic and to do it quickly.
The Bush administration has not insisted that he be transferred immediately, but it has said that it expects Yugoslavia to "ultimately cooperate." 
Yet inside Serbia, the dominant republic in what remains of the Yugoslav federation that Mr. Milosevic did so much to destroy, the question is far more complicated.
Mr. Kostunica, who came to power last October after a popular revolt forced Mr. Milosevic to step down, is both a Serb nationalist and a thoughtful constitutional lawyer. The nationalist side of Mr. Kostunica, which was a key to his attracting the votes needed to defeat Mr. Milosevic in an election last fall, has balked at being bossed around by the United States and the international community. He has criticized the Hague tribunal as being biased against Serbia.
The thoughtful lawyer, however, has conceded that cooperation with The Hague is in the long-term interests of his country. The economy of Yugoslavia was all but destroyed during Milosevic's reign. The country became an international pariah, its educated elite fled and NATO bombs dropped during the Kosovo war destroyed factories and infrastructure. Many officials in the new government have said that sheltering Milosevic from The Hague is not worth losing desperately needed foreign aid.
One likely scenario, supported by public opinion polls in Serbia, would have Mr. Milosevic tried in Belgrade. Likely charges include embezzlement of state funds, involvement in a number of unsolved killings of Serb officials and the purchase of his state villa at a bargain price.
These accusations, however, seem unlikely to get at the iniquitous heart of Mr. Milosevic's rule. While losing four wars and plunging Serbia into poverty, he nevertheless succeeded for nearly 13 years in tapping into a collective soft spot in the Serbian psyche.
Even as his proxy armies robbed, raped and murdered innocent civilians across much of what used to be Yugoslavia, Mr. Milosevic found widespread popular support by convincing many Serbs that they were the victims of a worldwide conspiracy. Before last October, he won three elections that were more or less fair.
A criminal trial in Belgrade for embezzlement or even murder would not expose the ways in which thousands of Serbs were involved in and profited from war crimes committed by Mr. Milosevic's government. During the Bosnian war, for instance, hundreds upon hundreds of tractor-trailer loads of stolen goods were transported out of Bosnia and into Serbia for resale. 
A war crimes trial in The Hague is far more likely to explain how the Serbs themselves sustained Mr. Milosevic, while ignoring evidence of Serbian crimes against humanity in Bosnia, such as the siege of Sarajevo and mass murder in Srebrinica.
As in the war crimes trials in Nuremberg that followed World War II, a trial in The Hague could systematically lay bare the inner workings of the Milosevic regime before a world audience that included Serbs.
A recent poll in Serbia suggested that there was growing acceptance of this kind of outcome in any arrest of Mr. Milosevic. More than half of Serbs said they would not object if their former leader was extradited to The Hague.
For years leading up to the popular revolt that toppled Mr. Milosevic last year, many Serbs said they found it impossible to imagine a time when their country would escape international isolation and economic privation. They also said they could not imagine why the world blamed them for atrocities in Bosnia and Kosovo.
An arrest of Mr. Milosevic -- and the possibility that he will be tried for crimes against humanity -- has the potential to redress both of these failures of imagination, restoring Serbia to its place in the community of nations while revealing the Serbs to themselves.
