HEADLINE: Del Webb Corp. Is Scaling Back Near Hilton Head 

BYLINE:  By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: BLUFFTON, S.C. 

 BODY:
THE builders of the Sun City retirement communities came here six years ago hoping to transplant large-volume building practices honed in a western desert to an eastern pine barren.
 But after sales that never matched expectations, executives at the Del Webb Corporation have decided to scale back plans for its Sun City Hilton Head community. They are negotiating to sell 1,000 of the 5,600 acres the company owns, which would let it finish the development early, perhaps by 2006, instead of 2013. 
 In all, 6,500 homes would be built, instead of the 8,500 originally planned. Del Webb has sold 2,200 so far. The company has also decided against building a third golf course. A similar reduction is under way at Del Webb's Sun City development in Georgetown, Tex. 
The change was spurred partly by sluggish sales here, but also by a revised strategic plan designed to increase earnings. The company intends to move toward building smaller developments that require less time and money to build. The plan was announced in March after a takeover attempt and stockholder revolt last fall.
"Del Webb is a Phoenix, Ariz.-based company and its success is based on a western development model," said M. Lewis Hammet, a spokesman for Sun City Hilton Head. Alluding to the climate, the semitropical growing conditions in which vegetation flourishes and the labor market here as compared with the West, he added: "You don't have to contend with rainy weather. Del Webb was used to trying to make things grow, not stopping them from growing, and the cost of labor here was far above what it is there."
Initially, the company expected to sell 500 homes a year in a development about 13 miles inland from Hilton Head Island, which has grown in the last three decades from a sleepy sea island to become one of South Carolina's pre-eminent resort communities.
In its best year, 1999, Sun City Hilton Head sold 425 homes. In the fiscal year that ended in June, the company sold 364 homes, ranging from 1,100 to 2,940 square feet and costing $119,000 to $315,900. The company also has a more expensive section, Riverbend, in which houses sell for $270,900 to $393,00 and range from 2,240 to 3,500 square feet.
The 1999 sales total of 425 does not include the 310-lot Riverbend section, which Mr. Hammet said was selling more quickly that expected. 
The reduction in the scope of the project did not come as a complete surprise to area residents. Last year, the company laid off 47 employees here and the year before lowered its age restriction to 50 from 55 to raise sales.
The development includes a 45-acre recreation area known as Town Square, which features a social hall, an arts and crafts center, a fitness center and sports facilities like tennis courts and a softball field.
The Del Webb Corporation, founded in 1960 by Del E. Webb, a former owner of the New York Yankees, represented a new concept in retirement living centered on recreation and limiting ownership to residents older than 55. In its first year, Phoenix Sun City sold 1,300 units and convinced bankers and investors that the idea had merit.
AT the same time, Mr. Webb's company was building Chicago's sports stadiums -- Comiskey Park, Wrigley Field and Soldiers Field -- and planning a corporate community known as Oak Brook, Ill., that is now headquarters for McDonald's and Ace Hardware. , 
Besides the South Carolina and Texas developments, Del Webb owns retirement communities in Phoenix, Tucson, Las Vegas, Palm Desert, Chicago, Ocala and Lincoln, Calif. 
From the beginning, Sun City Hilton Head faced challenges that other developments did not. It was farther away from its natural market in larger cities than the western communities are and the company's name was virtually unknown here. Corporate research showed that 90 percent of Southern Californians knew Del Webb and what type of business it was in. Few here had the same response. 
In addition, the company did not sell the lots to buyers, who, in turn, would bring in their own builder and decide what to build, as was common in Carolina coastal resorts. The company sold the entire package, bringing in its own contractors to build one of 14 designs after about 90 percent of the lots in a specific neighborhood had been sold. 
Del Webb executives have now decided to allow outside contractors here.
Contributing to sluggish sales were two record floods over the last six years and a tight labor market. South Carolina generally and Beaufort County specifically have among the lowest unemployment rates in the nation. 
Mr. Hammet said even though sales had never been what corporate executives had hoped, Del Webb had been by far the largest builder in the area. 
"Del Webb will continue to be here," he said. "We will shorten the cycle of return on investment. Del Webb is becoming more sensitive to investor concerns."
Last fall, the J. F. Shea Company, a Walnut, Calif., builder, offered $1.6 billion for Del Webb. The offer was for $30 a share for Webb's common stock, or $600 million, plus the assumption of Del Webb's debt. Del Webb fought back with allegations that Shea did not have the resources to accomplish the buyout.
At the same time, Pacific Partners, a Phoenix group of investors that owned 5.5 percent of Del Webb stock, tried to get two seats on Del Webb's board. Led by a former Del Webb executive and three Phoenix business leaders, the group called Del Webb's stock performance abysmal and management salaries excessive.
The company's slate of board members prevailed by only a 5 percent margin, a message that shareholders wanted a better return. After the meeting, Shea dropped its takeover bid. 
Mr. Hammet said negotiations were under way with several companies for the 1,000 acres, some of which would likely be developed as commercial or office complexes.
"Those looking at the land have been widely celebrated for doing upscale commercial developments," he said. "We don't want strip malls."
RESIDENTS, meanwhile, generally are taking a wait-and-see attitude about the sale and how it might affect their lives and their pocketbooks.
Herbert Sirowitz, 69, a retired certified public accountant from Pittsburgh, said he was somewhat concerned about Del Webb's change in plans. 
"I understand their rationale, but I'm not pleased," he said. "It may hurt people like us who came in expecting Del Webb to develop the entire community."
There is no assurance that whoever buys the land will maintain the same standards as Del Webb, he said, and contractors who come in to build individual homes may not be made to live by the same rules and regulations that have been in effect here.
"If Del Webb's making a profit, some should go to benefit the people," he said. "There could be some controversy down the road." 
Maureen Hermiston, 63, who moved here four years ago from Boston and is now the president of the Sun City Republican Club, said she did not expect the sale to affect her in any way. She said she came for the climate and to be closer to her grandchildren.
"The amenities are as they promised," she said. "It's a lovely setting. There is no utopia anywhere."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Homes in the Del Webb Corporation's Sun City Hilton Head development, above, and the town square. (Photographs by Lynn Riddle for The New York Times) Map of South Carolina highlighting Bluffton.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
An 11th-Hour Checklist For Saving on Taxes

BYLINE:  By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
Some last-minute tax filers get so panicky that they forget to sign their returns or put a stamp on the envelope. But even less-frenzied taxpayers may overlook money-saving opportunities.
 A checklist was offered by Laurence I. Foster, a partner in Richard A. Eisner & Company, a New York accounting firm, and chairman of the committee of personal financial specialists of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. 

FILING STATUS -- "Head of household" is more advantageous than "single," and a single parent with whom a child lives may qualify, even if a divorced spouse claims a dependency exemption for the child. "Married filing jointly" has the lowest rates, and a widow or widower may claim such a status for up to two years.

DIVIDENDS -- Some fund payments are a return of capital. No tax is owed on it, so check the Form 1099 before reporting it as a dividend.

DISASTER AREAS -- If you live in a federal disaster area, like Seattle, which was hit by an earthquake, you may claim a deduction for unreimbursed losses exceeding 10 percent of your adjusted gross income plus $100. You may claim a loss that occurred in 2001 on your 2000 tax return, so you get a refund sooner.

WITHHOLDING TAX -- If your employer went out of business and did not send you a Form W-2, you should still report the income and claim the tax withheld -- you may be due a refund. Attach a copy of your last pay stub and explain that you did not receive a W-2.

CHARITABLE DEDUCTIONS -- Do not overlook old clothes, furniture and other donations to charities. They are deductible at fair market value, not your original cost.
Among common tax traps, Mr. Foster said, are these:

ERRONEOUS W-2's AND 1099'S -- Taxpayers are responsible for what they report, so if you received an incorrect Form W-2 or 1099, get a corrected one.

OVERLOOKING TAXABLE INCOME -- Unemployment compensation may be taxable, and depending on other income received, Social Security benefits may be taxable. Interest on municipal bonds from another state may be taxable in your state.
If you have filed your 2000 return and realize you fell into a trap or missed an opportunity, you can file an amended return, Form 1040X. Jan M. Rosen

HEADLINE: Last Call for Silicon Alley's Famous Wingdings 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
IT will be remembered as the party when Silicon Alley danced on the lip of the volcano. Some 14 months ago, the invitations to DoubleClick's Willy Wonka-themed party, now legendary, were sent inside the wrappers of chocolate bars. Orange-skinned Oompa-Loompa bartenders served 2,000 guests at the Roxy, where purple-skinned women bopped on stage. The decor included psychedelic mushrooms, looming towers of candy and cream-filled boulders.
 That was then. Now, the frenetic socializing that distinguished Manhattan's Internet workers from their West-Coast counterparts has been downsized, like everything else about the dot-com industry. DoubleClick held an elaborate Egyptian-themed bash this year, shortly before cutting 10 percent of its staff. 
 For most companies, the era of free-flowing financing, visions and liquor that hit its peak last year has faded. Now it's pretzels instead of sushi, strictly a cash bar and an office space instead of a downtown club. 
"Sometimes you are lucky if there is any food," said Courtney Pulitzer, the host of Cocktails with Courtney, a long-running Silicon Alley networking event, attended by 600 at its peak. It now draws fewer than 100 people. 
The parties that have survived have become more low-key events, more focused and sometimes more costly to attend. Ms. Pulitzer now exacts a $25 cover charge to parties that once were free, as shrinking corporate marketing budgets have made sponsorships harder to come by. 
"Parties are alive and kicking," insisted Bernardo Joselevich, who runs Bernardo's List, a weekly e-mail listing sent to 11,000 Internet-industry workers. Started a year and a half ago, the mailing list rode the dot-com boom, and the party boom, to become a kind of social glue for Silicon Alley. "The parties have not gone south as far as the Nasdaq," he said. You just have to look harder for them.
A year ago, Bernardo's List would regularly include three or four lavish parties a night that were open to all, and up to a dozen on Thursdays, many featuring catered fare. Now the actual parties on the list are rare, buried among forums such as "Survivors: Silicon Alley," and "Your Road to Profitability." 
At one party a few weeks ago, introducing Metamorphnet.com's new Web site, the invitation noted that hors d'oeuvres were free, but it was a cash bar. That disincentive, combined with a rainy evening and a downtown location, produced a thin crowd. 
Springing up as it did overnight, with thousands of newcomers rushing to start businesses, Silicon Alley's party scene was more than a diversion; it was an effective way of doing business, events where potential financing, employees and dates could all be gathered at once. 
Events that began as intimate gatherings with a sense of camaraderie became bloated affairs, designed to serve the ends of corporate marketing, with their own professional coordinators and public relations firms. Fueled by venture capital, companies bought their way to buzz, subsidizing the bodies that came to their fetes, and to their Web sites, with millions of dollars.
Now as so many in the dot-com industry have gone to ground, the social events that survive have evolved. They tend to be selective, invitation-only, designed to introduce key players to one another. Ms. Pulitzer's latest cocktail invitation, for example, was sent out only to what she called her A-List, a group of "decision makers." 
Jason McCabe Calacanis, editor of the Silicon Alley Reporter, whose early issues were filled with party pictures in imitation of celebrity glossies, and who once gave lavish parties with sushi chefs serving in elevators, now plays host only to small gatherings for senior executives. "I don't publicize them," he said. "The networking has matured. It's elite. It's purposeful."
This shift has drawn some executives who had lost interest in the frat-like atmosphere of earlier parties. 
"I'm looking to meet the decision makers," said Susan Hoffberg, a director of marketing and business development with Arthur Andersen, at a recent Silicon Alley Reporter dinner that included a number of Internet chief executives. "They weren't there at those types of parties. Instead it was a lot of young people looking for free drinks."
Mr. Joselevich, for his part, has been encouraging readers of his list to keep their chins up. "Let's all be strong and party with what we have," he wrote not long ago. But some readers don't like the new, whistle-a-happy-tune tone. 
After the last such e-mail, Mr. Joselevich said, he received 10 times the usual number of requests to be dropped from the list.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
To Evaluate The Economy, Take Detroit's Temperature

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
FORGET about Microsoft, Cisco Systems and Oracle. When looking at specific companies to figure out whether the nation's economy is growing or shrinking, Detroit still offers the best approach. And the auto industry is showing surprising signs of short-term health, although executives worry that trouble may be on the way.
 While Internet and computer companies ballooned in value on Wall Street over the last decade, not one became very big as a share of the nation's economic output, which is based on sales of goods and services, not stock prices. 
 General Motors and Ford Motor each still account for more than a full percentage point of the gross domestic product, while Microsoft is about one-sixth of 1 percent -- not much more than a rounding error, by economic standards. G.M.'s sales of Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra full-size pickup trucks alone, at roughly $15 billion a year, easily exceed the annual sales of Oracle or Amazon.com.
So while much of the technology sector may be heading into a slump and dragging down Wall Street with it, how is the auto industry faring? Fairly well, notwithstanding the announcement on Thursday that Delphi Automotive Systems will shrink its work force by 11,500, mainly through retirements.
The auto industry considers annual sales of 16 million to indicate a strong market. Sales dipped to an annual pace of 15.4 million in December, prompting G.M., Ford and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler to cut production sharply in the first quarter. But sales in January suggested a 17.2 million annual pace, while February came in at 17.5 million. Most automakers will not announce their March sales until Tuesday, but these appear to be strong, too, although still down 7 percent from an extraordinary burst in the same month last year.
"We were all genuinely surprised at January and February," said Dieter Zetsche, Chrysler's chief executive, in an interview. "Now, March seems like it will come in again at 17 million."
The question facing auto executives is how much longer sales can remain almost immune to economic problems elsewhere. The answer, auto executives and economists say, depends on what is causing weakness in the economy now.
If this is a traditional inventory correction, in which excess supplies of goods are sold and then economic growth resumes, the auto industry is probably in pretty good shape. Inventories have fallen sharply. Sales appear to have declined 7 percent in the first quarter, while North American production by domestic and foreign manufacturers has plunged 18 percent.
Imports have been little changed but account for only one-sixth of the market, so their effect on inventories is modest.
What worries Detroit is the possibility that the current economic weakness is more than just an inventory correction. With most people investing more and saving less, the stock market's performance may be more important to the economy and to consumer confidence -- one of the best indicators of future sales.
BUT the idea that Wall Street now plays a central role in determining consumer confidence, as opposed to traditional factors like the unemployment rate, took a hard knock last Tuesday. That was when the Conference Board said its consumer confidence index rose in the first three weeks of March, when stock market indexes were plunging.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has publicly leaned toward the view that the nation's economy is in a temporary, inventory-led correction, and that sustaining consumer confidence, but not necessarily holding up the stock market, is the key to preventing a longer downturn. That is consistent with Detroit's view.
While auto industry economists still expect a slowdown later this year, the reduction in inventories that has already occurred provides some relief for auto workers, who may face fewer short-term layoffs. George Pipas, a market analyst at Ford, says the auto industry already has its biggest production cuts behind it unless sales deteriorate more than expected. With 4.7 million Americans working for automakers and their suppliers, and most earning high wages, fewer weeklong shutdowns of factories could mean more public confidence and more spending.
How much this will help the automakers' own bottom lines -- and their stock prices -- is less clear. Spring is the biggest selling season, when no automaker likes to lose market share. With more factories churning out cars, and little likelihood that sales will equal last year's torrid pace, automakers are already preparing to offer rebates and other incentives in the months ahead.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Fewer Fish in an M.I.T. Pond

BYLINE:  By Lynnley Browning

 BODY:
 Forget e-tailers gone bust and pink-slip parties. The latest sign of the new-economy crash is at the $50K Entrepreneurship Competition of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
Once a hot event in the venture capital world, the $50K this year has the fizz of day-old Champagne. 
 Fewer venture capitalists are participating, said Elad Gil, M.I.T. Ph.D. '01, the organizer, and those who are "seem more interested in a look around or in offering moral support" than in writing checks to student entrepreneurs. Even M.I.T.'s students are shying away -- entries plummeted to 135 teams chasing the $50,000 prize, compared with 206 last year. The winner will be announced on May 16. Jonathan Goldstein, a contest judge and a partner at TA Associates, a Boston venture capital firm, said "It's no longer a feeding frenzy." Lynnley Browning

HEADLINE: As the Market Goes, So Go the Rewards of Many Company Directors 

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON

 BODY:
CHIEF executives of big companies may have been largely insulated from the stock market's swoon, but many outside directors have not. These board members, often paid largely in stock or stock options, are feeling shareholders' pain this year, according to an analysis by Pearl Meyer & Partners, an executive compensation consultant in New York that reviewed proxy statements at 72 of the 200 large companies it regularly surveys. 
 Directors at corporate giants like General Electric, Goldman Sachs and Compaq Computer have seen the value of their compensation fall this year, at least on paper, by tens of thousands of dollars, according to Pearl Meyer, whose estimate of a typical director's compensation includes a value placed on the stock or stock options doled out. At Compaq, for example, total compensation for a typical director declined more than $100,000, to around $250,000, as the company's shares have fallen. 
 "It's working exactly the way it is supposed to," said Nell Minow, a longtime shareholder activist who is now editor of the Corporate Library (www.thecorporatelibrary.com), a Web site on corporate governance. 
In addition to paying directors their retainers in cash or stock, many companies have moved to stock options. "Today, we are finding more and more companies adding options," said Rhoda G. Edelman, a managing director at Pearl Meyer. 
Consider Hewlett-Packard. While three-quarters of its annual $100,000 retainer has traditionally been paid in stock, according to the company's proxy statements, outside directors were also given a one-time option grant for 40,000 shares last year. Their value helped push total compensation for a typical Hewlett-Packard director to about $265,000. 
Hewlett-Packard made the awards as part of its overall effort to link pay to performance, a company spokesman said, and to remain competitive in paying directors.
Companies have long expected directors to own some shares, but the push to compensate directors with some form of stock came about over the last decade. It stemmed from a desire to align their interests with those of shareholders. "The person needs to have some skin in the game," said Donald C. Hambrick, a business professor at Columbia University. But Mr. Hambrick, for one, worried that some directors might view options as "found money" and behave differently than they would if they actually owned a significant stake in a company, especially one they bought with their own money. 
SOME companies still rely largely on cash. At Genuine Parts, the auto parts maker based in Atlanta, the directors are paid in cash -- $49,000 a year, according to Pearl Meyer. Their relatively small equity stakes put them among the lowest-paid directors of the large companies evaluated. 
The directors, all of whom own some company shares, have the option of taking their pay in stock, said Jerry Nix, the chief financial officer of Genuine Parts, and some have done so. "They're capable of making their own decision," he said. 
While some companies, like Hewlett-Packard, are increasing the amount of equity they give to directors, Ms. Edelman said compensation for directors was likely to remain stable in the coming year, at about $140,000, at the 200 companies it evaluates. Only one-fourth of the 72 companies reviewed have chosen to give directors more equity this year.
But the increase in equity as a form of compensation has led to six-figure pay packages for many board members in the last few years. A typical director at the 200 large companies can expect to receive roughly twice as much as he or she could expect in 1994, when the pay averaged $79,000, according to Pearl Meyer. 
At the high end, the figures can be stunning. Cisco Systems, for example, pays a typical director more than $650,000, virtually all in equity, according to Pearl Meyer, which estimated the equity's value at the company's stock price at the time of its annual meeting last fall. Cisco pays its directors with equity to align their interests with shareholders, a company spokesman said.
One executive whose directors are among the highest paid defended the largess. "You're not paying them for the actual time spent," he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Directors may find themselves spending inordinate amounts of time if companies have unexpected debacles, whether a result of a failed strategy or the discovery of accounting fraud. "You're paying them for carrying the responsibility, losing a night's sleep," he said.

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
It's a Good Living, But Not Like Industry

BYLINE:  By JULIAN E. BARNES

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN may deserve a fair share of the credit for an economy that lifted the fortunes of American chief executives, but he shared little of the spoils. This year he will earn $161,239.
 The slowing economy and the stock market tumble may -- or may not -- start to put the brakes on chief executives' pay. But the captains of industry still take home far more than the top managers in government, sports, academia and nonprofit organizations. 
 There is little question that government work shows the starkest imbalance between money and power. The nation's best-paid governor, George E. Pataki of New York, earns $179,000. Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, will take home $258,552 this year. And George W. Bush, America's M.B.A.-in-chief, will make $400,000.
That is double what Bill Clinton earned, but as Mr. Bush knows well, the real money is in baseball. After all, the team of which he was a part-owner, the Texas Rangers, is paying Alex Rodriguez, its new shortstop, $23 million this year.
Sports are one of the few areas in which employees make more than management. But sports executives are not hurt for cash. Joe Torre, the manager of the New York Yankees, earns $3 million a year, and his crosstown rival, Bobby Valentine of the Mets, will make $2.45 million this year. They both make more than Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, who gets $2 million. Mr. Selig's salary is not shabby, but Vince McMahon outscores him, earning $2,250,073 last year overseeing the World Wrestling Federation and the XFL.
Given the quality of play in the XFL, it may be no surprise that Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, earns even more -- $5 million in 1999, according to the league office. (The 2000 figure has not yet been disclosed.)
Somewhere between elected officials and sports managers are the leaders of universities, museums and foundations.
In 1999, Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, made $483,479, plus $84,868 in benefits and $148,111 for expenses. Ellen V. Futter, president of the American Museum of Natural History, earned $441,959, and Paul LeClerc, president of the New York Public Library, earned $419,000, but, his spokeswoman said, that includes his $227,000 salary, $77,000 in benefits and a $115,000 housing allowance.
Susan Berresford, president of the Ford Foundation, earned $487,500 in 1999, plus $116,636 in benefits. Robert T. Coonrod, chief executive of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, earned $151,800 in both 1999 and 2000.
Judith Rodin, president of the University of Pennsylvania, earned $603,165 in the 1998-99 academic year.
Harvard University has been silent about the salary of its newly appointed president, Lawrence H. Summers. Still, he no doubt got a raise from his salary as Treasury secretary of $161,200 and will earn more than the retiring president, Neil Rudenstine, who made $315,000 in the 1998-99 academic year -- less than Joseph B. Martin, the dean of Harvard Medical School, who made $340,000, but more than Kim B. Clark, the dean of Harvard Business School, who made $278,000.
The real money at Harvard is in managing the investments of its $19 billion endowment. Jack Meyer, president of the Harvard Management Company, earned $1,573,567 in the 1998-99 academic year. Good money, but as in baseball, it was little compared with what his sluggers make. Philip J. Dubuque, a Harvard Management vice president, earned $9,494,658, and at least four other vice presidents earned $5 million to $8.9 million, because of incentive programs.
Leaders of nonprofit advocacy organizations are not so well compensated. Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club, earned $127,256 in 1999. Ira Glasser, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, earned $206,000. David N. O'Steen, executive director of the National Right to Life Committee, earned $96,700. The Rev. Jesse Jackson received $120,000 as head of the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition but earned a total of $430,000 thanks to speaking fees and a $5,000-a-week salary from CNN. Horace B. Deets, executive director of AARP, earned $369,000, plus $141,806 in retirement benefits. 
John Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, got a $33,000 raise in January, his first since 1993. That brought his annual pay to $225,000. Mr. Sweeney said he thought that was "a pretty good salary." But it is far less than those of company chiefs he squares off against.
"It's shameful that C.E.O. pay is going through the roof despite the fact that Wall Street is sliding," Mr. Sweeney said.
He complained that the average chief executive in the United States made 400 times the pay of a manufacturing worker, while Japanese chief executives made only 11 times workers' wages. 
Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said the comparison could not be more apt. Japanese chief executives' pay is not linked to performance, so there is little incentive to take risks and Japan's economy has suffered, he said. Mr. Donohue, who serves on the compensation committee of several companies, contended that in the United States, bonuses went only to executives who performed well and that with the stock market in decline, options would be worth much less.
THE economic boom may be fading, but the heads of trade associations have benefited during its run. For many years, Jack Valenti, chief executive of the Motion Picture Association of America, was at the top of the pack. This year, Mr. Valenti will make about $1.2 million, the association said. That no longer beats Frank G. Zarb, chief executive of the National Association of Securities Dealers. In 1999, when he was also chief executive of Nasdaq, he earned $4,335,397. (The New York Stock Exchange, a private company, refused to disclose the compensation of Richard A. Grasso, its chairman -- as did Nasdaq for its new chief, Hardwick Simmons.)
Mr. Donohue says pay for the heads of trade associations like his has edged up as the work has grown more sophisticated and the lobbying requirements broader. He made made $900,000 in 1999; He makes more now, but is coy about the details: "I'll tell you I make as much or more than Valenti," he said.

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
Overseas, Salaries Are Kept Hush-Hush

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
DAIMLERCHRYSLER will gladly tell anyone who inquires that it sold 4.7 million cars and trucks last year, employed 416,501 people in 37 countries and has 1.9 million shareholders around the world. But if a shareholder, say, asks how much the company pays its chief executive, Jurgen Schrempp, the information flow dries up.
 "We don't publish that," a company spokeswoman said. Although Americans own 17 percent of DaimlerChrysler's shares and its board members pay lip service to American corporate standards, Mr. Schrempp's total compensation -- salary, incentives and bonuses -- is secret. And it will probably remain that way. 
 That is traditional in Germany, as it is in France, Italy, Spain and most of the rest of Europe. Even as Europeans have reached around the world for investors, they have resisted pressure for greater disclosure of corporate information, including executive salaries, bonuses and share options. Britain is a notable exception. Accounting rules there require some disclosure of boardroom pay -- but no control of it by shareholders. 
European discretion has not prevented controversy. Nor has a pay scale that is modest compared with that for American executives. A shareholders group in Germany estimated that Mr. Schrempp received about $2.9 million in 1999 -- and deplored that sum as "shameless." Few were assuaged by the knowledge that Mr. Schrempp's salary was less than one-fifth the $16 million that Chrysler's chairman, Robert Eaton, was paid the year before Daimler-Benz bought his company.
Relatively modest executive pay is traditional in Europe, where business leaders have been more egalitarian and labor unions more militant. That is beginning to change, to the irritation of individual German investors who only recently began to put their money into stocks.
"The size of salaries at German public companies is peanuts compared to the U.S., anywhere between $500,000 and $2 million in the big car companies," said Daniela Bergdolt, a lawyer and shareholder activist in Munich. "But they are getting bigger with bonuses and stock options and so forth, and these variables are not disclosed. That is upsetting some investors."
Some Europeans, particularly fund managers and other institutional investors in Britain, say they do not mind the extra money paid in bonuses and options, provided that it is linked to smart management and solid gains on the stock market.
"We don't mind paying a great deal for stellar performance," said Peter Montagnon, the head of investment affairs at the Association of British Insurers. Its members hold one-fourth of the shares on the London Stock Exchange and control $1.4 trillion in assets. "We would rather have the performance and pay for it than put up with mediocrity."
BUT what if the benefits are not so obvious, and the bonuses are paid only for nimble deal making? Consider Fred Goodwin, the chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland, whose compensation last year zoomed to $3 million -- 250 percent more than in 1999. That included a bonus of about $1.2 million for his part in the bank's takeover of National Westminster Bank.
The increase made him the highest-paid banking chief executive in Britain, even ahead of Matthew Barrett, the chief executive of Barclays P.L.C., who was paid about $2.6 million last year in the first part of a remuneration package that could be worth $45 million over three years.
Such is the furor over the newest bonuses paid at the Royal Bank that representatives of some its largest institutional shareholders are threatening to vote out two directors who sit on the compensation committee -- Sir Iain Vallance and Sir Angus Grossart -- at the bank's annual meeting on April 11.
Many investors are particularly unhappy that Mr. Goodwin's payment came before the benefits of the National Westminster acquisition had been proved.
Still, Mr. Goodwin's paycheck was less than one-fifth the $15 million paid last year to Lawrence Fish, chief executive of the Royal Bank's Boston-based subsidiary, Citizens Financial Group.
A similar paradox emerged when the board of Vodafone awarded the chief, Chris Gent, a $15 million bonus for the acquisition last year of Mannesmann of Germany. (That deal also produced a furor in Germany over a $25 million bonus that Mannesmann paid its chief, Klaus Esser, whose avowed aim had been to keep his company independent.)
So great was the uproar over Vodafone's generosity toward Mr. Gent that the company -- the world's largest mobile phone business -- was obliged to apologize in public and promise not to do it again. It was not the first time that Mr. Gent had rued the difference between standards in the United States and those in Britain, where investors seek to tie bonuses to long-term achievements.
After he led Vodafone's $60 billion acquisition of AirTouch in 1999, Mr. Gent was asked whether he stood to make the same $300 million from stock options as AirTouch's Sam Ginn stood to reap from the deal. "Absolutely not," he replied.
OF course, part of the trans-Atlantic distinction lies in the deep cultural divide in attitudes toward success. In the United States, success stands as a beacon to the ambitious of what can be attained -- an outlook that appears to justify the kind of one-time windfall bonuses that bloat some American executive pay deals. In Europe, just as often, success breeds resentment.
That is one reason, despite moves toward more openness about corporate accounts, that individual salaries, bonuses and other perquisites are simply not disclosed in much of continental Europe. When Goran Lindahl, then chief executive of ABB, the Zurich-based engineering giant, was asked in an interview how much he earned, he declined to answer. Mr. Lindahl said he would provide a figure only when the company moved to American accounting rules -- that is, when required to do so.
In Germany, too, only the total amount of basic salary paid to an entire board of directors is routinely disclosed to shareholders. Individual amounts are not given.
The executives' reticence is related to two aspects of the German mentality, said Ms. Bergdolt, the shareholder activist in Munich. "We are not so open as Americans are about our salaries," she said in a telephone interview. "At home, even the children don't know what the father earns. And we have a stronger envy complex. In the U.S.A., if you earn a lot, you show it. In Germany, people don't show how much they earn because we are quicker to envy."
That could also be said of Britain, where the salaries of senior executives at the country's top 100 companies rose by an average of 20.4 percent last year, to around $1 million, according to New Bridge Street, a consulting firm in London. While that total is only about one-twelfth of the annual packages for the most successful American executives, the percentage increase far outstripped the national average pay gain of about 4 percent. 
Another consulting firm, Towers Perrin, said Britain's chief executives were paid 24 times the average manufacturing salary -- the highest multiple in Europe -- compared with 15 in Germany and 13 in Sweden. The average American chief executive made 475 times as much as the average blue-collar worker in 1999, according to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Britain has twice sought to tighten rules on executive pay. A commission led by Lord Cadbury in 1992 urged the creation of compensation committees made up of independent nonexecutive directors. Another, under Sir Richard Greenbury, the former chairman of the retailer Marks & Spencer, proposed the principle that bonuses be linked to performance over several years. The results have been ambiguous.
Compensation committees have come to be regarded as cozy clubs of a few hundred executives, serving as nonexecutive directors on one another's committees and setting one another's rewards. "There is an element of people helping each other to get the cookies out of the jar," said an investor from a leading insurer who spoke on condition of anonymity.
THE notion of performance-linked bonuses has occasionally led to lower awards for some. But it has collided with a corporate credo that pay is one area where even the largest investors should have no veto power. And the Labor government, with Prime Minister Tony Blair's pro-business policies sitting uneasily atop the party's socialist traditions, has shied from requiring shareholder approval of executive pay.
For their part, chief executives generally argue that the high risks they face merit high rewards. And companies say they need to offer executives the prospect of high income to kindle their ambitions and to prevent them from going elsewhere. That was the rationale when HSBC, the descendant of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, doubled the pay of its chairman, Sir John Bond, to $2.4 million in 2000. But generosity apparently is not limited to successful executives, and that annoys investors.
When Robert Ayling quit as chief executive of British Airways last year, for instance, the company had been pushed $361 million into the red, but he left with a $3 million bonus, a lifelong pension worth almost $400,000 a year and free airline travel for him and his family.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Bushspeak; 
The President's Sense of Humor Has Also Been Misunderestimated

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
HOW do you rib a man for his failings and foibles if he spends much of his time ribbing himself? That is a question that President Bush and his aides have clearly asked and just as clearly answered, and what they have decided is that there is no armor or inoculation as effective as self-effacement.
 If you want to call him lazy, you will have to hurry and do it before he gets there first. At the Gridiron Club dinner a week ago, he dreamed aloud of cloning Vice President Dick Cheney; that way, Mr. Bush said, he would not have to do even a stitch of work himself. 
 And if you want to tease him for his tortured use of the English language, well, Mr. Bush is already on top of that as well. His speech at the annual Radio and Television Correspondents Association dinner in Washington on Thursday night steered the event's tradition of comical presidential commentary in a mischievously masochistic direction. In fact, Mr. Bush took out a copy of "George W. Bushisms" (Simon & Schuster Trade, $9.95), a collection of so-called "Accidental Wit and Wisdom of the 43rd President," and reveled in his own ruminations. 
And, true to form, he bungled his delivery (or was it some sort of ironic intention?) as he joked that he had, just hours earlier at a news conference, coined the word "misunderstand," when what he really said was "misunderestimate."
This is what else he said. FRANK BRUNI
Thank you all very much. Well, Lew Ketcham, the event's chairman , thank you very much. Laura and I are thrilled to be here. I appreciate the members of the press. I think you serve a very useful purpose, especially tonight.
As you know, we're studying safe levels for arsenic in drinking water. (laughter) To base our decision on sound science, the scientists told us we needed to test the water glasses of about 3,000 people. (laughter) Thank you for participating. (laughter)
It's good to see so many members of the Congress here. My fellow Texan, Tom DeLay, here at the head table. (Applause.) Lew asked me a little earlier if Tom ever smiled. I said, "I don't know, I've only known him nine years." (laughter)
Senator Lieberman is here. (Applause.) We all know Joe is an Orthodox Jew, so he does no work from sundown Friday until sundown Saturday. This has so impressed me, I myself am thinking of converting. (laughter) So I don't have nothing to do from sundown Saturday to sundown Friday. (laughter) 
Most of you probably didn't know that I have a new book out. Some guy put together a collection of my wit and wisdom -- or, as he calls it, my accidental wit and wisdom. (laughter) But I'm kind of proud that my words are already in book form. So like other authors, I thought I'd read from it tonight. (laughter) It's like the thoughts of Chairman Mao, only with laughs, and not in Chinese. (laughter) 
Here's one from the book -- and I actually said this. (laughter) "I know the human being and fish can coexist peacefully." (laughter) Now, that makes you stop and think. (laughter and applause) Anyone can give you a coherent sentence, but something like this takes you into an entirely new dimension. (laughter)
Here's another: "I understand small business growth; I was one." (laughter) You know, I love great literature. (laughter) 
I actually said this in New Hampshire: "I appreciate preservation. It's what you do when you run for president, you've got to preserve." (laughter) I don't have the slightest idea what I was saying there. (laughter and applause)
Or how about this one: "More and more of our imports come from overseas." (laughter)
Now, most people would say, in speaking of the economy, we ought to make the pie bigger. I, however, am on record saying, "We ought to make the pie higher." (laughter) It is a very complicated economic point I was making there. (laughter) But believe me, what this country needs is taller pie. (laughter and applause)
And how about this for foreign policy vision: "When I was coming up, it was a dangerous world and we knew exactly who the they were. It was us versus them. And it was clear who the them was." (laughter) "Today, we're not so sure who the they are, but we know they're there." (laughter and applause) 
John Ashcroft, by the way, attributes the way I talk to my religious fervor. In fact, the first time we met, he thought I was talking in tongue. (laughter) 
Then there is my most famous statement: "Rarely is the question asked, is our children learning." (laughter) Let us analyze that sentence for a moment. (laughter) If you're a stickler, you probably think the singular verb "is" should have been the plural "are." But if you read it closely, you'll see I'm using the intransitive plural subjunctive tense. (laughter) So the word "is" are correct. (laughter and applause) 
Finally, let's see you wordsmiths out there diagram this sentence I said -- this may sound a little West Texan to you, "but when I'm talking about myself and when he's talking about myself, all of us are talking about me." (laughter) 
Now, ladies and gentlemen, you have to admit, in my sentences I go where no man has gone before. (laughter) 
But in closing, the way I see it is I am a boon to the English language. I've coined new words, like "misunderstanding" and "Hispanically." (laughter) I've expanded the definition of words themselves, using "vulcanized" when I met "polarized," "Grecians" when I meant "Greeks," "inebriating" when I meant "exhilarating." (laughter) And instead of "barriers and tariffs," I said "terriers and bariffs." (laughter)
And you know what? Life goes on. (laughter) My wife and my daughters still love me. (laughter) Our military still protects our shores. (laughter) Americans still get up and go to work. (laughter) People still go out and have fun, as we're doing tonight. 
I don't think it's healthy to take yourself too seriously. But what I do take seriously is my responsibility as president to all the American people. It's the office I hold. And that is what I came tonight to tell you. 
Thank you for inviting me, and thank you for your horspitality. (laughter and applause)

HEADLINE: 2001 BASEBALL PREVIEW; 
For Rodriguez, Attitude Smooths His Transition

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Randy Velarde remembers the night in 1997 when the Seattle Mariners were in Anaheim for the start of a three-game series. His Angels were taking batting practice when a young member of the Mariners walked across to their side of the field.
 "In front of us," Velarde remembered, "he called Larry Bowa, our third base coach, aside and asked him to watch him fielding during the series to see if he saw anything that he could improve on. That just doesn't happen. I thought that was bizarre. But it shows how this guy is going through leaps and bounds to be the best he can be out there. In my opinion, if there's a guy who's worth 252, it's Alex." 
 Velarde is now the second baseman for the Texas Rangers. Alex Rodriguez is the shortstop. They are the highest-paid double-play combination in the major leagues. 
"I'm not taking any part of that," Velarde said.
That's almost true. Rodriguez is making most of it, like Hank Aaron hitting 755 of the brother-record 768 home runs hit by him and Tommie. But one of the major reasons Rodriguez, a free agent, gained his record $252 million contract was the mind-set he exhibited in seeking out Bowa in his third season in the majors.
Rodriguez never stops trying to improve. Seven years into his career and with more money guaranteed than the entire major league roster of players earned in 1984, Rodriguez keeps thinking and keeps working, taking nothing for granted, assuming nothing. He didn't achieve his playing or economic status by resting on his record.
Nor did he bring an I've-got-mine attitude with him to the Rangers.
"He likes to come out early, when I have the kids out there, and do his work," said Bucky Dent, an old shortstop himself and the Rangers' infield coach. "He likes to do a lot of early work. His work ethic has been very good."
In Seattle, Rodriguez was notorious for his diligence and extra work and attention to every detail. While teammates played computer games or cards on team flights, for example, he watched baseball videotapes.
"This guy studies the game more than anybody I've seen," Jay Buhner, a Mariners outfielder, said. "He studies his swing when he's on the airplane. He's got tapes of himself. We used to bust him all the time because he was always watching himself. When we got on the plane to go to another city, he had all his at-bats against the pitchers we'd be facing and he was figuring out what was going on. He's got little tendencies that guys do."
Why does Rodriguez consume himself with study? Why did he seek out Bowa that night in Anaheim, a coach on an opposing team?
"I have a strong need to get better," Rodriguez said one recent afternoon in Port Charlotte, Fla. "I have a monster inside of me. I'm driven. I feel Larry Bowa was one of the best fielders of all time so I felt that a second opinion never hurts from a legend like Larry. Because he's at such a good angle as the third base coach, I thought perhaps he could give me a tip or two that could enhance my game, and it did. There's a few things he saw. He wanted me to be a little more aggressive, work on my rhythm."
Rodriguez worked on his rhythm. He still works on his rhythm, and everything else. 
"He's one of the hardest workers I've ever seen," said Mike Cameron, a Seattle teammate last season. "He had it easy and still he went out and did his job every single day. When you see him doing all that stuff he doesn't have to do, it rubs off on you."
His work ethic, Rodriguez said, was acquired from his mother, Lourdes Navarro. "When our backs were against the wall," he said, "she went out and got two and sometimes three jobs to keep us above water. I was under the impression we were middle class or very high class because we had everything we ever needed. It was because of her tireless work."
Navarro raised her son by herself, and he has become an impressive young man. He is only 25 years old.
"When I met him, I thought he was a grown-up man," Cal Ripken said, recalling how they met when Rodriguez was a high school senior in Miami. "I remember shaking his hand and talking to him a little bit. I was impressed with how he handled himself, how he presented himself physically and emotionally."
Buhner said Rodriguez was "almost too perfect, very robotic, almost where he's programmed."
Edgar Martinez, his close friend and Seattle teammate, said that when Rodriguez joined the Mariners three weeks short of his 19th birthday in 1994, the players immediately saw how advanced in behavior and stature he was.
"He's very mature for his age," Martinez said. "We were able to see that from the beginning. A kid that age, they don't know exactly what they want most of the time. He knew. He knew how to listen, how to watch and learn. He knew he needed to do that."
Rodriguez already has 189 home runs and three 40-homer seasons, and he has collected four Silver Slugger awards as the best-hitting shortstop in the American League. Tom Hicks, the Rangers' owner, saw those achievements last winter, but he also saw the person. It was Hicks's view of the person that sealed the deal and sent the total of the 10-year contract soaring to $252 million.
"To get a contract like that," Johnny Oates, the Rangers' manager, said, "you've got to be able to do more than hit a baseball, field a baseball and throw a baseball. You have to have a lot more going for you."
Unlike many players who secure lucrative contracts as free agents, Rodriguez readily acknowledged that his decision to sign with the Rangers was based in large part on the money.
"Obviously I made an economical decision," he said. "That was a huge factor in my decision, but there were so many positives."
One of those positives, he said, was Hicks, the owner, who also owns the Dallas Stars, the Stanley Cup champions in 1999. The Rangers, who moved to Texas in 1972, have been to the postseason only three times and never advanced past the first round.
"I think this guy's an architect," Rodriguez said of Hicks. "He built a world champion in hockey, he's built a world championship in business and I think he'll do the same thing here."
It was obvious, Rodriguez was told, that he and Hicks impressed each other. "I don't know about me with him," he replied, "but I know he did to me. When I saw him, I thought George Steinbrenner II. This guy has the same desire and hunger. He's driven by winning. He told me: 'Hey, I already have a hockey championship. I want a baseball championship.' That kind of got my juices going."
Rodriguez forevermore will be known not by his uniform number, 3, but by 252. His new teammates, however, say the contract has not affected them.
"No one has said anything about his money, not one," Rafael Palmeiro said. "He makes a lot of money and deservedly. We just want him to play well and help us win, regardless of how much money he makes."
When the Mets ended negotiations for Rodriguez before they started, their general manager, Steve Phillips, talked about his concern that Rodriguez would create a 24-and-1 clubhouse scenario. The Rangers haven't found that.
"Not only is he one of the top two or three players in the game on the field," Rusty Greer said, "but from what I know about Alex Rodriguez in the short time I've been around him, he's a good person and a good guy in the clubhouse. For me that's almost as important as doing a good job on the field. He has fit very well into the team concept and into the chemistry of the team. He has been every bit the leader that we saw on the other side of the field the past few years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alex Rodriguez has brought his skills and work ethic to his new team. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Mired in Debt and Seeking a Path Out 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS 

 BODY:
In promoting a tougher bankruptcy law that President Bush could soon sign, credit card and automobile companies depict a culture of spendthrift deadbeats who are excused from their debts only to go off on another binge. But those are not the people who crowd the corridors of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Memphis.
 Three mornings a week, lawyers, lenders and sullen debtors pour into the plastic chairs in George Stevenson's meeting room on the sixth floor of a black glass cube overlooking the Mississippi. 
 Sitting at a folding table with a computer terminal, Mr. Stevenson, a bankruptcy trustee, works with the rhythm of a clock, ticking through a thick docket of debt-payment plans for the court's three judges to approve, adjust, dismiss or schedule for trial. 
Some of the people here, like others among the more than a million nationwide who declare bankruptcy each year, build their own traps, like working the cash machines at Mississippi's neighboring casinos. In going bankrupt, they raise costs for other debtors, because lenders raise interest rates and fees to cover their losses. But many of the Americans who go bankrupt have only hard luck to blame. 
On this morning, Carl Mauk, 46, edged up to the table and steadied himself with his cane. The steroids he takes to control his severe arthritis have triggered diabetes and left his arms covered in sores. His wife, Priscilla, 42, is homebound with a heart condition.
Because of their health, the Mauks have quit jobs that together paid them more than $4,000 a month, his as head of a crew that laid water pipe for a utility and hers as a secretary. With little more than the $400 a month from Mr. Mauk's mother, who lives with them, they have fallen behind on their court-approved bankruptcy plan, the $1,800 they agreed to send Mr. Stevenson each month for disbursal to creditors. 
"Isn't it time to give up the house?" Mr. Stevenson asked. The Mauks' only measurable assets are her turquoise 1995 Toyota MR2, worth $6,000; his 1989 Volvo 740, worth $1,000; and their two-story brick house on a hill, worth $180,000. Their two mortgages, Mr. Stevenson said, come to $171,000, so by selling the house, "you might get something in the $6,000, $7,000 range."
Calmly, Mr. Mauk explained: "I just need a disability check. It's going to be in the mail." He said his former employer had delayed sending him an overdue payment. Ms. Mauk, meanwhile, is applying for a federal disability benefit that could bring in $500 a month. Rather than ask a judge to dismiss the case and compel the Mauks to sell their home, Mr. Stevenson gave them two more weeks to come up with a payment.
With the economy slowing and unemployment in cities like Memphis rising, the American Bankruptcy Institute reports that numbers of consumer bankruptcies nationwide are creeping up, too. Last year, there were 1.2 million personal bankruptcies. This year, that number is expected to rise. According to data compiled by Lundquist Consulting for banks that issue credit cards, bankruptcy filings increased 20 percent from Jan. 1 to March 3 of this year over the same period last year.
In Tennessee, the relative numbers of personal filings lead the nation. One in 43 Tennessee households filed last year, according to the institute, compared with 1 of 83 in California and 1 in 118 in both New York and Connecticut. According to the Administrative Office for the United States Courts, judges in Tennessee carry one of the heaviest bankruptcy loads in the nation.
Most of the cases come here, to United States Bankruptcy Court for the Western District of Tennessee. It is the second busiest in the country, after the Southern District of Georgia, when it comes to handling Chapter 13 cases, those in which debtors agree to pay off all or part of their debts over three to five years. 
For this reason, Tennessee is a proving ground for the principal change in the proposed bankruptcy law, now being refined in a Senate-House committee. Last year, judges here steered 73 percent of the debtors into Chapter 13, rather than into the more protective Chapter 7, which does not require people to repay their loans. Nationwide, 70 percent of all cases are filed under Chapter 7. (Business bankruptcies fall under Chapter 11.)
To the advocates of the tougher legislation, protection from bankruptcy is consistently abused. 
"Declaring bankruptcy is too easy an option for those who have the ability to pay but not the willingness," said Ken Guenther, chief executive of the Independent Community Bankers of America, an association of 5,400 banks, most of which issue credit cards. 
Among the active Chapter 13 cases here, several support Mr. Guenther's point. A random search of March filings produced the case of a 40-year-old woman who has been in and out of bankruptcy four times in the last eight years, using the courts in Atlanta and Memphis to close the gap between her meager earnings and her high living expenses. 
There was also a 62-year-old machine tool repairman who earns $36,000 a year. He and his wife had been able to carry the $177,000 mortgage on a four-bedroom house worth $185,000, but they got carried away.
The couple bought a 1998 Lincoln Navigator and a 1998 Chevrolet Blazer, incurring a debt of $48,000. They have run up $9,000 in debt for clothes and electronic goods. They bought a $10,000 woman's Rolex watch.
Neither the current law nor Congress's proposed law is likely to let them keep their property. 
The couple could file under Chapter 7 or Chapter 13. Under Chapter 7, they would stand to lose their home and cars, but most of their remaining, unsecured debt would be forgiven. Under Chapter 13, they would most likely keep their property, but depending on their income and basic living expenses, they would also commit to repaying 10 to 100 percent of the unsecured debt. Either way, the unsecured lenders -- like credit card companies and doctors' offices -- stand to lose all or a part of what they are owed. 
Some studies of bankruptcy, however, suggest that such people are in the minority. In Senate testimony in February, Randall J. Newsome, a former president of the National Conference of Bankruptcy Judges, cited a conference-sponsored national study showing that the median household income for personal bankruptcies was $21,540, about $15,000 below the national median. The study was based on 3,151 randomly selected cases filed in 1998.
Reviewing a wider sample of 5,235 cases, Mr. Newsome found that the average age of the debtors' cars was six to nine years and that 25 percent had medical debts exceeding $1,000.
"The multitude of people affected by bankruptcy laws are your lowest strata-class people, your blue-collar people and middle-class people whose companies close or size down and who can't get another job at the same salary," said Lawrence C. King, a law professor at New York University who specializes in bankruptcy law. "Something happens that throws their lives out of kilter." 
Brady C. Williamson, a lawyer in Madison, Wis., who was chairman of the nonpartisan commission that reviewed the existing law for the United States Supreme Court, said the operating premise of proponents of the new law is that the system is filled with people who are able to pay their debts and choose not to. "That," he said, "is a myth." 
In Memphis, the circumstances of people falling into bankruptcy tend to resemble the problems faced by Dimetra Howell more than those faced by owners of Lincoln Navigators. Like the Mauks, Ms. Howell fell into debt as a result of a lost job and a medical emergency.
"A lady poured hot water on my leg," said Ms. Howell, who last summer was working in a convenience store, earning $7 an hour, when a co-worker accidentally spilled a pot on her. The store covered her medical expenses, but she lost her job when her rehabilitation stretched into the fall. In January, she started a new job, paying $6 an hour, as a cashier in a supermarket. Still, Ms. Howell does not own anything of interest to a creditor, and she has fallen $3,500 behind on rent, telephone, utility and credit card bills. 
"I got an eviction notice," she said. A lawyer will be able to block the notice, but with take-home pay of $175 a week to support her two daughters, 9 and 11, Ms. Howell remains exposed to another round of bankruptcy. Under the proposed legislation, she would be unprotected if the landlord ordered her out because she is a repeat filer. 
In Memphis, many people like Ms. Howell sit on the edge because of the preponderance of low-wage service and retail jobs, most of them temporary. Mr. Stevenson said there were more than 100 temporary-help agencies in and around Memphis.
Ben G. Sissman, a lawyer who represents debtors and creditors, said Memphis "has people who are not fully employed."
"They are regular folks who just don't make enough money to live," Mr. Sissman said. "Far from abusing the economy, it's the economy abusing them." 
To cater to people who struggle to scrape by on their earnings, Tennessee has spawned a freewheeling industry of easy lending. On Union Avenue, a billboard proclaims: "Own a new car. Zero down. Credit no problem." Similar advertisements, for all manner of loans, dot the town. 
Lawyers and court officials say cases like Ms. Howell's and the Mauks' make them uneasy about the proposed bankruptcy legislation. Besides allowing landlord evictions and car repossessions of repeat filers, it would force more wage earners to file under Chapter 13. 
"I and every other bankruptcy trustee have been betrayed by the credit card industry," Mr. Stevenson said. "Trustees were never asked for input on that legislation." 
Todd J. Zywicki, a professor at the George Mason University Law School in Arlington, Va., who had a voice as an adviser to Congress, agreed that most people who file are legitimate users of the bankruptcy system. "But," he said, "there are large numbers who are not legitimate users. The bill eliminates the forms of abuse that are out there."
David S. Kennedy, chief judge of the court here, said he welcomed some proposed revisions in the law, like leaving out the names of minor children in filings and permitting the appointment of more judges.
But he added: "Some people have convinced members of Congress that fraud is just running rampant, when it is not. One doesn't need an elephant gun to do away with the relatively few bankruptcy gamers."

HEADLINE: Governor Risks Injury In California Crisis 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., March 31 

 BODY:
From the moment Gray Davis became governor of the largest state two years ago, his name was on the short list of Democratic presidential prospects, if only because of California's size and his 20-point victory margin. And though he was careful to pooh-pooh the idea in displays of public modesty, Mr. Davis was hardly displeased to be mentioned in the same breath with his only predecessor to make it to the White House: Ronald Reagan.
 But the state's electricity crisis has left Mr. Davis so embattled in his own backyard that his boilerplate protests about talk of the presidency's being premature now ring painfully true. As the state's Democrats gathered for their annual convention, which began here on Friday night with a party at Disney's new California Adventure theme park, the talk was not of Mr. Davis's national dreams for 2004, but of his prospects for re-election next year. 
 The hallway chattering today went so far as to wonder whether the governor, who only last year seemed a shoo-in for a second term, might face a primary challenge from a renegade Democrat. None has yet materialized, but in her speech here today, State Controller Kathleen Connell, struggling to break out of a crowded field of candidates for mayor of Los Angeles and barred from seeking a third term next year, warned of the dangers of an incremental approach to the electricity crisis in what some heard as a direct hit at Mr. Davis, though she never mentioned his name.
"Everyone's entitled to their point of view," Mr. Davis said later, after he assured the delegates that "we will solve this problem." 
"Maybe if she's not happy with that," he added, "she can run for governor next time, after she's finished running for mayor."
Mr. Davis is the first to insist he has no time to think about Pennsylvania Avenue.
"I'm not focused on that," he said sharply in an interview last week, cutting off a reporter who asked about the presidency. "If you're sitting in my seat, that would be the last thing you'd focus on."
What would Mr. Davis tell state and national party leaders who may be inclined to gossip about his White House chances? "Godspeed," he said. "I can't tell you what's going to happen Sunday, much less in 2004. My only intention is to manage this process successfully."
That will be challenge enough. Since the state's electricity shortage reached severe levels in December, California has spent nearly $5 billion -- about half its projected budget surplus for the coming fiscal year -- buying power on behalf of near-bankrupt utilities. It has had two rounds of rolling blackouts that disabled traffic lights and elevators for hours at a time, and worse problems are foreseen for the summer. It is well on its way toward doubling its bond indebtedness to pay for power and help stabilize the utilities by buying their transmission lines.
And this week, Mr. Davis's appointees on the state Public Utilities Commission voted to raise retail electric rates as much as 46 percent for some customers, starting in May, even as the governor, who is celebrated for his micromanagement and for keeping appointees on a short leash, insisted that he had no control over the vote and was yet to be convinced of what most state politicians conceded months ago: that rate increases were needed.
"It's pretty incredible," said Gale Kaufman, a top Democratic political consultant who often works for organized labor in Sacramento. "I take my hat off to him if somehow he's able to have the public believe that somebody that they don't know anything about mysteriously raised their rates without his knowledge or approval."
Today Mr. Davis insisted that "if a rate increase becomes absolutely necessary to keep our lights on and our economy strong," he would fight to protect poor people, reward conservation and punish waste. 
That received only the most tepid applause from the delegates.
For his part, Mr. Davis's chief strategist, Garry South, resorts to a political truism, "You can't beat somebody with nobody," in assessing the governor's prospects for next year.
Mr. Davis's only declared Republican opponent is the California secretary of state, Bill Jones, now the party's sole statewide officeholder, who has $118,336 in his campaign treasury. Mr. Davis, who is perhaps the most prodigious fund-raiser in California history, has more than $26 million, and in his convention speech, the Democratic state attorney general, Bill Lockyer, listed mock Academy Awards using movie titles and predicted that Mr. Jones would be "Gone in 60 Seconds."
Other potential opponents, including the actor Arnold Schwarzenegger and William E. Simon Jr., an investor and the son of the former treasury secretary, have yet to declare their intentions, and neither has ever faced electoral politics, much less the complexity of California's often-volatile electorate.
The mere fact that the Democrats are meeting for the first time ever in Orange County, a onetime Republican stronghold that has become more and more Democratic as the Hispanic and Asian population there has increased, is proof enough of the challenges faced by the Republicans.
"Obviously if the governor had his druthers, he'd rather this electricity situation wasn't happening," Mr. South said. "Will he take a hit for it? Probably. But in 2002, people will be assessing the governor against a real opponent. Right now, he's being assessed against himself and is under heavy fire." Mr. South said it was "way too premature" to talk about whether Mr. Davis would pledge to serve out his term if re-elected.
Dan Schnur, an aide to Mr. Davis's Republican predecessor, Pete Wilson, who himself staged a resounding second-term comeback after his approval ratings plunged in the recession of the early 1990's, insisted that Mr. Davis was vulnerable.
"If you'd asked me two weeks ago, I would've said Davis is damaged goods but he's still going to be a long shot to beat," Mr. Schnur said. "But I don't believe that any more. I think this has been the worst two weeks of the crisis by some margin."
This weekend's state convention also featured appearances by the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Terry McAuliffe, and the House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. But aside from Mr. Gephardt, none of the wide range of possible presidential candidates who were invited, from former Vice President Al Gore on down, accepted.
"Because it's March, it's a little early for people to start showing their colors," said the state Democratic chairman, former State Senator Art Torres. "But we invited everybody."
Mr. Davis has just assumed the presidency of the Democratic Governors' Association. That, coupled with speculation about his presidential ambitions, makes him attractive for national party officials, who want to encourage as appealing a field of presidential contenders as possible to help build energy and raise money for the midterm elections next year.
"As someone said, there are 26 million good reasons why Gray Davis is a good candidate for president," one party official said, referring to the governor's fund-raising prowess. "If he walks out of this energy crisis showing leadership, he's got an opportunity more than anybody else to show that there are some serious differences between our party and the Bush White House."
The electricity crisis aside, there are plenty of reasons why even some of Mr. Davis's aides have long considered the presidency a long shot. Their boss, like former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, is famous for trusting only a few people and liking to sleep in his own bed, though a similar distaste for travel did not derail the candidacy of the current president.
Mr. Davis is ambitious, but cautious to a fault.
Then, too, the track record of sitting California governors who seek the White House has not been good. Mr. Reagan was out of office after two terms as governor before he ever ran for president, while Mr. Wilson and Jerry Brown each saw their own efforts fizzle.
For now, Mr. Davis has his eye squarely on his current job. Asked if he had ever met Mr. Schwarzenegger, he replied brightly: "A couple of times, actually. If he runs for governor, I'm going to star in "Terminator III."

HEADLINE: In Defense of Soft Money 

BYLINE:  By Mitch McConnell; Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, is chairman of the Senate Rules Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
It now appears that among the legacies of the Bill Clinton presidency will be a "reform" of campaign financing that devastates the national political parties. The 1996 Clinton campaign's courting of illegal foreign contributions for the Democratic National Committee and the Clintons' use of the Lincoln Bedroom to entertain contributors, followed by Mr. Clinton's pardons for criminals championed by big donors to the Democrats, have cast a pall over national party committees. And all of this propelled the prohibition of soft money -- donations made to political parties and not subject to federal contribution limits -- to the top of the reform agenda.
 Earlier, the centerpiece of reform efforts had been limits on candidates' own spending. In 1997 Senators John McCain and Russ Feingold dropped these spending limits from their reform bill, along with bans on political action committees and on "bundling" -- when individuals and groups collect multiple contributions. 
 Hard money, in Washington parlance, is the funds and activities targeted to electing specific candidates to federal office. These funds are already subject to severe contribution limits, set in 1974 and never adjusted for inflation, and to requirements for disclosing the names of donors and the amounts they gave. The national parties themselves also raise money, which they need for issue advocacy, for helping state and local candidates, for paying overhead expenses like the costs of computers and lawyers (to comply with the array of election laws), and for get-out-the-vote efforts that benefit all of a party's nominees on Election Day. This "nonfederal" money is subject to regulations in the ates. But because it has often been used in ways that do help federal candidates, it has come to be called "soft money."
The Republican and Democratic National Committees, and the Republican and Democratic senatorial and congressional committees, are national in scope. Gubernatorial and state legislative elections are among the highest priorities of the national parties, so they help candidates in those races accordingly -- with funds governed under the relevant state laws and spent in consultation with state party committees. But federal candidates are a focus of the national committees, too. And with campaigns for federal offices starved for hard money by the antiquated 1974 limits, the national parties have become increasingly resourceful in utilizing soft money to fill the void in federal elections.
In recent years, the parties have used soft money to run ads defending their nominees from attacks by special interest groups and to help challengers compete against well-financed incumbents. Help from the parties often provides the only chance nonincumbent and nonmillionaire candidates have to be competitive in Congressional elections.
The McCain-Feingold bill now working its way through Congress would prohibit the national committees from raising or spending any soft money -- that is, any money not covered by federal contribution limits -- at any time for any purpose. It would also federalize campaign-related spending by state parties in even-numbered years, thus forcing even the state parties to rely on far more scarce hard money, with results that are likely to be devastating.
Even if only one federal candidate were on the ballot in a state where the chief voter interest was in the governor's race, a mayoral contest or control of the state legislature, all party voter registration and turnout activities in that state within 120 days of the election would be subject to the severe limits on contributions set by Congress -- and therefore underfunded and diminished. Special-interest group issue ads would go unanswered by the parties. Challengers, historically shunned by political action committees but boosted by parties, would be on their own. Incumbents and self-funded millionaire candidates would flourish.
Speculation rages over which party would get the greater advantage from the ban on soft money. Many Republicans, believing that liberal-leaning news outlets will favor Democrats and noting that much of the political activity of the biggest Democratic ally, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., is largely unimpeded by McCain-Feingold's provisions, fear Democrats may be the greatest beneficiary. Conversely, there is concern among some Democrats that forcing the parties to rely solely on the limited and relatively puny hard-money contributions may benefit Republicans.
One result of McCain-Feingold is certain: America loses. The parties are vital institutions in our democracy, smoothing ideological edges and promoting citizen participation. The two major parties are the big tents where multitudes of individuals and groups with narrow agendas converge to promote candidates and broad philosophies about the role of government in our society.
If special interests cannot give to parties as they have, they will use their money to influence elections in other ways: placing unlimited, unregulated and undisclosed issue advertisements; mounting their own get-out-the-vote efforts; forming their own action groups. Unrestrained by the balancing effect of parties, which bring multiple interests together, America's politics are likely to fragment. "Virtual" parties will be able to proliferate -- shadowy groups with innocuous-sounding names like the Group in Favor of Republican Majorities or the Citizens for Democrats in 2012 that will hold potentially enormous sway in a post-McCain-Feingold world where the parties are diminished for lack of money.
Under McCain-Feingold, the power of special interests will not be deterred or diminished. Their speech, political activity and right to "petition the government for a redress of grievances" (that is, to lobby) are protected by the First Amendment. Political spending will not be reduced; it just will not flow through the parties.
Do we really want the two-party system, which has served us so well, to be weakened in favor of greater power for wealthy candidates and single-issue groups? McCain-Feingold will not take any money out of politics. It just takes the parties out of politics.
