HEADLINE: The Evolving Presidency; 
A Defining Test on Taxes

 BODY:
The most crucial item in President Bush's domestic agenda, his proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut, will be taken up by the Senate this week. It will actually cost closer to 50 percent more than that over the next 10 years, and the battle will be a closely fought one that will test both party loyalties and Mr. Bush's salesmanship. 
 A handful of Republican and Democratic senators are in a position to stop the tax cut cold or reshape it significantly. Among Democrats, only Senator Zell Miller of Georgia has defected from his party colleagues and said he will vote for a budget resolution that contains the Bush tax cut. Another Democrat, Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska, may go along with Mr. Miller. 
 On the Republican side, those with expressed misgivings include Senators Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, James Jeffords of Vermont and John McCain of Arizona. Senator Pete Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, continues to maintain that there are not now enough votes for the tax cut, but he is sounding more hopeful about corralling them.
The word in Washington is that over this weekend the White House and Trent Lott, the Republican leader, are furiously pummeling the G.O.P. waverers with a mixture of threats and promises to increase budget spending in the senators' favored areas -- such as education for Mr. Jeffords -- all in order to give the president a signature victory this week. This is budget politics of the baldest kind, and it is no way to do the Senate's business. Promising to increase spending in some areas is a particular travesty, since the Senate is being asked to adopt Mr. Bush's overarching $2 trillion spending plan without knowing where specifically he intends to cut spending.
Instead of the open and bipartisan process that Mr. Bush had promised to work for, the Senate is going about the budget and tax issue with maximum hurry and minimal information, debate and opportunity for amendments. Many experts have shown that there is not enough money for the tax cut and the spending programs that Americans favor. The rushed process suggests an awareness by Mr. Bush and the Republican Senate leadership that they need to pass the tax cut before Americans find out about it. The tactic worked in the more compliant House of Representatives, which last week passed its budget resolution and Mr. Bush's tax wish list.
But the Senate may be trying to reclaim its reputation as a place that challenges presidents as often as it obeys them. On Friday, a parade of Democratic senators led by Robert Byrd of West Virginia took to the floor to point out the ludicrous nature of the upcoming budget process. 
First is the fact that the resolution is going to be debated, and presumably adopted, before Mr. Bush submits his own budget on April 9. Second is the fact that there has been no consideration of the budget in the Budget Committee, because Mr. Domenici says he does not have the votes to pass a budget in any form. Third is the fact that there have been no independent estimates of the cost of Mr. Bush's proposals by the bipartisan Joint Tax Committee and the Congressional Budget Office. Republicans are asserting in response that eight years ago the Congress adopted a budget resolution before President Bill Clinton submitted his budget. But there was a lot more information about Mr. Clinton's budget at that time, and a lot more scrutiny by independent analysts.
The tax cutters know that spending details are their enemy. Mr. Bush's budget outline of a month ago had no such detail. It was filled with euphemisms about "redirected" spending and "offsets." Reports that some of these would cut programs affecting children's health and education have been denied by administration budget officials, but there has been no documentation on where precisely the cuts would fall. There have been other reports of proposed reductions in the program that pays for police officers in cities. 
But it makes no sense to ram through an unfair, unaffordable tax cut that would necessitate budget cuts when the only knowledge of the funding loss comes from scattered newspaper leaks. There is indeed no need to rush on this tax cut. A better idea would be to adopt a smaller immediate tax cut to stimulate the faltering economy, something for which there is broad bipartisan approval, and wait to see how the larger tax cut fits into Congress's spending plans on health, education and other pressing needs. That would be the fiscally prudent course, but it would not provide the political bang that Mr. Bush needs and that Senate Republicans are determined to give him.

LENGTH: 873 words

HEADLINE: The Evolving Presidency; 
A Bow to Political Realities

 BODY:
For the first nine weeks of George W. Bush's presidency, millions of Americans seemed to be experiencing agenda shock -- the political equivalent of sticker shock. They simply did not believe he was that conservative. Nor had they perceived him as so hostile to the government's role in conservation and workplace regulation or so determined to turn key agencies over to administrators hostile to their basic missions. Mr. Bush's response to questions and complaints had one theme. He was a leader who did not take his signal from the polls, but simply did what he thought was right for America.
 Then came week 10, a period that will be remembered as the days in which Mr. Bush discovered the complications of being president. It is one thing to dream of a new conservative hegemony and to thrill G.O.P. ideologues by out-Reaganing Ronald Reagan with a blizzard of anti-regulatory executive orders. It is easy, before a friendly crowd in Kalamazoo, Mich., to explain tax windfalls for the rich by airily asserting that "if we're going to have tax relief, everybody who pays taxes ought to get relief." 
 The problem, of course, is that sooner or later the presidential helicopter has to land again inside the Beltway. That highway is supposed to reflect some kind of enduring opinion divide between the suburban conservatives who voted for Mr. Bush, on one side, and on the other the Democrats and Republican moderates who, in combination, could hold the balance of power in Congress. The events of the last few days suggest that on a variety of issues, including the environment and campaign finance, Congress may be less out of touch than the president, and that Mr. Bush is beginning to get it. 
All this is to say that we are only now getting to the testing of George W. Bush and to seeing how he will react to the customary impediments of Washington life. What we saw in the first palmy weeks was a blend of Reaganesque ease and Bushian hyper-energy. Not since Mr. Reagan have we had a chief executive who seemed so comfortable and comforting in his public role yet so seemingly unbending in his calculations. We also saw a president in a hurry. Staff research has convinced him that chances for legislative victories tail off sharply after the first three months. 
Perhaps for that reason, Mr. Bush seems inclined to make a huge bet on a political game plan that seems daringly compact after the sprawling initiatives of the Clinton years. He is counting on an uptick in the economy in time for the midterm elections. To show his social conscience, he wants an education bill that pushes more money and accountability on to the states. To solidify his business base, he wants fewer environmental rules and more oil and gas exploration. Above all, this is a White House that wants some kind of tax cut that bears Mr. Bush's stamp rather than that of the Democrats. 
Simple game plans are fine. Presidents should concentrate on a few big things. The problem is that Congress will also concentrate on those same big things -- taxes and spending, in particular. As for the public, sometimes the polls that Mr. Bush ignores are better guides than, say, Senator Frank Murkowski, to what citizens really think about trees, air, water and oil. 
So by Thursday, Mr. Bush was recalibrating the breathtakingly open pro-wealth, pro-business bias that dominated White House actions and statements for the past two months. At a press conference, his usual paean to oil and gas drilling was modified by the observation that maybe Congress would not allow such activities in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Mr. Bush may even want to reconsider his cure for the purported energy crisis. This, after all, is a nation that was outraged by the closed-door nature of the Clinton health initiative. How will it react when Vice President Dick Cheney and a panel dominated by pro-exploration forces emerge from behind closed doors with new plans for drilling on federal lands? 
In the coming weeks, we are likely to see more bending from Mr. Bush on another issue about which he had strong feelings. He will almost certainly have to sign the McCain-Feingold campaign legislation if it reaches his desk. We will also venture that it would be a political mistake for him to encourage Representative Tom DeLay to scuttle the strong Senate bill in the House. 
On taxes, however, Mr. Bush has yet to blink. He is still calling for his full tax cut, as outlined in the editorial below. Politically, this is a must-win situation for the president, and he will get huge credit even if victory comes by way of a tie-breaking vote from Vice President Cheney. 
But a 50-50 Senate emboldened by the McCain-Feingold fight may be thinking of new definitions of Mr. Bush's favorite word, bipartisanship. The lesson of week 10 is that Mr. Bush may have to redefine bipartisanship as something more inclusive than finding enough Democrats to pass his core proposals. We are probably at the end of the days when his reputation as a genial compromiser will allow him to put all his political effort into shoring up the populist conservative base and protecting the financial interests of the wealth wing of the G.O.P. Now it is time to deal with the rest of the American family.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Not So Fast; 
Suddenly, Bush's Smooth Ride Turns Bumpy

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE steamroller has stalled.
 The Senate is about to pass a bill the president does not like, written by a senator he does not like: John McCain's campaign finance legislation. The president's tax bill has run into a Democratic counter-proposal and resistance to his own claim that tax cuts in future years would cure an economic slowdown this year. Congress may reject the president's plan to drill for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Reserve, he conceded Thursday. His faith-based charity initiative is encountering doubts from some churches. European nations are angry at the president's dismissal of the Kyoto treaty on global warming. 
 Meanwhile, national polls, while showing approval of President Bush's job performance at nearly 60 percent, also showed public disapproval creeping up from the 20's to the 30's.
None of this is fatal, of course. Presidents don't have to be invincible to succeed, and usually aren't. About this time eight years ago President Clinton's economic stimulus plan was being battered; a few months later his budget passed. Besides, Mr. Bush will probably get a tax bill enough to his liking to crow over. And if the president signs a campaign finance bill, it might be painful for him, but it will be popular. Further, his public standing is still pretty strong. 
In any case, few imagined the Bush juggernaut of the first weeks would last, not with a 50-50 Senate, which depends for its nominal Republican control on the longevity of 98-year-old Strom Thurmond. Still, Mr. Bush's new difficulties accompany a growing understanding that this is a very conservative administration.
The dawning of that perception has its comic moments, as when abortion rights advocates, environmentalists, even labor, take turns in proclaiming, like Captain Renault in Casablanca, that they are "shocked, shocked to find that there is conservatism going on in here." 
It is true that Mr. Bush ran on a platform that was a litany of conservative principles, from school vouchers to protecting "the life of the unborn." But he also insisted that he was a "compassionate conservative," who would reach across the party aisle. On the stump, voters heard a great deal about moderation and bipartisanship, very little about red-meat conservative issues. Again, when the Supreme Court effectively ended the election, Mr. Bush said in his Dec. 13 speech to the nation, "Whether you voted for me or not, I will do my best to serve your interests, and I will work to earn your respect." 
Coming from someone known for good manners and not for divisive name calling in the style of Newt Gingrich, that certainly sounded to many like a promise that he would work carefully to build consensus. But instead Mr. Bush's approach has been to avoid anything that might seem tentative, and to seize as his mandate not the popular vote but the oath of office. 
Those who had been lulled into the expectation of a centrist administration had, arguably, only themselves to blame, having ignored several clear indications of Mr. Bush's real thinking. 
First, there was his record in Texas, where labor, the environment and health care received little attention. Second, there was the fact that conservative political groups remained solidly behind him, whatever genial message he offered. And finally, those professing dismay today might have at least remembered their own campaign ads from last fall, which portrayed Mr. Bush as an enemy of the working family and the environment.
IN fact, there was enough wish-fulfillment in the left's view of Mr. Bush that it's hard to disagree with Anne Coulter, a conservative writer, who said last month that Mr. Bush had shown "how easy it is to hornswoggle liberals." 
"All you have to do is go around calling yourself nice," she said. "He just treats liberals like small children having nightmares. Darn if it didn't work." 
Mr. Bush himself could have been making a similar point March 24 when he joked at the annual Gridiron dinner in Washington that Democratic power-broker Robert S. Strauss had told him "You can fool some of the people all of the time, and those are the ones you have to concentrate on." 
Now that the scales are falling from the eyes of the innocent, the obvious question is whether the growing view of Mr. Bush as very conservative will hurt him -- and if so, how much. Obviously his managers saw that image as a negative during the campaign; otherwise they would have embraced it. It is still a problem, since the American voter generally feels more comfortable with politicians near the middle of the road, not the shoulder. But how much it may hurt is likely to depend on the economy.
"A level of strong conservatism in his policy preferences will not work substantially against him if we're in the middle of a substantially robust economy," said Norman J. Ornstein, a political scientist at the American Enterprise Institute. But if the slowdown continues "then any flaw works against him." 
Possibly the most dangerous of those flaws emerged in an ABC News/Washington Post Poll released last week: It found that 61 percent of the public thought Mr. Bush cared more about "protecting the interests of large corporations" than about those of "ordinary working people." Only 31 percent thought he cared more about workers. 
Even without a deep recession, continued Republican control of Congress is uncertain. 
The House, where the 10-vote G.O.P. majority had held so far, is inherently unstable. And in the Senate, 20 Republican seats (including Mr. Thurmond's) are up for election in 2002, compared to only 13 for the Democrats.
Republicans believe that having control of the White House, Senate and House for the first time in half a century will work in their favor. But, as one senior House Democratic aide said: "They run the whole show. Just as we lived and died with Clinton for eight years, they live and die with Bush. If Bush is for anti-environmental things, then House Republicans are. The president becomes the face of your party."
Maybe. But one tactic that served him well with the Texas legislature is also at work in Washington. This administration is not pushing a lot of bills as its own. It's a kind of stealth politics. Anti-abortion forces, for example, want a bill that would apply federal murder statutes to fetuses. No one doubts that Mr. Bush would sign the bill, but it is up to the Congressional backers and the National Right to Life Committee to get it passed, and to take all the political heat. 
MANY of Mr. Bush's most criticized and most conservative actions have been taken by executive order. Indeed, of all his decisions, the most politically damaging may be the one to reverse a Clinton administration rule reducing the amount arsenic allowed in drinking water. This, far more than changing the rules about carbon dioxide in the air or ergonomic standards in the workplace, is something everyone can understand. Arsenic is a poison, and it's easy to make a campaign ad that serves, as Stan Greenberg, a Democratic pollster, put it, as "an exclamation point for a cascade of decisions."
In the Senate, Mr. Bush has a different problem. There, he can either stand on principle and sometimes lose, or he can craft compromises, as he often, and adroitly, did with the Texas legislature.
Thus far, the administration has sent mixed signals. On his education plan, the administration has already hinted that it won't insist on vouchers. On taxes, however, Mr. Bush he repeatedly said that $1.6 billion in cuts over 10 years is "just right." 
Even if Mr. Bush reveals himself to be a political realist, happy to take a half-loaf over the next three years, it is unlikely this White House will face widespread disaffection from true believers on the right. David Keene, head of the American Conservative Union, said the once-impatient conservative movement had matured. The style and genuine conservatism of this administration may have spurred that change. 
In the administration of President Bush's father, Mr. Keene said, "Conservatives were treated as if they were in the stands," like home team fans expected to cheer. Now he said, through appointments and consultations, "Conservatives are part of the team. If you're part of the team you tolerate mistakes or failures more than you do as a fan."

HEADLINE: Bush Angers Europe by Eroding Pact on Warming 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 31 

 BODY:
European leaders frequently bristle about American behavior, but President Bush's abrupt decision this week to abandon a treaty on global warming has provoked even more than the usual level of anger and frustration. 
 "Irresponsible," "arrogant," even "sabotage" are just a few of the charges that Europeans have leveled at Mr. Bush since he announced his refusal to follow through on the treaty, the Kyoto Protocol. And European Union representatives will take their case in favor of the accord to Washington on Monday, though their arguments are not expected to prevail. 
 The response is so intense in part because the decision has aggravated a mixture of grudges that have gnawed at Europeans for years. 
They are angry that the United States appears oblivious to widespread environmental concerns across most of Europe.
They are frustrated that the United States, by virtue of its size, can undermine a treaty that was negotiated by more than 100 countries.
Most of all, they are depressed that there is not much they can do about it. 
The United States produces about 25 percent of the gases associated with global warming, and its refusal to meet goals set by Kyoto to reduce those emissions makes it difficult for competitors to stick with their goals. 
"To suggest scrapping Kyoto and making a new agreement with more countries involved simply reflects a lack of understanding of political realities," said Margot Wallstrom, Europe's commissioner for environmental affairs. "We could lose years of work if we were to start from scratch."
Ms. Wallstrom will lead the delegation that meets on Monday with Christie Whitman, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency. The group is also expected to include Environment Minister Kjell Larsson of Sweden, whose country currently holds the rotating European Union presidency, and representatives of Belgium, which takes over from the Swedes in July. 
The meeting is part of a diplomatic push that is also supposed to include visits to China, Russia, Iran and Japan to assess whether it would be possible to carry through on the Kyoto treaty without the United States. 
Today, environment ministers from European Union countries discussed the Bush decision at a previously scheduled meeting in Sweden, where the reaction was one of indignation. 
"Kyoto is still alive," said Mr. Larsson, who was host of the meeting in Kiruna, 60 miles north of the Arctic Circle. "No country has the right to declare Kyoto dead." 
The anger at the United States is spread evenly across Europe.
Dominique Voynet, France's minister for the environment, called Mr. Bush's decision "completely provocative and irresponsible" and warned the United States against "continuing the work of sabotage" if other countries decided to embrace the goals of the Kyoto agreement on their own. 
Le Monde, the French daily newspaper, called Mr. Bush's decision "a brutal form of unilateralism." In London, The Independent reported that "history will not judge George Bush kindly." 
When Mr. Bush met with the German Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, in Washington on Thursday, Kyoto formed a central disagreement. "We will not do anything that harms our economy, because first things first are the people who live in America," Mr. Bush said. 
This kind of America-first sentiment prompted sharp criticism from the European Union Commission president, Romano Prodi. "If one wants to be a world leader, one must know how to look after the entire earth and not only American industry," the former Italian prime minister told La Repubblica newspaper. 
But nobody has any illusions about changing American policy, and the real question European leaders are asking is whether they can or should press ahead without America. 
"It is a catastrophe," said Gerd Billen, executive director of Germany's biggest environmental group, Naturschutzbund Deutschland, which has 350,000 members. "Everybody knows how hard it is to reach an international agreement on environmental issues like this, and this could destroy it."
Mr. Billen and other environmental leaders are pushing for a boycott against American companies, particularly oil companies that have extensive gas-station networks in Europe. 
"It would be a citizens' action, and if it is done right, it could really put pressure on the oil companies," said Alexander de Roo, deputy chairman of the European Parliament's environmental committee. "I don't think that begging will be very effective. I think they will only listen to powerful arguments."
As in many other international issues, from the decision to send peacekeeping forces to the Balkans to coordinating international currency rates, Europeans know from experience that it is difficult to accomplish anything without American collaboration. 
Under the Kyoto Protocol, which was approved in 1997 after years of negotiation, 37 other industrial countries agreed to reduce their emissions of greenhouse gases by 2012 to 5.2 percent below the levels in 1990.
But the United States is by far the biggest producer of greenhouse gases, both per capita and in total. The average American consumes twice as much energy as the average European, and the emission of greenhouse gases is also about twice as high per capita in the United States as in Europe.
If European countries press ahead with their own goal, European companies run the risk of incurring higher expenses while American companies benefit from easier rules. 
Ms. Wallstrom, the environmental commissioner, noted at a news conference in Brussels on Thursday that Europe did not want to end up rewarding the United States for its refusal to go along.
But abandoning the goals is politically treacherous, because they enjoy strong popular support in most countries. Despite the anger that many Europeans feel toward high gasoline taxes, support for environmental regulations remains much stronger than in the United States.
In the months leading up the Kyoto meetings in 1997, the European Union proposed a remarkably ambitious goal of reducing greenhouse emissions to 15 percent below the levels of 1990.
Reflecting the enormous difference in the political and social climates in the United States and Europe, European business groups merely tried to moderate those goals and many industrial associations committed themselves to steep reductions in emissions as a way to escape direct government regulation. 
Many European environmental leaders argue that Europe needs to press ahead. 
"If 55 countries representing 55 percent of worldwide CO2 emissions ratify the Kyoto protocol, then it begins to function," Mr. de Roo said.
On a broader level, many Europeans are convinced that Mr. Bush is leading the United States into greater isolation. Many commentators seized upon Mr. Bush's comment last week that he would not do anything to weaken the American economy. The announcement was front-page news across Europe, and it quickly prompted a storm of criticism.
"We are back to Ronald Reagan and America First," said Noel Mamer, a leader of the French Green party and a member of Parliament. "I think the decision is completely mad, and it is a reason for more isolation for America." 
But even some of the fiercest European critics admit that they have little leverage. In Brussels, European leaders carefully avoided making any threats and said they merely planned to "explain" their position to the Bush administration.
"The United States will probably come out of this crisis of trans-Atlantic relations as the winner," said Liberation, the left-leaning French newspaper. But, it added, "Those who spew gases run the risk of reaping, long before the climate has heated up, an explosive hostility in public opinion and diplomatic isolation."

PERSON: Jeffrey R. Immelt 

HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE PAY; 
A Power Behind the Pay Surge

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH STANTON

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
LAST November, when Jack Welch chose Jeffrey R. Immelt to be his successor as chief executive of General Electric, executive recruiters and corporate search committees from coast to coast scrambled to court the two G.E. executives who had also been in contention for the job. Few people knew where and when the two executives would land, but Robert J. Stucker knew that and more.
 Mr. Stucker, one of the country's top lawyers in the niche business of negotiating executive compensation packages, simultaneously represented both of them, W. James McNerney Jr. and Robert L. Nardelli. 
 "Neither of them knew I was representing the other," said Mr. Stucker, president of Vedder, Price, Kaufman & Kammholz, which is based here. "Once I almost called one of them by the other's name." 
Recounting the events of that harried week, Mr. Stucker said he and a six-member team of other lawyers worked 20-hour days to negotiate the two deals. One week after Mr. Welch's announcement, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing chose Mr. McNerney as its chief executive, and the next day, Home Depot nabbed Mr. Nardelli as its chief.
Mr. Stucker, 56, who began his executive-compensation career almost 20 years ago, is like a sports agent for his executive clients, sometimes sending shock waves through the business world. Negotiating contracts, for example, often includes severance packages, and it was Mr. Stucker who counseled John R. Walter when he was he brought in as president and heir-apparent to the top job at AT&T in 1996. After barely nine months in the job, Mr. Walter left with almost $26 million in compensation. 
Mr. Stucker's co-counsel on that compensation contract was Joseph Bachelder, 68, who some experts say made executive compensation negotiations a distinct specialty -- and his trademark -- after he started working in the field in 1980.
For a while, Mr. Bachelder, who is based in New York and employs 10 lawyers who do nothing but negotiate pay, had the high end of the field mostly to himself. But in the last decade, as negotiations have become more involved, the expertise and technique of Mr. Stucker have made him a household name, too, among chief executives. 
"There are two big guns, two major players in the industry," said Gerard R. Roche, senior chairman of Heidrick & Struggles International, the executive recruiters. "We let the client decide who they want to use, and they are both high-quality people. You've got Joe in New York and Bob in Chicago, but they're both national and they both do an amazing job."
In two of the latest compensation negotiations, Mr. Stucker's firm represented Hershey Foods and Campbell Soup, and Mr. Bachelder's firm represented their incoming chief executives, Richard H. Lenny and Douglas R. Conant. Although it is common for Mr. Stucker and Mr. Bachelder to find themselves on opposite sides of negotiations, they have never met -- though they have spoken briefly by phone a few times. And while some experts say Mr. Stucker may be pushing Mr. Bachelder out from his long-held near-monopoly of the field, each man denies there is competition between them.
"Both of us have been doing this for a very long time, and there's plenty of work out there," Mr. Stucker said. "We work together on things all the time, so I guess he's doing a very good job."
Mr. Bachelder, who has conducted negotiations between executives and companies like Bank One, Gillette, Nabisco, I.B.M. and TRW, said: "There's such a huge volume, it's a good thing there are many firms in the field. We could never handle it all on our own. The more the merrier." 
John Wood, a director at SpencerStuart, an executive recruitment firm, who has worked with Mr. Stucker and Mr. Bachelder, says the two lawyers have different styles. "Bob has a very pragmatic, practical, helpful approach to taking care of both sides," he said. "And Joe is a very aggressive advocator of his client."
Whether he is churning out a pay package in 48 hours or constructing a severance clause, Mr. Stucker is praised by clients for his availability and his adamant attention to detail. "When you're working on this, you have to be available every moment of every day," he said. "You have to be completely accessible. They come to me when they are most vulnerable, and for once in their life they aren't in charge, so I can't put them on hold and say, 'Let's take care of this on Monday.' "
After graduating cum laude in 1967 from Georgetown University with an economics degree, Mr. Stucker was almost certain that he wanted to practice law. He went to the University of Chicago Law School, and, J.D. in hand, he joined Vedder, Price, Kaufman & Kammholz in 1970. The firm had only 30 lawyers at the time, though today it has more than 200. 
"In the beginning, we had one person working on executive compensation," he said. "Now it's two-thirds of the firm." 
He says his knowledge of the field keeps the calls coming from chief executives across the country. "To be effective, you have got to know the art of it," he explained. "You can do this periodically, but it's hard to advise with certainty when you're not doing it 99 percent of the time. I bring a unique perspective to the table, because I know what is being done at the front lines -- because I'm doing it."
His help can cost several hundred thousand dollars -- either a fixed fee or accumulated through hourly fees of up to $595 or a percentage of the first year's compensation.
Stockholders and others have questioned the big pay packages for company chiefs, but Mr. Stucker makes no apologies for the huge increases in the last decade. He says his clients sign the dotted line of such packages because they have shown the same qualities in the executive suite that superstar athletes show on the field or on the court. 
"To recruit that all-star ball player that's at the height of his career, with 5 to 10 years left, you have to pay them an all-star salary," he said. "If you want to compete for Michael Jordan, he's not going to come for the salary of a guy that plays only two minutes a game. The companies are hoping the executives they bring in will have the magic formula to take their company to be a super performer, and you have to pay for that."
Mr. Stucker lists high energy, visionary skills, focus and the ability to pick a winning team as qualities that shine in some of his executive star clients -- like Leo F. Mullin, chief executive of Delta Air Lines; Edward G. Harshfield, executive chairman of MFN Financial; and Richard H. Brown, chairman and chief executive of Electronic Data Systems. 
MR. STUCKER has become a star himself among his clients, who have three to six phone numbers where thay can reach him -- including at home, where they sometimes chat with his wife, Ann.
"I feel like I'm part of their family," said Mr. Nardelli, the new Home Depot chief, though he has never met Mr. Stucker face to face. Mr. Nardelli called him "a tireless worker and professional who's contemporary in his recommendations." (Home Depot has not yet disclosed Mr. Nardelli's salary.)
When Mr. Stucker finds time away from his long workdays, he likes to golf. Twenty-eight years ago, he and his wife built their home along the sixth fairway of a golf course in Glenview, a Chicago suburb. For Mr. Stucker, that is a necessary convenience when chief executives are looking for him on a Saturday afternoon.

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Musicians Press Point In Online Rift

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
For years recording artists and the executives who promote their work have had a love-hate relationship.
 Executives at recording companies, which make billions of dollars a year distributing music on compact discs and in other formats, say their business is risky and they should be compensated for taking chances on young talent. Recording artists, for their part, have long grumbled that companies are too controlling, lining their pockets by exploiting musicians unschooled in business. 
 Now, while the debate in the music industry has focused on how recording companies should deal with the public online, the controversy has also reheated long-simmering tensions between musicians and executives. And some artists are taking advantage of the public's interest in online music rights to pursue the musicians' own agenda -- protesting what they describe as years of bad faith by the recording industry. 
A handful of recording artists, including the singer Don Henley, a former member of the band the Eagles, will be in Washington on Tuesday for Senate hearings on intellectual property rights in the online era. For Mr. Henley, these hearings are just the beginning of a campaign to influence lawmakers on the issue of artists' rights. His organization, the Recording Artists Coalition, successfully lobbied Congress last year to withdraw legislation that would have allowed recording companies to permanently own artists' master recordings. 
"Artists have been able to organize for every cause under the sun, but themselves," Mr. Henley said in an interview last week. "But things have come to a boiling point. When something as revolutionary as the Internet comes along, it allows for the discussion of other issues -- like unfair practices -- to be expanded."
Already the music industry is buzzing about a lawsuit that the rock musician Courtney Love recently filed against Vivendi Universal, demanding an end to the industrywide practice of offering only long-term contracts. Ms. Love's suit was in response to one filed last year by Vivendi, which as the owner of the Universal Music Group labels that include Geffen Records and Mercury Records is one of the largest global recording companies. Vivendi had sued Ms. Love and her band, Hole, for breach of contract, saying she tried to terminate her seven-year contract without delivering five recordings still owed to the company. Vivendi has asked for millions of dollars in damages.
Ms. Love's countersuit argues that the standard contract that artists are offered in the recording industry would be deemed unfair in other professions. She says she is also trying to expose accounting practices that she says cheat artists out of millions of dollars.
Industry analysts said such a lawsuit might not have commanded as much attention a few years ago. In fact, most previous disputes -- including one between Mr. Henley and Geffen Records -- have been settled privately, with artists renegotiating their contracts instead of going to court. 
But Ms. Love's suit comes at a time when the Napster battle has helped put the recording industry on the public relations defensive. As one record executive recently put it: "We are like tobacco companies. No one really likes us."
Industry executives say that if Ms. Love succeeds she could accomplish what the actress Olivia de Haviland did in 1945 when she sued Warner Brothers Pictures over its long-term contracts. The outcome of that suit, in which the court ruled that it was illegal to force an artist to be bound to one studio for years, was effectively the beginning of the end of the Hollywood studio system as actors were allowed to become free agents.
Vivendi Universal dismissed Ms. Love's claims, saying in court documents that she had willingly signed her contract and that her lawsuit was "on its face a bad faith, frivolous, everything-but-the-kitchen-sink attempt to attract media attention." 
Whether bad faith, righteous or on some moral middle ground, Ms. Love's effort may strike a chord with some members of the public who are beginning to demand that music companies justify their costs in the post-Napster era.
Artists' recent activism may be partly a reaction to the notion that it is the fans who are now driving the debate over music's future. Artists are speaking out now because their concerns are not being addressed, , said Jim Griffin, a former record executive who is now chief executive of Cherry Lane Digital, a digital entertainment company in Los Angeles. "An 18-year-old has more say than they do about their future."
Myles Davis, a music industry analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York, said the recording companies feel besieged. "The music industry has existed in its own world for so long," he said. "Now people are questioning, 'Why can't you just change?' I believe they are in a period of complete and utter confusion."
The Recording Industry Association of America, which represents the record companies, has embarked on a lobbying and public relations campaign to defend the industry's sullied image. "There is this perception that recording executives view artists as a commodity and are only in it for the money," said Hilary Rosen, chief executive of the association. "If we are not out there telling our story, the story gets written for us in an unflattering way."
If recording executives have an image problem now, analysts and industry experts say they have only themselves to blame. For years they have kept music fans at arm's length, leaving it to retailers to manage the customer relationships while the recording companies concentrated on promoting artists and producing discs. But all that changed when free online music started tipping the balance of power toward the listeners.
Critics say the industry is hindered by a leadership vacuum and that record executives have grown defensive -- and are unprepared to harness consumer-friendly technology and unable to articulate a vision of their business future. Right now, the recording business is about cost saving, said Michael Nathanson, a media analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "It's become a factory."
That is what the artists are protesting. Mr. Henley acknowledges that musicians have tried to organize before but have failed, largely because their interests are too varied. Name-brand artists may feel shackled, but garage bands may be all too happy for a chance to wear the golden handcuffs. 
"I'm old enough to know it's an uphill battle," said Mr. Henley, who is 53. "But I've never seen such hostility bordering on contempt from the highest echelons of the corporate world toward the musician. I don't know if we are going to be successful, but we are going to bring up some issues."

HEADLINE: E-Commerce; 
Borderless is out; advertisers now want to know if a customer lives in Cairo, Egypt, or Cairo, Ill.

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
FOR years, Internet marketers and retailers have been on a quest for so-called one-to-one marketing. That is, they want to know consumers so well that they can pitch the right product to a person the instant he shows up at a specific Web site. But that pursuit has devolved into a bushwhacking trek for executives, who are either knee-deep in customer data that they cannot process quickly, or are unable to find critical bits of information.
 One of the most basic pieces of data that Web sites often lack is a visitor's physical location. Until visitors register at the site or arrange delivery for a purchase -- or until the site's squinting employees comb through visitation logs -- companies typically have no clue whether their prospect is from South Beach or South Dakota, Normandy or Newark. And, of course, the geographic information someone enters on a registration form could be pure fiction. 
 Such fine points have not been a critical issue for most executives, who have had enough trouble just getting their sites to work, and getting to know the vagaries of Internet retailing, publishing and advertising. But for auction sites, gambling sites and others, geography is becoming increasingly important, because they must treat people from different locations differently, as is the case with the French government's barring the sale of Nazi-related items to its citizens. 
Online advertising companies, too, are increasingly desperate to use geographic targeting tools to reinforce their clients' faith in Internet marketing. In short, for a growing number of companies, this will be the year when the borderless Internet economy becomes an outmoded concept.
"Our customers told us over the past six months or so that it was an absolute requirement that we have geo-targeting," said Mark Joseph, chief technology officer for MediaPlex, an advertising company based in San Francisco. The company recently licensed software that enables it to deliver online ads that are tailored to a user's location, Mr. Joseph said. The software was created by RealMapping, an Amsterdam company.
If a hotel chain, for example, wants to display banner ads promoting a weekend special at its New York locations -- but wants to show those ads only to people in the New York metropolitan area -- the RealMapping software allows Mr. Joseph's company to do so.
Sjoerd van Gelderen, RealMapping's chief executive, said that determining a person's physical location on the Web was an arduous task. At its most basic level, that job involves mapping the roughly 1.5 billion so-called Internet Protocol, or I.P., addresses, which are assigned to computers connected directly to the Internet.
Notably, this does not include mapping the computers of individual Web surfers; otherwise, the technology companies in this category would not have survived infancy without a full-frontal attack by privacy groups. What are mapped, instead, are the server computers of Internet service providers or of employers -- the network access points through which individual users' PC's are actually connected to the Net. Mr. van Gelderen said it took 18 months for his company's staff of about 12 people to identify the I.P. addresses' physical locations, test them for accuracy and compile the information in a database. "We compare it to the human genome project," he said. "It's smaller scale, but the same type of number crunching."
RealMapping updates the database each month -- 2 percent of I.P. addresses change hands monthly -- and ships that list to its customers, who pay $2,500 to $15,000 a month to receive it. The fee, Mr. Van Gelderen said, depends on a number of factors, including whether the client wants country-specific tracking or city-specific tracking. RealMapping also charges $10,000 to $100,000 to set up the system so companies can combine the I.P. address data with their own databases.
Advertising companies have been quick to capitalize on this technology. But Web publishers are prepared to join the fray, according to David Ready, vice president for system operations at Amazing Media, which, among other activities, sells advertising technology to Web site publishers. Mr. Ready said his company, based in Fairfax, Va., had found increasing interest among publishers that want to sell and deliver their own geographically aimed ads, rather than pay an advertising network like Doubleclick or 24/7 Media to do so.
But the most fertile ground for geographic addressing services is actually outside the advertising field, according to Marie Alexander, the chief executive of Quova, one company that sells the technology. "There are a bunch of industries that haven't been able to make good use of the Internet because of the regulatory environment," said Ms. Alexander, whose company is based in Redwood City, Calif. 
Pharmaceutical companies, insurance companies, gambling operations and auction sites, among others, will be increasingly dependent on geographical technology, she said, because their industries must frequently respect national or state boundaries when they do business.
Pornography sites are also interested in the technology, said Ms. Alexander, whose technology is being licensed by at least two such companies. One of them is using the software to localize the content for viewers. "I'm not sure why, though," Ms. Alexander said. "Maybe if they know you're from Texas, they'll show a woman in a cowboy hat."
Credit card fraud has also pushed Internet businesses to look into this type of software. Internet executives say geographic focusing software is being used to identify users from regions with high instances of credit card theft. If credit cards come in from a region that has been deemed a high risk for fraud, the Web site could ask for further information to determine whether the card number is legitimate. Likewise, if the same card number is used within a few minutes by two users in different time zones, the Web site could apply greater scrutiny to the transaction.
Companies that must respect copyrights are also adopting this technology. For example, Vivendi Universal's Universal Music Group, one of the world's largest music publishers, has been using technology to detect a user's location since the middle of last year. Because distribution rights vary from nation to nation, depending on the deal a music publisher strikes with an artist, Universal was unable to offer digital downloads of its music without a mechanism to block downloads to people in certain countries.
Now, using technology from two companies -- Digital Envoy, in Atlanta, and Digital Island, in San Francisco -- Universal can sell music downloads through e-tailers like CDNow, TowerRecords.com and others and reduce the risk of copyright violations.
The various locator technologies are not perfect, of course, because users sometimes dial into Internet servers from remote locations. But despite such drawbacks, executives who use the technology say it is highly reliable.
Such adopters notwithstanding, many e-tailers have been slow to gravitate to location-spotting technologies. Many Web merchants have been much more concerned with cutting costs and providing easy site navigation than adopting so-called "personalization" features, which are seen more as luxuries than necessities.
Amazon.com, for instance, takes into account a customer's purchase history and location when presenting certain features, like recommended books, or when displaying its so-called Purchase Circles, which show users what people in various regions or certain companies are reading.
But for visitors who have not previously made purchases on Amazon, the site does not detect their locations and change the site accordingly, said Matt Williams, Amazon's director of community. Rather, the company is more concerned with designing the Web site so customers looking for certain products can find them on their own, without the company's needing to discern locale or language preference or other special needs as they arrive.
"It's interesting technology," Mr. Williams said. "But it's too early to say if we'd use something like that."

HEADLINE: MediaTalk; 
New Data to Show Drop In Minority Journalists

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
For 23 years, the American Society of Newspaper Editors has kept a count of the growing numbers of black, Hispanic, Asian and American Indian journalists in the profession, with the intention of increasing those numbers. Now, for the first time, they are declining.
 Although the precise data is not scheduled for release until tomorrow, several people who have seen the figures confirmed the decline, adding that it was not steep -- a nudge downward after several years in which the figures barely nudged upward. 
 But any decline shows that in 2000, a year of standout industry profits, the recruitment and retention of minority journalists failed to keep pace with the job growth in the industry in general. And it casts into doubt the viability even of the revised, slower timetables that call on the industry to mirror the nation's ethnic mix by 2025.
If this year's figures are anything like last year's, it will be hard to determine the exact cause of the decline, which coincided with a $5.5 million multiyear investment by two major journalism foundations to recruit, train and underwrite the salaries of young minority journalists.
The editors' group and other journalism organizations have long argued that unless the staffs of newsrooms reflect the diversity of the communities they cover, it is difficult for any newspaper to provide the fair and complete coverage deemed a requirement for journalistic and economic success. A.S.N.E.'s policy lays out its goals, saying, "At a minimum, all newspapers should employ journalists of color and every newspaper should reflect the diversity of its community."
Mark Trahant, the new chairman of the Maynard Institute for Journalism Education, said on Friday that he thought "one of the reasons the numbers are down is the complete inattention to retention." He said that during the go-go days of the dot-coms, "people who didn't feel appreciated in the newsroom or invested in the newsroom took advantage of other opportunities."
He added that the reversal "will really give us a kick in the pants. We need to work harder or be smarter about how we go about this."
Included in the numbers released a year ago was a hint of this year's trend: while minority employment in newsrooms overall rose 0.3 percentage point, to 11.85 percent, in 1999, the percentage of black journalists declined for the first time, to 5.3 percent from 5.4 percent. Last year's report showed that about 6,700 of a work force of 56,200 journalists were minorities.
Gilbert Bailon, the executive editor of The Dallas Morning News, said that increasing diversity would be difficult in a slowing economy. "Fewer jobs are open," he said. "Papers are scaling back. The highly competitive people will be hired. But the numbers -- increasing them is going to be hard."
 FELICITY BARRINGER

HEADLINE: Opportunities For Workers In Technology Despite Cuts 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
Despite significant layoffs and rising unemployment in the dot-com industry, nearly a half a million information technology jobs could go unfilled this year for lack of just the right candidate, a new report says.
 American companies will try to hire 900,000 information technology workers this year, but in 425,000 of those cases they simply will not find job-seekers with the needed skills and training, according to a report today by the Information Technology Association of America, an industry trade group based in Washington. The survey was based on telephone interviews with 685 managers in companies with at least 50 employees. 
 The study projects that demand for new information technology employees this year will be down 44 percent from last year, when the association found a demand for 1.6 million such workers and a shortfall of roughly 850,000. The decline in demand is attributable to the slowdown in the high-technology sector and general weakness in the economy.
But for the more nimble workers, the jobs are there. Over all in the United States, employment in information technology is up 4 percent from the year before, with 10.4 million people employed in information technology positions in 2001 compared with roughly 10 million in 2000. Those positions account for about 7 percent of total employment in the United States this year. Demand for information technology workers remains highest in the Midwest, followed by the West.
While the study showed that demand for workers remained relatively high, it also showed a major shift in the types of jobs employers are looking to fill. For example, demand for technical support personnel, long the strongest category by far, fell 65 percent, the study said.
"It's a derivative thing," said Harris N. Miller, the association's president. "When you see a slowdown of PC sales, there's a ripple effect in employment in things like tech support." Demand for technical writing workers is 73 percent lower this year from last year, while demand for digital media workers fell 62 percent. Likewise, demand for Web development workers was down 25 percent.
The emphasis this year is on the traditional information technology skills, like programming, software engineering and network design and administration. Demand for candidates in enterprise systems grew more than in any other category, for example, climbing 62 percent.
"At least for now," the report says, "the market seems to be signaling its preference for substance over flash." The changes in job categories appear to reflect an emphasis on tightening operations and justifying past technology investments, rather than staffing up in anticipation of new business.
Companies are hiring more cautiously this year as well, taking a "go-slow" approach. Mr. Harris pointed out that last year, employers showed greater willingness to consider candidates with technical training rather than general education. "This year, they're looking more to the traditional four-year college degree," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Satellite Venture Seeks To Offer Service on Ground
New ICO Global Communications, the satellite communications venture that Craig O. McCaw rescued from bankruptcy last year, has asked the Federal Communications Commission to let it and rival companies develop land-based cellular service using radio-frequency spectrum reserved for satellite communications.
 Without such a change in the rules, New ICO said, it is unlikely that any company will be able to develop high-speed Internet access and other broadband services for the vast areas beyond the reach of cable and high-capacity land-based wireless networks. Page C2.

Allianz in Deal to Buy Dresdner
Allianz, the large German insurer, confirmed that it would buy the 80 percent of Dresdner Bank it does not own for about $20 billion. C2.

Number of Minority Journalists Falls
The number of minorities in the journalism profession dropped slightly last year, according to data to be released tomorrow. C11.

A Women's Magazine Light on Gloss
While many women's magazines show off the glossy, manicured side of womanhood, the magazine to which Rosie O'Donnell has lent her name, true to Ms. O'Donnell's style, is not about perfection. The magazine, which arrives on newsstands this week, focuses instead on the pits and crags of the American woman's life. The first issue of Rosie spends more space on politically and emotionally charged issues like gun violence, addiction and crippling illnesses than most women's magazines do in a year. C11.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is unveiling a new logo today minus the words Dean Witter. The logo is intended to signal that the firm is starting fresh as a fully integrated company four years after a merger created it. C2.

Despite significant layoffs and rising unemployment in the dot-com industry, nearly a half a million information technology jobs could go unfilled this year for lack of just the right candidate, a new report says. C8.

Orbcomm Global, a bankrupt satellite company that was auctioned off in March for pennies on the dollar, will try to rise again after using the bankruptcy process to shed its original equity owners and a large amount of debt. C4.

Crisis in Turkey Takes Toll on Media
The economic troubles in Turkey have hit the news media particularly hard. About 3,000 of its 12,000 workers have been laid off. C11.

Group Looks on Web's Bright Side
The Association of Internet Professionals, a nationwide organization of 11,500 individual and 160 corporate members, is trying to raise $10 million to "vigorously address the media's portrayal of the Internet industry," and to counter the gloomy themes that are dominating Internet coverage. C4.

Borders Returning to the Internet
For many Web businesses, where their customers live is becoming increasingly important, because they must treat people from different places differently. For many companies, this will be the year when the borderless online economy becomes an outdated concept. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C10.

HEADLINE: Patents; 
The publication of patent applications on the Web sends one inventor to the drawing board.

BYLINE:  By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
IT might seem only a modest modification to a Web site. But it represents one of the most radical changes in United States patent law in a century. 
 A few weeks ago, the Patent and Trademark Office altered its Web page devoted to searching the patent database to make way for new links that permit searches of patent applications that are published 18 months after filing. So far, only 84 applications have been published, but the significance is much greater. 
 The shift is part of the 1999 American Inventors Protection Act, which decreed that any patent application filed in the United States on or after Nov. 29, 2000, would be made public in this country in 18 months. The first applications are being published now, just four months later, because their inventors filed earlier applications overseas. The months those applications have been pending in Europe or Japan count toward the 18-month American deadline.
Anyone who follows intellectual property issues will remember that in the mid-1990's, what became known as "harmonization" -- the adjustment of American patent law to conform to the systems in Europe and Japan -- was a painful, contentious process. The United States patent system had a long tradition of secrecy, and it was accepted that a patent application was confidential until the day the patent was awarded. After that, it did not matter who saw the details of an invention because the inventor owned a patent that he could defend against infringement. Suddenly, though, a new law threatened to undermine that fundamental precept of secrecy, and opponents warned that it would destabilize the entire patent process.
Proponents countered that the published applications would create a valuable archive for the government's patent examiners, and for the public. In the end, opponents could not stop the drive to bring American patent law into harmony with laws elsewhere, and the practice of early publication was adopted here.
The first application to be published before a patent is granted was number 20010000001, submitted by Lawrence Clark and James Priest for their invention titled "Solvent mixture for use in a vapor degreaser and method of cleaning an article in a vapor de-greaser utilizing said solvent."
To limit the potential for economic damage from the possibility that someone would steal an inventor's idea from his application, the law also enables inventors to claim "provisional protection." The patent and trademark agency has described that as the right to "reasonable royalties from others who make, use, sell, or import the invention during the period between the time the patent application is published and the patent is granted."
The first patent application was published on March 15, and can be viewed at www.uspto.gov/patft /index.html. The patent agency set each Thursday for publication of applications, and only a handful were published each of the first couple weeks. But the agency says that within two years it expects to publish about 3,500 applications each week. It already publishes between 2,000 and 3,000 new patents each Tuesday.
An inventor who filed an application before November 2000, when the new law took effect, is exempt from early publication. Still, those inventors can request disclosure. Though it seems counterintuitive to reveal an application's claims, inventors who are interested in the provisional protection might seek early publication.
Wayne Lin, an inventor from California and chief executive of a company called HomeGopher Inc., was the first to do just that. He filed his application in June 1999, but asked that it be issued during the first week of the new procedure. Like all published applicants, Mr. Lin is now eligible for provisional protection.
"It basically boiled down to balancing two factors," Mr. Lin's attorney, Neal Cohen, said of the decision to publish early. "One was potentially obtaining provisional rights under the new law, and the other was disclosure of what until now had been kept secret."
Mr. Lin's invention is called "systems and methods for transacting business over a global communications network such as the Internet." It includes, Mr. Cohen said, a method of setting prices for products sold on the Internet by playing a game. The higher the score achieved by a player, the lower the price he will pay for a product he wants to buy, Mr. Cohen said.
The system is already in use at Mr. Lin's company's Web site, homegopher.com, Mr. Cohen added. In addition, Mr. Lin filed an international patent application; its contents were made public 18 months after he filed his American application. The information in the international application was published 18 months later.
"So really, it was already a matter of public record," Mr. Cohen said. "We weren't threatened by the U.S. disclosure, and we were gaining provisional protection."
So now, Mr. Lin has some way to protect his invention, a strategy that other inventors may want to adopt.
"If we didn't have provisional protection, we'd have no way to enforce the patent until it was issued," Mr. Cohen said. 
"Being as HomeGopher has a business model in practice, and international publication, it's possible that someone could try to copy the invention, so it's valuable to have the provisional rights," Mr. Cohen said. "Even a few months could turn out to be very valuable."
Once Mr. Lin decided to be the first person to request early publication, his lawyer had his work cut out for him. The nascent process didn't go smoothly.
"It was extremely cumbersome," Mr. Cohen remembered. "It ended up taking me about ten or twelve hours. The patent office was very helpful and one person there helped me through step-by-step, but they weren't ready for this yet."
He said he had to download several different types of software, re-submit his client's application electronically, and battle to file drawings with incompatible software on agency scanners.
"I think I'm going to wait until they're past the guinea pig stage," Mr. Cohen said with a laugh. "I do a lot of trademark filings electronically and that system works well. But for patent filing, there still seem to be a lot of bugs, problems and inconveniences."
One of those appears on the patent agency Web site. The database has been updated to include published applications, but the frequently-asked-questions page continues to advise that "all patent applications are maintained in the strictest confidence until the patent is issued."

PERSON: Stanley H. Ruttenberg 

HEADLINE: Stanley H. Ruttenberg, Union Organizer, Dies at 84 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Stanley H. Ruttenberg, a union organizer and consultant for more than 40 years who was an assistant secretary of labor in the Johnson administration, died on Wednesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 84.
 Drawn to the trade union movement as a young man, Mr. Ruttenberg later became an economist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. before working for the federal government. 
 W. Willard Wirtz, the secretary of labor with whom Mr. Ruttenberg served, said Mr. Ruttenberg knew how to combine fiscal policies with "a program of hands-on job training."
In the mid-1960's, Mr. Wirtz recalled, Mr. Ruttenberg helped to eliminate widespread racial discrimination in state employment offices. At that time, Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibited discrimination in federally financed programs and directed government agencies to enforce that policy in the programs they administered.
The federal government at that time financed the United States Employment Service, established in 1933, but states operated the agency's local offices.
Mr. Ruttenberg, who was directing the Labor Department's enforcement of Title VI, sent 10 teams around the country to investigate nearly 50 complaints of discrimination and other suspicious situations.
While urging voluntary compliance, Mr. Ruttenberg made it clear that he was prepared to cut off employment service money to any state that refused to comply with the law. Some offices changed their practices.
In a newspaper interview at the time, Mr. Ruttenberg said change would come slowly because racial discrimination had such deep roots.
"You don't break that thing overnight," he said.
Stanley Harvey Ruttenberg was born in St. Paul , on March 19, 1917. He grew up in Nemacolin, Pa., and attended the Massanutten Military Academy in Woodstock, Va. He earned a bachelor of science degree at the University of Pittsburgh.
As a child, Mr. Ruttenberg recalled, he developed a lifetime dedication to the trade union movement when he stirred the soup pot for striking coal miners and heard them talk about their discontent.
In the 1930's, Mr. Ruttenberg was a union organizer in Cincinnati, Chicago and other Midwestern cities.
In World War II, he served as a first lieutenant in the Army on Okinawa.
Prominent as a union economist in the 1950's, Mr. Ruttenberg became head of the research department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
In 1963, President Lyndon B. Johnson appointed Mr. Ruttenberg as a special assistant to the secretary of labor. Five years later, the president named him to succeed Daniel Patrick Moynihan as assistant secretary of labor for manpower.
After six years in the Labor Department, Mr. Ruttenberg became a consultant, establishing himself as Stanley H. Ruttenberg & Associates in Washington, where he helped clients win federal contracts. He retired in 1982.
Mr. Ruttenberg is survived by his wife, Gertrude, of Bethesda; a daughter, Ruth Ruttenberg of Bethesda; two sons, Joel, of Katonah, N.Y., and Charles, of Rockville, Md.; four grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts City Plans To Destroy Public Housing 

BYLINE:  By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: FALL RIVER, Mass. 

 BODY:
Here, said the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to this dense old city of triple-decker tenements and textile factories by the sea. Here is $9 million to fix up a public housing project.
 No, thank you, was Mayor Edward M. Lambert Jr.'s response. We have enough public housing. We would prefer to tear the project down. 
 Tear down public housing? responded some advocates for the poor. That is no way to solve the problem. 
The problem, at its very bottom, is that an average two-bedroom apartment in and around Boston these days might rent for at least $1,500, and even in cheaper neighborhoods like Roxbury and parts of Dorchester rents are not much lower. An hour's drive south in Fall River, a two-bedroom place might rent for about $500. 
As a result, poor people increasingly squeezed out of Boston and its environs become ever more likely to seek refuge in distant suburbs or old outlying cities like Fall River, or Lynn, or New Bedford -- and they often bring needs that fall upon their new hosts. 
Boston's prices are extreme when compared with most regions', but similar pictures emerge around the country in cities, like Seattle, Chicago and Washington, that have especially prospered in the last decade, said Bruce J. Katz, director of the Brookings Institution Center on Urban and Metropolitan Policy. 
"There's a group of inner-ring suburbs and satellite cities that have not participated in the prosperity," Mr. Katz said; rather, they have ended up bearing more of the burden with fewer of the rewards. "Fall River is acting as an escape valve, but it is not benefiting; this is the problem," he said.
Mr. Katz and other experts noted that in a few other spots, including Prince George's County outside Washington, local officials have recently tried to fight what they see as an unfair load of low-income housing. In Lowell, Mass., city officials recently set a precedent for Fall River by declining state money to fix up a housing project, saying they wanted to tear it down instead.
But such moves draw fire from those who emphasize the overall shortage of affordable housing and argue that banning new units or tearing down old ones is the worst of solutions.
Here in Fall River, Mark Sullivan, director of Citizens for Citizens, a private nonprofit antipoverty agency, argued, "It makes no sense, when you have a housing crisis in the state, to knock down public housing."
Mr. Sullivan said he agreed that the situation was unfair. "They're using the smaller cities as a dumping ground to deal with a big-city problem," he said. But he differed on the solution: "The mayor wants to knock down public housing. I want these people to come with additional resources."
In Fall River, the population of poor newcomers, called by some the "Section 8 people" for the rent vouchers they get under a federal housing program, has become a political issue with racial overtones. Many of the boom refugees from Boston and other parts of the state are black and Hispanic. Fall River has long been dominated by the children of Portuguese, Italian and Irish immigrants. 
"Some people are racist here," said Bernice Edwards, a home health aide who lives in Watuppa Heights, the project the mayor wants to tear down. But Ms. Edwards, who moved here three years ago from the Dorchester section of Boston, said that overall, "I feel more comfortable here than I did in Boston." Her three children love the schools, and it is safer here, she said. Her sister has moved in nearby, too.
Still, Ms. Edwards tried to move back home to Boston a year or so ago. But she found that the $1,100 rent voucher she had would not begin to cover a three-bedroom apartment in Dorchester. So she stayed here. And now the Boston prices are even higher.
It is not that there are so very many such Boston exiles -- perhaps a few hundred a year, some estimate, in a city of more than 90,000. And it is not as if they are keeping Fall River from doing better: the city's unemployment rate has dropped from 19 percent in 1990 to about 4 percent, and new businesses, enticed by tax breaks and the ready labor pool, have been setting up shop here. The crime rate has dropped as well, though calls to the police have risen disproportionately in the housing projects. But city officials point out that despite the boom of the 1990's, a higher percentage of Fall River's residents were poor in 2000 than in 1990. 
"It's simply about fairness," Mayor Lambert said. "It's simply about the city doing what it needs to do for our poor, our disabled, our elderly, but not being asked to perform that service for other communities."
"Let them take the $9 million they want to give us for Watuppa Heights and use it to create units in Boston or in other places," he said, referring to the state government. "It's silly to put housing in communities that don't need it and don't want it."
Mayor Lambert said he was passing no judgment on the poor people arriving from Boston and elsewhere. In fact, he said, "There's a fairness issue here, too, for those families. Those families should not be displaced from their extended families in Dorchester" and other places. 
The city, which apparently needs the State Legislature's approval of its plan to tear down Watuppa Heights, recently hired a consulting firm to survey its housing. The firm found that 17.3 percent went to tenants getting government subsidies for their rent. 
That is one of the highest rates in the state. Still, many challenge Mayor Lambert's proposal. "Cities like Fall River disproportionately have to serve the needs of poor people, and there ought to be more attention to that on a broader basis," said Nicolas Retsinas, director of Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies. But, he added, "These kinds of actions in isolation are oblivious to what is a dearth of affordable housing, particularly in this part of the country."
In the Minneapolis area and a few other places, Mr. Katz of the Brookings Institution said, richer cities acknowledge the contributions of their poorer neighbors in the region's health by sharing some tax revenues. But such regional thinking is rare.
Earlier this year, Gov. Paul Cellucci of Massachusetts announced his administration's latest affordable-housing initiative. He proposed legislation to let nearly 1,000 acres of state land be developed; he also proposed a $460 million housing bond bill, mainly to maintain older units. 
But the governor's proposals inevitably looked puny next to the power of the market they sought to temper. In the latest city assessment of housing prices in Boston, assessors found that even in some of the city's poorest sections, like East Boston, some house values rose 50 percent last year alone. On average, house values rose 33 percent last year, and prices tended to rise across the board. Some three-family houses in lower Roxbury nearly doubled in value.
Poor people tend to be especially hurt by such price increases because they are usually renters rather than owners, and so are not insulated from the price inflation. 
Mr. Sullivan of Citizens for Citizens said that most of the poor people who come to Fall River do so "because they've been priced out of living in the city of Boston, and any opportunity to move back to Boston, they go."
In a larger sense, he said, "I guess this is a fight over the soul of Fall River" -- between those who want it to become more of a middle-class suburb and take a "not in my backyard" attitude to the poor, and those who like it as a gateway city for immigrants and the needy. 
And in an even larger sense, Mr. Sullivan said, "There's a point where nobody wants to deal with the poor, and we're just going to keep moving them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bernice Edwards moved from Boston to Fall River, Mass. She lives in the Watuppa Heights project, which the mayor wants to tear down. (Jared Leeds for The New York Times)
