HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
Who's Afraid of Challenges? Not Minneapolis Theaters

BYLINE:  By Stephen Kinzer 

 BODY:
From Minneapolis, near the source of the Mississippi, an extraordinary stream of theater has been pouring forth for years.
 Both the city's nationally known theater companies -- the Guthrie Theater and Children's Theater Company -- recently staged ambitious new productions, one of them a kaleidoscopic fantasy about the river itself. Their success has intensified enthusiasm for a planned building program that would enhance the city's reputation as a vital center of American regional theater. 
 The Guthrie, the brightest jewel in the city's cultural crown, is planning a $100 million three-theater complex on a vacant stretch of the Mississippi shore near the center of town. Advocates say this project would allow the Guthrie to expand its role in local and national cultural life and would also attract development downtown. 
Yesterday the Guthrie announced that it had selected the French architect Jean Nouvel, whose buildings include the Lyon Opera House, to build the new complex. The announcement said he was chosen for this project because of his success in creating "buildings that stretch far beyond traditional constraints."
No one in the Minneapolis area needs reminding of the Guthrie's importance. The theater has more than 30,000 subscribers and presents about 10 plays in each 12-month season. Some are produced there by directors and actors from around the world, while others, like the Royal National Theater's forthcoming "Hamlet" with Simon Russell Beale in the title role, come from other companies.
Critics lavished praise on the recent Guthrie production of Edward Albee's psychodrama "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" The roles of the brawling husband and wife were played by Patrick Stewart, a veteran of both the Royal Shakespeare Company and "Star Trek," and Mercedes Ruehl, a winner of both Tony and Academy Awards.
This play, widely accepted as an American classic, reflects the Guthrie's preference for plays that have stood decades or centuries of scrutiny. Mr. Albee does not often allow it to be performed, fearing that its message will be lost if productions do not meet high standards. He helped choose the actors in the Guthrie production and attended rehearsals and previews.
The director, David Esbjornson, developed a close relationship with Mr. Albee, whose "Play About the Baby" he recently directed in its New York premiere. Some directors shy away from "Virginia Woolf" because the film version starring Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor seems so definitive. Mr. Esbjornson, however, brought some new touches to the scathing argument this couple carries on for the entire length of the play.
Mr. Stewart's character was less physically aggressive than Burton's was; the liquor he drank over the course of the evening made him steadily more ironic and acerbic but rarely violent. He quietly lacerated his foul-mouthed wife, played by Ms. Ruehl as stalking, energy-packed and explosive. She moved constantly and dominated the stage, while he often faded into the background, sharpening his verbal knives.
If this production showed again what the Guthrie can do, it also reflected the house's shortcomings. The 1,300-seat theater is far too big to present new plays by emerging authors, and the company's smaller space is cramped and in another part of town. Offices, scenery workshops and wardrobes are also scattered.
"The flagship role of this theater has been lost a bit because we're not able to connect with contemporary playwrights," said the artistic director, Joe Dowling, who formerly led the Abbey Theater in Dublin. "If this new complex we're looking at becomes reality, we'll be able to do classic theater, serious modern theater at the top level and also a whole range of other things. And it would do so much for the town. Minneapolis doesn't have a signature building. This could be it."
The Guthrie is asking the city to provide about $25 million worth of site preparations for the new complex and plans to ask the State Legislature to approve another $25 million. The rest is to be raised privately at the same time that the Children's Theater Company hopes to raise $25 to $30 million to renovate and greatly expand its home.
Few people in Minneapolis doubt that both institutions will reach their fund-raising goals. Both are repeatedly cited as examples of the area's community spirit and dedication to culture.
Some people attribute these qualities to socialist traditions brought to the city by Scandinavian immigrants. Others say they arise from a conviction of local boosters that the wintry region needs something to make it attractive.
Children's theater is far less developed in the United States than in Europe and other parts of the world. The Children's Theater Company is unusual not only because it regularly produces large-scale new work in its own space, but also because it often hires directors who have made their names in productions for adults. Like the Guthrie, it has found that a combination of high-level directors, designers and performers can attract big audiences as well as national and even international attention.
In recent years the company has produced work by authors ranging from Dr. Seuss to Garrison Keillor to C. S. Lewis. Among the pieces in development is one based on a Gabriel Garcia Marquez story.
The recent show at the Children's Theater reflected the energy that this company invests in its productions. Called "Mississippi Panorama," it was a combination history lesson, adventure story and ecological fable about the river. It was two years in development, with cast members sometimes going to the extreme of pouring water over themselves in search of ways to convey the qualities of water onstage.
"Theater is important to children because it introduces them to metaphor, visual poetry, choreography -- things that can literally last a lifetime," said Peter C. Brosius, the artistic director. "But one thing we've seen from our success is the challenge of reaching older kids, the teenage audience."
'We need new ways to keep them engaged with theater," he said, adding, "I'm sure the community will respond."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
New Money, Old Divides, High Hopes

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
The conflicts roiling inside Luigi (Silvio Orlando), the central character of Mimmo Calopresti's elliptical family drama, "I Prefer the Sound of the Sea," might be seen as emblematic of the social divisions within Italy, a country whose northern and southern regions are as different from each other as those in the United States.
 A wealthy businessman living in Turin, Luigi grew up in the south, in the mostly rural, economically depressed region of Calabria, which forms the toe of Italy's "boot." Returning there for a visit, he exudes the smug magnanimity of a poor boy returning in glory to the scene of his humble roots. 
 Luigi's pride in having risen above his background is one reason he impulsively agrees to help a troubled distant relative, Rosario (Michele Raso), a handsome, unsmiling teenager whose mother was recently murdered and whose father is in prison. Luigi volunteers to bring Rosario back with him to Turin and enroll him in a school for troubled teenagers run by an old friend, Don Lorenzo (Mr. Calopresti), who is a priest. Luigi, who is estranged from his wife, is the father of a teenage son, Matteo (Paolo Cirio), Rosario's age, and he has high hopes that the two boys will become friends. 
The movie, filmed in muted colors by Luca Bigazzi, is a subtle but rambling exploration of how good intentions can go awry, especially if the assumptions underlying those intentions include an unconscious snobbery. The nouveau riche plushness of Luigi's life, it turns out, is far less secure than it initially seemed. The corporation for which he works has put him in charge of investigating and cleaning up some internal corruption, and Luigi discovers to his chagrin that the bosses may be setting him up to take the fall.
The heart of the story is the relationship between Rosario, who is devoutly religious and so private that he seems locked inside himself, and Luigi's spoiled, angry son. Rosario's extreme austerity and self-discipline inspire Matteo to sneer and lash out at his father's luxurious way of life. And in the film's most dramatic scene, one New Year's Eve he goes on a rampage of destruction in his father's home. That rampage was preceded by other acts of theft and vandalism. But Luigi, as naive about his son as he is about his business colleagues, has wrongly assumed Rosario to be the guilty party.
This moody, well-acted film, which New Directors/New Films is showing tonight at 6 and tomorrow night at 9 at the Museum of Modern Art, stirs up many psychological crosscurrents. But its tendency to wander from theme to theme diffuses its emotional impact. The movie doesn't devote nearly enough screen time to the relationship between the teenagers, and the tentative scenes between Luigi and his mistress might as well belong to another movie. The movie's emotional center of gravity isn't Luigi but the enigmatic, poker-faced Rosario, whose ferocious pride and sense of honor set him apart from everyone else. He remains an alien in their midst as well as a mystery to the viewer.
Laurence Attali's short film, "Baobab," which opens the program, is a witty mythical examination of the baobab tree, the national symbol of Senegal. In addition to having many practical uses, these twisting, gnarly trees are invested with centuries of folklore and are thought by many to house spirits that can work practical magic. 
The movie humorously cautions against investing the baobab with too many magical properties. 

I PREFER THE SOUND OF THE SEA

Directed by Mimmo Calopresti; written (in Italian, with English subtitles) by Mr. Calopresti and Francesco Bruni; director of photography, Luca Bigazzi; edited by Massimo Fiocchi; music by Franco Piersanti; art director, Allessandro Marrazzo; produced by Donatella Botti, Roberto Cicutto and Luigi Musini. HEADLINE: Old-Economy California Towns Fear a Slump 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: NORWALK, Calif., April 2 

 BODY:
Think of an economic slowdown in California, and the image that comes to mind these days is of dot-commers having to make do with town houses instead of mansions or, worse, regular coffee instead of caffe latte. 
 But while much attention has been focused on the evaporation of new-economy start-ups and the impact on the state, many local officials say the parts of California that are increasingly vulnerable to an economic slowdown are working-class cities like this one, a largely Hispanic suburb of Los Angeles filled with new immigrants just gaining a toehold in the middle class. 
 Norwalk, situated in an area whose old-economy industries were badly weakened in the recession of the early 90's, is critically dependent on volatile sales taxes to pay for local services. And because there are signs that consumers are starting to tighten their belts in a city where the retail base is already modest, officials are increasingly worried about the prospect of layoffs and of cutbacks in services like libraries, schools and parks. 
Some other warning signs are also starting to appear. A big contributor to the local economy was a Montgomery Ward, one of the chain of department stores that announced earlier this year that it was going out of business nationwide. In addition, another ailing retailer, Home Base, is closing its store here for what is expected to be a long renovation. Norwalk also used to have a Sears and a J. C. Penney. No more. 
Meanwhile, says Mayor Cheri Kelley, a number of owners of mom-and-pop stores have been telling her that they are witnessing slower sales even as they are also hit by soaring energy prices. 
" 'Vulnerable' is definitely the word for those kinds of towns," said Ted Gibson, chief economist for the California Department of Finance.
"We have not started to get the hard figures on sales, but the warning flags are flying," Mr. Gibson said. "Even if we avoid an actual recession, those are the communities that are going to feel any slowdown, even a small one, and it is likely to be pretty abrupt." 
Norwalk, a compact city of 110,000 people, is a magnet for immigrants who have started to build a nest egg. Many of its modest houses were built in the 1950's and 60's, and sell today for less than $200,000.
A major part of its fiscal problems, and those of the surrounding cities of southern Los Angeles County, involves the way property taxes are managed in California, and dates back to two issues: Proposition 13, the state voter initiative that lowered property tax rates two decades ago, and the measures the state government took to stanch the huge budget deficits of the last recession. 
Proposition 13 froze at 1978 levels the formulas for allocating property tax revenue. This meant that when the county governments collected the taxes and then passed a small portion to local governments, the cities that had not added their own, incremental tax on top received less per capita than cities that had. Norwalk was one of those so-called low-tax cities. 
Then, in the early 1990's, when the state was facing multibillion-dollar deficits, the Legislature ordered the counties to hand over 18 percent of the local property tax revenue to pay for state-run education programs. That took another bite out of the sums that made their way into city coffers. 
As a result of all this, officials here say, exactly one penny of every dollar in property taxes paid by Norwalk's residents winds up back in the city's budget. 
"The state uses cities like an A.T.M. machine," said Mayor Kelley, a local real estate broker. "When they need money, it's ka-ching." 
The problem has been the subject of several government studies, but no action. 
"When you have these growing, young populations in cities in urban areas, with a growing demand for basic services like schools, police and the like, and this kind of fiscal structure, you have the makings of a real crisis," said David Abel, a consultant who was chairman of a panel that produced a report on the problem for the state last year. 
On the other hand, California's cities get to keep a larger share of sales tax revenue: one cent of every 8.25, the tax paid on each $1 in purchases. The result is that while new housing does not generate much tax revenue for cities, retailing does. 
That has led to a fierce competition among cities like Norwalk to attract every national retail chain possible. 
"We have a Circuit City, and a Target is coming," boasted Ernie V. Garcia, the Norwalk city manager. "We're also getting an Office Depot. These are really pluses. This is all we think about, because retail is our lifeblood." 
Just to the north of here, the city of Pico Rivera is also competing for retailers, trying to transform an old 200-acre industrial site into malls, commercial buildings and factories. 
The site was originally home to a Ford factory, which was later bought by Northrop Grumman. But the factory was closed in the early 1990's, and 15,000 jobs were moved elsewhere or eliminated. 
"We lost more than half our tax base in the twinkle of an eye," said Dennis Courtemarche, Pico Rivera's city manager. 
More recently, Pico Rivera, like Norwalk, has also lost a Montgomery Ward, and it is contemplating a difficult future. 
"What contingency plans do we have if things get bad?" Mr. Courtemarche said. "We don't have any."

GRAPHIC: Photo: This ailing retailer is shutting its Norwalk, Calif., store for a renovation that could be lengthy. For Norwalk, the timing could hardly be worse. (Kim Kulish/Saba, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Chief Says Milosevic Shouldn't Be Sent to Hague 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, April 2 

 BODY:
President Vojislav Kostunica said today that Yugoslavia should not extradite former President Slobodan Milosevic to The Hague to face war-crimes charges, even if the United States again threatens to withhold foreign aid.
 "It should never happen," Mr. Kostunica said in an interview. "I think that it's possible to do everything so that it should never happen." 
 In the negotiations before Mr. Milosevic's surrender to the police early Sunday morning, he sought and received written assurances that his arrest on domestic charges of corruption and abuse of power was not a precursor to a transfer to The Hague.
Mr. Milosevic's arrest was an important event, said Mr. Kostunica, who defeated Mr. Milosevic in elections in September. "Its meaning is to make public all the violations of the law and rights committed by the old regime led by Milosevic, so people can have a complete, clear picture," he said. "There will be no hide-and-seek -- everything will come out. If we speak of the need for social catharsis, then the most important is this one."
Speaking personally, he said, the arrest of Mr. Milosevic ends "a very painful period in our lives and in the lives of all these states, a period of lost years." He said he was reminded of a book by the Yugoslav writer Borislav Pekic, who long lived in exile, about his time in jail in the 1930's for involvement with a pro-democracy group, called "The Years Eaten by Locusts." 
"I think about what this country might have been and the sort of lives we might have lived -- it lasted too long," he said.
He also said that what he considers misguided Western policy, including sanctions and isolation, helped preserve Mr. Milosevic's rule, not shorten it.
Mr. Kostunica criticizes the tribunal at The Hague that prosecutes war crimes in the countries that made up the larger Communist-era Yugoslavia. He contends that it is political and accuses it of practicing selective justice, following shaky rules of law and being biased against Serbia -- with little inclination to indict Croats, Bosnian Muslims, ethnic Albanians or NATO leaders for alleged war crimes. Still, Mr. Kostunica said, "one should make certain compromises" and cooperate with the tribunal.
Yugoslavia will investigate war crimes and help The Hague to do so, he said, and Mr. Milosevic should be brought to trial on war crimes charges, too -- but before domestic courts. Officials of The Hague tribunal say Yugoslavia, as a member of the United Nations, is obligated to turn over any indicted people on its territory, including Mr. Milosevic. Any domestic trial on war crimes charges must still end with his extradition, Carla Del Ponte, the chief prosecutor, has said.
The tribunal's current indictment against Mr. Milosevic, brought by her predecessor, covers the actions by Serbian troops against Kosovo Albanians in 1999. Ms. Del Ponte said today that she was getting ready to sign a new indictment of Mr. Milosevic for the war in Bosnia from 1992 to 1995, though she could use a few more months to prepare the case; her aides say she expects Mr. Milosevic in The Hague this year. Mr. Milosevic is widely blamed for supporting Serbian aggression in Bosnia and in Croatia as Yugoslavia split apart a decade ago.
Mr. Kostunica said he also supported a draft law on cooperation with the tribunal that would allow the extradition of those indicted, both Yugoslav citizens and non-citizens, after a rapid judicial procedure.
But the case of a former president is different, Mr. Kostunica argued, saying most members of the democratic coalition that ousted Mr. Milosevic agree. Even the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, who was a strong supporter of the early arrest of Mr. Milosevic, has publicly opposed extraditing Mr. Milosevic to The Hague. Serbia is the dominant entity in the current Yugoslavia.
"It's not legitimate," Mr. Kostunica said. "Other presidents are not being sent to The Hague. I must make some compromises, but there is a line I cannot cross. Even among those people in the Serbian and Yugoslav governments who don't think about legitimacy but about what might be politically useful, the prevailing view is that it would be unacceptable."
He understands the view in Washington that the arrest of Mr. Milosevic just before a March 31 deadline, in order to retain the flow of American aid, is proof that "pressure works."
"But that is incorrect thinking, even when Milosevic was in power," he said.
It was not international pressure that brought down Mr. Milosevic, he said, but the Serbian people themselves, by their votes and demonstrations. "If pressure did not work with Milosevic in power, and now he is no longer in power and we are having a horrible situation in Serbia, what is the sense of such threats now?" he said.
Mr. Kostunica described a bad economy and infrastructure and a ruined system of judicial and political institutions, all of which must be reconstructed, and an unstable regional environment.
The future of Yugoslavia itself is uncertain, with Serbia's tiny sister republic, Montenegro, pressing for independence. And Mr. Kostunica described "dangers from all sides," including Kosovo, southern Serbia and Macedonia, where ethnic Albanian militants are fighting for independence. Albania itself is not especially stable, he noted.
He wants to work with NATO and the NATO-led peacekeepers in Kosovo, he said. "But soldiers with arms should take some risks," he said. 
"It seems that only the lost lives of Serbs, Albanians and Macedonians are acceptable, but not the slightest scratch is acceptable for KFOR soldiers," he said, referring to the NATO-led peacekeeping force. He understands the fear Washington and the peacekeepers have of becoming targets of Albanians in Kosovo, he said, as in Vietnam. "But more must be done, because NATO becomes responsible for what it has not done," he said.
An independent Montenegro would produce more regional instability, he said, noting that more refugees live in Serbia -- about 800,000 -- than the 650,000 people in Montenegro. But he strongly opposes a moratorium or delay on Montenegro's deciding its future, saying Serbia would suffer from any further period of uncertainty.
Yugoslavia does not need more pressure and conditions from the United States and international groups, he said, "but patience, to let us cope with these problems, especially when one considers that the stability of Yugoslavia and Serbia is very important for this unstable region."
What Yugoslavia needs "is something that from the beginning of the American republic is called self-rule and self-government," he said. "How can our people and courts become competent to deal with questions like war crimes unless you're given a chance?"

HEADLINE: Ford Introduces Its Delayed Internet Shopping Site in 9 States 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., April 2 

 BODY:
In another sign that the Internet may not produce quick changes in the way cars are sold, the Ford Motor Company announced today that its much-delayed Internet service had begun doing business, but in only nine states.
 In seven of those states, moreover, the Web site will quote only the manufacturer's suggested retail price; customers will have to send an e-mail message to a dealer to ask for a lower price. Only in New Jersey and Delaware is the new service, known as FordDirect.com, quoting prices below the suggested retail price, and customers must still visit dealers to actually buy a new car or truck. 
 The seven states in which FordDirect.com will list only Ford's suggested retail price are California, Georgia, Massachusetts, Nevada, Tennessee, Texas and Washington. 
FordDirect.com, a joint venture between the automaker and its dealers, acknowledged that its start had been slower than expected. But it said that dealers would be trained to use the system in 15 more states this month and that regulatory approvals were being pursued in these states. When Ford announced FordDirect last August, it predicted that the site would start doing business in California in September and quickly spread to other states.
But the site ran into objections from state regulators and from Ford's own dealers. "We came out as a bunch of boastful dealers, probably, thinking we had everything taken care of," said David Kain, the chief operating officer of FordDirect.
Regulators in many states, including California, demanded that any price quoted on the Web site be made available to all customers, as required by many state rules for advertising. Dealers objected to quoting an online price below the suggested retail price, fearing that this would limit their ability to charge close to the suggested retail prices for customers who were not very good bargainers.
The site does not offer deep discounts, even in New Jersey and Delaware, online customers are quoted the average price that other customers obtain after haggling. But it does allow customers to see a list of which models are on each dealer's lot and how they are equipped. Baba Shetty, an online automotive retailing analyst at Forrester Research Inc., said that the site would probably influence many shoppers but that it was unclear how many people would use it for purchases. 
The Consumer Federation of America, a Washington-based coalition of consumer groups, recently began a campaign to change state regulations on auto sales, which dealers have used to discourage automakers and independent companies from selling directly over the Internet.
The state rules generally require that new cars be sold only by dealers who have been licensed and inspected by the regulators and specifically bar manufacturers from bypassing their dealers. Companies like CarsDirect.com must obtain their cars from dealers rather than purchasing directly from automakers.
Jack Gillis, the federation's auto expert, said that FordDirect's name was a misnomer. "Ford, for the most part, is still inhibited from selling direct to the consumer," he said.
At a news conference today at Ford's headquarters here, FordDirect officials introduced a New Jersey man who, they said, had been the service's first customer. Peter J. Grappuso, a 42-year-old trucking company supervisor from Beachwood, N.J., said he had found the site on the evening of Sunday, March 25, and had been able to buy a dark-red Ford Ranger pickup the next day at a discounted price with only a short visit to a nearby dealership.
Most automakers are using Web sites to provide information about vehicle features but are referring customers to dealers to obtain price quotes. The exceptions are Ford and General Motors, which has also run into obstacles after announcing an ambitious plan last August to set up a Web site with its dealers.
On May 1, the Chevrolet division of G.M. will begin a 90-day test in the Virginia and Maryland suburbs of Washington with Autobytel.com, listing online the inventory of 22 dealers. Each dealer in that experiment will have a choice of listing a discounted price, the manufacturer's suggested retail price or no price.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL BRIEFING 

 BODY:
 WEST

LOS ANGELES: DIRTY TRICK DRAWS INQUIRY -- The district attorney is investigating an apparent dirty trick in the mayoral race in which a woman identifying herself with a name that sounded like Gloria Marina left recorded telephone messages accusing one candidate, former Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, of being soft on crime. That outraged County Supervisor Gloria Molina, the city's most prominent Hispanic politician, who has endorsed Mr. Villaraigosa. Rival campaigns have disclaimed any responsibility for the calls, which were apparently aimed at white Jewish women, a key Democratic voter group in Los Angeles. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

SAN FRANCISCO: SUIT ON BALLAST WATER -- Three environmental groups filed a federal suit to seek controls over ships' discharge of ballast water. The plaintiffs -- the Center for Marine Conservation, San Francisco Baykeeper and the Pacific Coast Federation of Fisherman's Associations -- assert that the practice, permitted under the Clean Water Act, introduces invasive species that cost the economy billions of dollars a year. The Environmental Protection Agency has said it is trying to address the problem.
Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

HAWAII: TEACHER WALKOUT NEARS -- Hawaii's 13,000 public-school teachers are threatening to strike on Thursday if a contract deadlock over pay is not resolved. The Hawaii State Teachers Association is seeking a 22 percent raise over four years, at a cost of $260 million. The state is offering a 12 percent increase, costing about $67 million, saying it cannot afford to give the teachers more. Teachers, who earn $29,000 to $58,000, have been without a contract since January 1999. About 183,000 children, from kindergarten through 12th grade, would be affected. (NYT)

IDAHO: ANTI-ABORTION BILL ENACTED -- Gov. Dirk Kempthorne has signed a bill eliminating state financing of health-related abortions for poor women, saying it will protect "the lives of unborn children." Critics say it will just spark a legal battle, pointing to a 1994 court ruling that prompted the state to pay for health-related abortions under Medicaid. Abortions, meanwhile, are declining in Idaho: there were 867 in 1999, a record low since reporting began in 1977, the state said. The peak was 1981, with 2,706. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

MIDWEST

ILLINOIS: MORE SCRUTINY IN CICERO -- Federal observers will monitor polling places again today in Cicero, where Betty Loren-Maltese, the Republican incumbent, is being challenged by Joseph Mario Moreno in a hotly contested race for president of the Town Board. A court order allows federal authorities to monitor elections for the next five years in Cicero, which has been plagued in the past by political corruption and scandal. Observers were on hand during the primary in February, but found no major problems.
John W. Fountain (NYT)

SOUTH

SOUTH CAROLINA: A BACKTRACK OF SORTS ON HOME INVADERS -- Attorney General Charlie Condon said he would consult with police departments from now on before dismissing charges against residents who attack home invaders. Police officials in Walterboro had earlier said all charges should not have been dismissed against a woman who killed the father of her son. While Mr. Condon, a Republican, agreed to the policy shift, he also accused Gov. Jim Hodges and other Democrats of acting politically in spreading criticism about the home-invasion policy. David Firestone (NYT)

ALABAMA: NO VENUE CHANGE IN CHURCH BOMBING -- A state judge rejected a defense request to move the murder trial of two former Klansmen in the 1963 Birmingham church bombing that killed four black girls. Lawyers for the defendants, Thomas E. Blanton Jr. and Bobby Frank Cherry, had cited a poll showing that 42 percent of local residents thought they were guilty or probably guilty. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

NEW ENGLAND

RHODE ISLAND: LEAD-PAINT SUIT ADVANCES -- A judge gave the state attorney general the go-ahead to sue paint companies for health damage caused by lead paint. The suit, closely watched by other states and counties, seeks compensation for the costs of eliminating the paint and caring for sickened children. Industry lawyers had argued that the state lacked the authority to bring such a suit, which is modeled on nationwide tobacco litigation.
Carey Goldberg (NYT)

FLUSH TIMES ON THE SLOPES -- It has been so bounteous a year, snow-wise, for New England ski resorts that many are extending their seasons. Some big areas, like Cannon Mountain in New Hampshire, plan to stay open through Easter, and a few hope to last into May. New England weather has yet to really warm up, and some areas have received more than 200 inches of snow. This banner year follows several leaner, warmer ones for New England's resorts. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

WASHINGTON

REDUCTION IN CHILD ABUSE -- Reports of child abuse and neglect declined in 1999 for the sixthyear in a row, but there were still 826,000 victims of such maltreatment, the government reported. Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said the number of abused and neglected children had declined 19 percent since 1993, when the number of victims reached a record of 1,018,692. The government said 1,100 children died as a result of abuse or neglect in 1999. Children younger than a year old accounted for 43 percent of the deaths.
Robert Pear (NYT)

POOR GRADES FOR AIRLINES -- More airplanes are late and more passengers are complaining about service, despite industry promises to do better, a new study by two university professors said. It also found more passengers bumped from overcrowded flights and more mishandled checked baggage. Delta won the highest rating for passenger service among major airlines, followed by Alaska and Southwest. America West received the lowest ranking. (AP)

BUSH AND HISPANIC LAWMAKERS MEET -- President Bush met with 15 of the 18 members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and told them, "I respect the Hispanic culture a lot." A number of members said later that they were optimistic about working with Mr. Bush but had received no commitments that he would side with them on issues like amnesty for certain illegal immigrants, money for some education programs and restoring money for the Small Business Administration. The caucus also gave the president a letter signed by more than 110 members of Congress asking that he permanently stop the Navy exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques, but he had no comment. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

 CORRECTION:
A report in the National Briefing column on April 3 about a suit by three environmental groups seeking controls over ships' discharge of ballast water misidentified a plaintiff. It was the Northwest Environmental Advocates. The Pacific Coast Federation of Fishermen's Associations was among organizations that petitioned the Environmental Protection Agency about controls, but it did not sue.

HEADLINE: The Albanian Connection; 
As Italians Move Up, a New Group Does the Pizza and Pasta

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
The Famous Famiglia restaurant at Broadway and 50th Street in Manhattan is like many of hundreds of pizzerias in the city. A scene from Venice adorns one wall. Pictures of famous Italian-Americans like Frank Sinatra and Rocky Marciano hang from another. The menu offers "Italian specialties" like eggplant parmigiana and baked ziti.
 The only thing un-Italian about Famous Famiglia is the famiglia that own it: Tony, Paul, John and Giorgio Kolaj, Albanians from the former Yugoslavia. Like hundreds of their compatriots who fled to New York during the cold war or the Balkan conflict of the 1990's, the Kolajs have quietly prospered by opening Italian restaurants, cooking Italian food and playing down their own ethnic origins. 
 "We're very true to the Italian recipes, more than the Italians," said Paul Kolaj, who moved to the United States in 1970, grew up in the South Bronx and opened his first pizzeria in 1986. "I'm not sure I like the idea of advertising the fact that we're Albanian. It's a touchy situation." 
If the culinary affinity doesn't seem obvious -- Albanian cuisine includes dishes like faszle (bean stew), not pizza -- the Albanians say they are capitalizing on experience and geography. Many spent time in refugee camps in Italy, where they learned the food and the language, before immigrating to the United States. During the cold war, many residents of Albania defied their Communist government by tuning into Italian television. Before that, Italy under Mussolini annexed the country of Albania in April 1939, and controlled it until 1945.
Exact numbers are hard to come by, but some restaurateurs say ethnic Albanians own or operate more than 100 Italian restaurants and pizzerias in the metropolitan region, including all five boroughs, Westchester County, Connecticut and New Jersey.
The Kolajs own eight Famous Famiglia restaurants in New York City, and recently edged out larger Italian restaurant chains in a bid to open two pizzerias at Newark International Airport. Paul Vuli owns all or part of four Italian restaurants in the metropolitan region, including Fino in Murray Hill, and he is preparing to open a fifth. Imer Deja and his uncles, cousins and brothers own nine pizzerias in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The Patsy's Pizzeria in East Harlem is now owned by Frank Brija, an Albanian from Kosovo. 
"I've stopped looking for them, there are too many," said Ismer Mejku, who runs the Albanian Yellow Pages, a directory of Albanian-owned businesses in the United States. Mr. Mejku says he plans to run advertisements for about 75 Albanian-owned restaurants in New York in his 2001 edition, the overwhelming majority offering Italian cuisine. "There are hundreds." 
Many of their owners started out much like Mr. Vuli, who left Yugoslavia in 1972 and lived in Italy for a year while waiting to get into the United States. When he arrived in New York at 18, he spoke Italian but almost no English, and started washing dishes in a Brooklyn restaurant for $90 a week. He worked his way up from there, and opened his first restaurant, Piccolo Mondo, in 1977.
"Italy is where it all started," he said, between sips of bottled water at his table in Fino's.
But the link to Italy is not the only reason. Albanians say they are also capitalizing on an industry that has long depended on freshly arrived immigrants to thrive. As Italian-Americans have moved up the economic ladder and out to the suburbs, Albanians are taking over. 
"The Italians can't do the work anymore, they've gotten fat in America," said Joe Carnevalla, an Italian-American whose company supplies groceries to 700 pizzerias in the New York area. "You go into an Italian restaurant now, you see Albanians. You think they're Italian. They speak Italian, they look like us, the food is great." 
They have done much to cultivate such authenticity. While many of the restaurant owners describe themselves as fiercely patriotic, they set aside their ethnic pride when it comes to running their businesses. 
Imer Deja's family bought nine Italian restaurants in New York City and didn't change any of the names. Imer owns Mike's Pizza in Brooklyn; his brother, Zija, owns Charlie's Pizza in Brooklyn; Cousin Bill owns La Belleza Pizza in Manhattan. "If you change the name, you could lose customers," Imer Deja said.
When Gjergj Dedvukaj, an Albanian from Yugoslavia, bought Giovanni's in the Bronx, he decided against changing cuisines. "Customers don't know Albanian food," he said. Some of his customers think he is Italian, and he does little to dissuade them. "They think I'm Giovanni."
The Kolajs, the owners of the Famous Famiglia pizzerias, have made the most of their 14-month stay in a camp in Italy, where their father died and the youngest brother, Giorgio, was born. In a company brochure, the Kolajs don't mention their Albanian roots, but they do say that the family "made the pilgrimage from Italy to America." In their new line of Italian food products, which include spaghetti, marinara sauce and ziti, their mother, Roze Kolaj, is featured on the logo as Mamma Rosa, holding a bunch of tomatoes. 
At the same time, the Kolaj brothers have donated thousands of dollars worth of food and clothing to Albanians dislocated in the Balkans. "We've never forgotten our homeland," Mr. Kolaj said. 
Tony and Tina's Pizzeria in the Bronx is one of the few establishments that show their ethnic roots. The mostly Albanian crew tosses pizza dough beneath flags and posters celebrating the struggle of their brethren in Kosovo. The pizzeria also sells burek, an Albanian meat pie. 
The influx of Albanians into the pizza parlors and restaurants has sparked some skepticism and, perhaps, resentment. Until about a year ago, Sette Colli Ristorante in Brooklyn was owned by an Albanian, who had started the restaurant years before. Then a person of Italian descent bought it from the Albanian. Salvatore Adamita, the new owner, said he purchased Sette Colli last year when people in the neighborhood discovered that the former owner was not Italian. 
"We brought it back to the way it's suposed to be," Mr. Adamita said. "The food is much better. The customers notice." Mr. Adamita said it was only natural that Italians would know better about Italian food. "We originated it," he said. "We know how to do it."
Mr. Adamita seems to be in the minority. For the most part, Italian-American restaurateurs say they don't mind the competition, or the throngs of Albanians eager to buy their establishments. Often, the Albanian buyers have worked in their restaurants for several years.
"I appreciate the Italian guy, I learned from him," said Atli Tocci, an Albanian who bought Portobello Pizzeria Restaurant in Brooklyn from its Italian-American owner five months ago. "I worked here 10 years. I learned how to make good pizza. One day he say to me: You want to buy it? I say, why not?"
Like the Italians before them, the Albanians are using pizzerias to segue into the middle and higher ends of the restaurant business. Bruno Ristorante, a Midtown restaurant specializing in Northern Italian cuisine, was described as "elegant" and "excellent" in the 2001 Zagat Survey. Its owner, Bruno Selimaj, came to the United States from Yugoslavia in 1971 and began his career by washing dishes in an Italian restaurant in Midtown.
In 1999, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani led Gov. George W. Bush through the old Italian-American enclave of Belmont in the Bronx, he took him to Giovanni's, owned by Mr. Dedvukaj, an Albanian from Yugoslavia. 
The mayor, Italian by descent, has declared his approval. "The Albanians do a wonderful job of operating Italian restaurants and cooking Italian food." 
But Joe Carnevalla, the food supplier, doesn't think it will last forever. 
"Just wait," Mr. Carnevalla said. "Ten years from now, the Albanians won't want to work, and some other group will come in and do just what they did."

HEADLINE: In Albany, a $2.7 Billion Surplus Squabble 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 2 

 BODY:
The Pataki administration said today that the state ended its fiscal year on Saturday with a record $2.7 billion surplus. But the good news served only to worsen the impasse between the governor and legislative leaders over a new spending plan.
 The state's April 1 budget deadline has once again passed without even a hint that a deal might be reached soon. Lawmakers quit work last Thursday afternoon after passing emergency spending bills to keep the state running and took the weekend off. Beginning this Thursday, they are planning to take a 12-day break for Easter and Passover. 
 Gov. George E. Pataki played down the importance of the surplus today, asserting that the state must salt away as much money as possible to hedge against a national economic downturn. As he painted a gloomy economic future, Mr. Pataki said that the surplus stemmed mostly from taxes on stock gains that cannot be counted on again this year.
But Democrats, who control the Assembly, seized on the surplus as evidence that the state has the money to pay for the large increases in school aid, health care and jobs programs they have advocated in their own plan, which would cost $2.29 billion more than the governor's proposal of $83.6 billion. They have accused the governor of grossly underestimating revenues to build up a surplus he can dole out next year before his re-election campaign. 
"These numbers reflect that there is no need to say the sky is falling," said the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver. "The important thing is we don't have to make cuts to education, we don't have to make cuts to health care."
The Republican Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said he hoped that the large surplus "could represent a catalyst for us to get started in the budget process." He noted that the surplus was more than enough to cover the $1.2 billion that Senate Republicans have proposed adding to the governor's spending plan, mostly for tax cuts and a $600 million increase in aid to schools.
Still, the two legislative leaders and the governor remain far apart on how much revenue will come in over the next 12 months and on how much of that should be held in reserves. Nearly everyone in Albany is predicting a protracted budget fight that could go right up to the beginning of the next school year.
The April Fool's deadline for the budget has been a fiction for years. The last 17 budgets have been late. Because the state no longer borrows money in the spring to keep schools open from April to June, there are no longer any serious political consequences for missing the deadline. The Legislature and governor have also perfected temporary s1ending bills that keep the government humming along at the previous year's level without a new spending plan. 
This year, however, a confluence of political circumstances and the national economy's skittering downhill portend one of the most overdue budgets in history. 
The main reason for the impasse is that no one has an incentive to compromise early. The lawmakers do not face elections in the fall, so they do not need to rush back to their districts with a budget in hand. 
Mr. Pataki, meanwhile, faces a re-election campaign next year in the teeth of what could turn into a recession. He is seeking to stash away money in reserves to avoid cuts in an election year. The longer he fights for lower spending, the larger the state surplus will be. 
The Democrats in the Assembly are also in no hurry. Mr. Silver, while acknowledging that the economy is slowing, still predicts that revenues will grow more than the governor thinks. He would rather spend that money this yar on a huge increase in school aid than let the governor save them for the election year. New estimates of tax revenues for 2001 in mid-April and mid-July will make it clearer whether the governor's gloomy predictions are right.
The governor opened the bidding in January with a fairly generous $83.6 billion budget, a 5.3 percent increase over all, although the part of the budget financed with state taxes would grow only 3.6 percent. Under longstanding practice, the governor's proposal is considered the floor, and the whole debate is about how much the Legislature will add to it.
But the national economy took a serious downturn in the first quarter of this year. For weeks, Mr. Pataki has been hammering the idea that he will accept no spending increases. He regularly accuses the Legislature of wanting a "spending binge" and raises the specter of 1990, when the Cuomo administration had to cut the budget midyear because it overestimated revenues as a recession hit. "I do not intend to let that happen," he said in an interview on Friday.
Mr. Silver regards Mr. Pataki's stance as a negotiating strategy. The governor is using gloom-and-doom rhetoric, he said, to justify tighter spending and cutting school programs dear to the Democrats, like preschool and all-day kindergarten. "The governor is running for re-election next year, and he doesn't want to spend the money this year," Mr. Silver said.
Mr. Silver's $2.29 billion increase above the governor's plan this year is centered on a commitment to a $1.7 billion increase in school aid in each of the next two years along with increases in Medicaid spending for nursing homes and more money for transportation projects. 
Even if he wanted to, Mr. Silver is not in a good position to force his Democratic conference to rein in spending. Last year, he was nearly ousted as speaker after complaints that he was too autocratic. He was saved largely by the liberal wing of his conference, and it would be difficult for him to say no to its spending priorities. 
As in most years, the Republicans, who control the Senate, have entered the fray in the middle. Mr. Bruno's push to add $1.2 billion to the budget includes a bigger tax cut program than the governor's, at a cost of $260 million in the first year. 
Senator Bruno has blamed Mr. Silver for the deadlock, saying the Assembly has offered an outlandishly expensive budget. He maintains that the Assembly plan would commit the state to more than $8 billion in additional spending two or three years down the road, a contention Mr. Silver says is distorted and untrue.

HEADLINE: Food Is Not the Enemy 

BYLINE:  By Jeffrey Steingarten; Jeffrey Steingarten is food critic of Vogue magazine and author of "The Man Who Ate Everything."

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO 

 BODY:
Do you remember that food scare a few years ago when everybody was in a twist about the dangers of eating raw shellfish? I was having dinner around that time with an athletic friend, a captain of industry who showed up proudly wrapped in bandages and slings. He had earned these by crashing into a large shrub on the slopes of Aspen. He needed help turning the pages of his menu. And then he refused to share my lavish platter of cold, plump, briny, crisp and succulent oysters. "Raw shellfish," he gulped. "Don't you read the papers?"
 In the days that followed, I tracked down the facts. The Food and Drug Administration had done a risk assessment study and discovered that one out of every 2,000 servings of raw mollusks is likely to make you sick. But you can expect to suffer a substantial injury in every 250 days of skiing, especially if you include gondola crashes and pains that blossom after the hapless skier returns home. So it turns out that a day of skiing is eight times more dangerous than a delicious plate of raw oysters. It was then that I decided to give up skiing so that I could eat oysters to my heart's content. 
 Nobody would recommend a nonchalant attitude toward food safety. I have eaten raw chicken only twice, and that was in Japan, with peanut sauce, because everybody else was doing it. But you would think from reading the newspapers lately that eating is the leading cause of death. I knew something was out of joint less than a month ago when several major papers reported as news that foodborne illnesses cause 325,000 hospitalizations and 5,000 deaths a year: these statistics are two years old. They were published in the fall of 1999 in Emerging Infectious Diseases, a peer-reviewed journal of the federal Centers for Disease Control.
The real news was that the number of food-linked fatalities is only half of what had previously been thought. The newspaper headlines should have read, "Only Half of Americans Previously Feared Food-Dead Truly Are."
Scare stories about the dangers of eating are typically inspired by two groups. First are government agencies and nongovernmental organizations whose attempts to keep us ever vigilant toward dangers of food can sometimes goad us into needless panic. More fundamental are the dark forces of anhedonia, phobia and hypochondria -- that vast, joyless, middle-of-the-road conspiracy that tirelessly toils to deprive the rest of us of the spiritual and earthly pleasures of good and ample eating.
A few years ago these forces caused huge numbers of people to report themselves as lactose-intolerant, a condition that clinical studies at Massachusetts General Hospital and elsewhere have found to be extremely rare. I wonder how they will manifest themselves this year?
We have survived countless alarmist reports about nutrition over the past decade or so, and are stronger for getting past them. Now we know that salt is harmful to only a small part of the population. We know that consuming bushels of fruits and vegetables does not reduce the risk of colon cancer. That drinking alcohol lessens the risk of having a heart attack. That white sugar does not cause hyperactivity in children. That cholesterol accounts for perhaps less than one-quarter of all heart attacks. That eating large amounts of unsaturated fats does not lead to cancer or heart disease. That chocolate does not cause acne or migraines.
The moral of this story is that we are omnivores, and that it is best to eat a little of everything. I have for years maintained two simple yet scientific measures of our progress as eaters. 
One is the Cephalopod Index, or C.I., which is based on our national per capita consumption of squid, cuttlefish and octopus -- not too long ago only the stuff of nightmares among Anglo-American eaters. Well, our C.I. has jumped more than hundredfold in the past 30 years! I'll bet that calamari has practically replaced apple pie as the most ubiquitous item on American menus.
Second is the S.I., or SnackWell's Index, which is based on the annual per capita sales of that line of nonfat (but not unfattening) cookies, and tells us how many Americans have become and remain nutritional nincompoops. The popping of the SnackWell's bubble rivals that of the Nasdaq. And restaurants report that their customers have become more relaxed about new foods. This is all very good news, though not the stuff of headlines.
We are the first society in human history in which gluttony is economically an option for probably half the population. And we may be the first whose appetites are not held in check by religious dietary laws. Without a fear of food in some form, some may think we would be in grave danger of running completely amok.
Perhaps this is why the government keeps trying to take away my Camembert. The Food and Drug Administration has launched a campaign against raw-milk cheeses, but the agency's statistics show that there is much less danger in eating such cheeses than eating, say, a plate of smoked fish. Yet as you can observe every weekend, the entire Upper West Side of Manhattan is allowed to act as though ingesting smoked sturgeon were risk-free.
Even if eating raw-milk cheese were fully as dangerous as skiing, shouldn't I be allowed to choose the risk I am willing to bear? If we allow people the right to pursue happiness by skiing, then let me pursue mine by enjoying a pungent Langres or a potent Livarot, a brie de Melun or a snowy chaource.

HEADLINE: Economic Memo; 
The Downturn New Yorkers May Bring On Themselves

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
To get a handle on what's going on in New York City's economy, just stumble into the closest Duane Reade. You may see a matron with expensively streaked tresses scanning the shelves of do-it-yourself hair dye. You may see a man with a headache reach past the Advil to the generic ibuprofen. You may see heavy smokers buying cigarettes by the pack instead of the carton.
 What you will definitely see is a change of attitude on the part of formerly free-spending New Yorkers. 
 "People are paying attention to the dollars coming out of their pockets," said Anthony J. Cuti, chairman of Duane Reade, the drugstore-cum-five-and-dime. "They're trying to be frugal."
But while New Yorkers' economic anxiety has been rising, in reality, things are not so bad, at least so far.
True, the economy does not have that shaken-Champagne-bottle fizz it showed just a few months ago. But the housing market remains firm, companies are adding new jobs at a rapid clip, and in February, the most recent month for which figures were available, unemployment was still lower than it had been in any February since 1988. (Mr. Cuti still cannot find enough assistant managers for his stores.) 
So what gives? Why do so many feel so bad when things are still so good?
It is not just an academic question. Some economists worry that by cutting back on spending to prepare for a recession, consumers can turn an economic slowdown into an economic meltdown.
"It matters, because two-thirds of the economy is consumer spending," noted Douglas A. Lonnstrom, a director of the research institute at Siena College, near Albany.
As recently as October, New York City consumers were more confident about the economy than were their counterparts upstate or across the country, according to a monthly telephone survey that Dr. Lonnstrom has been conducting since 1999 in conjunction with a University of Michigan national survey. But in February, the situation reversed, and now city dwellers are as gloomy as people upstate, and more worried than the average American.
This is not a fluke. The Conference Board, a business-backed research group that does a bigger mail survey, found that in March, consumer confidence edged up a tad everywhere in the country, except here. In the Middle Atlantic region, which includes New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, consumer confidence continued to slide, and is the lowest by far of any region of the country.
Of course, residents here may just be catching up to the rest of the country. Along the Pacific Coast and in the Midwest, consumer confidence peaked a year ago. In this part of the world, confidence rose through August.
Unless the value of their homes starts to sink and their neighbors become unemployed, people eventually stop believing the bad news, said Ken Goldstein, an economist for the Conference Board. "It becomes a TV show, like who got voted off the island last week," he said.
There are parts of the country where extreme gloom is appropriate. In Kokomo, Ind., the unemployment rate soared to 8 percent in January, from 4 percent in December and 2.3 percent in September, as Chrysler began laying off workers. The number of jobs of any kind fell by several hundred in the last 12 months, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
By contrast, in the New York City metropolitan region in the last 12 months, employers created almost 90,000 jobs (almost equal to the population of Kokomo), and the unemployment rate is up just one-tenth of one percentage point over September's level.
Manufacturing is where most of the national economic problems have occurred, but only 6 percent of city workers have factory jobs. Meanwhile, office jobs are still booming.
Look at Manpower Inc., which provides temporary employees, who tend to be the canaries in the economic coal mine. Demand for industrial workers has dropped in New York City and across the country, said Craig Kasper, vice president for Manpower's Eastern region.
On the other hand, there has been a surge of demand for secretaries and administrative assistants in the city, he said. The biggest change has been psychological, Mr. Kasper said. "We're seeing an attitude of cautiousness out there," he said.
The national slump has had a huge effect on two important sectors of New York City's economy: Wall Street and Madison Avenue. 
When General Motors tries to cut costs, one of the first things to go is advertisements. That's bad for the people who create them, and for the publications that profit from them (some magazines that were as thick as phone books now look more like comic books). Combined with the end of the dot-com delirium, the advertising drought has prompted some publishers and news media conglomerates to lay off or buy out workers.
Wall Street, too, is threatening layoffs. But financial analysts note that such announcements are often designed more to impress anxious investors than to give an accurate notion of firing plans.
The Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's trade group, predicts that 9,000 to 12,000 people will lose their jobs this year, mainly because of mergers, said Frank Fernandez, the association's chief economist. But because the firms will also keep hiring, he said, the net job loss will be far lower.
That is not what happened after the stock market crashed in October 1987. By the end of 1988, Wall Street shed more than 10,000 jobs, and by the end of 1991 more than 33,000, a drop of about 20 percent, even though stocks rebounded quickly.
Some Wall Street watchers say that such carnage will not recur, because the financial firms were slower to add people this time around, contenting themselves mainly with paying the same people a lot more money. The average salary on Wall Street rose by almost 50 percent from 1992 to 1999, according to a soon-to-be-released report by H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller. (The average for financial firms, from the bigwigs down to the small fry, was $196,000; the average for everyone in the entire city was $47,000.)
Jason Bram, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has been surprised by the low level of layoffs on Wall Street. "But in six months," he added, "who knows?"
Of course, he lives in New York.

HEADLINE: Analysts Warn of a Shortfall In New Jersey's Next Budget 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 2 

 BODY:
The go-go years are gone, nonpartisan fiscal analysts told New Jersey lawmakers today, warning that the decline of the stock market had burst a nearly identical bubble of state tax receipts. The result, they said, could be a $1 billion shortfall in the next state budget.
 In a springtime ritual, the Legislature's independent budget officers picked apart the executive branch's revenue projections for the current fiscal year and the next, which begins in July. And after several years of uninterrupted one-upmanship regarding revenues and surpluses, the message today was that several categories of tax receipts were beginning to decline. 
 The Legislature's budget analysts and Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's economic advisers agree that the state economy will continue to grow and that a recession is unlikely. But they differ wildly on the pace of that growth. "To paraphrase somebody who should be Yogi Berra if he isn't, 'The future is not what it used to be,' " said Alan R. Kooney, the legislative budget and finance officer.
Administration officials and Republicans on the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee played down Mr. Kooney's warnings, made at a hearing here today. But Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr. of Hudson County, the ranking Democrat on the panel, called the new estimates "a flashing red warning ign," and urged lawmakers to reconsider Mr. DiFrancesco's proposals for $284 million in new spending for such measures as bigger property tax rebates.
Mr. Kooney and David J. Rosen, the Legislature's top revenue analyst, said the administration had vastly overestimated revenues, by $194 million for the fiscal year ending June 30, and by $836 million for the fiscal year ending in June 2002.
Worst of all, they said, capital gains taxes -- which skyrocketed during the late 1990's stock market boom, rising 50 percent last year alone -- would plummet by 25 percent next year.
By contrast, the administration has predicted a rise of 3.5 percent in capital gains taxes next year. That discrepancy accounts for $405 million of what they said could be a shortfall of $1.03 billion in Mr. DiFrancesco's proposed $23.2 billion spending plan. By law, a balanced budget must be in place by July 1.
Mr. Rosen said that estimating next year's capital gains receipts is a dicey proposition this early, because many people wait to book such gains until the end of the tax year. "The true magnitude may not be known until the Division of Revenue finishes opening the envelopes in late April or early May of 2002," Mr. Rosen said. In happier times, he added, treasury officials in Trenton, Washington and other capitals used to speak of the "April surprise."
"We think there could be a surprise of a less pleasant nature in April of 2002," Mr. Rosen said.
Mr. Rosen noted that December quarterly payments of the corporate business tax had fallen by a "startling 22 percent from the prior year's level," and predicted that corporate tax receipts for this fiscal year would be $52 million less than the administration has figured. For the next fiscal year, the State Treasury Department forecasts 7.2 percent growth in corporate taxes, but Mr. Rosen is predicting no growth at all.
He also gave a more cautious estimate for sales tax revenue, predicting 6 percent growth next year, compared with the administration's 7 percent estimate. 
Mr. Rosen said the $194 million in overestimated revenues for the current fiscal year mainly derived from a drop in collections of the inheritance tax. Inheritance taxes were budgeted to rise by 18.3 percent this year, but receipts were down 7.7 percent as of February, he said, adding, "It is unlikely that the inheritance tax will suddenly reverse course and rise strongly over the last four months of the fiscal year." 
New Jersey's inheritance tax is twofold, comprising a tax on transfers of assets to heirs and an estate tax that dovetails with the federal one now under attack by Republicans in Congress. Should the federal estate tax be abolished, the state tax would disappear as well, meaning the loss of more than $100 million in revenue.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David J. Rosen, left, and Alan R. Kooney, analysts in the New Jersey Legislature, said stock market declines have eaten away at tax receipts. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

PERSON: HALBFINGER, DAVID M; ROSEN, DAVID J; KOONEY, ALAN R 

GEOGRAPHIC: TRENTON, NJ, USA (92%) NEW JERSEY, USA (95%) UNITED STATES (95%) NEW JERSEY
