HEADLINE: COLLISION IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW; 
CHINA FAULTS U.S. IN INCIDENT; SUGGESTS RELEASE OF CREW HINGES ON OFFICIAL APOLOGY

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 3 

 BODY:
The Chinese government blamed the United States today for Sunday's midair collision of a spy plane and a trailing Chinese fighter jet and suggested that the release of the 24 American crew members hinged on Washington's willingness to apologize.
 The slow-moving American plane, filled with secret eavesdropping equipment, collided on Sunday with one of two Chinese fighters that shadowed it 65 miles off Chinese territorial waters. With a wing and an engine damaged, the plane made an emergency landing at a military base on the southern Chinese island of Hainan, where the crew was taken into custody. 
 The pilot of the Chinese jet, identified today as Wang Wei, reportedly parachuted out before his jet crashed, but Chinese rescuers have been unable to find him and he is presumed dead. 
Tonight, a government spokesman, asked when the 24 Americans might be freed, stopped just short of setting an absolute condition for their release. The spokesman, Zhu Bangzao of the Foreign Ministry, said "the answer to your question" lay in China's insistence on an apology and an explanation. 
"It was the U.S. side that caused this incident, and China is the victim," Mr. Zhu said at an unusual late-night news conference, held just before an American officer in Hainan met with the crew for the first time since the accident. "The United States should take full responsibility, make an apology to the Chinese government and people, and give us an explanation of its actions." 
President Jiang Zemin was quoted in Chinese state media as saying today that China has "full evidence" that the American plane caused the collision by violating standard flight rules. He also called on the United States to end its frequent reconnaissance flights along China's coast.
 As Mr. Jiang left the capital on Wednesday for a long-planned 12-day tour of Latin American nations, Reuters reported that the New China News Agency quoted him as saying, "The United States should apologize to the Chinese for this incident and bear all responsibilities for the consequence of the incident." His departure suggested that he did not expect a major crisis to develop from the collision. 
Speaking on American television this morning, the United States ambassador, Adm. Joseph W. Prueher, said his government would "have a problem" with apologizing. American officials have suggested that a miscue by the speedier jet, traveling too close for safety, must have caused the collision, and they maintain that China has no legal right to board the aircraft or hold the crew. 
Once American officials have debriefed the crew, more details should emerge of what happened on Sunday, when a seemingly routine cat-and-mouse game between an American spy plane and Chinese jets ended with one death, a potentially sensational gain for Chinese intelligence and a tense diplomatic confrontation that may stoke jingoistic sentiments on both sides. 
Today, American and Chinese officials seem to be describing two different occurrences, with clashing versions of who caused the collision, of the legality of the procedures followed by the spy plane before its emergency landing and of China's right, at this point, to scour the plane and hold its crew for interrogation. 
American and Chinese officials are worried about damage to relations from this episode, the latest in a series of strains including the 1999 bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's war against Yugoslavia, American allegations of Chinese nuclear spying, President Bush's plans for a national missile defense, weapons sales to Taiwan and American condemnation of human rights violations here. 
"This will definitely increase suspicions on both sides," said Yan Xuetong, director of the Institute of International Relations at Qinghua University in Beijing. "But I think the damage may be limited because both governments don't want this event to undermine the overall relationship." 
Beijing's leaders, who regard American cooperation as essential to China's economic development, have repeatedly said the two nations should have good relations despite differences over Taiwan, human rights and other issues. Mr. Yan said that view still prevailed in Beijing, and tried to explain why Chinese officials must nonetheless take a stern approach to the spy plane incident.
Given the circumstances, he said, Americans have made unrealistic and even hypocritical demands of China -- particularly by insisting that China should hand back the aircraft without searching it. 
"This was a spy plane, and the United States used it to gther intelligence from China," he said. "How can the United States say that 'we have a right to spy on you, but you don't have a right to enter a plane that landed on your territory without official agreement?' " 
"China simply cannot agree that the United States has a legitimate right to spy on us, and no other country could agree to that either," Mr. Yan said. He asked what would happen if a Chinese spy plane landed on American soil after causing the death of an American pilot. 
Chinese officials and citizens also charge that Americans, in their zeal to free the unharmed crew members, have shown little concern for the lost Chinese pilot. The United States says that it offered to aid the search effort but that China declined.
In comments today by President Jiang and by the Foreign Ministry, China described a sequence of events, and relevant international standards, that differed fundamentally from American assertions. 
Tonight, the Foreign Ministry spokesman gave a more detailed account of the Chinese version of events.
Just after 9 a.m. Sunday, he said, as the American EP-3E reconnaissance craft passed 65 miles southeast of China's 12-mile territorial water line with two Chinese F-8 fighters trailing in a "normal" manner, the American plane "made a sudden big movement" to the side, and its left wing bumped into the jet. 
Mr. Zhu did not say the crash was intentional, but he asserted that with its sudden turn, the plane had violated international rules as well as a military agreement between the United States and China concerning safety in aerial encounters.
All aircraft have the right to fly over the 200-mile "exclusive economic zone" that coastal countries maintain under international law, Mr. Zhu noted. But he asserted that the American plane, by spying in that region, had abused the "freedom of overflight" and had "threatened China's security." 
Mr. Zhu also said the aircraft, once damaged, had entered Chinese territory and landed without permission, "a violation of China's sovereignty." He said the air base in Hainan had received no notification of the imminent emergency landing, as required under international rules. "The U.S. plane had the time and the technology to notify, but it didn't," he said. 
A spokesman for the United States Pacific Command in Hawaii, Cmdr. Rex Totty, disputed that, repeating in an interview today that the crippled plane issued the standard "Mayday" emergency alert as it hurried to the nearest landing strip. Commander Totty said that by international practice, on hearing such an appeal, "an air field is obligated to open to that aircraft no matter what country it is from." But he acknowledged that until American officials talked with the crew, "we can't know exactly what happened."
The most delicate issue concerns China's right to enter the aircraft and hold the crew.
Chinese officials and experts scoff at the American concept that a military aircraft that makes an emergency landing has "sovereign immunity" and may not be boarded without permission. "Do we know of any country in history that let a foreign spy vehicle land on its territory without investigating?" asked Mr. Yan of Qinghua University.
Mr. Zhu, the spokesman, said tonight, "This was not a civilian plane but a military plane that entered without permission, violating international and Chinese law."
"There is no question of 'immunity,' " he added. "As the victim country, China is fully entitled to conduct investigations into the case." 
He refused to say whether the plane had already been boarded and inspected, as American officials assume, but asserted China's legal right to do so. 
He said China had the right to detain and question the crew as part of its investigation. "This is the right of any sovereign country," he said.

PERSON: Emily MacFarquhar 

HEADLINE: Emily MacFarquhar, 62, Writer On Asia for The Economist 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Emily MacFarquhar, who applied a scholar's meticulousness to many years of reporting on China and South Asia, notably in more than 20 years with The Economist, died on March 18 in her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 62.
 The cause was a brain tumor, said her son, Rory MacFarquhar. 
 Mrs. MacFarquhar, who traveled widely in Asia and whose reports and observations had a keen audience among scholars and foreign policy experts, also worked for several years for British television and for U.S. News & World Report, covering subjects like Mao's Cultural Revolution, the Bangladesh war of independence and women's rights.
Although her articles for The Economist carried no byline, her work was recognized and praised by experts in her field. She wrote at length about Chinese dissidents, often befriending them when they visited the West, said Merle Goldman, a professor of Chinese history at Boston University.
By examining South Asia, Mrs. MacFarquhar helped focus the West on an often ignored region, said Amartya Sen, master of Trinity College at Cambridge University and a Nobel Prize-winning economist.
Jonathan Mirsky, former East Asian editor of The Times of London, credited Mrs. MacFarquhar with unusually good training before she began reporting in China, remarkable diligence and excellent contacts. "She was a significant China journalist of her time," he said.
An early published work was a pamphlet in 1968, "China: Mao's Last Leap." It was was one of the first detailed examinations of the Cultural Revolution. Mrs. MacFarquhar did not publish books, but worked on a book about former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan. The writer could not conduct interviews for the book because of deteriorating eyesight.
Emily Jane Cohen was born on June 23, 1938, in the Bronx. She worked on school newspapers at the Bronx High School of Science and Wellesley College.
After college, the writer Irving Kristol, a distant relative, helped her land a job at The China Quarterly, a new journal. For six months, she was secretary to the editor, Roderick MacFarquhar. She then earned a master's in East Asian studies from Harvard, studying with John K. Fairbank, the historian and China expert.
After a year in Taiwan studying Chinese, she returned to the United States by way of India, where she ran into her former supervisor, who was covering Nehru's funeral. They were married six months later and settled in London, where The Economist hired her in 1965. Her routine was to make long interview trips to Asia several times a year, using reports from The Economist's extensive freelance network at other times.
In her last years in London, she also worked on a program on commercial Channel 4, covering politics from Northern Ireland, Hong Kong and British regional issues. 
When Mr. MacFarquhar accepted an offer to be chairman of the Harvard government department, Mrs. MacFarquhar wrote for The Economist from Cambridge until joining U.S. News in 1986 as foreign editor. She later becoming a contributing editor.
In 1994, she helped organize a report on women's difficulties in the struggle for equality, "The War Against Women."
Surviving are her husband and son, both of Cambridge, and her daughter, Larissa, of Brooklyn.

Citigroup Joins Other Firms In Laying Off Employees
Citigroup started notifying hundreds of workers that their jobs were being eliminated, becoming the latest Wall Street firm to lay off employees amid the prolonged slump in the stock market.
 The layoffs will continue until several hundred people in the corporate and investment banking operations of Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney unit have been dismissed, people inside the firm said. Page C11. 

Scrutiny Urged of Herbal Drink
The Council of Better Business Bureaus plans to announce today that it is asking the Food and Drug Administration to investigate Hornell Brewing's marketing claims concerning its herbal Rx Memory Mind Elixir. C8.

Tax Cut Passes First Senate Test
The Senate blocked a Democratic proposal to reduce the president's tax cut by $158 billion and use the money for Medicare. A1.

President Bush's budget will propose deep cuts in health programs for people without health insurance, officials said. A1.

An Accidental Career Path
Heidi Schneider, executive vice president at Neuberger Berman, an investment management company in Manhattan, said she planned to go into broadcasting after college, but those jobs were scarce, so she took a job with New England Mutual Life. The company had the largest television studio outside a TV station, she said, and she thought she would move into that area. "I found I liked the investment part of the business, though, and I began to appreciate my father's influence," she said. "He had shared his experience in investing in the stock market with me." The Boss. C9.

Sharing of Network Costs Sought
Short of cash after spending billions to win wireless licenses, Europe's mobile phone companies are asking the companies that sell them equipment to share the cost of building the networks. World Business, Section W.

PSINet May File Chapter 11
PSINet, a provider of Internet-based communications services, said that it would most likely seek bankruptcy protection as it faces a shortage of cash. C4.

Racketeering Claim Is Dismissed
A federal judge has thrown out racketeering claims in a lawsuit that accuses New York Life Insurance of charging tens of millions of dollars in excess fees to retirement plans it maintains for its workers and sales agents. But the judge ruled that a trial could proceed on a claim that New York Life violated its duty of loyalty to its workers and agents by charging the retirement plans up to 25 times the market rate for managing such funds. C10.

Factory Orders Decrease 0.4%
New orders at manufacturers dropped 0.4 percent in February to their lowest level in 16 months as demand softened for industrial equipment like computers, construction machinery and communications gear, government figures showed. The decline in February orders came after a decrease of 4.3 percent in January, larger than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said. C8.

Hearings Begin on Online Music
Napster asked Congress to force music publishers to offer their catalogs online as hundreds of its users and some well-known musicians sat in on the hearings. C4.

An M.B.A. That's a Lot Like Work
Texas Instruments is an early player in a fledgling trend: the customized M.B.A. The company worked with the University of Texas to create a special curriculum for its up-and-coming managers. Management. C9.

Court Revives Claim in S.& L. Case
A federal appeals court revived a claim by Golden State Bancorp for hundreds of millions of dollars in a suit accusing the federal government of breaking promises made during the savings and loan crisis of the 1980's. C11.

SECTION: Section C; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1631 words

HEADLINE: Newspaper Economics; 
Cuts Raise Concern About the Quality Of Journalism

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Last week, Gary B. Pruitt, the 43-year-old chief executive of the McClatchy Company, found himself seated at a lunch table with two newspaper industry elders, Frank A. Bennack Jr., chief executive of the Hearst Corporation, and Allen H. Neuharth, now retired, who reinvented the Gannett chain and started USA Today in the 1980's.
 Mr. Pruitt broke the ice with a simple question. "You are the two guys to ask," he said. "Which is the way to go? Public? Or private?" 
 Their responses fitted their roles like a custom-made suit. Mr. Bennack, whose Hearst newspapers are the symbolic core of his corporation, praised the freedom of not having to please Wall Street. "I did say that it remained my view that there were clear benefits in being private so long as you have the discipline to compare yourself with public-company performance," he said. 
Mr. Neuharth, who supercharged the acquisition and cost-cutting crusade that has made Gannett an investor favorite, recalled that he told Mr. Pruitt: "Without our being a public company, the resources would not have been there to expand. To grow. And to do innovative things."
Public or private? The question of how best to structure a media company to balance good journalism and good profits has an extra-sharp edge these days as advertising revenue drops and the cost of newsprint rises. But there are no simple answers.
Last month, Jay T. Harris, the publisher of The San Jose Mercury News, resigned rather than endorse the newsroom layoffs that he believed were inevitable, given the profit margins that his bosses at Knight Ridder had promised Wall Street.
The layoffs have not materialized, but this startling move personalized the lingering civil war between those who believe the industry's goal of high profit margins is killing good journalism and those who believe that strong financial performance will save good journalism.
Wall Street is taking note of this argument. A recent report by Bear, Stearns glumly noted that newspaper companies "do not have a lot of scope in trimming staffing, especially with the public backlash by some journalists concerned about cost control measures."
Not that public companies have a monopoly on cost cuts. Across the industry, in large and small markets, newspapers are cutting space, contemplating buyouts and reducing travel expenses whether or not they have public stockholders. 
The reasons are clear. Revenues are down; costs are up. Not long ago, newspaper advertising revenue gains were running at double-digit rates. But in the first two months of this year, advertising revenue at the Tribune Company newspapers was down 1 percent from the first two months of 2000; it was down 2 percent at Gannett; off 5.4 percent at The New York Times Company; and off 0.7 percent at Knight Ridder. As the advertising decline accelerates, newsprint prices are set to rise 8 percent this month, to $660 a ton.
With the industry caught in this squeeze, some editors at Knight Ridder are reminded twice a month or so if they are within their budgets. Editors at private companies face similar pressure from their owners. But right now, journalists who work in privately held companies like Hearst and Advance Publications are saying that it is better for their readers if Wall Street is out of the companies' hair.
"To me, it's a huge, incalculable advantage to belong to a company that is privately owned," said Sandra Mims Rowe, editor of The Oregonian in Portland, owned by Advance Publications. "We just don't do the sharp cutbacks a day and a half after revenue falls."
Her newspaper, with a daily circulation of 348,000, is having cuts, but its newsroom still has a budget for about 435 journalists. By comparison, The Star Tribune of Minneapolis, the biggest newspaper owned by McClatchy, a publicly held company, employs only about 380 journalists even though it has a slightly greater circulation of 374,000. 
But that is not the whole story. The Star Tribune's newsroom has added five or so journalists since it was bought from the privately held Cowles Media four years ago, and the space devoted to news and features is 15 percent greater now than in 1997, its last year in private hands.
"Mine is a public company that is to a certain extent saying we are going to go our own road," Tim McGuire, The Star Tribune's editor, said. "I'm extremely comfortable in my situation, yet I am with a public company. There are many who are with public companies that are not as comfortable. And I'm hearing a lot of things from private companies. This is a tough time."
Some chief executives at privately held companies, like Dean Singleton of the MediaNews Group, have been excoriated by journalists for cutting newsroom staffs and salaries to leverage the purchase of more newspapers. 
Still, in the last decade, Mr. Singleton has increased the newsroom staff and space devoted to news at his flagship newspaper, The Denver Post. The Post, with a circulation of 420,000 -- up from 243,000 a decade ago -- now has 240 journalists, compared with 170 when it was bought in 1988 from Times Mirror, a public company since acquired by the Tribune Company.
Journalism-minded editors and profit-minded owners do have one thing in common. Both need money. Editors get theirs from their business executives. Owners in private companies get theirs from banks, from their own fortunes or from a limited pool of private investors.
The managers of public companies say they not only have access to investment capital on the open market, but because of their higher visibility they also find it easier to borrow and can use stock to make deals and reward talented executives.
But that advantage does not necessarily apply to the smaller chains.
Gannett, with a market capitalization of $15.8 billion, and the Tribune Company, with $12.3 billion, are the industry giants. McClatchy, Belo and Pulitzer, by contrast, are only valued by investors at $1 billion to $2 billion. Having a market capitalization under $2 billion means not even being considered a midcap stock -- and losing a swath of institutional investors who avoid smaller companies. 
Size alone does not determine a public company's destiny -- particularly when, as with these companies and the larger New York Times and Washington Post Companies, family control is assured through a two-tiered stock system. But investment bankers and analysts say that smaller companies risk being overlooked or discounted by Wall Street if they fail to grow fast enough.
Companies that are overlooked may have to consider selling. Douglas H. McCorkindale, chief executive of Gannett, which last year bought Central Newspapers -- publisher of The Arizona Republic and The Indianapolis Star -- and 19 newspapers that had been part of Thomson, says consolidation will further thin the ranks of newspaper companies.
"When a smaller public company does not get recognition by Wall Street, it can be very frustrating for the owners," Mr. McCorkindale said. "That tends to lead to discussions that lead to mergers with larger companies and more liquidity for their stock. I suspect some of that is going to happen in the next 5 to 10 years."
But if smaller companies want to remain independent, their executives have reason to wonder if they should borrow enough to buy back all their stock and reinvent themselves as private companies.
Robert W. Decherd, chief executive of Belo, rejects that idea. "If it's not a good fit by personality or there are certain competitive circumstances that make it unproductive to be publicly held, the answer is to sell the company, not go private," he said. "As soon as you go private, you are back where you started. Not to mention you have a lot of debt."
Mr. Pruitt of McClatchy is less sure how to weigh the public-private balance. On one hand, he said, public ownership enforces financial discipline and makes it easier for owners to sell stock. "Many owners are wealthy on paper but don't have quite as much liquid wealth," he said. "The public marketplace has a ready place to sell."
Ticking off the names of family-owned newspapers that sold out after financial disputes among heirs, he said: "One of the reasons McClatchy went public was to remain independent. It was not the sole reason, but it was a reason."
The effect of that decision, he said, was to bring Wall Street into the company's life, sometimes for better, sometimes not.
Executives at private companies, Mr. Pruitt said, "don't have to deal with the broad array of public shareholders and all that that entails: annual reports and analysts' meetings and a fiduciary duty to a broad number of shareholders."
He added: "That obligation brings with it a great deal of time, expense and effort. And increasingly in recent years, it brings demands on meeting short-term profit expectations."
Profits are not optional for private companies, which often have taken on debt to finance growth. But Mr. Singleton of MediaNews said meeting his interest and principal payments was "a lower bar" than the hurdle of profit-margin growth that faces executives of companies traded on stock exchanges.
When companies go public, he said, "they go on a road show around the country and say, 'If you will give your money to buy my stock, I will give you double-digit earnings growth for the rest of your life.' "
He added: "They take the money. Then they've got to keep their end of the bargain."
But Mr. Decherd of Belo said that such bargains need not harm newsrooms and that neither public nor private companies had a monopoly on good -- or mediocre -- journalism.
"Each of these companies has a personality," he said. "Each has demonstrated over time that it has a commitment of various kinds and intensity to journalism and community. I believe those personalities will play out during this period and beyond."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
2 New Predictions Of Slower Ad Spending

BYLINE:  By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
There are two additional indications of the faltering media economy.
 Zenith Media in London, owned by the Cordiant Communications Group and the Publicis Groupe, is revising downward a forecast of American advertising spending in 2001 that the agency made in December. 
Zenith is halving the predicted growth rate for this year to an increase of 2.4 percent -- or flat compared with last year, if inflation is factored in. 
 The forecast, however, remains mildly bullish for later this year and beyond. Zenith is predicting an improved outlook for the final months of 2001 and is modestly raising ad spending estimates for 2002 and 2003.
Also, Myers Reports in New York, which publishes media and research newsletters and reports, released results of a survey of executives at ad agencies and client companies showing confidence as of March fell 24 percent from December.
Only 20.2 percent of respondents at client companies said they planned to increase ad spending this year, compared with 47.6 percent who said that in December. And 35.6 percent said they planned to decrease ad spending, compared with only 12.8 percent who said that in December.
One counterpoint was an increase in the number of respondents who said they would spend as much on advertising in 2001 as they did in 2000, to 44.2 percent from 39.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
The Class Warrior

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
When George W. Bush first became governor of Texas, he tried to cut the state tax on business profits while increasing the sales tax -- that is, he tried to cut taxes on wealthy shareholders while raising taxes that bear most heavily on ordinary families. This top-down class warfare was too much even for Texas, and Mr. Bush learned that it's better to take a less direct approach: use unrealistically optimistic budget projections to justify tax cuts for the rich, then when reality strikes use the pressure of a tight budget to squeeze programs for the poor and middle class.
 Until last week, the word was that Mr. Bush's tax cut had to be passed immediately to give the economy a short-term boost. Then Democrats came up with a much cheaper proposal that puts more money into consumers' hands this year. Now the word is that tax cutting is about long-term incentives, not short-run economic management. 
 But the push to pass the tax cut quickly, with minimal discussion, is still on. After all, who knows what wavering moderates might learn if they have time to check the details?
Not a week goes by without the discovery that some feature of the plan will cost far more than originally admitted. Last week's bombshell was a report from the bipartisan Joint Committee on Taxation that repealing the estate tax would offer wealthy Americans an array of new strategies that would allow them to legally avoid paying hundreds of billions in income taxes. That original "trillion-dollar tax cut" is now at $2.7 trillion and rising.
Republican leaders dealt with this blow, sort of, by postponing the phase-out of the estate tax. This does nothing to make the tax cut more affordable in the long run. But they hope that they can keep people focused on 10-year budget forecasts, and that nobody will ask what happens in year 11. Meanwhile, this news has another implication: Mr. Bush's tax plan is, believe it or not, even more tilted toward the rich than previously thought.
For all those chants of "no fuzzy math," Mr. Bush's people have never actually refuted independent estimates that about 40 percent of his tax cut goes to the richest 1 percent of families. In fact, a table released by the Treasury Department last month, although it was designed to convey the impression that the tax cut favored the middle class, actually contained enough information to show that if Treasury officials had calculated the share of the benefits going to the top 1 percent (they didn't), and if they had included the effects of estate tax repeal (they didn't), they would have come up with about the same number.
But now it seems that this is an underestimate. The Joint Tax Committee tells us that estate tax repeal will make it easier for the rich to avoid income taxes. So we can now surmise that more than half of the benefits of the tax cut will go to the wealthiest 1 percent. Or to put it in raw numbers: We're talking about a tax cut that would be worth nothing to the poorest quarter of families, which contain one-third of the nation's children; that would give an average of $616 per year to families with incomes between $30,000 and $40,000 (I calculated that number directly from the Treasury table. So much for that $1,600 "typical" tax cut); but would probably give more than $60,000 to families in the top 1 percent, whose average income is more than $1 million. 
Meanwhile the big squeeze has already begun. Mr. Bush hopes to rush through the tax cut before anyone has a good look at his spending plans, but some details are starting to emerge: the Department of Health and Human Services intends, among other things, to slash spending on rural health, disease prevention and aid to senior citizens. And we can be sure that's just the beginning. 
Will Mr. Bush eventually accept a revised tax plan that is less tilted toward the wealthy? I doubt it. Everything we have seen so far is consistent with the theory that those tax cuts for the rich are the whole point of the plan, that the middle-class cuts, such as they are, are no more than a loss leader designed to attract unwary customers. 
And about those who thought Mr. Bush meant something kinder and gentler by "compassionate conservatism," all I can say is, let them eat cake. And drink arsenic.

HEADLINE: The Flip Side of Fed Worship 

BYLINE:  By Steven Rattner; Steven Rattner is managing principal of Quadrangle Group, an investment firm.

 BODY:
Now comes the second-guessing of Alan Greenspan. Once held in awe as almost godlike, he suddenly can do no right. But just as the deification was overdone, so, too, is the current criticism.
 Mr. Greenspan has administered our most powerful economic tool -- control over the money supply -- admirably. History will judge him particularly well for his nimble changes of direction in response to economic indicators, all made without sacrificing his conviction that inflation is our most pernicious economic demon. 
 Mr. Greenspan recognized that American business was becoming more efficient, and he allowed faster economic growth than at least some of his more cranky predecessors would have. And his willingness to defy miserly central banker traditions and make large amounts of credit available after the 1987 stock market crash and again after the 1998 Asian economic crisis may well have averted far more significant economic disruptions.
In the years while Mr. Greenspan has been chairman of the Fedral Reserve, we have had our longest period of steady growth, creation of a huge number of jobs, low inflation and, yes, goodly appreciation in stock values. Even the Nasdaq stock index, despite its big fall over the ast year, is still more than triple what it was 10 years ago. Mr. Greenspan is hardly responsible for all of this, of course, but why the carping at him?
It's true that Mr. Greenspan nudged interest rates up prematurely in 1994, and in 1998 he might have shoved them down a bit too much. Most recently, he has offered uncharacteristically illogical justifications for tax cuts proposed by President Bush. But monetary policy, relying as it does on economic predictions, is not a perfect science. And the job has gotten even tougher with the advent of round-the-world trading desks that push markets violently at the slightest provocation, ever more arcane financial instruments, and microscopic tracking of the Fed's every move against arbitrary and often ill-defined "expectations" -- all chronicled breathlessly by 24-hour business television broadcast to millions of day traders.
Now we face a particular economic challenge: the aftermath of a speculative binge. The stampede into foolish ventures can hardly be blamed on Mr. Greenspan, who warned so famously about "irrational exuberance." The $4 trillion that has been lost in the stock markets was built on assumptions of earnings multiplying to the sky and on the fairy dust of dot-com and telecom start-ups; it had no substance. Priceline was never worth as much as most of the airlines combined. Even great companies like Cisco couldn't possibly justify their lofty valuations. And the Dow Jones index wasn't going to 36,000.
Should Mr. Greenspan have moved more aggressively to prick this speculative bubble, as some now suggest? That lament is particularly curious considering that when we were celebrating the new economy and the purported abolition of inflation and recession, every upward nudge that Mr. Greenspan gave to interest rates was met by a chorus of groans.
In the current circumstance, business needs time to absorb the massive industrial capacity created by the cheap money of equity and venture capital investors, as well as low-cost debt. Consumers need time to sleep off the hangover of stock market mania. Americans have been spending more than they could afford, incurring record amounts of debt. And then there is the threat of fallout from a record trade deficit.
The Nasdaq isn't going back to 5,000, at least not for a while. Consumers will have to adjust, and that may be still more painful than we can now see. Even at 1,670, the Nasdaq may well be overvalued, and the rest of the stock market may not be far behind. The average price-to-earnings ratio of stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 -- perhaps the most important stock market measure -- is now 23, compared with its long-term average of 15.
Our situation should serve as a humbling reminder to those who wish Mr. Greenspan to do something -- anything -- to make the hurt go away. We cannot expect miracles from the Fed, but only the slow salve of interest rates gliding prudently down. Instead of blaming Mr. Greenspan, we should reflect on the willing suspension of disbelief that allowed us to ignore everything we have been taught about sound investing. We brought this period of drying out upon ourselves.

HEADLINE: Asian Markets Seem Calm in China Crisis 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 3 

 BODY:
As diplomats and political leaders in Beijing and Washington traded testy statements today, investors here traded shares, in seeming disregard of the mushrooming dispute over a collision between American and Chinese aircraft over the South China Sea last weekend.
 That ho-hum reaction pervaded stock markets across Asia, and stood in sharp contrast to the United States, where markets have been buffeted by fears of the increasing tension between Beijing and Washington. 
 Analysts here said investors were confident that neither government would allow the incident to escalate into a more dangerous dispute. They also expressed belief that the crisis would not affect China's economic relations with the United States nor derail its quest to enter the World Trade Organization. 
"The market is expecting that the patrol plane issue will be resolved quickly," said Richard Margolis, first vice president for strategy and planning at Merrill Lynch in Hong Kong. "It's assuming, quite correctly, that the whole W.T.O. issue is being handled on a different track."
Mr. Margolis said Asian investors were resilient in absorbing political shocks. Stock markets in Hong Kong, Tokyo and Taipei have performed as well or better than United States markets since the beginning of the year, even as the region weathers a period of political turbulence.
"There is a sense that we're the jam in the sandwich between the U.S. and China," Mr. Margolis said. "But in this part of the world, political events very seldom create a new secular trend in the market."
In Hong Kong, a small crowd massed in front of the United States Consulate to demand an apology from Washington for the collision, in which a Chinese fighter jet was brought down. The consulate closed for an hour.
Yet the protests barely registered at the stock exchange nearby, where shares fell 1.12 percent, weighed down by an 11 percent drop in Pacific Century CyberWorks.
In Taiwan, where political sensitivities are more acute, the benchmark index dropped 2.87 percent. But again, the decline was caused mainly by domestic concerns. Several big corporations on Taiwan are about to report earnings, which are likely to be hurt by the American slowdown in technology spending.
The market in Taipei, Taiwan's main city, had risen in recent weeks as the Bush administration neared a decision on whether to sell advanced weapons to Taiwan. Many there think that President Bush is leaning toward selling some weapons, while deferring the sale of the sophisticated Aegis radar system, which China has said it does not want Taiwan to have. "From a stock market point of view," said Peter Kurz, chairman of Insight Pacific, a research advisory group in Taipei, "this would be the best outcome because it would supply Taiwan with necessary weapons but at the same time defuse tensions between China and the United States."
Mr. Kurz thought it was too soon to say whether the dispute over the surveillance plane would affect the arms sales. But he noted that heightened suspicion between the two powers would inevitably spill over into Taiwan-China relations, which would drag down the stock market.
American business leaders in Hong Kong and Beijing expressed some optimism that the dispute would have little effect on Chinese-American trade ties. Some expressed the view that Beijing had to some degree eschewed the strident tone it used after NATO planes bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in 1999.
China has ample economic incentive not to rupture American ties. It shipped $100 billion of exports to the United States last year, a 22 percent increase over 1999. 
"There are two things that will stay China's hand," said Simon L. Ogus, an independent economic analyst in Hong Kong. "They want to win the Olympics in 2008, and they want to get into the W.T.O. this year."
Despite the general equanimity in Asian markets, there were a few pockets of concern. Shares of companies based in mainland China and listed in Hong Kong fell more sharply than the broader Hang Seng index. China Unicom, the No. 2 Chinese telephone company, reported earnings for 2000 that were far higher than analysts' expectations. But its stock still declined 1.2 percent.
And some fund managers said they were watching nervously as United States officials struggled to retrieve the surveillance plane and its crew from Hainan, the Chinese island 400 miles southwest of Hong Kong.
"I think people are underestimating the potential it has to turn into a protracted issue," said Henry Lee, a director at Hendale Asset Management here. "It certainly doesn't set the right tone for the new administration and China."

HEADLINE: Lenders Try to Fend Off Laws on Subprime Loans 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Advocates in more than a dozen states and cities are pressing to pass laws limiting so-called predatory lending, rousing lenders into a coordinated counterattack that has managed to fend off or weaken some of the farthest-reaching proposals.
 The latest battle is in Philadelphia, where Citigroup, Household International and other lenders are seeking to derail a measure scheduled for a vote tomorrow in the City Council. 
 The spate of proposals is in response to what advocates of the measures say is the spread of unscrupulous lending practices and rising foreclosures of inner-city homes. While similar legislation has floundered in Congress, advocates have scored victories in several places, including North Carolina, Chicago and Washington. 
Lenders say the proposals will curtail access to credit for many families and create an awkward patchwork of regulations across the country. Among the industry's advisers are Connie Mack, the former Republican senator from Florida, and Thomas F. McLarty, former chief of staff for President Bill Clinton. 
North Carolina took the lead in banning predatory lending with a law passed in 1999, and the issue captured the interest of politicians elsewhere, particularly in big cities that have seen high numbers of foreclosures on high-fee, high-interest loans known in the industry as subprime.
Restrictions are being considered in California, Illinois and Tennessee, among other states, and in cities like Oakland, Calif., and Cleveland and Dayton in Ohio. Regulators have recently toughened rules in New York and Massachusetts; last month, legislation was defeated in Georgia and Nebraska.
Predatory lending refers to the practice of deceptively packing high fees, costly credit insurance and other charges into loans to unsophisticated borrowers. These fees, often exacerbated by so-called flipping -- refinancings that bring no benefit to borrowers but generate fees for lenders -- leave many homeowners with large monthly bills and balloon payments they cannot pay, except by ceding their home to the lender.
Last month, the Federal Trade Commission filed a lawsuit against the Associates First Capital Corporation, one of the country's biggest consumer lenders, charging it with routinely lying to and deceiving customers. Officials described it as the agency's most significant action against predatory lending. Citigroup, which purchased Associates last year, did not dispute the charges but said the lawsuit was counterproductive in light of its negotiations with the commission.
Advocates say more measures are needed to protect homeowners. "This has exploded," said Irv Ackelsberg, a managing attorney at Community Legal Services in Philadelphia. "You would have to be a rather distracted person not to notice that equity is being stolen all over the city. It's a public crisis."
Mr. Ackelsberg points to people like Veronica Harding, 72, a retired clothing factory worker who bought a row house in North Philadelphia for $7,500 in 1980 but now owes about $35,000 after refinancing five times in four years. The last loan generated $5,600 in fees, or 16 percent of the loan value. 
"It went so that one company would call and say, 'We'll pay off the other one,' and then another lender would call," Ms. Harding said.
With a monthly mortgage of $308 and Social Security income of $629, Ms. Harding said it was a struggle to pay bills. But she worries most about the $29,000 balloon payment she must make in 10 years -- a provision that Ms. Harding said she did not understand until a friend reviewed the loan after the closing.
"Lenders showed me how this would help me, but it wound up hurting me," she said. "I didn't know what this stuff was all about."
The lending industry prefers federal legislation -- though in a much milder form than some state proposals -- instead of piecemeal efforts. Last month, the American Bankers Association warned that "the proliferation of different state and local lending rules threatens to balkanize the lending market" and increase costs that are sure to be passed to consumers.
Household International, the consumer finance company, recently said it would draft "model legislation" and had appointed Mr. Mack and Mr. McLarty to a board of advisers.
"We are going to concentrate on the federal and state level," Mr. McLarty said.
Officials from large lenders including Countrywide Credit, one of the nation's largest mortgage lenders, and Bank of America gathered in Dallas three months ago for what was billed as a "predatory lending summit." Participants mapped strategies, such as creating a "swat team" of lobbyists to crisscross the country to defeat these measures. 
The attendance list underscored the fact that big investment and retail banks are active in subprime lending, either by financing lenders or owning their own units, like EquiCredit, a unit of Bank of America.
Subprime loans are typically made to borrowers with weaker credit, and they carry high interest rates and fees -- for example, a 13 percent interest rate for a home mortgage, versus current prevailing rates of about 7 percent. 
Of course, many subprime loans are not predatory, and lenders argue that the proliferation of these loans has made credit available to far more families than a decade ago. Restrictions, the industry says, can harm people who otherwise would not qualify for loans. 
Last year, Countrywide withdrew from subprime lending in North Carolina, saying that the state's new law made it too difficult to do business.
But consumer advocates say the soaring growth of subprime lending has resulted in many borrowers taking on predatory loans they will never be able to repay. 
Last year, a report by the Treasury Department and Department of Housing and Urban Development on predatory lending found that "evidence from a number of cities demonstrates that foreclosure actions have grown at a disturbing rate in inner city neighborhoods." In Baltimore, for example, foreclosure petitions increased to more than 5,000 in 1999 from 1,900 four years earlier.
The report concluded that borrowers of subprime mortgages do not understand that "the downside risk is no longer just bankruptcy, but loss of a home."
Fueled by money from Wall Street, subprime home refinancings rose 900 percent, to 790,000 annually, from 1993 to 1998, HUD reported last year. More than half of the refinancings in predominantly black neighborhoods in 1998 were made with subprime loans, over five times the rate in white neighborhoods, HUD found.
Some bankers say they are unfairly being dragged into what should be a fight over subprime lending practices. 
"Traditional banks are not where the problem is," said Joe Brannen, president of the Georgia Bankers Association, which this year successfully fought to defeat strict state legislation and replace it with what consumer advocates described as a substantially weakened measure.
The sponsor of the Georgia legislation, Vincent Fort, a Democratic state senator from Atlanta, said banks make too much money from subprime lending not to resist the legislation. 
"All of them, to one extent or the other, do subprime lending," Mr. Fort said, "or they plan on getting into it."
Advocates do not expect strong federal legislation, and they acknowledge that existing federal law limits how much states and cities can do. Representative John J. LaFalce of New York, ranking Democrat on the House Financial Services Committee, recently introduced antipredatory lending legislation, but with lenders opposed, he doubts the legislation has any better chance than past measures, which have failed.
The Federal Reserve has stepped into the fray with a proposal to expand consumer protections on certain high-cost loans to at least 5 percent of subprime loans from the current 1 percent.
However, advocates may be having the most success at the local level. In Chicago, the City Council passed an ordinance last year forbidding the city to do business with predatory lenders. In Chicago and its suburbs, foreclosures on subprime loans increased to almost 5,000 in 1999 from 131 in 1993, said Gov. George H. Ryan of Illinois. 
Now, lenders have turned their attention to Philadelphia, where a similar ordinance proposed by Councilwoman Marian Tasco is scheduled for a vote this week. Citigroup, for example, has hired local lobbyists and has sent in staff lobbyists from other cities to make its case.
Despite efforts to stop Ms. Tasco's bill and others like it around the country, Citigroup is "in favor of supporting legislation that would go after the bad actors out there," said Pamela Flaherty, who manages community relations for the company. "We don't want to do it in a way that hurts the ability of people with less than perfect credit to get loans."
Last week, a Citigroup lobbyist tried to get the Philadelphia council to support an amendment that would have exempted affiliates of banks, such as its own Citifinancial unit, which is one of the bigger subprime lenders in the city. The amendment failed to find a sponsor. 
"Household and Citibank wanted to amend the bill to the point where it would really be gutted," she said.

HEADLINE: Liberties; 
The Tyro's Twister

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Yellow ribbons. Energy crisis. Economic yips. The president shrinking into a tiny little figure in political cartoons.
 We're not getting Bush II. We're getting Carter II. All we need is the Killer Rabbit. And that is not where you want to be at the beginning of your presidency. 
 This is supposed to be a business-friendly, Harvard M.B.A. administration, but every time W. opens his mouth the markets tumble.
The White House had to wait until 4 p.m., when the markets closed, to let the president come out to the Rose Garden and start talking tough to China. Those little red Nasdaq and Dow numbers diving next to W.'s mouth moving would have undermined the image of American strength.
"The only issue now is whether his statements will drive down the Japanese markets," said one member of Bush II.
The only time W. has any luck with numbers is when it comes to counting and recounting the vote in Florida.
An already retro administration became even more vintage yesterday, with our spy plane "detained" in Communist territory. First we get in a tussle with Russia. Now China. Let's get out the yellow paint and start touching up those fallout shelter signs.
During the campaign, W. vowed, "We'll have a foreign policy that is humble." Humble is fine. But humbled is not so fine.
W. was green when he ran. But he promised to surround himself with gray. His inner circle -- Cheney, Rummy, Condi and Colin -- was supposed to offer a couple of hundred years of combined experience in government.
After the adolescent Clinton era, the grown-ups were back in charge.
So why has this crowd made all of us -- including the rest of the world -- so nervous?
Because, as a top foreign policy official in Bush I told me, they are too belligerent, too conservative, too blunt, too negative and too improvisational in dealing with the globe on everything from missile defense to Kyoto.
Alluding to the "Grumpy Old Men" foreign policy of Dick & Rummy as they advise the Tyro in Chief on how to handle Russia, China, Taiwan, Korea and the Middle East, an editorial in a leading German paper recently dubbed the new American president "Bully Bush." You know you're in trouble when the Germans complain you are too bellicose.
Even though his administration has been arrogant, W. still seems tentative when he ventures out to draw a line in the sand.
"You're never quite sure," somebody in the administration conceded, "if those papers in front of W. blew away in the wind, if he would know what to say."
If W. has to be supervised by officials who are in loco parentis, I would prefer the real parents. At least George Bush senior is not a wingnut, and at least he was a diplomat in China.
When Bill Clinton was president, he was always plunging into personal chaos. 
His management style was a mess. He ran a college-dorm White House. Meetings did not start on time. He pulled all-nighters. There were endless debates and endless greasy pizza deliveries. His private life was always exploding.
But outside his twister, things were palmy in the country and the markets.
W. is in a genial bubble. But outside his inner peace, the world looks more and more like a twister. He's taking naps and knocking off early while the rest of us are getting jittery and losing sleep.
The Bush organization men start every meeting on time and end every meeting on time. They have a ban on beepers and cell phones during press conferences, and a ban on sloppy clothes.
But everything outside the smoothly running White House is not smooth.
Seventy-five days into the Bush regime and I'm a wreck. I'm afraid to drink the water. I'm afraid to breathe the air. I'm afraid glaciers will melt and seas will rise. I'm afraid to visit California in the dark. I'm afraid the Dow will dip below 5,000. I'm afraid Russia will take leave of its senses. I'm afraid China will take lave of its senses. I'm afraid North Korea will lob a missile our way. 
At the rate things are reeling backward, soon I'll be fearing fear itself.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Nightmare on Wall Street: A Tightfisted Consumer

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
During the first three months of the year, many investors wondered just how much worse things could get in the stock market. They are getting their answer, loud and painfully clear, in April.
 Technology stocks, which have taken the brunt of this bear market's beating, endured more punishment yesterday. The Nasdaq composite index lost 6.17 percent as investors dumped shares of software companies and telecommunications concerns. The Nasdaq is now down 32.3 percent for the year. 
 But the selling also spread to the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday, which lost 292.22 points, or almost 3 percent of its value. Only one of the 30 stocks in the Dow registered a gain -- Home Depot. 
The decline in the Dow appears to represent a shift away from the view, held by many investors, that the bear market could remain relatively contained to technology shares. Such a sentiment had helped keep the Dow Jones industrial average -- with its broad array of companies from a variety of industries -- afloat in the Nasdaq storm. Now the Dow is being buffeted by sellers who seem to think there is no haven in United States stocks, after all. 
Adding to some investors' unease yesterday was the heightened dispute between China and the United States over the collision of a Chinese fighter and a Navy intelligence plane, and the status of the American crew and aircraft in Chinese hands. 
James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, said: "Until late February, the entire stock market was just correcting the technology bubble. Now, this has broadened out to be not just a tech decline but looking more like a full-blown recessionary decline." 
Technology shares continue to tumble as demand wanes for Internet routing equipment, cellular telephones and fiber optic cable. Fears of rising bankruptcy filings among smaller telecommunications concerns have infected industry giants like Nortel Networks, Lucent Technologies and Qualcomm. All three hit new 52-week lows yesterday.
In the last two days alone, the Nasdaq composite index is down more than 9 percent, closing yesterday at 1,673. It has lost more than two-thirds of its value since it reached a close-of-trading-session peak of 5,048.62 on March 10, 2000. 
Investors fleeing the carnage took refuge earlier this year in shares of companies selling goods and services to consumers, who have continued to spend. Technology expenditures might fall, their thinking went, but surely the consumer could again be relied on to pick up the slack and keep the economy out of recession. 
Now they are not so sure. 
It is consumer spending, the engine of economic growth, that concerns economists and analysts most. It helped prop up the Dow industrials until recently, but continued strength is in doubt, some say. Witness the recent declines in the shares of Philip Morris, Coca-Cola, Wal-Mart Stores and other companies that had remained somewhere near their recent highs as technology stocks collapsed. 
"Our general feeling is the next shoe to drop in the economy is a slowdown in consumer spending," said Jason Trennert, economist at ISI Group, a broker-dealer in New York specializing in economic research. "For us, it is inconceivable that you could take $5 trillion out of stock market wealth and not see a major impact on consumer confidence."
There is no doubt that consumers are crucial to economic growth. Their spending accounts for a significant portion of the growth in the gross domestic product. And even as a great deal of stock market wealth has evaporated, consumers have remained surprisingly upbeat. Consumer confidence, while down from its peaks, bounced back in March.
Purchases of big-ticket items like new cars and homes have remained healthy. General Motors said auto sales slipped less than had been expected in March, indicating that consumers continue to spend in the economic slowdown.
A key reason for the buying power is a still strong employment market. According to the Labor Department, 135,000 jobs were added in February. 
But consumer spending could dry up if a recent increase in layoffs begins to multiply. Delphi Automotive Systems, Charles Schwab, Citigroup, Motorola and Procter & Gamble have announced recently that they are cutting their work forces. More cutbacks, economists say, are close on the horizon.
"What has become clear in the last couple of weeks is that there is excess capacity and excess headcount beyond technology companies," said Liz K. Miller, portfolio manager at Trevor, Stewart Burton & Jacobsen, a money management firm in New York. "Managements are going to respond the same way they have in every other recession -- through general contraction." 
The problem is that consumers have little cushion to soften the blow of layoffs. Many of their personal balance sheets are creaking under a load of debt, and savings are close to nonexistent. During the 90's, Americans piled on debt. Consumer debt as a share of the gross domestic product now stands at close to 71 percent, a new high, and up almost half from the early 1980's. As a share of personal income, household debt has risen to 85 percent, also a record. 
According to Moody's Investors Service, American households' liquid financial assets -- including savings accounts and other assets that can be converted to cash relatively easily -- dropped 13.2 percent in the first three months of this year from the first three months of 2000. Although these household assets as a percentage of debt are still greater than they were from 1985 to 1990, this quarter's plunge would be the steepest since a 14.3 percent decline in late 1974, during a recession and a bear market.
And personal savings as a percentage of disposable income went into negative territory last July, meaning that for the first time, consumers as a whole were spending more than they had in disposable income. In January, the figure fell to a negative 0.98 percent, the lowest ever. In February it rose a bit, but it remains at a negative 0.91 percent.
"Indebtedness-to-income levels are as high as they've ever been," Mr. Paulsen of Wells Capital said. "You can be very indebted, but it will never surface if everyone has a job. If we have a large rise in unemployment, we may find out how bad the debt problem is among the lower half of the income distribution. And that has a lot of ripples."
Mr. Paulsen says that the recent weakness in the prices of consumer stocks may be forecasting a decline in consumption itself in coming months. "Even though stock markets don't predict recessions accurately," he said, "the moves do predict speed-ups or declines in the economy. This move tells me that three months out, we'll start to see some of these consumer statistics really tail off."
Economists at Goldman, Sachs estimate that from 1995 to 2000, the rise in household net worth -- largely owing to the stock market's surge -- propelled growth in the gross domestic product by more than one percentage point a year. At the same time, the savings rate fell.
Now that stock investors have lost several trillion dollars, at least on paper, they will probably try harder to save. "I think they're already feeling the need to try to compensate by saving a little more," said Edward McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. "But there has been no progress in doing that, which suggests that we are likely to have more retrenchment in consumer spending." This spending is expected to show 2.7 percent year-over-year growth for the quarter just ended, from a year earlier. By the third quarter, Mr. McKelvey estimates, the growth will have slowed to 0.8 percent from a year earlier. 
So, stock investors, already fearful that corporate earnings will not turn up anytime soon, are adding the worry of a parsimonious consumer to the mix. "The market's very troubled by the fact that earnings aren't recovering," Mr. McKelvey said. "Add to that a nervousness about the consumer and a general recognition that the slowdown we are in has a significant risk of turning into a recession."
The Wall Street economist Henry Kaufman agreed. "There is a recognition within the market," he said, "that the easing by the central banks so far is not going to arrest the slowdown immediately. For the first time, the Fed is admitting there is a negative wealth effect. My own view is we ought to have a substantial tax cut now."

HEADLINE: National Briefing 

 BODY:
 SOUTHWEST

TEXAS: EXPANDED USE OF DNA TESTS -- A bill making it easier for inmates to use DNA tests to try to prove their innocence received final approval from the Legislature, and Gov. Rick Perry is expected to sign it into law. The legislation requires prosecutors to preserve biological evidence and provides state-paid DNA testing if it was not available at trial and could clear an inmate. One amendment to the bill requires courts to provide lawyers for indigent inmates; another allows inmates who pleaded guilty to request testing. AP

ARIZONA: A RIOT AFTER A LOSS -- The police arrested six people in downtown Tucson on Monday night for assault, disorderly conduct and trespassing in disturbances after the University of Arizona's loss to Duke in the college basketball championship game. Hundreds of fans set fire to cars, smashed store windows and exploded fireworks, and were subdued by police officers with tear gas and rubber bullets. Similar violence by fans of losing teams has erupted this year in Indiana and Maryland. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

MIDWEST

MISSOURI: DEMOCRAT WINS IN ST. LOUIS -- As expected, Francis Slay, left, the Democrat who presides over the aldermanic board in St. Louis, easily won election as mayor. The Republican contender, Michael Chance, a computer programmer, had urged voters to "try something different" after 56 years of Democratic leadership under which the city's population shrank and social and economic problems grew. But Mr. Slay was so confident they would not -- few cities are more heavily Democratic -- that he campaigned relatively little and ran no television advertisements. Mr. Chance had no money for advertisements. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

SOUTH

LOUISIANA: SETBACK IN CASE AGAINST GUN MAKERS -- The State Supreme Court ruled that New Orleans could not sue gun makers for the costs of treating victims of gun violence. The city was the first in the country to pursue a legal strategy against gun manufacturers in 1998, but the State Legislature passed a law to block the suit. In a 5-to-2 ruling, the court said the law was justified because the state had the power to regulate guns. David Firestone (NYT)

MID-ATLANTIC

DELAWARE: BUSH PUSHES EDUCATION PLAN -- President Bush visited an after-school program in a poor neighborhood of Wilmington in an effort to raise the political profile of his education plan. The plan broadly seeks to loosen restrictions on how states use federal money for education, in exchange for annual testing in grades three to eight. Republicans and Democrats have clashed ove cents educational vouchers, which would allow students to leave failing schools and take some federal money with them. A possible compromise being discussed would be a demonstration project that would allow limited use of vouchers. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

NEW ENGLAND

MASSACHUSETTS: MORE 'BIG DIG' TROUBLES -- The state attorney general has opened a criminal investigation into whether state officials tried to cover up huge cost overruns on the "Big Dig" highway project beneath downtown Boston. The price has climbed to $14 billion, although as late as last year state officials said they were meeting their $10.8 billion budget. The attorney general's office said it was not investigating Gov. Paul Cellucci, who is to appear before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as President Bush's choice for ambassador to Canada. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

RHODE ISLAND: DEBATE CANCELED -- A Brown University student group has canceled a debate scheduled for today that would have featured David Horowitz, the conservative author who placed advertisements in several campus newspapers, including Brown's, denouncing calls for reparations to black Americans for slavery. The cancellation was first reported in The Brown Daily Herald. "We felt there was definitely the potential for violence," said Abby McEwen, the president of the Brown College Republicans, the organization that had invited Mr. Horowitz to Providence, to debate the president of a local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

WASHINGTON

AGRICULTURE AIDES ANNOUNCED -- Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman, who is from California, selected her top aides today, choosing farmers from the Midwest and the South. Her choice for deputy secretary is James R. Moseley, a hog farmer and former agricultural official from Indiana, which is also the home of Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Republican who heads the Agricultural Committee. For undersecretary for marketing and regulation, Ms. Veneman selected Bill Hawks of Mississippi, who was recommended by his state's two Republican senators: Trent Lott, the majority leader, and Thad Cochran, chairman of the Agriculture subcommittee on appropriations. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

POSTAL CUTS EXPECTED -- The Postal Service said that it would consider cutting back to a five-day schedule that would eliminate mail delivery on Saturdays. And post office officials also said they would look into potential savings from consolidating and closing some postal plants and offices. The service faces a $2 billion to $3 billion loss this fiscal year, officials said. (NYT)

HEADLINE: COLLISION WITH CHINA: THE WASHINGTON VIEW; 
Powell Sees No Need for Apology; Bush Again Urges Return of Crew

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin N. Powell declared today, "We have nothing to apologize for" in the collision of an American spy plane with a Chinese fighter, while President Bush briefly emerged to warn China "it is time for our servicemen and women to return home."
 In a brief statement in the Rose Garden minutes after he talked by telephone with the American general who visited the crew of the United State plane held by China, the president set no deadlines and left unclear what kind of options he would pursue if Beijing failed to comply. But he also tried to sound reassuring, saying that the crew members had "suffered no injuries" and they "send their love to their families." 
 Then, after calling for their immediate return, he turned on his heel and walked quickly back to the Oval Office, declining for a second day to take any questions.
Tonight, a senior administration official, asked about China's demand today for an apology before releasing the crew, said: "There isn't a need for an apology. If we can get past the point of recriminations, we can figure out what happened." 
The senior official who briefed reporters tonight said the United States was not willing to cut back on the number of spy missions along the Chinese coast, another Chinese demand. "The United States was well within its rights to do what it was doing in international airspace," the official told a small group of reporters, "and that is not up for discussion."
There was some discussion within the administration today of getting a third country to act as an intermediary. Singapore would be the obvious choice, since many of its officials are Western-trained ethnic Chinese, who consult closely with Washington. But one official said the idea was "not likely to fly," and another said it had not reached the White House.
Based on the meeting today with the crew members detained on Hainan Island, Bush administration officials described the plane as damaged far more severely than they originally thought. One engine was knocked out entirely by the collision with the Chinese fighter plane, which crashed into the sea, and another propeller was damaged. The pilot had no working airspeed indicator, and the plane plunged 8,000 feet immediately after the impact. "It was a miraculous job of piloting," one official said. 
The extent of the damage suggest ed that the aircraft's crew members had little time to focus on destroying military software, data and equipment aboard as they stabilized the aircraft and prepared for what was a risky landing. "You're briefed to address the safety of the crew before the compromise of information," a Pentagon official said.
Mr. Bush's appearance in the Rose Garden this afternoon was the second time in two days that he has issued a terse comment in the standoff with the Chinese leadership. He seemed nervous initially, taking a deep, audible breath before delivering his brief statement.
Once again, he left unanswered many questions about American strategy in a strange incident that the new administration, in the words of one of his senior advisers, is taking "step by step."
In their private communications with American officials -- both here and in Beijing -- the Chinese have not indicated how long they intend to hold the 24 Americans. "The Chinese said they need time to, I believe the words were 'to complete their investigation,' " the senior administration official said tonight.
Toward that end the Chinese have questioned the crew members, many of them cryptology specialists, and by some accounts have removed intelligence equipment from the plane. While the spy plane remains in open view on the airfield where it landed, crew members have been removed to a military guesthouse, where they are sleeping two to a room.
Behind the scenes, Mr. Bush's top aides were acknowledging that they had little leverage over the Chinese.
"There aren't a lot of good options," one senior official said. Another noted that withdrawing America's ambassador in protest would "deprive us of our point man," and that threatening economic sanctions against a country that supplies American industry with critical components for everything from phones to computers would be "counterproductive at best, stupid at worst." 
There was also increasing anger at the Chinese, which was not alleviated by the circumstances surrounding the visit to the crew members today. Officials said that Brig. Gen. Neal Sealock, the American defense attache in Beijing, who led the delegation on Hainan Island, was not permitted to discuss in detail with the crew the circumstances of their collision with a Chinese fighter jet over the South China Sea on Sunday.
With Chinese officials sitting in on the conversation with the 24 -- no individual meetings were permitted -- the envoys could not take up the issue of how the crew shut down the plane or what intelligence-gathering equipment, software and files they were able to destroy before the plane was boarded by Chinese military.
"It was a tense encounter with the Chinese," said one official who had read the reports of the meeting on Hainan Island. One official said General Sealock was not permitted to distribute candy that he had brought along for the detained crew members.
In his public statement, Mr. Bush said, "We have allowed the Chinese government time to do the right thing," a statement that officials here said was intended to signal to the Chinese leadership that Washington had run out of patience. 
And Mr. Bush made his most specific suggestion that America's broad engagement with China as at risk. "This accident has the potential of undermining our hopes for a fruitful and productive relationship between our two countries," he said. "To keep that from happening, our servicemen and women need to come home."
Mr. Bush's use of the Rose Garden to deliver his personal messages to President Jiang Zemin and other Chinese leaders -- rather than the hotline between the White House and Mr. Jiang's office -- is a curious choice. Public statements assure that all Chinese leaders, military and political, hear the same message at the same time. But it may also undercut efforts to make a private deal, the way the Clinton administration dealt with the American bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, and Henry Kissinger set up Richard Nixon's first opening to Beijing.
There have been private conversations under way: The American ambassador in Beijing, Adm. Joseph W. Preuher, has met with with the senior vice foreign minister, Zhou Wenzhong , according to State Department officials. The undersecretary of state for political affairs, Marc I. Grossman, met with the newly arrived Chinese ambassador, Yang Jiechi. And Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage met today with Mr. Yang.
General Powell, speaking with reporters on his flight from Florida to Washington today, described both meetings with Mr. Yang as an "exchange of views" and not a dialogue.
Asked if President Bush would talk directly to Mr. Jiang, whose own power to resolve the standoff is now being questioned in the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency, the official said that "at some point it may be appropriate to push this to higher levels."
That would entail some risk. President Clinton once said the hot line was useful only after the leaders on each end got to know and trust each other. Mr. Bush and Mr. Jiang have not met.
Some American officials speculate that Mr. Jiang cannot risk seeming to bend to the new president's will, especially because Beijing fears that Mr. Bush will approve the sale of advanced weapons and radar to Taiwan. "Jiang is probably feeling pretty exposed," one senior American diplomat said.
Mr. Bush may have similar feelings. He is caught between one wing of his party, propelled by American business interests, that wants deep economic engagement with China and another that wants to contain China's power.
At the Pentagon today, a spokesman was asked whether Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was planning to voice concerns. "Clearly, we believe that there is a diplomatic solution to this incident and not a military one," said the spokesman, Rear Adm. Craig Quigley.
The administration faces a difficult choice in the next few days: How to dissuade China from making an apology the prerequisite for the crews' release or, alternatively, how to fashion a statement that would satisfy the Chinese but also be acceptable to the administration and Congress.
One possibility is to set up a commission of American and Chinese officials to investigate the collision and come up with a plan to avoid repeating it.
On his plane today, General Powell sidestepped questions about how long the Chinese could hold onto the crew without provoking a sharp American reaction. "I don't want to put a time limit on it," he said.
