 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 39

LENGTH: 4620 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by an elegance, an economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

"ALUMINUM BY DESIGN: JEWELRY TO JETS," Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through July 15). Once regarded as a precious metal, aluminum today is one of the cheapest and most useful of all materials, the stuff of lawn chairs and airplanes. Though lacking the kind of sumptuous objects you would find in an exhibition devoted to gold or silver, this exhibition tells a fascinating story. It begins with Victorian jewelry, pauses for a good look at elegant Modernist furniture and housewares, touches on sports equipment and soda cans and concludes with contemporary objects like a chaise longue by Marc Newson, a silvery blob with riveted skin that looks like a prop from David Lynch's film "Dune." Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays to 9 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $5, students and 62+ (Ken Johnson).

* "BITSTREAMS" AND "DATA DYNAMICS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through June 10). Companion digital shows with a well-mannered, slightly dull air of decorous efficiency and cheerful modernity that encapsulates what you may regard as an ethos at large. Both affairs survey the new technological age in art, and there is no denying the inevitability of the big message here, which we discount at the risk of sheer stupidity: technology is changing how artists, especially young ones, make all types of art and, in turn, how we experience it. Still, the work produced needs to answer the old question: Does it move us? And there's the rub. A few artists, like Paul Pfeiffer and Jeremy Blake, stand out in "BitStreams." In "Data Dynamics," works like "Apartment" and "Netomat," metaphors for the Web as global unconscious, suggest that Internet art is at least becoming more like traditional media, whereby most but no longer all of what you see is unremarkable. Don't skip the sound section in "BitStreams," 25 audio artists working squarely in the tradition of musique concrete, a half-century-old movement but with new digital means replacing tape recorders. Hours: Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "COMMITTED TO THE IMAGE: CONTEMPORARY BLACK PHOTOGRAPHERS," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through April 29). This sharply installed survey of 94 artists covers several decades of work, much of it by a generation of photographers who came of age in the 1960's and 70's. The pictures are sorted by broad themes (people, beauty, family, religion, etc.), and formal polish tends to predominate over conceptual grit. The terrain, over all, is unsensational ordinary life, with the heat turned up high now and then. Images of urban churchgoers, Louisiana sugar cane cutters, the magnetic Billie Holiday and children in African refugee camps sit side by side. The eclectic array has its share of bland entries, but there are dozens of wonderful artists here, and their collective spirit is persuasive. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 am. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of the month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

"THE GLOBAL GUGGENHEIM: SELECTIONS FROM THE EXTENDED COLLECTION," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through April 22). Of the big permanent collection shows that have been taking up so much space, the Guggenheim's is the last. It's also the coolest, the prettiest, the least programmatic and the most conservative. Despite the "global" spin of the title, this is strictly a Euro-American affair. And thanks to the eye of the curator, Carmen Gimenez, it is a very beautiful one. The great Wright spiral feels freshly swept out; the bays are sparingly hung; and dozens of top-notch works, including a few from the Hermitage in St. Petersburg and Guggenheim branches abroad, have been paired and grouped to ignite free-associational sparks. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 am. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "ANDREAS GURSKY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). The giant pictures in this midcareer retrospective of Mr. Gursky, the 46-year-old German photographer, are so eye-poppingly, drop-dead gorgeous that in this world, where no good turn goes unpunished, you may feel compelled to react with suspicion and reserve. But knee-jerk resistance at the sight of the nondescript global emblems of new capitalist sprawl that he photographs is short-circuited by sheer awe at the incredible, sublimely weird, almost erotic glamour he imparts to them. The work is instantly attractive to the point of alarm, which is the feeling of falling in love. You might as well give yourself over to it and worry about the consequences later. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; until 8:15 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"HERE AND THERE/AQUI Y ALLA: SIX ARTISTS FROM SAN JUAN," El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, East Harlem, (212) 831-7272 (through May 20). The six ambitious, cosmopolitan Puerto Rican artists in this show -- four men and two women, all in their 30's, all working with some form of installation -- are a lively crew. Minimalism isn't their scene; nor, in any overt way, is politics. For the most part they are into sound, color, humor and unfastidious beauty, with several media cooking away simultaneously. The results are a high-spirited, obstacle-ridden, outre-and-proud sort of show, the kind you move slowly, even cautiously, around in rather than one you breeze through. Hours: Wednesday through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* PAUL McCARTHY, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through May 13). From his far-out position where the psychic security of Hollywood's packaging of sex and violence doesn't exist, Mr. McCarthy taps veins deep in the collective subconscious, well beyond where most shock artists have the audacity or intelligence to operate. He has been a cultish presence in Los Angeles for years, and his moment has finally come in New York. We see an artist of wild highs and lows, of black comedy, cheap jokes, unspeakable actions, dry formalism and some real fiascos -- the mark of an artist risking failure, a good sign. There is something beyond mere Pop parody or social provocation in the work, something to do with deep private needs and desires, which we perceive secondhand as comic pathos. It is art as tough therapy, disturbingly honest. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "19TH- AND 20TH-CENTURY CHINESE PAINTINGS FROM THE ROBERT H. ELLSWORTH COLLECTION, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Aug. 19). The 19th and 20th centuries were shattering times for China, bringing wars, civil violence and the fall of an empire. In art, old forms survived and flourished but also changed. This exhibition surveys how elite painting traditions developed for a new audience and under Western influences from 1850 to 1980. Among the highlights is a group of paintings by Qi Baishi (1864-1957), deservedly one of the most popular of all Chinese artists. The big news is that a major museum has quietly taken a firm stand on modern art in Asia, seeing it not as a postscript to a great tradition but as an integral, living part of the continuum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "THE TREASURY OF BASEL CATHEDRAL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 27). The jewel-embellished gold and silver liturgical objects and reliquaries in this show exist on some exotic outer fringe of beauty where the crass and the ineffable meet. Together they have a cliffhanger of a tale to tell, as frustrating as it is uplifting. (They were preserved as an ensemble until Basel city politics intervened in the 19th century.) There's the rarity factor: almost none of the 75 works have visited the United States before. And it's hard to remember the last time anythig quite like their single-minded incandescence radiated from a local museum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "VAN GOGH'S POSTMAN: THE PORTRAITS OF JOSEPH ROULIN," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). This revelatory micro-exhibition reunites five portraits of the postal worker Joseph Roulin, whom van Gogh met while in Arles. The show affords an excellent opportunity to study the painter's craft as he processes a single motif through a series of approaches from painterly naturalism to richly patterned symbolism. It is fascinating as well to see the portraits in light of the biographical background. Roulin cared for van Gogh after the famous ear-cutting incident, and he grew in the artist's imagination from an amusing local character to a figure of Christ-like benevolence. Hours and admission: See above (Johnson).

* "VERMEER AND THE DELFT SCHOOL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through ay 27). Genius does not flourish in a vacuum. That's the simple lesson vividly conveyed by this alternately tousled and crystalline exhibition. With 15 Vermeers -- nearly half his known paintings -- serving as ballast, this exhibition almost giddily spotlights a succession of artists, tracking the emergence of an increasingly effortless illusionism in Delft in the 1650's and 60's. Flower still lifes, whitewashed church interiors, townscapes and genre scenes by Pieter de Hooch, Carel Fabritius and Gerard Houckgeest are part of the mix, along with drawings and a breathtaking selection of small landscapes by artists you've never heard of. All this contextualizing sharpens one's sense of Vermeer's achievement, but it also spells out the milieu without which he would not have been Vermeer. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

Galleries: Uptown

NICK BLOSSER, "Out-of-Doors," Adam Baumgold, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338 (through April 14). This Tennessee-based painter works from actual landscapes but abstracts, distorts and animates his observations to transcendentalist effect. Painted with unfussy directness in egg tempera on wood panels, the undulating rhythms of trees, clouds and winding paths, the fuzzy textures of foliage, grass and shrubbery and the wintry light -- all compactly contained within wide, dark frames -- make for small worlds that are at once magical and all-natural (Johnson).

* "ENDURING ART OF JADE AGECHINA: CHINESE JADES OF LATE NEOLITHIC THROUGH HAN PERIODS," Throckmorton Fine Art, 153 East 61st Street, (212) 223-1059 (through April 14). Organized by the art historian Elizabeth Childs-Johnson and accompanied by a substantial catalog, this show includes 70 pieces, most of them shirt-pocket size, arranged chronologicaly around the gallery. Despite the diminutive scale and the notorious intractability of jade itself, each piece is spectacular, with pinpoint-fine carved detail. No wonder jade had mystical allure for the ancient Chinese: it's as adamant as political ambition, as luminous as trapped light (Cotter).

* NEIL JENNEY, "The Bad Years: 1969-70," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through April 14). Twenty-one paintings from the beginning of Mr. Jenney's career demonstrate that in the early 1970's the medium was not only not dead, but was also absorbing the strategies and attitudes of Conceptual and Process Art. With their lackadaisical brushwork, Dick-and-Jane simplicity, heavy black frames and teasing titles, these works twist the connections between word and image, surface and depth, and glibness and something dark and more than a little disturbing. Three more recent works give an idea of what Mr. Jenney is up to now (Smith).

"NIGHTLIFE," Bonni Benrubi, 52 East 76th Street, (212) 517-3766 (through April 15). A gleeful couple on a Parisian bumper car by Robert Frank; Robert Frost captured by Arthur Rickerby being lionized by two young bare-shouldered women at his Nobel Prize dinner; Marilyn Monroe and her amazing elevating skirt in two different images by George Zimbel; glowing movie and theater signs of New York by Benn Mitchell, Sam Ross and Louis Stettner; fireworks over Niagara Falls on New Year's Eve 2000, by Jed Devine -- all this and more make up this cornucopia of photographic nocturnes (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

BILL BRANDT, "Known and Unknown," Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070 (through May 5). Parlormaids and coal miners, portraits, landscapes and nudes, are some of the subjects tackled by Brandt (1904-1983), perhaps the greatest of English photographers. His high-contrast prints are often infused with the Surrealist spirit he absorbed in Paris as a young man. After World War II, Brandt gave up documentary photography to concentrate on the poetic side of his art, and there is a wonderful selection here of his famous nudes, some straight, some distorted versions of the female body or abstracted parts. They disturb the viewer's sense of rightness-with-the-world, but that was the aim of Brandt's adventurous lens (Grace Glueck).

* "THE JINA COLLECTION," Frederick Schultz Ancient Art, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 758-6007 (through April 28). Few examples of sculpture associated with the Jain religion of India are on permanent view in New York, which makes this show a rare treat. The 25 pieces are all of male spiritual heroes known as jinas. A seventh-century bronze figure has been rubbed as smooth as sea-stone from countless ritual baths. A big image from Rajasthan is among the earliest known Jain metal images of its size, and another, carved from sugar-white marbl, is surely among the most beautiful. The show was organized in collaboration with Peter Marks, one of the city's top dealers in South Asian art (Cotter).

Galleries: Chelsea

EUGENIO DITTBORN, "The Foreseen and Unforseen Position of Their Bodies," Alexander and Bonin, 132 10th Avenue, between 18th and 19th Streets, (212) 367-7474 (through April 14). Since 1984 this Chilean conceptualist has been folding up his paintings and exporting them by airmail, at first to evade government censors and later as a metaphor about geography, distance and modernity. Unfolded and pinned to the wall, his expansive stitched, printed and stained fabric collages of words and pictures offer an oblique, sometimes witty, sometimes horrific poetry of historical, philosophical, political and personal reflection (Johnson).

GRAHAM DURWARD, JEAN-FREDERIC SCHNYDER, "Three Paintings," AC Project Room, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 645-4970 (through April 14). Two artists, the first a Scottish New Yorker, the second Swiss, both with restless conceptualist tendencies, show three paintings. Two are large, one little. Mr. Durward's expansive, Sam Francis-like abstractions, painted on grids of vellum panels, have a lush, watery prettiness. But Mr. Schnyder's 8 1/2-by-12-inch picture of a green alpine landscape that harbors a nuclear power plant has a rich, painterly concentration that steals the show (Johnson).

SHARON GOLD, "Seeing Subjects," Pardo Lattuada, 210 11th Avenue, near 25th Street, (212) 242-8523 (through April 17). Viewers who know Ms. Gold as a prominent painter of rectangle-style abstractions in the 1970's and 80's might be surprised by her new works: small, figurative oil paintings, many of which depict 19th-century women using various sorts of viewing devices like mirrors, spectacles, magnifiers or stereoscopes. The artist was evidently transformed by reading theory about looking, the gaze and so forth (Johnson).

"HOME AND THE WORLD: AN EXPLORATION OF IDENTITY AT CROSSROADS," India Center of Art and Culture, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 462-4221 (through May 31). The recently opened nonprofit space is devoted equally to art, literature, music and film, and most of those media play some role in this group exhibition of contemporary artists of Indian descent (Cotter).

JUSTINE KURLAND, Gorney Bravin + Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through April 14). In her second show, which feels transitional, this young photographer pushes her teenage girl-in-landscape theme in some different directions, while greatly reducing its double meanings and odd intimations of magic kingdoms and myths. Most images settle for after-school banality; others render the figures incidental to a growing emphasis on landscape, which is notable for its clarity of light and detail (Smith).

* CLAUDETTE SCHREUDERS, "Burnt by the Sun," Jack Shainman, 513 West 20th Street, (212) 645-1701 (through April 14). There is a dark side to the irresistibly charming faux-folk, carved and painted wood sculpture of this young, white South African artist, for in variously subtle ways it alludes to the experience of growing up under apartheid. "Mingle" portrays the young artist herself holding a glass of wine, a shy person at an art opening perhaps. Seen against the background of apartheid, however, the title takes on a much more loaded urgency and the anxiety of the artist a far greater poignancy (Johnson).

BEVERLY SEMMES, Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-8450 (through April 14). An artist known for her sculptures in the form of gigantically oversize women's clothing here presents something monumental and absurd but abstract: a great, vaguely fecal mound of convoluted, fat, stuffed tubes of electric green nylon. Gallery personnel are wearing overalls made from the same material, which creates a mysterious sense of industrial purpose (Johnson).

MARK SHEINKMAN, Von Lintel & Nusser, 555 West 25th Street, (212) 242-0599, (through April 14). Made by a methodical process of taping, painting and smearing, Mr. Sheinkman's glossy autumn-hued abstractions have a shimmering, allover luminosity; but the technique is too obviously formulaic. On small pieces of paper, on the other hand, he carefully plows through paint with blunt instruments to create layered tubular compositions that are more engagingly various and materially delicate (Johnson).

AL SOUZA, Charles Cowles, 537 West 24th Street, (212) 925-3500 (through April 21). Mr. Souza makes pictures entirely from jigsaw puzzle parts. Using sections from many different puzzles, side by side or glued on top of one another, he produces surrealistically disjunctive compositions, including images of cats, New England barns, comic book superheroes and packaged candy. The kitschy, kaleidoscopic busyness is fun, but when you get close, you wish they were made in some more interesting way (Johnson).

"THREE CONTEMPORARY PAINTERS," Bose Pacia Modern, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 989-7074 (through April 23). Work by three Indian-born artists, including Dhruvi Acharya's symbolic tableaus of dream-travelling women; a terrific multipart piece by Manisha Parekh from the reent Havana Biennale; and, most haunting, spare calligraphic paintings by Nilima Sheikh illustrating episodes from the life of the Buddha (Cotter).

Galleries: SoHo

"AT THE EDGE: THE HORIZON LINE IN CONTEMPORARY ART," Dorsky, 379 West Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 966-6170 (through April 14). This 15-artist group show might have taken a less literal, more imaginative approach to its potentially rich theme, but it offers some pleasing pictures. These include three small, delicately atmospheric seascapes painted by Pat de Groot and assorted expansive photographic landscapes or waterscapes, ranging from lush color pictures by Stuart Klipper and Richard Misrach to the Minimalistic black-and-white approaches of Hiroshi Sugimoto or Tom Bamburger (Johnson).

DONALD BAECHLER, "Five Easy Pieces," Tony Shafrazi, 119 Wooster Street, (212) 274-9300 (through April 14). Each of the five handsome works in this nicely spaced show consists of a big, primitivistic black-and-white flower, roughly painted over a seemingly aged patchwork collage of dots or stripes, generic cartoon faces, geometric forms and old prints of flowers or soldiers. The faux naivete is calculated, but nevertheless the nostalgia for childhood is not unaffecting (Johnson).

"JOSEPH BEUYS, GERHARD RICHTER, BINKY PALERMO, SIGMAR POLKE," Nolan/Eckman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-6190 (through April 14). These four famous Germans may be -- or in the case of Palermo and Beuys, may have been -- giants; but this selection of works on paper is not the show to convince nonfans. It includes a richly spilled and layered painterly abstraction by Mr. Polke and a set of six mysterious photographs of ghostly figures in a room by Mr. Richter, but most of the work is too sketchy to excite the unconverted (Johnson).

FRANCES KUEHN, "Figure in Landscape," Phoenix Gallery, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 226-8711 (through April 14). With deadpan photo-based realism, Ms. Kuehn paints Sisyphean allegories of earth-bound labor. The hero, a middle-aged woman resembling the artist, is depicted digging a hole with a shovel, scrubbing the ground with a bristle brush, sunk almost to her armpits in dirt and putting her shoulder to a huge round boulder. These unassumingly wry, neatly made pictures have an oddly affecting psychological poignancy (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "BELGIAN FASHION: ANTWERP STYLE," Fashion Institute of Technology, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street, (212) 217-7999 (through April 14). Starting with Martin Margiela, this exhibition brings together 75 ensembles designed by 10 Belgian designers; all but one studied at Antwerp's Royal Academy of Fine Arts in the last 20 years. Destruction and inspired, self-knowing tampering are the names of the games here, along with wildly creative borrowing, from Victorian to Goth to pop culture. Olivier Theyskens's white-leather outerwear and Jurgi Persoons's expressively hand-stitched garments are among the highlights, but the general level is high. Coherence and dissonance, required of any group exhibition regardless of medium, prevails throughout (Smith).

"FIRST STEPS: EMERGING ARTISTS FROM JAPAN," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through April 14). Six young artists and an artist team are making a collective American debut in this exhibition, which is all over the place and takes a few directions you may hesitate to follow. But over all it is ingenious and fun. Work includes do-it-yourself origami Nintendo icons, stitched maps of an artist's daily moves and sculptures made from nail clippings and saliva (Cotter).

Last Chance

"ABSTRACTION AND IMMANENCE," Hunter College/Times Square Gallery, 450 West 41st Street, Clinton, (212) 772-4991 (through tomorrow). Prompted by the title, some viewers may pick up spiritual vibes, but the prevailing feeling of this 18-artist show is one of formalist conservatism. There are handsome grid paintings by Stephen Westfall and Peter Stroud; softly luminous paintings by Gwen Hardie and Nancy Haynes; and dense, single-color squares by Marcia Hafif. The freshest works are Christian Garnett's surfaceless visions of glaring white light and a dark blue ellipse by Erik Saxon (Johnson).

JOE AMRHEIN, "Critical Mass," Roebling Hall, 390 Wythe Avenue, at South Fourth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5352 (through Tuesday). Exhibiting Conceptual sympathies and a sign painter's skills, Mr. Amrhein's latest works consist of well-chosen bits of contemporary art criticism writ large in big, gaudy, circusy letters on staggered layers of vellum. Their piled-on phrases suggest both the intermittent poetry and disembodied strainings of art writing, and pay homage while exacting an exuberant revenge (Smith).

"ANCIENT CHINA: MUSIC AND RITUAL," J. J. Lally & Company, 41 East 57 Street, (212) 371-3380 (through tomorrow). This small, handsome exhibition centers on a group of bronze bells of varying sizes, and includes a melodic cluster of related objects: an earthenware gong, a bronze tuning key with a bear teetering on top, a simian-looking drum bearer and a live-wire Western Han dancer who preens and bends (Cotter).

* "DRAW AND TELL: THE TRANSFORMATIVE LINES OF NORVAL MORRISSEAU/COPPER THUNDERBIRD," The Drawing Center's Drawing Room, 40 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166 (through tomorrow). Mr. Morrisseau, who also uses his Native American name, Copper Thunderbird, produced the 50 drawings in this show while in prison in the early 1970's. They're executed in pencil on torn-off sheets of paper towel, and they are extraordinary. They combine pictographic human and animal forms with elements of modernist style in hallucinatory narratives. The results aren't ingratiating or beautiful. Like visionary work in many cultures, they are aggressive, sometimes violent, as much about fearfulness as transcendence (Cotter).

MK KAHNE, "Clubbing: Rotation," Janos Gat, 1100 Madison Avenue, between 82nd and 83rd Streets, (212) 327-0441 (through tomorrow). This Berlin sculptor's seductive mock-commodities recall Ashley Bickerton's box works from the 1980's. The four works by Mr. Kahne include an elaborate portable bar, a video surveillance kit, a sound system for listening to Punk Rock and a phototransparency light box for personal publicity. All fold up into ultra-sleek pieces of luggage for the overprivileged modern nomad (Johnson).

* "WOMEN DESIGNERS IN THE U.S.A., 1900-2000: DIVERSITY AND DIFFERENCE," Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, Design and Culture, 18 West 86th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3000 (through Sunday). At the turn of the 20th century, female designers were mostly white, middle-class and skilled in "female" pursuits; today they are ethnically diverse and have made enormous progress in their field. Architecture, landscaping, interiors, furniture, textiles, apparel, posters, tableware, wallpaper, ceramics, lighting, jewelry, floor coverings, silverware, car doors, costumes and industrial products are represented in this bountiful show, which shoehorns some 220 objects into three floors of tight gallery space. Works by American Indians and African-Americans are given special attention (Glueck).

HEADLINE: Standoff Worries U.S. Companies in China 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 5 

 BODY:
As the standoff over a midair collision between United States and Chinese military planes enters its sixth day, American businesspeople here are repeating like a mantra, "It's business as usual."
 But while Motorola, Procter & Gamble and other companies insist that the dispute need not damage commercial ties with China, a few are starting to acknowledge that it is far from business as usual. 
 General Motors issued a memorandum on Wednesday warning its expatriate staff in China to take extra precautions in the coming days. The memorandum, signed by the chairman of GM China, Philip Murtaugh, noted that sentiment toward Americans could sour quickly. It advised employees to stay out of crowds and avoid discussing the incident with people they do not know. 
"It's a good idea to remind people who are not natives to be a little careful," said Alan Adler, a spokesman for GM China. "There's been no operational change in our business, but it's clearly on people's minds."
Hostility between Beijing and Washington is a recurring nightmare for companies like G.M., which have huge investments in China. The automaker operates a $1.5 billion car plant in Shanghai and a $230 million truck factory in Shenyang. It employs 3,500 people in China, 100 of them expatriates.
Several executives said the dispute was not yet as grave as the one surrounding NATO's accidental bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade in 1999, which touched off attacks on American diplomatic missions throughout China. This time, they noted, China has squelched attempts to protest outside the United States Embassy in Beijing.
But the executives said that unless the standoff was resolved quickly, it could spill over into issues like China's entry into the World Trade Organization and Beijing's trade relations with the United States.
"You've already got various members of Congress talking about trying to block China's accession to the W.T.O.," said Frank Martin, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong. "Then there is the extension of China's normal trade status, which is coming up for a vote in Congress."
"These are the things we are talking about among ourselves," Mr. Martin said, "and nobody has any easy answers."
Few businesspeople say they believe that Congress will reverse its vote granting permanent normal trade relations to China. But Beijing's entry into the W.T.O. is a thornier issue. It has already been delayed until at least the fall because of squabbles at W.T.O. headquarters in Geneva over the subsidies the Chinese government can pay farmers.
Some executives worry that if the standoff poisons the atmosphere between the United States and China, it could magnify the wrangling over relatively trivial details into a deal-breaking impasse.
"People are getting antsy about the stalled situation in Geneva," said Eden Y. Woon, the director of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "In any multilateral setting, the U.S. usually takes the leadership role. If there is bad blood with China, how will that affect the negotiations?"
In the short run, the tension will probably halt some American investments in China, if only temporarily. China will barely feel the pinch: foreign direct investment in the country has soared, with $2.22 billion of new investment in January, a 22 percent increase compared with figures in the month a year earlier.
An escalating dispute would also damp China's ability to tap capital markets. The Chinese government hopes to issue shares in two major state-owned companies, Bank of China and China Telecom, early next year. But shares of two of the best-known Chinese state companies, China Mobile and China Unicom, plunged in Hong Kong on Wednesday. The market was closed for a holiday today.
For American companies with big operations in China, there is little to do but watch, wait and hope for the best. "We're concerned and we'd like to see this amicably resolved as quickly as possible," said Steve Lyons, a spokesman for Motorola, the semiconductor and cellular phone maker. "We see the Hainan thing as an unfortunate situation that is much more political than economic."
Motorola's concern is understandable. With 12,000 employees and $3.4 billion worth of investments in China, the company has perhaps a greater Chinese stake than any American corporation.
Mr. Adler of G.M. said he was somewhat optimistic that Beijing and Washington could work things out, particularly since the United States secretary of state, Colin Powell, expressed regret over the loss of the Chinese pilot. But he noted that domestic politics on both sides made the situation unpredictable.
Unlike G.M., Motorola and P.& G. have not issued warnings to employees. But a spokesman for P.& G., John Yam, said the company was monitoring the situation and would act if necessary. It employs 4,000 people in China and has plants in Guangzhou, Beijing, Tianjin and Chengdu.
"There have always been ups and downs in the U.S. relationship with China," Mr. Yam said. "But we have a long-term commitment to China."

HEADLINE: Brazil Scrambles for More Energy 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 5 

 BODY:
Though nightly newscasts show cars floating down flood-prone streets here, residents are hoping for more rain -- at least 20 percent more than normal for this time of year, to be precise.
 That is how much the operators of Brazil's electricity grid say needs to fall to ensure that hydroelectric plants will continue to run at full capacity, averting the need for energy rationing, like the recent rolling blackouts in California, in at least part of Brazil later in the year. 
 Here, as elsewhere across the globe, the struggle to deregulate has been coupled with soaring demand for power. As the Brazilian government seeks other energy sources, formulates a rationing plan and encourages consumers to voluntarily cut back energy use, companies -- especially those in power-hungry industries -- are scrambling for ways to make sure their electricity needs will be met. And independent local and foreign power developers, like EnergyWorks, based in Landover, Md., are hoping to be of service, offering to construct minipower plants on the companies' premises. 
"A lot of companies have been calling us in the last two weeks to see if it is possible to invest in this type of project," said Nelson Cardoso de Oliveira, business development manager for EnergyWorks, a unit of the electric utility Iberdrola S.A. of Spain.
For the last few years, experts have warned of an impending energy crisis in Brazil, as increasing industrialization has caused the demand for energy to outpace supply by about 20 percent. The government's three-year-old effort to attract more investors through the privatization of most of the country's power grid has had a slow start. Local companies have been hindered by a lack of financing. And uncertainties in the newly deregulated power market over such things as the pricing of electricity have stymied grid-expansion plans by the private enterprises, including Enron, that bought up the former state-owned companies. 
Even the completion last year of a natural gas pipeline from Bolivia has been slow to stimulate investments in thermoelectric power, a move that was meant to reduce the country's near-total dependence on hydroelectric power. Only 15 of the 49 thermoelectric plants that the government focused on almost two years ago in its emergency power plan seem close to coming on line, in the next year or so.
With rainfall missing major reservoirs and a shortage of transmission lines preventing excess power that does exist from moving among regions, the government says that the power situation in Brazil will be touch-and-go at least until 2003.
So some of the country's biggest power-intensive companies are taking matters into their own hands, hoping to ensure a constant power supply with their own natural-gas-fired generators. Among those that have recently done so are Cia. Siderurgica Nacional, a steel maker, and Globo Comunicacoes e Participacoes, parent of the Rio de Janeiro daily newspaper O Globo. So have two rival breweries: Cia. Cervejarias Kaiser, owned by the Coca-Cola Company, its Brazilian bottlers and Heineken; and the maker of Brahma beer, Cia. de Bebidas das Americas, known as AmBev. Plants are planned for the Brazilian units of the American-based multinationals Corn Products International and International Paper.
Rudi Anvari, director of Engineering and Technology at Corn Products Brazil, said the company's decision was based on the "need to count on a reliable and flexible source of energy."
In a study of power use in the state of Sao Paulo, the state's secretary of energy found that companies produced 14 percent of the energy they consumed in 2000, up from 5 percent in 1994.
In some cases, the excess power from these company plants can be sold to the national grid. Jayme de Hollanda, general director of the National Institute for Energy Efficiency, a nonprofit advocacy group, said that this so-called cogenerated power should account for about 15 percent of the country's electricity supply by 2010.
"The volumes that we are dealing with don't provide a complete solution for the country, but they can certainly resolve localized problems," said Ivan Marimon, the sales manager at Guascor do Brasil, a joint venture controlled by Grupo Guascor of Spain, which builds small-scale power plants for hospitals. 
Companies said that part of the appeal of small power projects was that they required less time to build than a public power project -- sometimes as little as six months. And the cost, at about $6 million for a small 5-megawatt plant, could be just as cost effective for some companies as buying electricity from the national grid, especially since electricity prices were expected to increase significantly in the next several years.
Some private power concerns, including EnergyWorks, even finance the projects outright. But for a project to be viable for financiers and builders, companies need to agree to buy the electricity for 15 to 20 years. That is a daunting proposition for Brazilians, who have been made shy of long-term commitments by years of economic turmoil. Part of the doubt has been caused by exchange rate worries. Unlike natural gas prices, which are charged in dollars, electricity prices are fixed by the government in local currency.
Indeed, private power plants are clearly not for everyone.
"For most companies," said Pio Gavazzi, director of infrastructure at the Federation of Industries of the State of Sao Paulo, a trade group, a solution "could just be a matter of renegotiating existing electricity contracts or installing more energy efficient parts in the factory."

HEADLINE: Telecom Start-Up Will Cut Jobs and Halt Expansion 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Yet another once-promising upstart has demonstrated how difficult it can be to achieve a foothold in the telecommunications industry.
 Winstar Communications said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,000 jobs -- 43 percent of its work force -- and halt expansion of its network, which provides telephone and Internet service to 32,000 business customers nationwide. 
 Winstar, which said the job cuts would take place immediately, said it had enough money to continue operating for another year. But investors, skeptical about the company's prospects, have already begun treating the company as if it were destined to collapse. 
Shares in Winstar have plummeted this year, falling from $22.75 in mid-January to 44 cents yesterday. The company's bonds due in 2010 were traded yesterday for only 3 percent of face value.
The company said yesterday that it was considering "several material transactions" to turn its business around, but it is unclear whether the company is putting itself up for sale or seeking to enter into other types of agreements.
Qwest Communications, which had been mentioned as a potential suitor, released a statement yesterday saying that it did not plan to acquire Winstar.
"We're hoping to refocus our strategies now on our existing network," said Kevin Cavanaugh, a spokesman for Winstar.
A year ago, Winstar rose to $64.88 a share on the promise of its technology, which uses so-called fixed wireless systems to connect office buildings to the telephone network and Internet in places not served by fiber optic networks.
But as even big communications carriers have been hit by the economic downturn, smaller competitors like Winstar have had an even tougher time.
"Like some of its counterparts, Winstar was just too ambitious and aggressive for its own good," said Jerry Paul, who manages the high-yield bond portfolio for Invesco Funds in Denver. "If Winstar does fail, hopefully its assets will be picked up by a healthy company that can make use of them."
Winstar, which is based in New York, is not alone among the small communications companies known as competitive local exchange carriers, or CLEC's (pronounced SEE-lecks), which are facing difficulties during a financing drought. Many of the companies were formed after the passage of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which sought to increase competition with big local telephone companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications.
Companies including E.spire Communications of Herndon, Va., and ICG Communications of Denver have already filed for bankruptcy protection. And shares of competitors like Teligent Inc. of Vienna, Va., which also provides a type of wireless service like Winstar's, have been punished in recent weeks. Analysts increasingly expect only a handful of CLEC's to survive.
The problems with CLEC's are similar to those of a separate group of small communications companies -- those that focus on providing high-speed Internet access services.
In nearly all these cases, the companies are buffeted by a struggle to raise money for expansion or even continued operations. And the carriers' weaknesses threaten to undermine even large established makers of communications equipment like Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Cisco Systems, which are facing a decline in revenue as companies like Winstar defer expansion plans.
And the financial instability of the small carriers raises other risks for Lucent, Nortel and Cisco, which have all provided financing to enable carriers to buy their products.
In Winstar's case, Lucent had extended about $400 million of financing; the recovery of that has been cast into doubt. Citing scrutiny from the Securities and Exchange Commission ahead of its earnings announcement planned for later this month, officials from Lucent declined to comment on the matter. 
"Winstar's announcement sets the stage for a broad-based revision of capital spending across the entire sector," said Glenn Reynolds, chief executive of CreditSights, an independent credit research company. "It's like one part of the food chain is nearing extinction and people are wondering how their hunger will be satisfied."
Still, it may be too early to gauge what effect difficulties at Winstar and its counterparts will have on companies like Lucent, which has had a steep decline in its own share price as investors have questioned its capacity to satisfy the solvency requirements of its creditors.
Until the dust settles from this latest round of difficulties, large equipment suppliers are expected to retrench, focusing on sales to their largest clients, big local phone companies and large foreign companies like Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom. 
So far these big carriers have been left relatively unscathed by turmoil in the rest of the telecommunications industry. In fact, they could emerge from the downturn even stronger as the weakest competitors are weeded out.
"If any comparison can be made between today and a year ago it would be that there are fewer stupid players than there used to be," Michel Bon, chairman of France Telecom, said in an interview yesterday.

HEADLINE: An Aluminum Behemoth Is Born in Russia 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 5 

 BODY:
The Russian government has approved a huge merger that unites most of the country's sprawling aluminum industry in a single giant company second in output only to Alcoa of America.
 The company, Russian Aluminum, is now moving rapidly to consolidate its control of plants throughout Russia, changing the face of the industry here. And though the deal has been criticized for reducing competition in the domestic market, most analysts consider it a step forward in Russia's start-and-stop economic development. 
 Profiteering plagued the industry through much of the 1990's, when most Russian aluminum plants were in the hands of shadowy overseas trading companies whose true owners were often obscure. The trading companies tended to starve the plants of investment and funnel profits into offshore bank accounts.
Since then, Russia's rules have changed along with its economy, and the industry is beginning to operate along more conventional, transparent lines. And the owners of Russian Aluminum say they now have both the incentives and the cash to invest in upgrading the plants and increasing production.
"The whole approach to business is changing," said Svetlana Smirnova, a metals analyst at Renaissance Capital here. "Before, the traders just wanted the biggest margin possible, to buy at a low price. It was enough that the factory was functioning. Now people want to see value in the company."
With a green light this week from the government, Russian Aluminum, created last year as a holding company for aluminum assets, will finish absorbing 16 companies, combining their results in a single set of financial statements by the end of May. The dozens of exporting companies through which metal had been passed from plant to customer -- and through which revenue in the Russian industry is commonly diverted -- have been slimmed down to just six. The moves will make the industry much easier for analysts and investors to understand.
"In Russia, conditions are being created for companies to build value," Oleg Deripaska, one of Russian Aluminum's two principal owners, said in an interview.
Mr. Deripaska and his major partner, Roman Abramovich, who has oil interests, are among Russia's most powerful business executives, and are often accused of using political influence in the Kremlin to further their business interests. That antitrust officials approved a merger of about 70 percent of the aluminum industry is cited as an example.
Mr. Deripaska, 33, denies that he wields any special political influence. In his view, he said, Russian Aluminum is simply a cleaner, better player in a dirty old industry.
But his business rivals disagree. The company has been sued in the United States, where Russian rivals have asserted that the owners stooped to illegal means to gain control of some of their holdings. The company denies the charges.

HEADLINE: Where Bush's Team Disengages, Russia Looks for New Roles in Diplomacy and Trade 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 5 

 BODY:
As the Bush administration continues to review its foreign policy and has turned its attention this week to a crisis with China, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is doing what he can to move into the areas where Washington appears to have disengaged, Russian officials say.
 The officials say that Mr. Putin is trying to strengthen Moscow's bonds with Europe, increase Russia's role as a mediator in regional conflicts and open new trade links with Asia. 
 The Russian leader is acting in part, they say, to gain leverage for the day when he and President Bush sit down to chart a new agenda in a relationship that has been cut adrift by disputes and the changes of administration in both countries.
Kremlin officials say Mr. Putin is not only seeking a stronger role for Russia in Western affairs, but also a hedge against any Bush administration attempt to exclude Russia from security decisions that affect Russia's interests -- like NATO expansion and missile defenses. 
Mr. Putin's actions are also intended to strengthen the case being made by prominent voices in the United States to broaden -- not reduce -- economic and security ties with Russia, a policy that has enjoyed bipartisan support in Washington since the collapse of the Soviet Union.
"Putin is a proud person and smart person at the same time," said Irina M. Khakamada, a pro-reform leader in Parliament. "The smart person in him wants a strategic partnership with Europe and the United States, and the proud person in him wants some kind of leverage that will enable him to come to terms with the Bush administration." 
Today, Mr. Putin said he would like to undertake a peace mission to the Middle East to help mediate a solution to the rising violence between Israelis and Palestinians. He has invited the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, and Syria's foreign minister, Farouk al-Shara, to visit Moscow this month, and he is working with Arab leaders to push for an end to United Nations sanctions against Iraq in return for greater compliance with resolutions demanding a resumption of weapons inspections.
Also, as the Bush administration has temporarily withdrawn from active diplomacy on the Korean Peninsula, Mr. Putin is expected to meet the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, this month in an effort -- now joined by the European Union -- to convince the mercurial Mr. Kim to reconcile with South Korea and to abandon the ballistic missile program that has been cited by Washington as a large part of its rationale for a missile defense. 
At the same time, Mr. Putin is strengthening Moscow's bonds with Europe. Russia announced today that it has opened discussions with the European Union to cooperate with the independent European defense force being formed outside of NATO. Mr. Putin was invited to the European summit talks last month in Stockholm, and European leaders will gather for another summit meeting in Moscow in May.
Javier Solana, the European Union's top diplomat, said here today that a "strategic partnership is being shaped up" with Russia "in a very rapid manner and a very profound manner," most notably in the area of crisis management.
In his first year in office, Mr. Putin may have set a record for miles logged by a Russian or Soviet leader, with more than 18 foreign trips, not to mention a record-setting amount of travel within Russia. Much of his energy has been directed at cleaning up Soviet-era debts, from Havana to Hanoi, and at opening markets for Russia's nearly bankrupt heavy industries.
What initially sent Mr. Putin into motion last June was the prospect of a decision by President Bill Clinton on whether to start building a national missile defense system in violation of a 1972 treaty banning such systems. That decision was deferred after Mr. Putin helped to galvanize opposition.
Mr. Bush, by contrast, arrived in Washington with less experience in foreign affairs and has resisted an active American role in the Balkan conflicts and the Middle East peace effort. He has made clear that the United States will involve itself only where it sees American interests directly threatened. Although he is still new in office, his first and only trip abroad has been to Mexico.
His presidency has introduced a distinctly negative tone toward Russia, amplified by a contentious espionage dispute and policy debates that seem headed toward a significant downgrading of relations.
In response, Mr. Putin has moved closer to Europe; he has taken an important step toward settling a long-standing dispute with Japan over the Kurile Islands chain and he has sought to open significant new trading links with Asia. 
"I think he has made an incredibly effective use of the vacuum of policy we have in the United States, and he has been playing a weak hand rather strongly," said Michael McFaul, a specialist on Russia at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington, who recently took a sampling of European views on United States-Russia relations.
"There are a lot of people around the world not too enamored with the Americans right now," Mr. McFaul said. "The Europeans see this too, and they are waiting for a response from Washington."
Mr. Putin's diplomacy is also about money.
In Korea, Mr. Putin hopes that reconciliation between North and South will allow the opening of a new rail transport corridor crossing both Koreas to connect the ports of Asia with Europe via the Trans-Siberian Railroad. That would bolster Russia's internal markets along the way.
In Iran, where sales of equipment by Russia have brought American opposition, Russia predicts that it will sell at least three nuclear power plants at the existing Bushehr site and two coal-fired power plants elsewhere.
Russian arms industries also hope to win contracts to rebuild Iran's air defense network and its conventional armed forces, devastated in the Iran-Iraq war of 1980 to 1988.
While critics point to the danger of selling arms that could be turned on Russia, Mr. Putin contends that Moscow can help to bring Iran out of its isolation, something the United States has long sought to achieve.
Though some of Mr. Putin's foreign policy ventures, especially in Iran, have touched off concerns at home and in the West, much of his diplomacy seems to be earning praise for Russia in Europe.
After leaders of the European Union met with Mr. Putin in Stockholm in late March, they announced that they were sending their own diplomatic mission to North Korea and would establish diplomatic relations with Pyongyang, in tandem with Mr. Putin's efforts to support reconciliation on the peninsula. European leaders said they were acting in consultation with the Bush administration, but Mr. Bush's team is conspicuously absent from the process.
Like Mr. Bush with regard to Russia, Mr. Putin has taken care to emphasize that his goal is a constructive dialogue with Washington. In an interview on the anniversary of his first year in office, Mr. Putin told Russian journalists that he was not trying to recreate the old Soviet alliances against the United States by visiting old Soviet haunts in Cuba, North Korea, Vietnam and India.
"Our foreign relations used to be based on ideology, and little, if anything, else," he said. "We pumped huge resources into some countries without knowing when we could expect anything in return, or sometimes without knowing why we were doing it at all.
"However," he added, "not everything was so thoughtless," like the oil exploration program Moscow runs with Vietnam. "So why should we lose the huge potential built up over decades?"
Russia's foreign policy, he said, "will not include any great power chauvinism" and he said he considered the United States "one of our major partners."
But privately, many Russian officials fear that under President Bush, that sentiment is no longer shared.

HEADLINE: U.S. Treasury: No Lending; 
With Big Budget Surpluses, Some See The End of New Bonds and Notes

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A world without a Treasury market? That was unimaginable a few years ago, when budget deficits stretched as far as the eye could see. But with a rising government surplus, the unthinkable no longer seems beyond the pale.
 Many traders and analysts, expecting the White House and Congress to give away most future surpluses through tax cuts and spending, still consider the Treasury market's demise unlikely. 
 But because the projected surpluses are large and have a momentum of their own, it could happen a lot faster than many think.
The United States, to make ends meet, has been borrowing since the nation was born, especially during wartime. But the Treasury market as we know it today did not take shape until the mid-1970's, when deficits soared in the wake of a severe recession and rising oil prices. The wild volatility of interest rates late in the decade and into the 80's focused intense attention on the bond market. 
That spawned the growth of a Wall Street infrastructure, fostered the bond-trading "masters of the universe" of "Bonfire of the Vanities" fame, and made the Treasury market the benchmark for the world's bond markets, a haven for cautious investors around the globe. 
But now, the trusty 30-year bond is threatened with retirement, a move recommended by a Treasury advisory group. Other maturities and types are also vulnerable. The last one-year Treasury bill was issued in February, and inflation-indexed bonds are on the chopping block.
Any threat to the Treasury market has been dismissed by many because they simply do not believe that the surpluses will last.
"That story is kind of on the back burner," said Thomas Connor, head government trader at J. P. Morgan. "The economic slowdown and the tax cut is going the opposite way of paying down the debt."
Yet pressing relentlessly against the Treasury market's viability is the expected size of budget surpluses compared with the amount of debt maturing each year. When the surplus exceeds the amount of old Treasury notes and bonds maturing, the government has no need to raise more cash to operate. So it will have a hard time arguing that it needs to keep selling new securities, including the 10-year note, which has already replaced the 30-year Treasury bond as the benchmark.
Barring surprises, the date when the government faces this matter may not be far away. Based on current forecasts, and assuming approval of President Bush's $1.6 trillion 10-year tax cut or of alternative legislation at similar cost, the surplus would exceed the total of maturing debt, including the cost of debt buybacks, in less than five years.
A mild recession would not delay that, according to the Congressional Budget Office's projections.
An accelerated tax cut and a sharper economic slowdown would significantly reduce the administration's anticipated surpluses. But even that might put the date off only a year or two. Pinning it down precisely is not possible because the date depends on the economy and the budget, as well as Treasury Department decisions on how fast to curb the issuance of new debt.
At the end of the 2005 fiscal year, there could be just over $2 trillion in publicly held Treasury debt, so it would still be traded. But without new issues, it may just be on life support. "A big part of what makes a market function well is the infusion of new debt," said John Youngdahl, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs.
Thus, well before all the publicly held debt is paid off, a new touchstone may be required for the fixed-income markets. The pricing of corporate, agency, mortgage and other asset-backed bonds will have to start elsewhere. The usual hedging to reduce risk will have to be done with other securities. And new benchmarks will have to be found. All these functions will have to be performed without the special character of Treasuries: they are risk-free.
The Treasury market has for years been the safest place for conservative investors. Without Treasuries, they will scramble for alternatives. There would no Treasury safe harbor for investors to flee to in a crisis. "While it is difficult to discern the consequences of this for market dynamics and systemic risk," a new report from the International Monetary Fund says, "this issue has received relatively little attention both by policy makers and by market participants."
All this leaves the Bush Treasury with major decisions to make, including the immediate fate of the 30-year bond. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill could decide to let market forces take their course, or he could try to keep the market working by continuing to issue new debt, even though it might not be necessary. One way to do this would be to create an exchange program, in which new debt is issued only in exchange for existing debt, so the total of debt outstanding does not increase.
Looming over the whole debate are the retiring baby boomers. Forecasts by the Congressional Budget Office and others say that deficits are likely to return as the full force of these retirements takes hold in the late 2020's, straining the Social Security and Medicare systems. At that point, again barring major surprises, government borrowing and the Treasury market would be back.
Many analysts and traders say the added cost of restarting the Treasury market would be much less than the cost of keeping it alive when it is not needed. It would be easy to restart, they argue, and is not the be-all and end-all that some believe. After all, the 30-year bond has been regularly auctioned only since 1977.
Treasury officials, while saying that they are considering all options, will not comment on specific proposals. "Any speculation about what we may or may not do can have a significant impact on the market," said Michael J. Paulus, deputy assistant secretary for federal finance.
The debate over the Bush budget has obscured the importance of the size of the surplus compared with the decline in maturing debt. But more participants in the Treasury market are seeing the end of Treasuries -- at least temporarily -- as inevitable.
"We still have to go through this period where the Treasury market ceases to function, whether the 10-year projections are right or not," said James M. Keller, executive vice president for government bond trading at Pimco, the asset management firm. "And that is what the Treasury has to plan for."
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, has also endorsed closing the Treasury market. "It would be better to have a large Treasury debt outstanding so that those of us who deal in the financial markets have easy benchmarks and easy means of pricing and of funding," he told senators in February. But he added, "The trade-off very clearly says by far the most important thing is to get the debt down, and we will handle the problems as best we can."
Signs of adjustment are evident. The last outstanding three-year Treasury note matures in May. There have been sharp reductions in the amount of other Treasury securities, including the 10-year, 5-year and 2-year notes. Annual issuance of new debt had fallen nearly 50 percent by the 2000 fiscal year from 1996 levels.
When the Fed cut short-term interest rates in January, the first to follow its lead was the interest-rate swaps market, where investors exchange fixed-rate debt for variable-rate debt. And the yield on 10-year swaps fell further than that on the 10-year Treasury note.
Issuance of new debt by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, government-sponsored agencies that package home mortgages in bonds that are considered very safe but are not backed by the full faith and credit of the United States, is skyrocketing as these issuers seek to become the new benchmark for interest rates.
The Bond Market Association has approved guidelines for a when-issued market -- once reserved for Treasuries -- for these government agency securities to allow trading between the time a new issue is announced and the settlement date.
The Fed, which has operated through the Treasury market to move interest rates, is broadening the list of non-Treasury securities it will accept in this process. Candidates include certain state debt and the debt of foreign governments.
Traders at some Wall Street firms say that as much as 90 percent of the hedging of risk they see in the fixed-income market is now done with interest-rate swaps. And the role of the Treasury market in key indexes of the fixed-income market is shrinking. At its peak early in 1986, the Treasury bond market made up 50 percent of the Lehman Brothers aggregate bond index. It is now 26 percent, behind mortgages at 35 percent and soon to slip to third behind the corporate bond market.
James R. Capra, president of Capra Asset Management and chairman of the Treasury's Wall Street advisory committee, put the situation personally: "I am going to be out of business if I am only in Treasuries. The situation is moving inexorably in that direction."
But the fight to save the Treasury market is in full swing. A Bond Market Association committee, separate from the one advising the Treasury, is recommending Treasury exchange programs to keep the market functioning as long as possible. This could prolong the useful life of the 30-year bond and of the 10-year note, as well.
Even with outstanding debt at a low level, "it behooves the Treasury to keep issuing new debt with an exchange," said Charles Parkhurst, managing director for government bond trading at Salomon Smith Barney. But asked if the market will function well this way or be on life support, he replied, "You are not going to know until you get there."
Gary Gensler, the Treasury official who oversaw government debt markets during the Clinton administration, said he still thought "there will be a viable Treasury market throughout all this period because the United States government will be a safer, yet smaller and stronger borrower." But he acknowledges that "other securities will come to be relied on as pricing vehicles, hedging vehicles and benchmarks."
What Treasury officials decide to do depends a lot on how they balance the main goals of managing a government bond market: financing the federal government, doing it at the lowest cost, and promoting efficient capital markets.
Will these add up to keeping the Treasury market alive just because the public has had one it liked for a quarter of a century? Stay tuned.

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
California Schemin'

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO 

 BODY:
Arnold Schwarzenegger is mulling a race for governor of California. There are reasons to regard this as a really positive development.
 1) The demands of candidacy would probably require an indefinite postponement of "Terminator III." 
 2) The cost of the campaign would give a much-needed boost to California's slowing economy. 
3) If Jesse Ventura runs for re-election in 2002, we might all have a chance to live in a nation that includes two governors who starred in the movie "Predator."
The current governor of California, Gray Davis, is stuck with a dreadful energy crisis. It is not of his own making, but it's not of his own ending either, and people are getting frustrated. The Republicans do not have a plan to fix things, but they have discovered through the miracles of hindsight that the whole crisis could have been solved last summer if only Mr. Davis had shown "bold leadership." 
"Well, that's not his style. He's an incremental kind of guy. He's being bolder on this than he normally is on stuff," said John Burton, the Democratic president pro tem of the Senate, in an excellent demonstration of the enthusiasm for Mr. Davis that reigns within his own party.
The rules for a democracy would seem to suggest that people ought to be standing in line to run against Mr. Davis next year. But so far the only declared candidate is Secretary of State Bill Jones. A farmer from Fresno, Mr. Jones doesn't seem to have an energy plan, although he enthusiastically yells "procrastination and timidity!" every time the governor's name is mentioned. 
The key to Mr. Davis's power is the $26 million he has in his campaign treasury. Mr. Jones has around $100,000. "He's never been a good fund-raiser -- he's never demonstrated he can raise two nickels to rub together," said Garry South, the Davis campaign strategist, in a tone of extreme contempt.
There's a general consensus that anybody who wants to take the nomination away from Mr. Jones is going to have to be what politicians delicately call "self-financing," and California's supply of obscenely rich people with time on their hands has not been entirely depleted by the recent economic unpleasantness.
William Simon Jr., the son of the former Treasury secretary, has established an exploratory committee. He has no political experience, but he is blessed with a stirring riches-to-riches personal saga. (Sal Russo, Mr. Simon's consultant, says his client and his family ran "an old-fashioned merchant banking company," in a valiant attempt to make that particular line of work sound cozy.) Beyond that, nobody knows a thing about him. 
"No interviews," said Mr. Russo. Mr. Simon's position on the energy crisis, he added, is that Gray Davis should show more leadership.
Mr. Schwarzenegger, who has had previous political experience as the 1990 chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness, seems to be enjoying the attention, despite a recent spate of stories portraying him as a compulsive groper, which Mr. South diligently faxed to the California press corps.
"Arnold, who I sat down and talked with at his request, I have great respect for," said Mr. Jones. "It was a good conversation." Mr. Schwarzenegger's end seems to have been a little brief. "To be candid," the secretary of state revealed, "he said: 'We're looking at it.' "
Beyond the actor formerly known as Conan the Barbarian and his own mystery candidate, Mr. Russo said the list of possible alternatives to Mr. Jones includes Robert Conrad the actor and Ben Stein the comedian.
"If I can be of some service at the appropriate time, I'd be happy to move forward," said Mr. Conrad, whose old TV series "Baa Baa Black Sheep" can now be seen on the History Channel. His most recent political experience has included serving as the designated Republican celebrity to attack Martin Sheen for calling President Bush "a moron." 
Mr. Conrad, who stressed the need for leadership in the energy crisis, said he did not think Mr. Schwarzenegger would make a credible candidate: "I don't think he can handle the heat. And he's from Austria."
Maybe, if we wish hard, they'll both run. Then we can have a California Republican primary in which two of the candidates appeared in the movie "Jingle All the Way."

HEADLINE: Second-Guessing Alan Greenspan 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Suddenly, Critics Are Taking Aim at Greenspan" (front page, April 2): 
 Much of the criticism is unwarranted. 
The Federal Reserve has only one weapon, the interest rate. This can affect only the cost of funds, and business and consumer psychology. 
The Fed is not omnipotent. Fiscal policy must do its share. President Bush has been preventing a fast 2001 tax decrease by tying the short-term tax decrease to his long-term plan. Congress is preventing a fast 2001 tax decrease by debating endlessly who gets what this year and beyond.
Politics is trumping economics. Even a sagacious monetary policy cannot compensate for foolish fiscal policy.

PETER GUTMANN
New York, April 2, 2001

The writer is a professor of economics at Baruch College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: Second-Guessing Alan Greenspan 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Suddenly, Critics Are Taking Aim at Greenspan" (front page, April 2): 
 The Federal Reserve did not give the private markets a chance to do their job of allocating scarce resources. 
In pursuing a "soft landing" -- depressing the economy's growth rate -- the Fed made matters worse by reinforcing contractionary forces already at work. 
Had the Fed pursued its primary function of providing a smooth flow of liquidity in support of noninflationary growth at whatever rate the economy generates instead of undertaking the role of economic manager, the present painful slowdown could have been greatly mitigated.

LEON KOROBOW
Great Neck, N.Y., April 3, 2001

The writer is a retired assistant vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: Second-Guessing Alan Greenspan 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Your comments about the change of attitude toward the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, indicate that economists, news commentators and politicians are beginning to see that the Fed does not control everything (front page, April 2). 
 Over recent decades, it has been convenient to believe that business growth and individual economic welfare are largely determined by the Fed -- likewise, that the Federal Reserve and its chairman can be blamed for any financial difficulties.
The fact is that nothing the Fed can do can overcome the fiscal policy effects of government spending, especially deficit spending.

MARSHALL E. SURRATT
Dallas, April 3, 2001

The writer, a former assistant national bank examiner, was a commercial banker.

HEADLINE: Second-Guessing Alan Greenspan 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Steven Rattner is far too generous in his defense of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman ("The Flip Side of Fed Worship," Op-Ed, April 4). While Mr. 
Greenspan did give his famous "irrational exuberance" warning in December 1996, he backed away from those words in subsequent comments. 
 At times, he even suggested that the extraordinary valuations in the market could make sense. The basic arithmetic of the price-to-earnings ratio noted by Mr. Rattner showed otherwise. 
There was no plausible story that could have made sense of an average price-to-earnings ratio of more than 30, which we saw at the market's peak, or even the 23 we see today. 
If Mr. Greenspan had lectured on this point with the same fervor that he has lectured on other topics, like deficit reduction, it is unlikely that the bubble would have ever grown as large as it did.

DEAN BAKER
Co-director, Center for Economic and Policy Research
Washington, April 4, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
